And He was, or became, great in respect of estimation, rank, or quality. (So accord. to an explanation of the inf. n. in the KL [agreeably with an explanation of the epithet faxomN].) See also mufax-amN, below.
And one says also faxuma AlOamoru [meaning Great in estimation is the thing or affair or event or case!]. (Ḳ in art. bx, in which see baxo.)

hom.sense: 2. tafoxiymN is syn. with taEoZiymN [as signifying The magnifying a man, honouring him, or treating him with respect or reverence or veneration]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) one says, OatayonaA fulaAnFA fafax-amonaAhu meaning [We came to such a one] and we magnified him, or honoured him, and paid him high respect: and tfx-mhu↓ signifies [the same as fx-mhu, i. e.] He magnified him, or honoured him,, &c.; syn. Oajal-ahu, and EaZ-amahu. (TA.)

tafoxiymu AlHarofi is the contr. of UimaAlatuhu [i. e. it signifies The pronouncing of the word with the broad sound of the lengthened fet-ḥ (approaching to the sound of “a” in our word “ball”)]: (Ṣ:) [and also with a full sound of the letter l:] or Alt-afoxiymu is the abstaining from AlUimaAlap; (Ḳ, and Kull p. 127;) and the contr. of Alt-aroqiyqu; i. e. i. q. Alt-agoliyZu; and signifies the inclining of A towards the place of utterance of w, as in the word AlS-alawpu; and the uttering of l from the lower part of the tongue [i. e. with the tongue turned up], as in the word Aall-eh [i. e. in the word Qll-eh not immediately preceded by a kesreh]: (Kull ubi suprà:) it is [predominantly] peculiar to the people of El-Ḥijáz, like as AlAmAlp is to the tribe of Temeem. (TA.)
See also what next follows {5}.
[And it is also trans., like 2:] see 2, first sentence.

entry.sense: faxomN [seems to signify primarily Large, big, bulky, or thick. And hence,] A man having much flesh in the balls, or elevated parts, of the cheeks. (TA.)

[And predominantly,] Great in estimation, rank, or quality; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. fixaAmN: the fem. is faxomapN. (TA.) And it is likewise applied to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour]. (TA.)
And to speech, or diction, (manoTiq,) meaning Strong; sound, or correct; or chaste, clear, or eloquent, and comprehensive; syn. jazolN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
faxomapN fem. of faxomN [q. v.]. (TA.)
And A great army or military force. (TA.)

fuxamiy-apN, like juhaniy-apN, (so in the JK, Ḳ, and TA, [in the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ fuxayomap, like juhayonap,]) Self-magnification, pride, or haughtiness, and assumption of superiority. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)

fayoxamaAnN A person of authority, (TA,) one held in honour, from whose judgment events are made to proceed, and without whom no affair is decided. (Ḳ, TA. [In the explanation of this word in the CK, yaSoduru is a mistranscription for yuSodaru.])
Oafoxamu i. q. OaEoZamu [as meaning Most, or very, great in estimation, rank, or quality; applied to a man]. (TA.)

mufax-amN, occurring in a trad., as an epithet applied to the Prophet, means Magnified, honoured, or regarded with respect or reverence or veneration, in the minds and the eyes [of others: and so it means when applied in a general manner]: not largeness in his bodily make: or, as some say, it means [characterized by] faxaAmap↓ in his face, [i. e.] its nobleness, and fulness, with beauty, or comeliness, and a quality inspiring reverence or veneration. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. fad-a, aor. _i {yafodidu}, inf. n. fadiydN (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and fad-N, (M, L,) He (a man, Aṣ, Ṣ) uttered his voice, called out, cried out, or vociferated: (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ:) or did so vehemently: (T, M, L, Ḳ:) or raised his voice; (TA;) and so fadofada↓, said of a man, and of a camel: (L:) or they (a number of sheep or goats) made a sound by running: or made a sound by running with their pastors and those driving them with singing: (Ḳ:) or he, or it, made a sound like that termed HafiyfN; (Lth, T, M, Ḳ;) as also fadofada↓, inf. n. fadofadapN: (M, L, Ḳ:*) and he (a man) ran, making a sound by his running. (L.)
fad-a,, aor. _i {yafodidu}, inf. n. fadiydN, It (a bird) moved, or flapped, (Hav-a,) its wings, expanding and contracting them. (M.)
He ran, (Ḳ, TA,) fleeing. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]

fad-ati AlUibilu The camels crushed the ground with their feet, by the vehemence of their tread. (M, L.) And fad-a, aor. _i {yafodidu}, inf. n. fad-N and fadiydN; (L;) and fadofada↓; (M, L;) He (a man) trod vehemently upon the ground, by reason of exultation, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (M, L.) [See also 2.]
huwa yafud-uniI wayaEud-uniI means He threatens me. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. fd-d, inf. n. tafodiydN, He cried out, or vociferated, or did so vehemently, in buying or selling. (IAạr, T, L, Ḳ.)
And He (a man) walked upon the ground proudly and exultingly. (IAạr, T, L, Ḳ.*)
R. Q. 1. fadofada, inf. n. fadofadapN: see 1, in three places.
Also He (a man, TA) ran, fleeing from an enemy or a beast of prey. (T, L, Ḳ.) [See also 1, latter half.]
fudaAdN: see fad-aAdN, last sentence.

hom.sense: fadiydN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].
Also Abundance of camels. (M, L.)
And UibilN fadiydN Many camels. (M, L.)

entry.sense: fudaAdapN and fadaAdapN: see the next paragraph, last two sentences, in three places.
fad-aAdN Having a strong, or loud, voice, (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ,) and rude, coarse, or uncivil, in speech; (L, Ḳ;) as also fudofudN↓ and fudafidN↓. (Lḥ, M, L, Ḳ.)

Having a vehement tread. (M, L, Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., qado kunota tamoXiI fawoqiI fad-aAdFA i. e. [Thou usedst to walk upon me] treading vehemently, as said by the earth, (M, L,) to a dead man buried in it. (L.)
Proud, (Ḳ, TA,) and exulting. (TA.)

And Possessing camels in number from two hundred (in some copies of the Ḳ [and in a copy of the T] from hundreds, TA) to a thousand, (AO, T, Nh, L, Ḳ,) and therewithal rude, coarse, or uncivil, and proud. (AO, T.)
Pl. fad-aAduwna. (L, Ḳ, &c.)

The pl. occurs in a trad., in the saying, Uin-a AljafaACa waAlqasowapa fiI Alfad-aAdiyna, (T, Ṣ, L,) meaning [Verily rudeness, or coarseness, and hardness, are in] the men whose voices are high, or loud, in their corn-fields and among their cattle: (El-Aḥmar, Aṣ, T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or (in the Ḳ “and”) the tenders of camels, and pastors, and tenders of oxen and of asses: (Th, T, Ḳ:) or (in the Ḳ “and”) the tillers of the ground; (M, A, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) because they vociferate in their corn-fields: (A, Mgh:) or (in the Ḳ “and”) the people of the deserts; (M, Ḳ, TA;) the men who dwell in the fadaAfid [pl. of fadofadN, q. v.]; (MF;) because of the roughness of their voices, and their rudeness, or coarseness: (M:) or (in the Ḳ “and”) the possessors of many camels. (M, Ḳ, TA.) [See also art. fdn.]
Alfad-aAdapu↓ signifies The frog: (A, Ḳ:) so called because of its croaking. (A.)
Also, fad-aAdapN↓, (IAạr, Th, M, L, Ḳ,) and fudaAdapN↓, (IAạr, L,) or fadaAdapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) A cowardly man. (IAạr, Th, M, L, Ḳ.)
Also, fad-aAdapN↓, (L,) or fudaAdapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) A certain bird: (M, L, Ḳ:) n. un. of fad-aAdF, (L,) or fudaAdu↓. (M.)
fad-aAdapN: see the last three sentences of the next preceding paragraph.

fadofdN A desert, or waterless desert, (T, M, L, Ḳ,) wherein is nothing: (T, M, L:) or an even tract of land: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or a spacious and pebbly tract of land: (A:) or a rugged and pebbly tract of land: or a hard place: (M, L:) or a hard and rugged place: (Ḳ:) or an elevated place (Aṣ, T, L, Ḳ) in which is hardness: (Aṣ, T, L:) pl. fadaAfidu. (L.)
fudfdN: see fad-aAdN, first sentence.

hom.sense: fudafidN: see fad-aAdN, first sentence.

Also Thick milk: (IAạr, T:) or i. q. hudabidN, (Ḳ,) which signifies very thick milk: (Ṣ and L and Ḳ in explanation of the latter:) or both signify sour and thick milk. (T and L in explanation of the latter.)

entry.sense: 1. fadaHahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafodaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. fadoHN, (TA,) It (a debt, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and an affair, and a load, TA) burdened him, burdened him heavily, oppressed him, or overburdened him: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) AfdHpu↓ [in this sense], said of debt, has not been heard from any one in the correctness of whose Arabic speech confidence is placed. (Ṣ.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}:
and that here following {10}.
10. AstfdHpu He deemed it (i. e. an affair [&c.]) burdensome, heavily burdening, oppressive, or overburdening: (A, TA:) or he found it to be so; as also AfdHp↓. (Ḳ.)
AfdHhu A debt, (A,) or an affair, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or a load, (see 1,)] burdening, burdening heavily, oppressing, or overburdening. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
fAadiHapN A misfortune, an affliction, or a calamity: [pl. fawaAdiHu:] fawaAdiHu Ald-ahori signifies the afflictions, or calamities, of fortune. (Ḳ,* TA.)
mufodaHN: see the following paragraph.
mafoduwHN A man burdened, heavily burdened, oppressed, or overburdened, by debt, or by an affair, or by a load: (Ṣ,* L, TA:) mufodaHN↓ in this sense is not allowable. (L.)

1. fadaxa raOosahu, aor. _a {yafodaxu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. fadoxN, (TA,) He broke his head with a stone: (Ḳ, TA:) and fadaxotu AlX-aIoCa I broke the thing: (TA:) [but] the verb is not used except in relation to a thing in which is moisture. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. fadara, (Lth, IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yafoduru}, (M,) or _i, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. fuduwrN (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and fadorN; (Ḳ;) and fd-r↓, (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafodiyrN; (O;) and Afdr↓; (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ;) said of a stallion, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, &c.,) primarily of a stallion-camel, (IAạr, T,) He desisted from covering; (IAạr, T, Ṣ, O;) or he desisted from covering, being wearied by much indulging therein: (Ṣ, O:) or he flagged, or became remiss, or languid, in covering, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) and desisted therefrom: (M, Ḳ:) the w in fadara, thus used, may be a substitute for the t in fatara: (O:) accord. to IAth, it signifies he lacked power, or ability, to cover. (TA.)

fadara, inf. n. fuduwrN, said of a mountain-goat, He became such as protected himself in the mountain from the hunter: or he became large, or big, and advanced in age, or full-grown; thus says IḲṭṭ. (TA.)
And fadara said of cooked flesh-meant, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. fuduwrN, (TA,) It became cold. (Ḳ, TA.)
fadira, aor. _a {yafodaru}, inf. n. fadarN, He was, or became, foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence.
hecihi HijaArapN tufad-aru means These are stones that break into small and large pieces. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, first sentence.
5. tfd-r, said of a stone, It, being struck, broke in pieces. (TA.)
fadarN: see faAdirN, in two places.
fadirN Foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)
And Wood that quickly [or easily] breaks. (O, Ḳ.)

fidorapN A piece of flesh-meat: (M, Ḳ:) or a compact piece thereof: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, O:) or a piece of cold, cooked, flesh-meat: (T: [mentioned in the TA as from the M:]) and a piece of anything: (TA:) pl. fidarN. (T, TA.)
A lump of dates [compacted together]: (M:) or a large lump of dates compacted together; as also finodiyrN and finodiyrapN, (TA in art. fndr.)
A piece of a mountain: (T, Ḳ:) or an overtopping, or an overhanging, or a projecting, piece of a mountain. (M.) See also faAdirapN.
And A portion of the night. (M, Ḳ.)
fudarapN A man who goes away by himself; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) like furadapN; formed by transposition. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.) [See also faAdirN, last signification.]

hom.sense: fudur-N Silver. (O, Ḳ.)
And also, (Ḳ,) or gulaAmN fudur-N, (O,) A boy, or youth, that has nearly attained to puberty: or fat, or plump. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: faduwrN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: faAdirN, applied to a stallion, [primarily to a stallion-camel, (see 1, first sentence,)] Desisting from covering; or desisting from covering, being wearied by much indulging therein: (Ṣ, O:) or flagging, or becoming remiss, or languid, in covering, and desisting therefrom: (M, Ḳ:) [or lacking power, or ability, to cover: (see 1:)] pl. fawaAdiru, (Ṣ, O,) or fudorN. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, and faduwrN↓, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and fadarN↓, (M, Ḳ,) applied to a mountaingoat, Advanced in age, or full-grown: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or youthful, and complete in make: (M, Ḳ:) or large, or big: (Ṣ, O:) or that protects himself in the mountain from the hunter: (M, Ḳ:) faAdirN applied to a mountain-goat as meaning advanced in age is like qaAriHN applied to a horse, and baAzilN to a camel, and SaAligN to an animal of the bovine kind and to a sheep or goat: (Aṣ, T:) accord. to IAth, it is from fadara said of a stallion as meaning “he lacked power, or ability, to cover:” (TA: [and the like is said in the O:]) the pl. (of faAdirN, M) is fudurN, (M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or fudorN, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) or both, (Ṣ, O, [see an ex. of the latter plural in a verse cited voce tadav-ara,]) and fawaAdiru and (of fadarN↓, M) fuduwrN, and (quasi-pl. n., M) mafodarapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) like maXoyaxapN. (M.)
And faAdirN, (O, Ḳ,) [thus] without p, (O,) signifies also A she-camel that goes away alone, apart from the others; (O, Ḳ, TA;) like faAridN. (TA.) [See also fudarapN.]

entry.sense: faAdirapN † A great, (T, O, Ḳ,) hard and solid, (M, Ḳ,) mass of rock, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) which one sees (T, O) upon the head of a mountain; (T, M, O, Ḳ;) likened to the mountain-goat; (M, O;) as also fidorapN↓. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

finodiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and finodiyrapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) A great mass of rock that projects, or juts out, (tanoduru,) from the head of a mountain: (Ṣ:) what is thus called is short of (duwna) what is termed fidorap [in relation to a mountain]; (M, Ḳ;) by which may be meat dwn in respect of place and projection, not in respect of size. (TA.) [See also fidorapN and faAdirapN: and see more in art. fndr.]

TaEaAmN mufodirN, like muHosinN [in measure, app. in some one or more of the copies of the Ḳ like muHoSanN, for, as is mentioned in the TA, El-Bedr El-Karáfee says that it is anomalous, like musohabN from Osohaba, and muHoSanN from OHoSana], Food that stops from copulation; (Ḳ;) as also mafodarapN↓. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: mafodarapN: see what next precedes:
and see faAdirN.
Also A place of the mountain-goats termed fudur. pl. of faAdirN: (Ṣ, O:) [or] makaAnN mafodarapN signifies a place in which are many of those mountain-goats. (M, Ḳ.)

1. fadiEa, with kesr, [aor. _a {yafodaEu}, inf. n. fadaEN,] He was, or became, such as is termed OfodaEu [q. v.]. (O.) And fadiEato qadamuhu, (O, Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] fadaEato,) [aor. and inf. n. as above,] occurring in a trad., His foot had the affection termed fadaEN [meaning as expl. below; and in like manner the verb may be used in relation to the hand]. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
See also fadoEN.

entry.sense: 2. fd-Epu, (O, TA, from a trad.,) inf. n. tafodiyEN, (O, Ḳ,) He caused him (a man, O, TA) to be, or become, such as is termed OfodaEu. (O, Ḳ,* TA.)
fadoEN [app. an inf. n. of which the verb is fadaEa↓] A breaking, or crushing, syn. XadoxN [q. v.]: and a slight splitting or cleaving or slitting. (TA.)

fadaEN [mentioned above as an inf. n.] Deflection, and distortion: this is [said to be] the primary signification. (TA.) [Generally] A distortion of the wrist or of the ankle-joint, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that the hand or the foot becomes turned towards the inner side: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the walking upon the back [i. e. the upper surface] of the foot [from an explanation of OafodaEu by IAạr, mentioned in the Mgh and O and Mṣb and TA; but it seems rather to mean a distortion of the foot that occasions the so walking]: (Ḳ: [see also rawaHN:]) or height of the hollow part of the sale of the foot, such that if the person trod upon a sparrow it would not hurt it [from an explanation of OafodaEu by Aṣ, mentioned in the O]: (Ḳ, TA:) or a distortion (EiwajN, Ḳ, TA, [in the O EarajN,] and mayolN, TA) in the joints, as though they were dislocated, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) mostly in the wrists and ankle-joints, (Lth,* O,* Ḳ,* TA,) by nature (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA) or by disease, as though the person were unable to extend them: (Lth, O, TA:) or a deflection between the foot and the shank-bone, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and the like in the arm, being a state of dislocation of the joints: (TA:) or it is a colliding of the [inner] ankle-bones, and a wide separation of the feet, (Mgh, TA,) to the right and left. (TA. [See, again, rawaHN.]) In the camel, (Ḳ,) or in the fore legs of the camel, (ISh, O, TA,) it is The state in which one sees the animal to tread upon the part between the phalanges of his foot, so that the fore part of his foot becomes raised; (ISh, O, Ḳ, TA;) and it is nought but a rigidity in the pastern [that occasions this]. (ISh, O, TA.)
fadaEapN The place of what is termed fadaEN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) in the wrist or ankle-joint. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

OafodaEu Having a deflection; and distorted. (TA [in which it is implied that this is the primary signification].) [Generally] Having the affection termed fadaEN [q.v.]; applied to a man; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and to a he-camel: (O, Ḳ:) fem. fadoEaMCu; (O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a woman; (Mṣb;) and to a she-camel; (O, Ḳ;) and to a female slave as meaning whose hand is distorted in consequence of work. (IDrd, O.) And the masc. is applied to a male ostrich, as meaning Having a distortion of the extremities of the fore parts of his feet; in like manner as when it is applied to a he-camel. (Lth,* O, TA.) And hence, AlOfodaEu, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, signifies The male ostrich. (TA.) And OfodaE is applied by Ru-beh to fish (samak) as meaning Bending, crooked, or curving. (O.) And AlfadoEaMCu is a name of † The well-known asterism called AlciraAEu [q. v., the Seventh Mansion of the Moon; also called fadoEaMCu Aln-avorapi, because Alnvrp is the Eighth Mansion]: a poet says,
yawomN mina Aln-avorapi Oawo fadoEaAYihaA
yuxoriju nafosa AlEanozi mina wajoEaAYihaA
[A day of the auroral setting of Alnvrp or of its fdEMC that causes the soul of the she-goat to pass forth from her anus]; meaning, by reason of the intenseness of the cold. (TA.)
The dim. of OafodaEu is OufayodiEu↓. (TA.)
OufayodiEu: see what next precedes.

1. fadagahu, aor. _a {yafodagu}, inf. n. fadogN, He broke it, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or crushed it; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or (Ḳ) it is said when the object is a hollow thing, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or a moist, or soft, thing, (TA,) a person's head, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and a grape, and the like: (O, TA:) and he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it coarsely: and he clave, split, or rent, it slightly. (TA.)
And fadaga AlT-aEaAma He put much clarified butter into the food. (O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
And one says also, fadaga AlkamoOapa fiI Als-amoni [app. meaning He preserved the truffles in clarified butter]. (O.)
7. Anfdg It (anything dry, or rigid,) became soft, or supple. (O, Ḳ.*)
fadagN Distortion in the foot: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) like fadaEN, which is more common. (O.) [See fadaEN.]
mifodagN An instrument for breaking, or crushing. (Ḳ, TA.) And applied to a man; like midaq-N [q. v.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. fadamotu EalaI fiyih biAlgidaAmi, [aor. _i {yafodimu},] inf. n. fadomN, I covered his, or its, mouth with the fidaAm [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) or fadama faAhu, and EalaI fiyhi, aor. _i {yafodimu}, and fd-m↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tafodiymN; (TA;) he put the fidaAm upon his, or its, mouth: (M, Ḳ:) [app. used in relation to a man and also to an Uiboriyq or other vessel: but the latter verb, and as trans. without a particle, seems to be more commonly used in relation to both:] one says of Persians or other foreigners, and of Magians, on the occasion of their giving to drink, fad-amuwA↓ OafowaAhahumo They bound the fad-aAm upon their mouths: (T:) and fd-m↓ AlUiboriyqa, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafodiymN, (Ḳ,) He put the fidaAm upon the mouth of the Abryq. (M, Ḳ.*)

faduma, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. fadaAmapN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fuduwmapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He was or became, such as is termed fadom [q. v.]; or he was or became, heavy, sluggish, or dull; and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in three places. One says also, fd-m AlbaEiyra, meaning He bound upon the camel's mouth the fidaAmap, (M,) which means the gimaAmap [q. v.]. (TA.)

fadomN Impotent (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) in speech, (T, M, Ḳ,) and in adducing an argument; (T, M;) [as though his mouth were covered with a fidaAm, for it is said in the Ṣ to be from fadamotu EalaI fiyhi biAlfidaAmi;] heavy, sluggish, or dull; (Ṣ;) or with heaviness, sluggishness, or dulness, and softness, and paucity of understanding: (M, Ḳ:) or unintelligent: (Mṣb:) and thick; (M, Ḳ;) fat; (M;) foolish, or stupid; rough, rude, or uncivil: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to IAạr, the heavy, sluggish, or dull; as being likened to blood, which is thus called: (T:) and vadomN is a dial. var. thereof, or, accord. to Yaạḳoob, the v is a substitute for the f: (M:) the fem. is with p {fadomapN}: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the pl. is fidaAmN [agreeably with analogy]. (M, Ḳ: in a copy of the T fudum [which I think a mistranscription].)
Also Heavy [and app. thick] blood: and, accord. to IAạr, blood [itself]. (T.)

And A garment, or piece of cloth, (T, TA,) saturated with dye, (T,) or saturated with red dye by its being put again into the safflower time after time. (TA.) And Red that is saturated (M, Ḳ) with redness: (Ḳ:) or of which the redness is not intense. (Thus also in some copies of the Ḳ.) [See also mufodamN.]
fadaAmN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fidaAmN and fadaAmN↓ and fad-aAmu↓ and fad-uwmN↓, (Ḳ,) or fad-aAmN↓ [only], (Ṣ, T, M,) A thing which the Persians or other foreigners, (T, Ḳ,) and the Magians, (Ḳ,) bind upon their mouths on the occasion of their giving to drink; (T, Ḳ;)
or a piece of cloth with which the Magian binds his mouth; (Ṣ;) or a sort of thing with which the Persians or other foreigners wipe [app. the mouth] when they give to drink; one of which is termed fad-aAmapN↓. (M. [In the Ṣ it seems to be implied that this last word is syn. with fad-aAmN as expl. above.])

Also, (Ḳ,) or the first, (T, Ṣ, M,) and also fad-aAmN↓, (Ṣ,) or and also fadaAmN↓, (M,) A strainer, or clarifier, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) for a mug and an Uiboriyq and the like; (T;) a thing that is put in, or upon, the mouth of the Abryq, for the straining, or clarifying, of what is in it: (Ṣ, M:*) also called vidaAmN. (M.)

And fidaAmN signifies also the same as EimaAmapN: thus in copies of the Ḳ [and in a copy of the M]: but the former word is correctly fidaAmapN↓ [as is implied in one place in the M]; and the word by which it is explained is correctly gimaAmahN, [as in some copies of the Ḳ,] meaning A thing that is put upon the mouth of the camel. (TA. [See 2: and see also the first paragraph {1} of art. gm.])
fidaAmapN: see the next preceding paragraph {2}.
fad-aAmN: see fidaAmN, in three places.
fad-uwmN: see fidaAmN.
mufodamN: n. un. of fad-aAmN: see fidaAmN, former half.
mufodamu: see mufad-amu.

Also A garment, or piece of cloth, saturated with red dye: (Sh, T, Ṣ, M, and some copies of the Ḳ:) or of which the redness is not intense. (M, and some copies of the Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. that he [the Prophet] disliked the mufodamo for the muHoram, but saw no harm in the muDar-aj [q. v.]. (TA.)
Also Dye thick and saturated. (Ṣ.)
And cul-u mufoduwmN ‡ Deeplystained, intense, vileness or ignominy. (TA.)

mufad-amN (T, M, Ḳ) and mafoduwmN↓ (T) and mufodamN↓ (M, Ḳ) An Uiboriyq [a vessel for wine] having a strainer, called fidaAm, (T, M, Ḳ,) in, or upon, its mouth: (M, Ḳ:*) and so muvad-amN. (M.) It is said in a trad., Uin-akumo madoEuw-uwna yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mufad-amapF OafowaAhukumo biAlfidaAmi [Verily ye will be summoned on the day of resurrection having your mouths closed with the fdAm]; meaning, ye will be withheld from speaking with your mouths, so that your skins will speak. (M.)
mufad-amaAtN [Vessels of the kinds called] OabaAriyq and dinaAn [pls. of UiboriyqN and dan-u]. (Ṣ.)
mafoduwmN: see mufad-am.
2. tafodiynN signifies The making a building tall. (Ḳ. [See fadanN.])
And ‡ The fattening of camels. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, fd-nhu, meaning ‡ He (the pastor) fattened him [i. e. a camel]; made him like the fadan, i. e. the qaSor. (TA.)

hom.sense: fadanN A [pavilion, or building of the kind termed] qaSor, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) raised high, or made lofty: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OafodaAnN; (M, A;) to which fat camels are likened. (A. [See 2.])
And A certain red dye. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: fadaAnN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

fad-aAnN The bull; (M, Ḳ;) and so fadaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) the bull with which one ploughs: (IAạr, TA:) or, (AA, AḤn, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also fadaAnN↓, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the oxen, (AA, Ṣ,) or the two bulls (AḤn, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) which are coupled together (AḤn, M, Ḳ) in [or by means of] the [cord called] qiraAn (Mgh) [and] which plough, (Ṣ,) or with which one ploughs; (AḤn, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and one thereof is not called fad-aAnN: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) or fad-aAnN signifies, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and so fadaAnN↓, (Mgh,) or the former, (Ṣ,) or each, (M, Mṣb,) signifies also, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) [the plough; or the apparatus, or gear, thereof; i. e.] the implement, or the apparatus, or gear, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the two bulls, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) for ploughing; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) or the whole apparatus, or gear, of the two bulls [which are coupled together] in [or by means of] the [cord called] qiraAn: (M:) but accord. to Abu-l-Ḥasan Es-Sikillee, fadaAnN↓, without teshdeed, signifies the implement, or apparatus, with which one ploughs: and fad-aAnN, with teshdeed, has a different meaning, expl. in what follows, relating to land: and IAạr says the like: (TA:) [see also EiyaAnN:] the pl. of fad-aAnN is fadaAdiynu, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning oxen with which one ploughs: (M, TA:) the pl. of fadaAnN↓ is OafodinapN [a pl. of pauc.] and fudunN, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and the vulgar say fidon, with kesr. (TA.)

fad-aAnN, with teshdeed, also signifies A certain commonly-known quantity [of land]; (IAạr, TA;) said by Abu-l-Ḥasan Es-Sikillee to signify a limited portion of land, subdivided into four and twenty keerats; (TA;) [loosely reckoned as the quantity of land which a yoke of oxen will plough in one day; thus corresponding to the Latin term jugerum, and our acre; and commonly defined as consisting of 333 kasabehs (or rods) and one third; (the kasabeh being 24 kabdahs; and the kabdah being the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect, or about 6 inches and a quarter;) but different in different times and in different parts of the same country: hence, perhaps,] it is also expl. as signifying a place of seed-produce. (M, TA.)

Alfad-aAduwna is said to signify OaSoHaAbu AlfadaAdiyna [The possessors of ploughing oxen]; like as jam-aAluwna signifies “possessors of camels:” but it has been otherwise expl. in [its proper place, as pl. of fad-aAdN, in] art. fd. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: binaMCN mufad-anN A building that is [made] tall, or lofty. (M.)
And vawobN mufad-anN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with fadan. (TA.)

entry.sense:
1. fadaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yafodiyhi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. fidaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ, [omitted in my copy of the Mṣb, probably by inadvertence,]) and fadFI, (Mgh,) or fidFI, (so in the M, accord. to the TT,) or also both of these, (Fr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of them said by Fr, on one occasion, to be the more common, (T, TA,) [which is the case when it is a subst., like fidoyapN,] but ʼAlee Ibn-Suleymán El-Akhfash [i. e. El-Akhfash El-Asghar] is related to have said that this is not allowable except by poetic license, and El-Ḳálee says that AlfidaI was used by the Arabs in conjunction with AlHimaI, [see HimaMCu, in art. HmI,] but other forms were used in other cases [among which he seems to mention fadaMC, with fet-ḥ and the lengthened alif, but the words in which I find this expressed are somewhat ambiguous, and are also rendered doubtful by an erasure and an alteration]; (TA;) and AftdAhu↓, (M,) [whence an ex. in a verse which will be found in what follows,] or AftdI↓ bihi (Ḳ, TA) and minohu, (TA,) [but I do not know AftdI in either of these phrases as having any other than the well-known meaning of fadaI nafosahu, which is strangely omitted in the Ḳ;] and know fAdiAhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. mufaAdaApN and fidaMCN; (Mṣb, TA;) but some explain this differently [as will be shown in what follows]; (T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) He gave his ransom; (Ṣ;) he gave a thing, (Ḳ, TA, [AaEoTAhu in the CK being a mistake for OaEoTaI, without the affixed pronoun,]) or a captive, for him, (TA,) and so liberated him; (Ḳ, TA;) [i. e. he ransomed him;] or he liberated him, or ransomed him, mina AlOasori [from captivity]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or fAdAhu↓ signifies he loosed him, or set him free, and took his ransom: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or mufaAdaApN signifies the giving a man and taking a man [in exchange]: and fidaMCN, [as inf. n. of fadaAhu,] the purchasing him [from captivity or the like]: (Mbr, T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or the preserving a man from misfortune by what one gives by way of compensation for him; as also fadFI: (Er-Rághib, TA:) you say, fadayotuhu bimaAliI I purchased [i. e. ransomed] him with my property, and binafosiI with myself: (T:) or, accord. to Nuseyr Er-Rázee, the Arabs say, faAdayotu↓ AlOasiyra [I ransomed the captive], and fadayotuhu biOabiI waOumiI [I ransomed him in a tropical sense with my father and my mother], and bimaAlK [with property], as though thou purchasedst him and freedst him therewith, when he was not a captive; and you may say, fadayotu AlOasyra meaning I freed the captive from the state in which he was, though faAdayotu↓ is better in this sense: as to the reading tafoduwhumo [in the Ḳur ii. 79], Aboo-Mo'ádh says, it means Ye purchase them from the enemy and liberate them; but the reading tufaAduwhumo↓, he says, means ye contend with them who are in your hands respecting the price and they so contend with you: (T, TA:) [that AftdAhu↓ is syn. with fadaAhu is shown by what here follows:] a poet says,
yufotadaI lafadayotuhu falawo kaAna maytN
bimaA lamo takuno Eanohu Aln-ufuwsu taTiybu
[And if a person dead were to be ransomed, assuredly I would ransom him with what minds would not be willing to relinquish]. (M, TA.)

[The inf. ns. of the first of these verbs are much used in precative phrases:] they said, fadFI laka [for fadaAka fadFI, and therefore virtually meaning fudiyta Mayest thou be ransomed; the l being lilt-aboyiyni i. e. “for the purpose of notifying” the person addressed]: (TA:) and biI Oa fadFI laka [for fadaAka OabiI binafosihi fadFI, and therefore virtually meaning simply fadaAka OabiI binafosihi May my father ransom thee with himself; so that it may be well rendered may my father be a ransom for thee]: (Ṣ:) and fidaMC, with tenween, some of the Arabs pronounce with kesr [to the C, i. e. they pronounce fidaMC with the tenween of kesr], peculiarly when it is next to [meaning immediately followed by] the preposition l, saying fidaMCK laka, because it is indeterminate; they intending thereby the meaning of a prayer; and Aṣ has cited [as an ex. thereof] the saying of En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee],
maholFA fidaMCK laka AlOaqowaAmu kul-uhumu
wamaA Ouvamiru mino maAlK wamino waladi
[Act gently: may the peoples, all of them, and what I make to be abundant of wealth and of offspring, give themselves as a ransom, or be a ransom, for thee: fidaMCK being app. assimilated to an indeterminate imperative verbal noun such as SahK in the phrase SahK yaA rajulu, which is as though one said Ausokuto sukuwtFA yaA rajulu; thus meaning here liyafodika: but De Sacy mentions, in his “Chrest. Arabe,” see. ed., vol. ii., p. 460, three allowable readings (not the foregoing reading) in this verse, namely, fdMCN and fdMCF and fdMCK; and adds that what here follows is said by a commentator to be, of several explanations, that which is the right: wAlqwl AlMxr whw AlSHyH An fdMCi bmEnI lyufdika fbnAh kmA bnI AlAmr wkclk tarAki w darAki lAnh bmEnI Atrk w Adrk: this, it will be observed, is similar to the explanation which I have offered of fidaMCK lk; for lyufdik is app. a typographical mistake for lyafdik: and I incline to think that fdMCi, though supposed to be correct and therefore likened to tarAki and darAki, is a mistake of a copyist for fdMCK; and the more so because I find in Ahlwardt's “Divans of the Six Ancient Arabic Poets” the three readings fidACN and fidACF and fidACK, but not fidACi]. (Ṣ, TA.)
wafadayonaAhu biciboHK [in the Ḳur xxxvii. 107] means And we made an animal prepared for sacrifice to be a ransom for him, and freed him from slaughter. (T, TA.)
fadato nafosahaA mino zawojihaA and Aftdt↓ [alone] mean She gave property to her husband so that she became free from him by divorce. (Mṣb, TA.)
See also what next follows {2}.

2. fd-Ahu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or fd-Ahu binafosihi, (Ṣ,* TA,) [or both, for both are correct,] inf. n. tafodiyapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and fadaAhu↓ bnfsh, (Ṣ, TA,*) aor. yafodiyhi, inf. n. fidaMCN; (TA;) He said to him fidaAka juEilotu↓ [May I be made thy ransom, i. e. a ransom for thee]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
3: see 1, former half, in five places.

In the saying respecting bloodwits, waUino OaHab-uwA faAdawoA, the meaning is, [And if they like,] they free the slayer, or his next of kin who is answerable for him, and accept the bloodwit; because this is a substitute for the blood, like as the ransom is a substitute for the captive. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 4. AfdAhu AlOasiyra [in the CK (erroneously) AlAsyru] He accepted from him the ransom of the captive. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of the Prophet to Kureysh, when ʼOthmán Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah and El-Hakam Ibn-Keysán had been made captives, laA nufodiykumuw humaA Ht-aI yaqodama SaAHibaAnaA [We will not accept from you the ransom of them two until our two companions shall come], meaning [by the two companions] Saạd Ibn-Abee-Wakkás and 'Otbeh Ibn-Ghazwán. (M.)
AfdI fulaAnN Such a one danced, or dandled, his child: (Ḳ, TA:) because of his [often] saying, fadiI laka OabiI waOumiI [May my father and my mother be ransoms for thee]. (TA.)
AfdI also signifies He made for his dried dates a store-chamber. (Ḳ.)
And † He became large in his body; (IAạr, T, Ḳ, TA;) as though it became like the fadaMC [q. v.]. (TA.)
And He sold dates. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tfAdwA They ransomed one another. (Ṣ, TA.)
And † They guarded themselves, one by another; as though every one of them made his fellow to be his ransom. (Mṣb, TA.)
And tfAdI minohu ‡ He guarded against it, or was cautious of it, and kept aloof from it. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
8: see 1, first quarter, in two places; and again, near the middle of the paragraph.

As intrans., AftdI signifies [He ransomed himself;] he gave a ransom for himself. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, AftdI minohu bikacaA [He ransomed himself from him with such a thing]. (Ṣ.) Hence the usage of the verb in the Ḳur ii. 229. (TA.) See 1, last sentence but one.

fadFI and fidFI↓ and fidaMCN↓ and fidoyapN↓ all signify the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. [A ransom;] a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) or a captive, (TA,) that is given for a man, who is therewith liberated: (Ḳ, TA:) [the first three are also inf. ns. (and have been mentioned as such in the first paragraph); therefore when you say fadFI laka OabiI and fidFI lk AbI, the words fadFI and fidFI may be either inf. ns. or substs.: as substs., the second and third are more common than the first:] fidoyapF [is also sometimes expl. as an inf. n., but accord. to general usage] signifies as above; (Ḳ, TA;) or property given as a substitute [or a ransom] for a captive: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and property by the giving of which one preserves himself from evil in the case of a religious act in which he has fallen short of what was incumbent, like the expiation for the breaking of an oath and of a fast; and thus it is used in the Ḳur ii. 180 and 192: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and its pl. is fidFI and fidayaAtN. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)
fidFI: see the next preceding paragraph. [Hence the phrase] juEilotu fidaAka: see 2. It is also a pl. of its syn. fidoyapF. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: fidoyapN: see fadFI.

xuco EalaI hidoyatika wafidoyatika, accord. to the Ḳ, but in the Ṣ, xuco fiI hidoyatika waqidoyatika, mentioned in art. qdI, is a saying meaning [Take thou to] that [course] in which thou wast: the author of the Ḳ seems to have followed Ṣgh, who has mentioned it here: (TA in the present art.:) fidoyahN and qidoyahN are dial. vars. (TA in art. qdI.)

entry.sense: fadaMCN An OanobaAr, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. (TA) a collection, of wheat: (M, Ḳ,* TA:) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (M,) a collection of food, consisting of barley and dates and the like: (M, Ḳ:) or an OanobaAr, i. e. a collection, of food, consisting of wheat and dates and barley: (Ṣ:) and it is said to signify a place in which dates are spread and dried, in the dial. of ʼAbd-El-Keys. (M.)
And The Hajom [or protuberant, or prominent, part, or perhaps the bulk,] of a thing (M, Ḳ) of any kind. (M.)
fidaMYN: see fadFI.

AlfidaAwiy-apu is the appellation of A class, or rect, of the xawaArij of the duroziy-ap [or duruwz, whom we call the Druses; it is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is fidaAwiI-u; the w being a substitute for C: it is used to signify those who undertake perilous adventures, more particularly for the destruction of enemies of their party; as though they offered themselves as ransoms or victims; and hence it is applied to the sect called in our histories of the Crusades “The Assassins”]. (TA.)
[mafodiI-N, originally mafoduwIN. In the saying binafosiI fulaAnN mufodiI-N With my soul, or myself, may such a one be ransomed, mafodiI-N is often suppressed; being meant to be understood.]

hom.sense: 1. fac-a Eano OaSoHaAbihi, [aor. _i {yafocicu}, inf. n. fac-N,] He was, or became, apart from his companions, and remained alone. (L.)
And fac-, (TA,)) [aor. _u {yafocucu},] inf. n. fac-u, (Ḳ, TA.) He drove away (Tarada) vehemently. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Afc-hu He made him, or it, to be single; sole; or one, and no more; syn. Oawotarahu; (Ṣ in art. wtr;) and jaEalahu fac-FA, i. e. witorAF. (TA in that art.)
And Oafac-ato She (a ewe or goat) brought forth one only, (El-Aḥmar, T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Mṣb,) at a breeding; (Mṣb;) inf. n. UifocaAcN. (El-Aḥmar, T, M, L.) [See mufic-N.]
5: see next following paragraph {10}.

10. Astfc-bihi He was, or became, alone; independent of others; without any to share, or participate, with him; in it: (Ḳ, TA:) you say, Astfc- EalaI-a biAAlOamori He was, or became, alone, or independent, exclusively of me, in the affair: (O:) and tfc-c↓ bihi also has the former meaning: (Ḳ, TA:) or this latter signifies He was, or became, alone with him. (O.)

R. Q. 1. facofaca He contracted himself (taqaASara), to leap, deceiving, or circumventing, (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ,) or in order to deceive, or circumvent, when leaping; (IAạr, T in art. cf;) said of a man. (IAạr, T, O.)
[And accord. to the Ḳ, in art. cf, i. q. tabaxotara; like cafocafa: but] accord. to IAạr, cafocafa has this latter meaning, and facofaca signifies as expl. above on his authority. (T in art. cf.)

fac-N Single; sole; only; one, and no more; [and alone, or apart from others; (see 1;)] syn. farodN; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, L, Ḳ;) and waAHidN: (L, Mṣb:) pl. [of mult.] fucuwcN (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OafocaAcFA. (M, L, Ḳ.) One says, cahabaA fac-ayoni They two went away singly. (Ṣ, O, L.) And jaMC Alqawoma OafocaAcFA: see fucaAcaI.
And tamorN fac-N Dates that are separate, each one from others; (IAạr, Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ;) not sticking together; (IAạr, M, L;) as also faD-N; (M;) and fav-N. (T in art. fv.)

And Alfac-u is [a name of] The first of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir: (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ:) it has one notch; and for it is gained one share [of the slaughtered camel] when it is successful, and one share is exacted when it is unsuccessful: (Lḥ, M, O, L:) the arrows are ten: the 2nd is called Alt-awoOamu; the 3rd, Alr-aqiybu; the 4th, AlHilosu; the 5th, Aln-aAfisu; the 6th, Almusobilu; the 7th, AlmuEal-aI; and there are three for which there is no share, namely, Als-afiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu. (Ṣ, O, L.) [See Alrqyb.]
kalimapN fac-apN: see faAc-apN.
fuc-aAcFA: see the next paragraph, in two places.

jaMCa Alqawomu fucaAca, (O,) or fucaAcFA↓, (Mṣb,) and fuc-aAcFA↓, and OafocaAcFA↓, The people, or party, came one by one; singly. (O, Mṣb.) And OakalonaA fucaAcaI, (Ḳ, TA,) and facaAcaI, (CK,) and fucaAcFA↓, and fuc-aAcFA↓, We ate separately. (Ḳ.)
fuc-aAcFA: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

kalimapN faAc-apN, and fac-apN↓, i. q. XaAc-apN [i. e. A word, phrase, proposition, or sentence, extraordinary, or exceptional, in respect of rule, or of usage]. (M, L.) And MyapN faAc-apN A verse of the Ḳur-án that is alone in meaning. (L.)
Oafac-u An arrow having no feathers upon it; (T, O, Ḳ;) opposed to mariyXF: so says Aboo-Málik: others say Oaqac-N [q. v.], with q: but he allowed only the former. (T, O.)

mufic-N A ewe or she-goat bringing forth one only, (El-Aḥmar, T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) at a breeding: (Mṣb:) [like muforidN and muwHidN:] one does not apply this epithet to a she-camel, because she never brings forth more than one. (Ṣ, M, O, L, Mṣb.)
mifocaAcF A ewe or she-goat that usually brings forth one only. (T, Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. far-a, aor. _i {yaforiru}, inf. n. firaArF (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and farN (M, Ḳ) and mafarN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and mafirN, (Ḳ,) or the last is a n. of place [and of time], (Ṣ, M,) He (a man, T) fled: (T, Ṣ:) or he turned away or aside, to elude, and fled, (M, Ḳ, TA,) from a thing that he feared. (TA.) Oayona Qlomafar-u [in the Ḳur lxxv. 10] means Whither is the [fleeing or] turning away, &c.? (M, TA:) or it may mean when is the time thereof? (TA:) and Ayn Almafir-u, another reading, where is the place of fleeing, &c.? (I’Ab, Zj, Ṣ, M, TA,) as also Almifar-u, (Zj, Ḳ, TA,) which is an instrumental noun used as a noun of place: (Ḳ, TA:) but the first is the common reading. (TA.)
far-a mino Eaduwihi, aor. as above, inf. n. far-N, He wheeled about widely from his enemy, to turn again. (Mṣb.)
And far-a UilaI AlX-aIoCi He went, or betook himself, to the thing. (Mṣb.)
And [hence] far-ato yaduhu His arm, or hand, fell off; like Tar-ato and tar-ato. (O.)

far-a Alfarasa, (Ṣ, O,) or Ald-aAb-apa, (M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaforuru}, (Ṣ, M, O,) i. e. with damm, (O,) [in copies of the Ḳ _i, but afterwards in those copies _u, which is the regular and correct form,] inf. n. far-N (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and furaArN and firaArN and faraArN, (Ḳ,) or furaArN is a simple subst., and firaArN is an inf. n., (Meyd, in explanation of the prov. which here follows,) He looked at, or examined, the teeth of the horse, (Ṣ, O,) or he exposed to view the teeth of the beast that he might see what was its age. (M, Ḳ.) Hence, (TA,)
Uin-a AljawaAda Eayonuhu furaAruhu , (Ṣ, M,* Meyd, Ḳ,*) and firaAruhu, (M, Meyd, Ḳ,) and faraAruhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes thus pronounced with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) ‡ [Verily the fleet and excellent horse, his aspect (see EayonN) is (equivalent to) the examination of his teeth, i. e. he is known by his aspect], is a prov., applied to him whose external state indicates his internal qualities; (Meyd, O, Ḳ;) meaning that one knows his excellence from his Eayon [i. e. aspect] like as one knows the age of a beast by examining his teeth; (TA;) his external appearance rendering it needless for thee to test him, (Ṣ, Meyd, O, Ḳ,) and to examine (Oano tafur-a) his teeth: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and [with the same meaning] one says, far-u AljawaAdi Eayonuhu: (A, TA:) and [in like manner] Alxabiyvu Eaynuhu furiAaruhu [The bad, his aspect, &c.]; (Meyd, O, TA;) i. e. thou knowest his badness by his Eayon when thou seest him. (TA.) And one says also, fararotu fama Alfarasi I opened the mouth of the horse that I might know his age. (Ḥar p. 28.) And far-a Eano OasonaAni Ald-aAb-api, aor. _i {yaforiru}, He examined the teeth of the beast. (Ḥar p. 233.)

[Hence the saying of El-Hajjáj, furirotu Eano cakaMCK, expl. in art. ckw.] And [hence also] one says, far-ahu Eano OaXoyaMCi ‡ He examined him respecting things (O,* TA.) And far-a AlOamora, (M, TA,) and far-a Eani AlOamori, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA,) ‡ He examined, looked into, scrutinized, or investigated, the affair; searched into it; inquired, or sought information, respecting it. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA.) And far-a fulaAnN Eam-aA fiI nafosiI ‡ Such a one interrogated me in order that he might know, from what I should say, what was in my mind. (TA.)

And fur-a AlOamoru jacaEFA † The thing returned to its first state; it recommenced. (M, O, Ḳ.) And fur-a AlOamora jacaEFA † Commence thou the affair from the first thereof. (M, in the TT. [But the MṢ. has in this case, as in that here immediately preceding, AlAmru: the right reading is evidently AlAmra; as in a similar phrase voce jacaEN, q. v.])
far-a, aor. yafir-u or yafar-u, (accord. to different copies of the T,) He became intelligent after being weak [in mind]. (IAạr, T, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. faArarotuhu, inf. n. mufaAr-apN, ‡ I investigated his state, or condition, he investigating mine. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Afr-hu He, or it, made him to flee; (Ṣ, O;) or made him to turn away or aside, for the purpose of eluding, and to flee: (M, Ḳ:) or (O) he did to him a deed that made him to flee; (Fr, AO, T, M, O, Ḳ;) as also Afr-bihi. (TA.) It is related in a trad. that the Prophet said to 'Adee the son of Ḥátim, maA yufir-uka Eani AlUisolaAmi Uil-A Oano yuqaAla laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehu (T, M, O, TA) i. e. Nothing induces thee to flee from El-Islám except the saying “There is no deity but God:” many of the relaters say yafur-uka; but Az says that the former is the right. (TA.)
Hence the saying, Afr-Qll-ehu yadahu God made, or may God make, his arm, or hand, to fall off; like OaTar-ahaA and Oatar-ahaA. (O.)
And Oaforarotu raOosahu I split, or clave, his head, with a sword; like Oaforayotuhu. (Yz, T, O, Ḳ.)
Oafar-ato liloUivonaMCi, said of camels, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and of horses, (M, Ḳ,) They shed their milk-teeth and had others come forth. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tafar-ara biI i. q. DaHika [He laughed at me, derided me, or ridiculed me]; (Ḳ, TA;) mentioned by Ṣgh. (TA.)
6. tfAr-wA They fled, one from another. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8. Aftr- He laughed in a beautiful manner, (M, Ḳ,) beyond what is termed AinokilaAl [inf. n. of Ainokal-a, q. v.]. (M.) One says, Aftr-a DaAHikFA He showed his teeth laughing; (Ṣ;) as also Aftr Eano vagorihi. (T.) It is said of the Prophet, AlgamaAmi wayafotar-u Eano mivoli Hab-i meaning And he used to smile so as to show teeth the like of hail-stones, without a reiterated, or a loud, laughing. (T.)

Hence, (TA,) Aftr- Albaroqu † The lightning glistened. (M, Ḳ.) And hence the saying, AlS-arofahu naAbu Ald-ahori Ql-aciI yafotar-u Eanohu [Es-Sarfeh is the dog-tooth of time, or fortune, which it shows smiling]: for when Es-Sarfeh [which is the Twelfth Mansion of the Moon] rises, [but it should be, when it sets, aurorally, for it so set, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 9th of March, O. Ṣ.,] the blossoms come forth and the herbage attains its full height. (M, L. [See more in art. Srf.])
See also fur-N.
Also He snuffed up a thing into his nose. (M, Ḳ.)

R. Q. 1. farofarahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. farofaArN, (M,) or firofaArN, (TA,) He put in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; shook; or shook about; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or him. (M.) One says of a horse, yufarofiru All-ijaAma fiI fiyhi He puts in a state of motion,, &c., the bit in his mouth. (M. [See also an explanation of the verb as intrans., in what follows.])
He broke it, i. e. a thing. (M, Ḳ.)
He cut it. (Ḳ.)

He clave, split, slit, rent, or tore, it. (TA.) [Thus] farofara signifies He rent, or tore, [skins such as are termed] ziqaAq [pl. of ziq-N], and other things; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and slit, or rent, them much. (TA. [In two copies of the T, instead of Alz-iqaAqa wagayorahaA, the reading in the O and Ḳ and TA, I find AlruqAqa wgyrh.])
[He mangled it.] One says, Alc-iYobu yufarofiru AlX-aApa The wolf mangles the sheep, or goat. (O,* TA.)
And, (O, Ḳ, TA,) hence, (O,) inf. n. farofarapN, (TA,) † He defamed him, and mangled his reputation. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And † He discommended it, [as though] mangling it with discommendation: the verb occurs in this sense in a trad., having for its object Ald-unoyaA [meaning the enjoyments, or good, of the present world]. (TA.)
Also, (inf. n. farofarapN, TA,) He called or cried, or called out or cried out, to him. (M, Ḳ.)
farofara as intrans., He (a camel) put his body in a state of commotion, or agitation. (M, Ḳ.)
He (a horse) struck his teeth with the fOos [q. v.] of his bit, and moved about his head. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
He hastened, or sped, and went with short steps. (M, O, Ḳ.)
He was light, and unsteady, (Ṣ,* M,* O,* Ḳ, TA,) in mind; (TA;) inf. n. farofarapN. (Ṣ, M, O, TA.)
He hastened, or was hasty, with foolishness, or stupidity. (IAạr, T, TA.)
And He confounded, or confused, and was profuse, fiI kalaAmihi [in his speaking, or talking, or his speech, or talk]. (M, Ḳ.)
And [app. He talked; for] AlfarofarapN signifies AlkalaAmu [which is often used as a quasi-inf. n. of kl-m]. (M.)
farofara also signifies He made the kind of vehicle called farofaAr. (T, Ḳ.)
And He kindled [a fire] with [wood of] the species of tree called farfaAr. (T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: far-N: see faAr-N, in two places.

fur-N [The best, or choice, of men, &c.]. One says, huwa fur-N qawomihi, (O,) or fur-N Alqawomi, (Ḳ,) and fur-atuhumo↓, (O, Ḳ,) He is of the best, or choice, of his people, or of the people, (O, Ḳ,) and of the chief persons thereof, (O, Ḳ,*) who show him smiling (Aal-aciyna yafotar-uwna↓ Eanohu, perhaps better rendered who withdraw from him so as to render him conspicuous): (O, Ḳ:) or huwafur-apN↓ qawomihi he is the best, or choice, of his people: (T:) and hecaA fur-apN↓ maAliI, (T,) or maAlihi, (O,) this is the best, or choice, of my, or his, property, or camels, &c. (T, O.)

fur-apN and Oufur-apN↓ and Oafur-apN↓ The beginning, or first part, of the heat: (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or they signify, (T, Ṣ, M,) or signify also, (O, Ḳ,) the vehemence thereof: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) but [Az says,] the second and third are in my opinion from Oafara, the O being the first radical letter: and Ks states that some change the O into E, saying Eufur-ap and Eafur-ap. (T.) maA zaAla fulaAnN fiI Oufur-apK↓ Xar-Kmino fulaAnK is a saying mentioned by Lth, (T, TA,) meaning [Such a one ceased not to be] in a vehement state of evil or mischief [proceeding from such a one]. (TA.)
Also Confusion and difficulty. (M, Ḳ.) One says, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI fur-apK and Oufur-apK↓ and Oafur-apK↓ The people, or party, fell into confusion and difficulty. (M.)
See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
fir-apN A smiling: [or rather a manner of smiling:] one says, Un-ahA laHasanapu Alfir-api [Verily she is beautiful in respect of the manner of smiling]. (TA.)
fururN: see furaArN.
furarapN: see faAr-N.

furaArN and faryrN↓ The young one of the ewe, and of the she-goat, (M, Ḳ,) and of the cow, (M,) or of the wild cow, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) as also, in this last sense, (O, Ḳ,) and in the first and second senses, (Ḳ,) furofurN↓ and furofuwrN↓ (O, Ḳ) and faruwrN↓ and furaAfirN↓: (Ḳ:) or they [app. referring to all the foregoing words] signify lambs: (Ḳ: [but see what follows:]) the female is termed furaArapN: (M:) and furaArN is pl. also; (T, M, Ḳ;) i. e. it is applied to a pl. number as well as to one; (TA;) it is said to be pl. of fariyrN↓; (T, Ṣ, M, O;) and is of a rare form of pl.; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;*) and it signifies the small in body of the young ones of the goat-kind; (M;) or fariyrN↓, as some say, signifies thus: (TA: [but this I think doubtful:]) this last word is said by IAạr to signify the young one of the wild animal, of the gazelle and of the bovine kind and the like; and in one instance he says that it signifies lambs: (M:) and, (T, A,) as Aboo-l-ʼAbbás [i. e. Th] states on the authority of IAạr, (T,) furaArN (T, M) and furaArapN (T) and fariyrN↓ (M) and fururN↓ and furofuwrN↓ and furaAfirN↓ (T, M) signify the lamb when it is weaned, (T, M,) and has become what is termed jaforN [q. v.], and obtained plenty of herbage, (M,) and has become fat: (T, M:) accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, (O,) the last two signify a lamb (Hamal, O, TA, in the Ḳ jamal, a mistranscription, TA) when it eats, and chews the cud: (O, Ḳ: [see also furofuwrN below:]) and [it is also said that] furaArN signifies great bahom [app. as meaning lambs or kids], and one thereof is termed furofuwrN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov.
nazowu AlfuraAri Qsotajohala AlfuraAraA
[The leaping of the wild calf, or with equal propriety AlfrAr may be here rendered the kid, excited to lightness the other wild calf, or kid]: (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) AʼObeyd says, on the authority of El-Mu- ärrij, [and so says Meyd, and the same is implied in the Ṣ and O,] that AlfrAr here means the young one of the wild cow: (T:) i. e., when the frAr attains to youthful vigour it takes to leaping, and when another sees it [do so] it leaps in like manner: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the prov. is used in relation to him of whose companionship one should be cautious; meaning, if thou become his companion thou wilt do as he does: (T, O, Ḳ:) some relate it otherwise, saying nazowa, meaning nazaA nazowa AlfuraAri. (O.) [See also a similar prov. in art. sfh, conj. 5.]
farurN: see faAr-N. It is applied to a woman as meaning Wont to flee from that which induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. (Ṣ.)
See also the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: fariyrN: see furaArN, in four places.

Also The place of the mHas-ap [thus in a copy of the M (app. miHas-ap i. e. currycomb, as though meaning the part that is currycombed), in the Ḳ of the mjas-ap (i. e. majas-ap, q. v.), and in the O of the mjm-, which last I think to be a mistranscription,] of the maEorafap [or part, or flesh, upon which grows the mane] of the horse: (M, O, Ḳ:) or the base (OaSol) of the maEorafap of the horse. (T; and accord. to the TA, mentioned by Ṣgh, and there said to be tropical.)
And The mouth: (O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Z in a manner indicating that it is of the horse or the like. (TA.)

entry.sense: faruwrapN: see faArN.
katiybapN fur-aI [A military force, or troop,, &c.,] defeated: (T, O, Ḳ:) as also ful-aI. (T.)
far-aMCu, applied to a woman, i. q. gar-aMCu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) meaning Beautiful in the front teeth. (TA.)
far-aArN: see faAr-N.
[Hence,] Quicksilver; so called because flowing quickly, and not remaining in a place: thus says Esh-Shereeshee. (Ḥar p. 139.)
fur-ayorapN, in the dim. form, with teshdeed, [A spinning-top;] a thing with which children play. (TA.)

faAr-N (Ṣ, M) and far-N↓ (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and faruwrN↓ (M, O, Ḳ) and faruwrapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and far-aArN↓ (M, O, Ḳ) and furarapN↓ (Ḳ) are epithets from far-a signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: (Ṣ, T, M, O, Ḳ:) [the first and second meaning Fleeing; or turning away or aside, to elude, and fleeing: the third, fifth, and sixth, fleeing,, &c., much: and the fourth, fleeing,, &c., very much:] but far-N↓ is applied to one and to two and to more, and to a female; (Ṣ, O;) it has no dual nor pl. [nor fem. form]; (T;) the sing. [and dual] and pl. [and masc. and fem.] are alike; (M;) as it is an inf. n. used as an epithet; (M, O;)
and it may be a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of faAr-N, (Ṣ, M, O,) like as rakobN is of raAkibN, (Ṣ, O,) and SaHobN of SaAHibN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) or XarobN of XaAribN: (M:) it is related in the trad. respecting the Flight that Surákah Ibn-Málik, when he saw the Prophet and Aboo-Bekr fleeing to El-Medeeneh, and they passed by him, said, hecaAni far-N qurayXK OafalaA Oarud-u EalaI qurayoXK far-ahaA, (T,* Ṣ,* O,* TA,) meaning [These two are] the two fugitives [of Kureysh: shall I not turn back to Kureysh their fugitives?]. (AʼObeyd, T, TA.)
furofurN: see farofaArN:
and furaArN:
and furofuwrN, in three places.
firofirN: see furofuwrN, in two places.
furafirN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: And The lion; because he mangles his antagonist: (Z, TA:) or the lion that mangles his antagonist (O, Ḳ *) and everything; (O;) as also firfaArN↓ and furofurN↓, (Ḳ,) or furafirN↓, (O,) and furaAfirN↓ and furaAfirapN↓. (O, Ḳ.)
And Light and unsteady in mind: (Lth, T, M, O, Ḳ:) fem. with p {farofaArapN}. (Lth, T, M, O.)
And Loquacious; talkative; a great talker; (M, Ḳ;) like varovaArN: (M:) fem. with p {farofaArapN}. (Ḳ.)

Also A species of tree, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) hard, having much endurance of fire, (T, O,) of which are made [bowls such as are termed] qiSaAE (M, O, Ḳ) and EisaAs: (M, O:) AḤn says, it is a great kind of tree; (O;) it becomes tall like the dulob [q. v.]; its leaves are like those of the almondtree; it has blossoms like the red rose; (O, TA;) and it becomes thick so that great [bowls such as are termed] EisaAs, and OaqodaAH, are turned from it: (O:) when its tree becomes old, its wood becomes black like ebony: (O, TA:) it is a hard wood, that blunts iron; and the bowls thereof are thin and light, and of pleasant odour: small saddles, called maxaASir, pl. of mixoSarapN, for excellent she-camels, were also made of it, and the curved pieces of wood (OaHonaMC) thereof amounted [in price] to two hundred dirhems. (O.)
And A sort of vehicle, or saddle, for women (T, O, Ḳ) and for pastors, resembling the Hawiy-ap and sawiy-ap [described in arts. HwI and swI]. (T.)

entry.sense: firofaArN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: furofuwrN: see furaArN, in three places. [It is said that] it signifies A fat jamal (Thus in copies of the Ḳ [an evident mistranscription for Hamal, i. e. lamb, as is indicated in the TA by the addition such as has become what is termed jaforN].)

And A certain bird; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also furofurN↓ (O, Ḳ) and firofirN↓: (Ḳ:) a small EuSfuwr [i. e. sparrow, or passerine bird]: (ISh, T, M:) so it is said: (M:) and furofurN↓ signifies the EuSofuwrN [in an absolute sense]; (M, Ḳ;) as also furofuwrN: (Ḳ:) accord. to AḤát, Et-Táïfee says that Alfurofuru↓, of which the pl. is AlfaraAfiru, signifies the naqaAqiyr; thus he says, [using the pl.,] not the nuq-aAr [or naq-aAr? (see EuSofuwrN)]; and he adds that sometimes it is said that the furofuwr is the Sir- [q. v.]; and some say Alfirofiru↓, with kesr, but he says, I am not confident of its chasteness: (O:) [accord. to Ed-Demeeree, as stated by Freytag, furofurN is the name of a small aquatic bird like the dove or pigeon: SM says, app. relying upon the correctness of a modern application of the word,] I have seen the furofuwr in Egypt, and it is smaller than the Uwac- [which is applied to the goose and sometimes to the duck]. (TA.)

Also, and furaAfirN↓, Parched meal (sawiyq) prepared from the yanbuwt [a tree described in art. nbt, which see, and see also gaAfN], (M, O, Ḳ,) i. e. from the fruit thereof; (O, Ḳ;) as some say, from the ynbwt of 'Omán. (TA.)

entry.sense: firofiyrN [Purple;] a certain sort of colour. (Ḳ.)
And The violet: or violet-colour: syn. in Pers. bnfXh [i. e. banafoXah, which is said to have both of these significations]. (KL.)
[And Purslane, or purslain. (Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár.)]
firofiyriI-N [Of a purple colour]. (TA: there applied as an epithet to the flower of the faAwaAniyaA [or peony].)
furaAfirN A horse that moves about, or agitates, the bit in his mouth, (M, O, Ḳ, TA,) to which Z adds, in order that he may disengage it [therefrom, or] from his head. (TA.)
And i. q. Oaxoraqu [Rough, ungentle,, &c.]; (M, O, Ḳ;) applied to a man. (O, Ḳ.)
See also farofaArN, in two places:
and furaArN, likewise in two places:
and furofuwrN, also in two places.
furaAfirapN: see farofaArN, second sentence.
Oufur-apN and Oafur-apN: see fur-apN, in five places.
mafar-N an inf. n. of far-a. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ. [See the first and second sentences of this art.])

Also A time [and a place] of fleeing: (TA:) and mafir-u↓ signifies a place of fleeing: (I’Ab, Zj, Ṣ, M, TA:) and so does mifar-u↓; (Zj, Ḳ, TA,) an instrumental noun used as a noun of place. (Ḳ, TA.) [See 1, second sentence.]
mafir-u: see the next preceding paragraph.
mufir-u [Making to flee:, &c. See its verb, 4].
[Hence, app.,] AlOay-aAmu Almufir-aAtu † The days that reveal, or make manifest, [or cause to fly abroad,] news, or tidings. (O, Ḳ.)

mifar-u [originally an instrumental noun: and hence,] A horse fit for one's fleeing upon him: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or excellent in fleeing. (Ḳ.) One says farasN mikar-N mifar-N A horse well trained, willing, and active, ready to return to the fight and to flee. (TA in art. kr.)
See also mafar-u.
mufar-aru: see what follows.
maforuwrN and mufar-arN↓ Examined, looked into, searched into, inquired respecting, or interrogated. (TA. [See 1.])

faraOo (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and faraMCN↓, (Ḳ,) both of these forms authorized by the Koofees, (TA,) A wild ass: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or a youthful wild ass: (M, Ḳ:) but the absolute [i. e. the former] meaning is that which is commonly known: (TA:) pl. (of mult., TA) firaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and (of pauc., TA) OaforaMCN. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, kul-u AlS-aydi fiI jawofi AlfaraA [Every kind of game is in the belly (or might enter into the belly) of the wild ass]; (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) meaning that every kind of game is inferior to the wild ass: (T, O, Ḳ:) a prov., (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and therefore [the last word is] without hemz, on account of the final pause; (Ḳ;) but some write it with hemz: (TA:) it is said to have originated from the fact that three men went forth to hunt; and one caught a hare; and another, a gazelle; and the third, a wild ass; and the first and second boasted against the third, who thereupon said as above: it is applied to him who excels his fellows: (Meyd:) or to a man who is, with respect to other men, as the wild ass with respect to other kinds of game: or to the case of a man who, having several wants, one of which is a great one, accomplishes that great want, and cares not for the others' being unaccomplished. (T, TA. [See also Ḥar pp. 468-9.]) And OanokaHonaA AlfaraA fasanaraI [We have married our daughter to the wild ass, and we shall see,] (T, Ṣ, M, O) is another prov.; (T, Meyd;) in which alif is substituted for the hemzeh, (Ṣ, M,* O,) for the purpose of the agreement [of AlfaraA in rhyme] with sanaraI: (M:) said by a man to his wife when a man demanded in marriage his daughter and he refused, but his wife consented, and overcame the father so that he gave her in marriage to him against his wish; then the husband made the intercourse [with her] to be evil, and divorced her: it is applied in cautioning against an evil consequence: (Meyd:) or it is applied to a man when his affair has been endangered and he has seen what he does not like; and it means we have wasted our precaution, and the affair has brought us to an evil result; (Aṣ, T;) or we have considered the affair, and we shall see what it will disclose; (T;) or we have sought after high things, and we shall see what our case will be afterwards. (Th, M.)
faraMCN: see above, first sentence.
XaIoCN fariIoCN i. q. fariI-N [q. v.] (O, Ḳ.* See art. frI.)

Q. 3. Aiforanobaja, said of a lamb, (Lth, O,) or of the skin of a lamb, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [some of the copies of the latter of which have Aljamal in the place of AlHamal,]) and of the skin of a kid, (O,) It was roasted so that the upper parts of it became dried up. (Lth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

muforanobijN [part. n. of the verb above]. A man said, describing a roasted female kid,
faOakalotu mino muforanobijK mino jilodihaA
[And I ate of such as was roasted so that the upper parts were dried up, of its skin]. (O.)

farobayuwnN, (Ḳ, TA, [in several copies of the Ḳ farofayuwn,]) also called OafarobayuwnN↓, (TA,) [Euphorbium; an inspissated sap of a certain African plant;] i. q. lubaAnapN magoribiy-apN; the best of which is that which dissolves quickly in water; (TA;) an attenuant medicine, beneficial as a remedy for sciatica, and for cold of the kidneys, and for colic, and for the sting, or bite, of venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, and for the bite of the mad dog, and it causes abortion, and attenuates viscous phlegm. (Ḳ.)
OafarobayuwnN: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. faruta, aor. _u {yaforutu}, inf. n. furuwtapN [said in the M to be a subst.], It (water, T, Mṣb) was, or became, sweet [or very sweet or most sweet (see furaAtN)]. (T, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
farata, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaforitu}, (M,) or _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n farotN, (M,) He acted vitiously, or unrighteously; or committed adultery, or fornication; syn. fajara. (M, Ḳ.)
farita, [aor. _a {yaforatu},] He became weak in his intellect, after having possessed ample intelligence. (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: firotN i. q. fitorN [The space measured by the extension of the thumb and fore finger]; (IJ, M, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of the latter word; as though formed by transposition. (M.)

furaAtN, applied to water, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) and furaAhN, both chaste forms, and well known, like taAbuwtN and taAbuwhN, (Towsheeh, MF, TA,) Sweet: (Ṣ, O:) or very sweet: (Ḳ:) or of the sweetest kind: (T, M, L:) or that subdues thirst by its excessive sweetness: (Bḍ in xxv. 55:) so called, accord. to Z, because it breaks the vehemence of thirst, and allays it; as though from rafata, and formed by transposition: (TA:) you say maMCN furaAtN, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and in a copy of the Ḳ firaAtN also, (TA,) and miyaAhN furaAtN, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and firotaAnN, (M, Mṣb, in copies of the Ḳ furotaAnN, and in the CK farotaAnN,) like girobaAnN [pl. of guraAbN], when furaAtN is pluralized, but this is rarely the case. (Mṣb.)

AlfuraAtu signifies also [The Euphrates;] the river of El-Koofeh; (Ṣ, Mgh, O,* Ḳ;*) a great, celebrated river, which issues from the limits of Er-Room, then passes by the borders of Syria, &c., and, after meeting with the Tigris, forms therewith one river, and pours forth into the Sea [or Gulf] of Persia. (Mṣb, TA.) And AlfuraAtaAni is an appellation applied to [The Euphrates and Tigris; i. e.] AlfuraAtu and dijolapu: or, accord. to the Ṣ [and O] AlfuraAtu and dujayolN [The Euphrates and Dujeyl, which latter is a branch of the Tigris]. (TA.)
Also The sea: (M, Ḳ:) so in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb describing pearls as found therein. (M.)

farotanaA, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-Ḥabeeb from farata [q. v.], but accord. to Sb the n is radical, (M,) or AlgarotanaA accord. to IB, (TA in art. frtn,) The fornicatress, or adultress. (M and Ḳ in this art.* and in art. frtn.) And The female slave: (Th, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. frtn:) or so AlfarotanaA: and Aibonu AlfarotanaA The son of the female slave that is a fornicatress. (IAạr, TA in that art.) And Aibonu farotanaA The low, ignoble, mean, or sordid. (El-Ah wal, IB, TA.)
Also, farotanaA, the name of A certain woman. (M and Ḳ in art. frtn.)
And AlfarotanaA The young one of the hyena. (Ḳ in art. frtn.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. farotana, (T, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. farotanapN, (T, TA,) signifies Xaq-aqa kalaAmahu waQhotamaXa fiyhi [app. meaning He uttered, or endeavoured with repeated efforts to utter, his speech in the best manner, and proceeded slowly therein]: (T, Ḳ,* TA:) in the copies of the Ḳ, Ahtms, with the unpointed s, is put for AhtmX, which is the right reading. (TA.)
And He went along with short steps. (Ḳ.)
And He (a man) became angry, and in a state of excitement: from what here follows [and therefore, app., post-classical]. (TA.)

entry.sense: furotunapN, with damm, [meaning with two dammehs,] A state of commotion of the sea arising from the violence of the winds: app. post-classical. (TA.)
farotanaA, in which the n is held by some to be radical, and by others to be augmentative, see in art. frt.

hom.sense: 1. faravotu AlkariXa: see 4.

farava Aljul-apa, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaforuvu}, (T, O,) or _i, (M,) or both, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. farovN, (T, M,) He scattered, or dispersed, [the contents of] the jul-ap [or receptacle made of palm-leaves, for dates]: (T,* Ḳ:) or ripped the jul-ap, and then scattered, or dispersed, its contents, (ISk, Ṣ, M, O,) entirely, (M,) liloqawmi [for the people, or party]. (ISk, Ṣ, O.)

And in like manner, (M,) farava kabidahu, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaforuvu}, (ISk, Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or _i, (O, and so in other copies of the Ḳ,) inf. n. farovN; (Ṣ, O;) and far-avahaA↓, (ISk, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taforiyvN; (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) He struck, or smote, him, (ISk, T, Ṣ, O,) or his liver, (Ḳ,) he being alive, (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) so that his liver became scattered. (ISk, T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And [hence] one says, farava AlHub-u kabidahu, and far-avahaA↓, and AfrvhA↓, meaning † Love crumbled [or crushed] his liver: [like as we say “it broke his heart:”] (M, TA:) and farotN is used in like manner of men, as meaning the crumbling of the liver by grief and molestation. (TA.)
See also 7.
fariva, aor. _a {yaforavu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. faravN, (M, O,) He was, or became, satiated. (M,* O,* Ḳ.) You say, Xariba EalaI faravK He drank on an occasion, or in a state, of satiety. (M, TA.)
fariva Alqawomu The people, or party, became scattered, or dispersed. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next following paragraph {4}:
and see also the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.

4. Afrv AlkariXa He scattered the contents of the krX [or stomach of a ruminant animal]: (T:) or he ripped the krX, and threw away what was in it: (ISk, Ṣ, O:) or faravotu↓ AlkariXa Eani Alfarovi, aor. _u {yaforuvu}, inf. n. farovN; and OaforavotuhaA, and faravotuhaA↓; I ripped the krX, and scattered what was in it. (M, TA.) Accord. to the Ḳ, one says, Afrv Alkabida, meaning He ripped the kbd [or liver], and threw away the furaAvap, i. e., what was in it: but this is taken from two passages in the M and T, which the author of the Ḳ has confounded. (TA.)

And [hence, app.,] Afrv OaSoHaAbahu † He exposed his companions (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) to the ruling power, (T,) or to the censure of men: (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or he pronounced them to be liars, in the presence of a people, or party, in order to lessen them in their estimation: or he exposed to reproach their secret: (M:) or he calumniated, or slandered, them. (IF, O.) And Afrv Alr-ajula † He reviled, vilified, or vituperated, the man; charged him with a vice, fault, or the like; defamed him; or detracted from his reputation. (M, O.)
See also 1.
5: see the paragraph here following {7}.
7. Anfrvt kariXuhu His (a ruminant animal's) stomach became ripped and its contents became scattered, or dispersed. (M.)
And Anfrvt kabiduhu His liver became scattered by a blow, (ISk, T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) he being alive. (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Ainofaravato said of a pregnant woman; as also tafar-avato↓; (O, Ḳ, but only the inf. ns. are mentioned in the Ḳ;) and farivato↓; (T, A, O, Ḳ, but only the inf. n. is mentioned; in a copy of the T written farav; in the Ḳ, farov, and so in a copy of the A; [accord. to the TḲ, the pret. is faravato, and the aor. taforuvu; but is probably only inferred from the form of the inf. n. in the Ḳ;]) She had a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit. (T, A, O, Ḳ.*) [And] Aunofuriva bihaA She (a woman, in the beginning of her pregnancy,) was affected with a spitting, and with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit. (M.) [See also the last of the following paragraphs.]

hom.sense: farovN The sirojiyn [here meaning feces] (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ) while remaining (Ṣ, O) in the kariX [or stomach of a ruminant animal]; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) the dregs in the krX: (Jel in xvi. 68:) or i. q. siroqiyn [a dial. var. of srjyn]: and the srqyn of the krX; as also furaAvapN↓, (M,) [i. e.] AlfuraAvapu signifies what is extracted from the krX [like Alfarovu: it is erroneously expl. in the Ḳ: see 4]: (O:) the pl. of farovN is furuwvN. (Ṣ, O.)
And Anything that is scattered from a bag or other receptacle for travelling-provisions, &c. (M.)
Also A small [leathern vessel for water, of the kind called] rakowap [q. v.]; (T, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of qarovu: (Ḳ:) or the small rakowap is called Alqarovu [only], with q. (O.)
See also the last of the following paragraphs.

entry.sense: furaAvapu: see the next preceding paragraph.
mafaArivu [a pl. of which the sing. is app. maforavu or maforivN] The places in which [slaughtered] sheep and other animals are ripped [and eviscerated] and skinned. (O.)
mutafar-ivapN: see the following paragraph, in two places.

Uin-ahaA lamunofaravN bihaA, said of a pregnant woman, Verily she is affected with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, (O, Ḳ,* TA,*) by reason of the heaviness of pregnancy: (O:) [or] one says of a woman in the beginning of her pregnancy, Un-ahaA lamutafar-ivapN↓, meaning [Verily] she is affected with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, and the phlegm at the head of her stomach is much in quantity: so says ISk, on the authority of AA: but [Az, after citing this, adds,] I know not whether it be munofarivapN or mutafar-ivapN↓: (T, TA:*) and AimoraOapN farovN↓, (M, TA, [in the former, as given in the TT, the latter word is written frovN, without any vowel-sign to the f,]) it is said, (TA,) means A woman who spits, [or expectorates phlegm,] and has a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, in the beginning of her pregnancy. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faraja bayona AlX-ayoYayoni, aor. _i {yaforiju}, inf. n. farojN, He made an opening, or intervening space, [or a gap, or beach,] between the two things; or he opened the interstice, or interval, between the two things: (Mṣb:) [and faraja AlX-IoCa He opened the thing; and particularly by diduction, or so as to form an intervening space, or a gap, or breach; he unclosed it: and in like manner fr-ij↓, inf. n. taforiyjN; for ex.,] you say, Haluwbatihi far-aja maA bayona rijolaIo [He made an opening, or intervening space, between the hind legs of his milch camel; i. e. he parted her hind legs]; (Ṣ and O and Ḳ in art. fHj, &c.;) and fr-j bayona OaSaAbiEihi He made openings, or intervening spaces, between his fingers. (MA.)
The saying in the Ḳur lxxvii. 9 waUicaA Qls-amaMCu furijato means [And when the sky] shall be opened so that it shall become portals: (Ksh:) or shall become cloven, or split, or rent. (Bḍ and Jel.)
And you say, faraja AlbaAba He opened the door. (A, TA.) And faraja faAhu He opened his mouth to die. (TA.)

And faraja Alqawomu lilr-ajuli, aor. _i {yaforiju}, inf. n. farojN, [and faraja lahu, aor. _u {yaforuju}, inf. n. farojN and furojapN, seems from the context to be mentioned in this sense in the L,] The people, or party, made room, or ample space, for the man, in the place of standing or of sitting. (Mṣb.)

And faraja, aor. _i {yaforiju}, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. farojN; (O, Mṣb;) and fr-j↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taforiyjN; (Ṣ, O;) signify also He (God) removed, cleared away, or dispelled, grief, or sorrow; syn. kaXafahu. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, far-aja↓ Qll-ehu gam-aka and faraja Qll-ehu Eanoka gam-aka [May God remove, or clear away, from thee thy grief, or sorrow; and in like manner, suppressing the objective complement but meaning it to be understood, far-aja↓ Eanoka and faraja Eanoka]. (Ṣ.)
See also 7, in two places.
farija, [aor. _a {yaforaju},] inf. n. farajN, He had his pudendum (faroj) constantly uncovered (Ṣ, TA) when he sat. (TA.)
[And, app., He had buttocks which did not meet, or which scarcely met, by reason of their bigness. (See farijN and Oaforaju.)]
farijato said of a she-camel: see 4.
[Freytag adds, as from the Ṣ, another signification of farija, “Liberatus fuit curis, tristitia, laetatus fuit:” but for this I do not find any authority.]
2. fr-j: see the preceding paragraph {1}, first sentence:
and again {1}, in the latter half, in three places.
Also, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taforiyjN, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, extremely aged, or old and weak. (O, Ḳ.) [From fr-j laHoyayohi, which see expl. voce fak-a.]

4. Afrj Aln-aAsu Eano Tariyqihi The people cleared themselves away from his road, or path; removed out of his way. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*) And AfrjwA Eani Alqatiyli [as also AnfrjwA↓ (occurring thus in the Ṣ and Mṣb and TA in art. jlw)] They cleared themselves away, or removed, from the slain person: (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) implying that it was not known who had killed him. (Mṣb.) And AfrjwA Eani AlmakaAni They left, abandoned, or quitted, the place. (O, Ḳ.)
Afrj AlgubaAru The dust became dispersed. (TA.)
And Afrj signifies also His shooting, or casting, became altered [for the worse], having been good. (TA.)

Afrj Alwaladu Aln-aAqapa The young one caused the she-camel to be in the state in which one says of her farijato↓, i. e. Ainofarajato↓ fiI AlwilaAdapi [app. meaning She became unknit, or loosened, in the joints of the hips in parturition (see explanations of fariyjN as applied to a ewe and to a woman)], when bringing forth for the first time; whereby she was caused to suffer extreme distress: whence faArijN↓ signifies Distressed. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: 5. tfr-j: see 7, in two places.

[It also signifies He diverted, amused, or cheered, himself; or became diverted,, &c.; often followed by EalaI XaIoCK, meaning by viewing a thing, i. e., some rare, or pleasing, object: but thus used, it is app. post-classical. (See also the next paragraph {7}.)]

Ainofarajato siyataAhaA is said of a bow such as is termed faruwjN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) as also Ainofaj-ato [i. e. Anfj-t hiIa, which shows that the meaning is, Its two curved extremities were such as to have an open space between them and between the intermediate portion and the string]. (TA.)
See also 4, second sentence:
and the same, last sentence; and fariyjN, in two places; and faArijN.
[Ainofarajotu Eani AlkalaAmi occurs in the L, in art. fS, app. meaning I broke off from, or intermitted, speaking.]

Anfrj said of grief, or sorrow, or anxiety, [and the like,] signifies It was, or became, removed, cleared away, or dispelled; (A, O, TA;) as also tfr-j↓; (Ṣ,* O,* TA;) and so faraja↓, aor. _u {yaforuju}, inf. n. furuwjN. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
walilX-ar-i baEoda AlqaAriEaAti furuwju↓
meaning [And to evil, after striking and agitating calamities, there is, or shall be,] a removing, clearing away, or dispelling: (Ṣ, O, TA:) the last word being the inf. n. of the last of the verbs above mentioned; or it may be a pl. of farojapN↓, like as SuxuwrN is of SaxorapN. (TA.)
Also He was, or became, happy, or cheerful. (KL. [See also 5.])
farojN: see furojapN.

The space between the hind legs of a horse or mare: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) so in the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
lahaA canabN mivolu cayoli AlEaruwsi
tasud-u bihi farojahaA mino duburN
[She has a tail like the skirt of the bride, with which she fills up the space between her hind legs, from behind]. (Ṣ, O.) And The space between the fore and hind legs of a horse or the like. (L.) [Hence, app.,] one says, malaOa farojahu and furuwjahu, and sd-a furuwjahu [in which phrase mad-a is erroneously put for sad-a in one place in the TA], and jaraI miloCa furuwjihi, meaning † He (a horse) ran swiftly. (TA.) And malaOa furuwja farasihi † He made his horse to run at the utmost rate of the pace termed HuDor. (TA in art. mlO.)

The pudendum, or pudenda; the part, or parts, of the person, which it is indecent to expose; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) applied to the pudenda of men and of women and of youths, with what is around them; and so of horses and the like: (TA:) or the anterior pudendum [i. e. the external portion of the organs of generation] of a man and of a woman, by common consent of the lexicologists; and applied to this and the posterior pudendum [in the conventional language of the law] because both belong to the same [legal] predicament [in certain cases]; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or because each of them is a place of opening; (Mṣb;) or because between the legs: (TA:)
but in common parlance it is mostly applied to the anterior pudendum: (Mṣb:) or peculiarly, accord. to some, the anterior pudendum of a woman [i. e. the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation of a woman: and the vagina]: (MF, TA:) pl. furuwjN. (Mṣb.) fulaAnN Qbonu farojihi means † Such a one is solicitous for his faroj. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnI.)

And i. q. fatoqN [app. as meaning An open, wide, place]: pl. furuwjN: (Mṣb:) which latter also signifies The sides, or lateral parts, quarters, or tracts, of a land. (TA.) And The part between the two sides, i. e. the baTon, of a valley: and hence used in relation to a road, as meaning its entrance: and a faj- [or wide, or depressed, road,] of a mountain. (ISh, TA.)
