And AfrE He began, or commenced, discourse, or a narration; (Ḳ;) and so AstfrE↓; (Sh, O, Ḳ, TA;) and AftrE↓: (Sh, TA:) and likewise, as also AstfrE↓, a thing. (Ḳ.) One says, biYosa maA OaforaEota bihi Very evil is that with which thou hast begun, or commenced: (Ṣ, O:) and niEoma maA OaforaEota [or OaforaEota bihi] Very good is that which [or with which] thou hast begun. (Mṣb.) And AfrE safarahu, and HaAjatahu, He began, commenced, or entered upon, his journey, and his needful affair. (TA.) And AfrEwA mino safarihimo They came, or arrived, from their journey when it was not the proper time for their coming. (TA.)
And AfrEwA They sought after herbage in its place (AinotajaEuwA) among the first, or foremost, of the people. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

AfrE Oaholahu, thus in all the copies of the Ḳ, expl. as meaning kafalahumo, and likewise in the O, is a mistranscription by Ṣgh, whom the author of the Ḳ has here followed: it is correctly, AfrE AlawAdiI Oaholahu i. e. The valley sufficed its people; syn. kafaAhumo. (TA.)
OuforiEa bisay-idi baniI fulaAnK, (O, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) means The chief of the sons of such a one was taken (O, Ḳ, TA) and slain. (TA.)
5. tfr-Et OagoSaAnu AlX-ajari The branches of the trees became abundant. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)
And [hence,] tfr-E AlwaAdiI † [The valley branched forth]. (TA.)
[See also an ex. in a verse cited voce faZiyEN.]

tafar-aEato mino hecaA AlOaSoli masaAYilu (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) ‡ Questions, or problems, or propositions, were derived, or deduced, from this fundamental axiom or principle; (Mṣb;) or were made to be the furuwE [i. e. the branches, meaning derivatives,] thereof; (Ḳ, TA;) [they ramified therefrom;] is a tropical phrase. (TA.)

tafar-aEahumo ‡ He set upon them (O, Ḳ, TA) with reviling and the like; as in the A and L: (TA:) and he was, or became, superior to them, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in eminence, or nobility; and excelled them: (TA: [see also 1:]) or it signifies, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or signifies also, (O,) ‡ he married, or took to wife, the chief of their women, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and the highest of them: (TA:) and tafar-aEotu bibaniI fulaAnK ‡ I married among the noble and high of the sons of such a one; like tacar-ayotuhumo and tanaS-ayotuhumo. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AftrE: see 4, latter half.
Hence, (TA,) He devirginated a maid; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also faraEahaA↓. (Ḳ.)

And hence, AftrE qaSiydapa kacaA ‡ [He broached such an ode], and maEaAniIa kacaA [such meanings]: (Ḥar p. 61:) and yafotariEu OabokaAra AlmaEaAniI ‡ [He broaches virgin meanings]. (TA, and Ḥar ubi suprà.)

hom.sense: 10: see 4, former half, in two places:
and the same again {4}, latter half, in two places.

faroEN The upper, or uppermost, part of anything; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the faroE being what branches forth (yatafar-aEu) from the lower, or lowest, part thereof: (Mṣb:) pl. furuwEN only. (TA.) It is said in a trad. OaI-u AlX-ajari OaboEadu mina AlxaArifi qaAluwA faroEuhaA qaAla wakacelika AlS-af-u AlOaw-alu [What part of trees is furthest from the plucker of the fruit? they said, The uppermost part thereof; he said, And such like is the first row of the persons worshipping in the mosque]. (TA.) Thus faroEu AlOucuni signifies The upper, or uppermost, part of the ear; (Ḳ,* MF, TA;) pl. as above. (TA.) And furuwEu Almuqolatayoni The upper, or uppermost, parts of the two eyeballs. (TA.)
[Hence,] A branch of a tree or plant: (KL, TA:) or the head of a branch: or a great branch: and a branch of anything. (MA.)

[And hence, † A branch, or subdivision, or derivative, of anything that is regarded as a fundamental or a whole;] a thing that is built, or founded, upon another thing; opposed to OaSolN: (Ḳ, TA:) [the pl. furuwEN, as opposed to OuSuwlN meaning “fundamentals,” signifies, in the conventional language of the lawyers and the men of science in general, the derivative institutes of the law,, &c.: see 2:] Eilomu AlfuruwEi [the science of the derivative institutes of the law] is what is commonly known by the appellation of Eilomu Alfiqohi [the science of jurisprudence; because it is mainly concerned with institutes derived from fundamentals]. (Ḥájjee Khaleefeh.)

And ‡ The hair of a woman: pl. as above [app. used in a collective sense like the French “cheveux”]: (Ḳ, TA:) one says AimoraOapN Tawiylapu AlfuruwEi [meaning ‡ A long-haired woman]. (TA.) And (Ḳ) ‡ Full [or abundant] hair. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)

And ‡ The noble, or man of eminence, of a people or party: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) one says, huwa faroEu qawomihi ‡ He is the noble, or man of eminence, of his people or party, (Ṣ, O, TA,*) and mino furuwEihim of their nobles,, &c. (TA.)

And [app. from the same word as signifying “a branch of a tree,”] † A valley branching off. (TA.) And † A channel in which water runs to the XiEob (Ḳ, TA) i. e. the waAdiI [here meaning the water-course in a low tract or between the two acclivities of two mountains]: (TA:) [but] in this sense its pl. is firaAEN. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also [or qawosN faroEN] A bow that is made from the extreme portion of a branch, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) from the head thereof: (Aṣ, TA:) and (Ḳ) a bow that is not [made from a branch] divided lengthwise (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) is called qawosN faroEN; (Ṣ, O, TA;) such as is [made from a branch] divided lengthwise being called qawosN filoqN: (Ṣ, O:) or the faroE is [one] of the best of bows: (AḤn, Ḳ, TA:) and [this word is used as an epithet, i. e.] one says qawosN faroEN and faroEapN. (Ḳ.)

Also, i. e. faroEN, Property that is beneficial, or serviceable, and made ready, or prepared: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to the Ṣ, it is faraEN↓ which has this signification; but this is said by Ṣgh [app. in the TṢ], and after him by the author of the Ḳ, to be a mistake; and a verse in which it occurs with the r quiescent is cited in the O and Ḳ as an ex. of it in this sense: it may be, however, that the poet has made the r quiescent of necessity [by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]; or it may here [properly] signify “a branch,” and be metonymically used as meaning recent property. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, latter half.

faraEN The firstling of the camel, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of the sheep or goat, (L, Ḳ,) which they used to sacrifice to their gods, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) looking for a blessing thereby; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and faraEapN↓ signifies the same: (Mgh, Mṣb:) hence, (Mgh, O, Ḳ,) it is said in a trad., [implying the prohibition of this custom,] laA faraEa walaA EatiyrapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) or laA faraEapa↓ walaA Eatiyrapa: (Mgh: [see EatiyrapN:]) or when the camels amounted to the number for which their owner wished, they sacrificed [a firstling]: (TA:) or when one's camels amounted to a complete hundred, (Ḳ, TA,) he sacrificed a he-camel thereof every year, and gave it to the people to eat, neither he nor his family tasting it, or rather, it is said, (TA,) he sacrificed a young, or youthful, he-camel to his idol: and the Muslims used to do it in the first part of El-Islám: then it was abrogated: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to the Bári' and the Mj, the firstling of camels and also that of sheep or goats are thus called: (Mṣb:)
the pl. [of faraEN] is furuEN, with two dammehs. (Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., Oaw-alu AlS-ayodi faraEN [The first of what are taken by the chase or the like is a frE] as being likened to a firstling: so says Yezeed Ibn-Murrah. (TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 35.])

The poet Ows Ibn-Hajar, (Ṣ, O,) or Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim, has used it as meaning The skin of a faraE; (Ṣ, O;*) suppressing the prefix jilod: (Ṣ:) for they used to clothe with its skin another young one of a camel, in order that the mother of the one sacrificed might incline to it [and yield her milk]. (O; and the like is said in the TA.)
Also, and faroEN↓, Lice: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, small lice: (TA:) and one thereof is termed faraEapN↓ and faroEapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, frEp signifies a large louse. (TA.)

And the former (faraEN), Food that is prepared [app. for persons invited to partake of it] on the occasion of camels' bringing forth; like as xurosN signifies such as is on the occasion of a woman's bringing forth. (TA.)
And A portion, or share; syn. qisomN: (O, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to some, peculiarly of water. (TA.)
See also faroEN, last quarter.
It is also the inf. n. of fariEa. (TA. [See 1, last sentence.])

faroEapN A high, or an elevated, place of a mountain: pl. firaAEN: so in the saying, Aiyoti faroEapF mino firaAEi Aljabali faQnozilohaA [Come thou to one of the high places of the mountain and descend it]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, it signifies particularly the head of a mountain. (TA. [See also faAriEapN.])
And faroEapu Aljul-api The highest, or uppermost, of the dates of the [receptacle called] jul-ap [q. v.]. (TA.)

And frEp AlTryq [i. e. faroEapu AlT-ariyqi] and frEth [sic, app. faraEatuhu↓,] and faroEaAWuhu↓ and faAriEatuhu↓ all signify The highest part of the road, and the place where it ends: or the conspicuous and elevated part thereof: or faAriEatuhu↓ signifies the sides, or borders, thereof. (TA. [See also qaAriEapu AlT-ariyqi.])
And one says, Oatayotuhu fiI faroEapK mina Aln-ahaAri ‡ I came to him in a first part of the day. (TA.)
See also faraEN, latter half.

entry.sense: furoEapN The blood of the virgin on the occasion of devirgination.

hom.sense: faraEapN: see faroEapN.
[Also] A piece of skin that is added in the qirobap [or water-skin] when the latter is not full-sized, or complete. (O, Ḳ.)
See also faraEN, first quarter, in two places:
and the same again, latter half, in one place.
It is also a pl. of faAriEN [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
furuwEu AljawozaMCi means The most intense degree of heat: (Ṣ, O, TA:) [or rather AlfuruwEu is a name of a certain asterism of AljawozaMCu (which is an appel-lation of Orion and of Gemini, either whereof may be here appropriately meant,) at the season of the auroral rising of which the heat becomes most intense:] Aboo-Khirásh says,
waZal-a lahaA yawomN kaOan-a OuwaArahu
cakaA Aln-aAri mino najomi AlfuruwEi Tawiylu
[And a day continued to them, the heat whereof was as though it were the blazing of fire, from the asterism of the furuwEi; a long day]: (Ṣ,* O, TA:) in the Ṣ, waZal-a lanaA; but correctly lahaA, meaning to the she-asses: (TA:) and Aboo-Saʼeed related it as above with the unpointed E in AlfrwE: (Ṣ,* TA:) in the same manner, also, it is expl. by him as used in the phrase fayoHu najomi AlfuruwEi [which I would render the vehement raging of the heat of the asterism of the frwE] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh: El-Jumahee related it differently, with g; but the furuwg [or rather the farogaAni] are of the stars of Aquarius; and the season thereof [i. e. of their auroral rising] is cold; there is then no fyH. (TA.)

furayoEN, occurring [with tenween, perfectly decl.,] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, (O, Ḳ,) i. q. firoEawonu↓, (O,) which is a proper name of such as was King of the Amalekites [or rather of the ancient Egyptians, in general], like as qayoSar was of the Room [or Greeks of the Lower Empire], and kisoraI of the Persians, (Ksh in ii. 46,) [and also] a foreign word, (Mṣb,) [wherefore it is imperfectly decl., in Hebr. פַּרְעֹה, i. e. Pharaoh,] a dial. var. of firoEawonu, or used by poetic license: (Ḳ:) the pl. of the latter is faraAEinapN. (Mṣb.)
firoEawonu: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: faAriEN [Overtopping, or surpassing in height or tallness: this seems to be the primary signification]. You say jabalN faAriEN A mountain higher, or taller, than what is next to it. (Ṣ, O.)
And High, or tall; applied to a man, and to an extended gibbous piece of sand. (TA.)

And High, or elevated; goodly in form or aspect or appearance; beautiful: (Aboo-ʼAdnán, O, Ḳ:) or [simply] high [app. in rank or dignity]: (IAạr, O:) and also low, ignoble, or mean: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) thus having two contr. significations. (O, Ḳ.)
And a man of the Arabs said, laqiytu fulaAnFA faAriEFA muforiEFA↓, meaning [I met such a one] one of us ascending and the other descending. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
Also sing. of faraEapN, which signifies The armed attendants, or guards, of the Sultán, or sovereign: (O, Ḳ, TA:) it is like waAziEN. (TA.)

entry.sense: faAriEapN The higher, or highest, part of a mountain [and of a valley]: one says, Ainozilo bifaAriEapi AlwaAdiI waQHocaro Oasofalahu [Alight thou in the higher, or highest, part of the valley, and beware of its lower, or lowest, part]. (Ṣ, O.) See also faroEapN, in two places.

AlfaAriEapu mina AlganaAYimi means The surplus that is deducted [so I render AlmurotafiEapu AlS-aAEidapu, app. such things as cannot be divided and are therefore removed,] from the main stock of the spoils before they are divided into fifths. (TA.)

And fawaAriEN, ( pl. of faAriEapN, TA,) applied to tilaAE, [a word variously explained, here, I think, used as signifying either high, or low, grounds, (see its sing. taloEapN,)] (Ṣ, O,* Ḳ,*) means Of which the channels wherein the torrents flow are in high, or elevated, parts. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
fayofaroEN (Ḳ, TA) and fayofaraEN (TA) A species of trees. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: OaforaEu Free from deficiency in the hair [of the head]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) contr. of OaSolaEu; (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) used only in this sense; not applied to a man who is large in the beard or in the whole head of hair: (IDrd, Ṣ, O:) the Prophet was OaforaE, (Ṣ, O,) and so was Aboo-Bekr, (O, Ḳ,) and ʼOmar was OaSolaE: (O:) fem. faroEaMCu; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) accord. to IDrd, applied to a woman as meaning having much hair: (Ṣ, O:) pl. furoEaAnN, (O, Ḳ,) like its contr. SuloEaAnN; (O;) and also furoEN. (Ḳ.) ʼOmar, being asked, “Are the SuloEaAn better or the furoEaAn,” said “The frEAn are better,” meaning to assert the superior excellence of Aboo-Bekr over himself. (O.)
faroEaMCu AlT-ariyqi: see faroEapN.

Also i. q. muwasowisu [app. as meaning Such as is subject to diabolical promptings or suggestions]: so in the trad., laA yaWum-an-akumu AlOaforaEu [The AfrE shall by no means act as your Imám]. (Nh, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: muforaEN Anything tall. (TA.)
muforaEu Alkatifi A man broad in the shoulder-blade: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or high therein. (TA.) And katifN muforaEapN A shoulder-blade high, projecting, and broad. (TA.)
muforiEN: see faAriEN, last sentence but one.
miforaEN One who interposes as a restrainer between persons [at variance], (O, Ḳ, TA,) and makes peace, or effects a reconciliation, between them: (TA:) pl. mafaAriEu. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Q. 2. tafaroEana He (a man, TA) affected the nature, or disposition, of the faraAEinap [pl. of firoEawonu, and here meaning such as are inordinately proud or corrupt or unbelieving,, &c., as were the Pharaohs]. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)
faroEanapN Cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and pride, haughtiness, or insolence. (TA.)

firoEawonu [Pharaoh;] the surname of El-Weleed Ibn-Mus'ab, king of Egypt: (Ṣ:) or the surname of every king of Egypt: (Ḳ:) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (Ṣ,) [app. used as a proper name,] anyone inordinately proud or corrupt or unbelieving; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) insolent and audacious in acts of rebellion or disobedience, or extravagant therein and in wrongdoing:
as also furoEuwnu and furoEawonu; (Ḳ;) the last mentioned by IKh, from Fr, and anomalous: (TA:) pl. faraAEinipN. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) It is said in a trad., OaHadunaA firoEawonu hecihi AlOum-api [app. meaning One of us is the Pharaoh of this people, or nation]. (Ṣ: in one of my copies of the Ṣ, OaxaconaA and firoEawona.)
And [it is said that] AlfiroEawonu signifies The crocodile, (Ḳ, TA,) in the language of the Copts. (TA.)
Ald-uruwEu AlfiroEawoniy-ipu Certain coats of mail so called in relation to the firoEawon [or Pharaoh] of Moses. (Sh, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faraga, [aor. _u {yaforugu}; and app. fariga, aor. _a {yaforagu} and _u {yaforugu}, as below; inf. n. furuwgN and faraAgN; or, accord. to some, the latter is a simple subst., but it is more commonly used than the former;] said of a thing, It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xalaA. (Mṣb.) [You say, faraga mino kacaA It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, or destitute, of such a thing; or unoccupied thereby.] And faraga laka AlX-aIoCu [The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee; as though it were a place, or a vessel: and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA voce xalaA.)
[Hence,] faraga (O,* Ḳ,* TA) said of a man, (TA,) [and app. fariga also, as below,] inf. n. furuwgN, ‡ He died; (O, Ḳ, TA;) because his body became devoid of his soul, or spirit. (TA.)

And faraga mina AlX-ugoli, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yaforugu}, inf. n. furuwgN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [more commonly] faraAgN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and farag, aor. _a {yaforagu}, (O, Ḳ,) mentioned by Yoo; (O;) and fariga, aor. _a {yaforagu}, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Temeem; (Mṣb;) and fariga, aor. _u {yaforugu}, a compound of two dial. vars.; (O, Mṣb;) He was, or became, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See also 5.]
[And hence, faraga mina AlOamori He ceased from, ended, or finished, the affair.]

And faraga lahu and Uilayohi, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaforugu} and _a {yaforagu}; (TA;) and fariga, (O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _a {yaforagu}; inf. n. furuwgN and [more commonly] faraAgN; (TA;) He made him, or it, his object, or the object to which he directed himself; syn. qaSada: (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) [or he made him, or it, his exclusive object; agreeably with an explanation of the phrase here following]: whence, in the Ḳur [lv. 31], lakumo sanaforugu We will make you our object; expl. by IAạr as meaning sanaEomidu [which is syn. with sanaqoSidu]; (TA;) and some read sanaforagu; (O, TA;) and some, saniforagu; (O;) and some, saniforigu, asserting that Temeem say niEolimu; (O, TA;) and some, sanaforagu Uilayokumo, meaning sanaqoSidu Uilayokumo; or sanaforugu lakumo means We will apply ourself exclusively (sanatajar-adu) to the reckoning with, and the requiting of, you; and it is said to be a threat; (Bḍ;) a metaphorical phrase, from a man's saying to him whom he threatens, saOaforugu laka, (Ksh, Bḍ,) meaning I will apply myself exclusively to the making an assault upon thee: (Ksh:) one says [also] in threatening, laOaforugan-a laka [meaning in like manner I will assuredly apply myself, &c.]. (TA.) [See, again, 5.]
fariga AlmaMCu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaforagu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. faraAgN, (Ṣ, TA,) The water poured out or forth, or became poured out or forth. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
faruga, [aor. _u {yaforugu},] inf. n. faraAgapN, ‡ He (a horse) was easy, or good, and quick, in pace, and wide in step. (TA.)
farugati AlD-arobapu ‡ The [wound made by a] stroke, or blow, was wide; (O, Ḳ, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket. (TA.)
And faraAgapN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faruga, TḲ) signifies The being impatient, and disquieted or disturbed or agitated. (O, Ḳ.)
faraga as trans.: see 4.

entry.sense: 2. far-agotuhu I made it empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; as also Oaforagotuhu↓. (Mṣb.) taforiygu AlZ-uruwfi signifies The making the receptacles empty. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And some read [in the Ḳur xxxiv. 22], Hat-aI UicaA fur-iga Eano quluwbihimo, (O, TA,) expl. as meaning Until, when their hearts shall be made void of fear, or fright: or, accord. to IJ, fur-iga and fuz-iEa and QforanoqaEa [which are all mentioned as readings in the same passage] have one meaning. (TA. [See 2 in art. fzE.])

[Hence one says, fr-ghu likacaA He made him to be, or become, or he left him, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; or made him to be unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; so that he might apply himself exclusively to such a thing.]
See also the next paragraph {4}.
4: see 2, first sentence.

Afrghu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiforaAgN and muforagN, (O,) signifies [also] He poured it out, or forth; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) namely, water [&c.]; (Ṣ;) as also fr-ghu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taforiygN; (Ṣ, O;) and Afrg likewise signifies he poured forth blood; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and faraga↓ Ealayohi AlmaMCa, meaning he poured out, or forth, upon him, the water, is mentioned by Th, who has cited as an ex.,
faragona AlhawaI fiI Alqalobi vum-a saqayonahu
SubaAbaAti maMCi AlHuzoni biAlOaEoyuni Aln-ujoli
[They (referring to women) poured desirous love into the heart; then they gave him to drink the remains of the water of grief, by looking with the wide eyes: but perhaps faragona is here used for far-agona, by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]: (TA:) UiforaAgapN signifies A single act of UiforaAg; and hence the trad. kaAna yuforigu EalaI raOosihi valaAva UiforaAgaAtK [He used to pour upon his head three pourings]. (TA.)

[Hence,] rab-anaA Oaforigo EalayonaA SaborFA, in the Ḳur [ii. 251 and vii. 123], means ‡ O our Lord, pour forth upon us patience, like as [the water of] the leathern bucket is poured forth: (O, TA:) or send down upon us patience (Mṣb,* TA) that shall envelop us: (TA:) or Oaforaga Qll-ehu Ealayohi AlS-abora means † God inspired him with patience. (Mṣb in art. rbT.)

[Hence, also,] Oaforaga Ealayohi canuwbFA [lit. He poured forth upon him a bucketful of water] means ‡ he talked with him of that in consequence of which he was confounded, or perplexed, by shame. (TA.)

Afrg also signifies He poured metal, such as gold and silver, &c., in a molten state, into a mould. (TA.) And He cast a thing, i. e. formed it by pouring molten metal into a mould. (Mṣb. [See its pass. part. n., muforagN.])
And Afrg Einoda AljimaAEi He poured forth his maMC [or sperma] on the occasion of jmAE. (TA.)

5. tfr-g He was, or became, or he made himself to be, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; syn. taxal-aI mina AlX-ugoli. (O, Ḳ.) [See also faraga mina AlX-ugoli.] Hence the trad. of the Prophet, tafar-aguwA mino humuwmi Ald-unoyaA maA QsotaTaEotumo [Be ye, or make yourselves to be, vacant, or free, from the anxieties of the present state of existence as much as ye are able]. (O.)

And tafar-agotu likacaA [I was, or became, or I made myself to be, vacant, or free, from business, occupation, or employment; or unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; for such a thing: and I applied myself exclusively to such a thing]: (Ṣ: [these meanings are there indicated, but not expressed; and are well known:]) one says, tfr-g liloEibaAdapi [He applied himself exclusively to religious service]: (Mṣb in art. btl:) and tafar-agotu liloOamori means [also, simply,] taSad-ayotu lahu [i. e. I addressed, or applied, or directed, myself, or my regard, or attention, or mind, to the affair]. (Mṣb in art. Sd.) [See also faraga lahu and Uilayohi.]
And tfr-g bihi signifies taxal-aI bihi [meaning He confined himself exclusively to it; or contented himself with it exclusively of other things]. (Ḳ and TA in art. xlw.)

8. Aifotaragotu I poured forth upon myself (Ṣ, O) water: (Ṣ:) [and so Aftrgt EalaI nafosiI; for one says,] raOayotuhu yagotarifu AlmaMCa vum-a yafotariguhu EalaI nafosihi [I saw him taking, or lading out, the water; then pouring it forth upon himself]. (A, TA.) And Aifotaragotu linafosiI maMCF I poured out for myself water. (O, Ḳ.)

10. Astfrgi [He drew forth water, &c.]. One says, Astfrg maA fiI Alr-aAwiyapi mina AlmaMCi [He drew forth what was in the leathern water-bag, or pair of leathern water-bags, of water]. (TA in art. Ezl.) El-Akhtal said respecting Esh-Shaabee, meaning to denote the largeness of the latter's retentive faculty, OanaA Oasotaforigu mino UinaMCK waAHidK wahuwa yasotaforigu mino OawaAniIa Xat-aI ‡ [I draw from one vessel, and he draws from divers vessels]. (TA.)
Also He vomited intentionally; or constrained himself to vomit: (O, Ḳ:) thus it signifies in the conventional language of the physicians. (O.)
Aisotaforaga fulaAnN maA fiI SaHofatihi is a prov., meaning Such a one [exhausted, or] chose for himself, as his share, [the whole of] what was in his SHfp [or large bowl]. (TA in art. SHf.)
And one says, Astfrg fulaAnN majohuwdahu ‡ Such a one exhausted his power, or ability; or exerted it unsparingly, or to the utmost; (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) fiI kacaA [in such a thing]. (Ṣ, TA.)
farogN Width, breadth, or ampleness. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

And The place whence the water pours forth, between the cross-pieces of wood (AlEaraAqiI), of the leathern-bucket; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also firaAgN↓: (Ḳ: [expl. in the O as signifying the side of the leathern bucket from which the water pours forth:]) pl. of the former furuwgN (TA) and mafaArigu, [which is anomalous, like maXaAbihu and maHaAsinu, &c.,] (A, TA,) or this is pl. of maforagN↓. (TA.)

Hence AlfarogaAni, (Ṣ, O,) farogu Ald-alowi Almuqad-amu and farogu Ald-alowi AlmuWax-aru, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or Alfarogu AlOaw-alu and Alfarogu Alv-aAniI, (Ḳzw,) Two of the Mansions of the Moon, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) the Twenty-sixth Mansion and the Twentyseventh; four stars, wide apart, forming the corners of a square, or four-sided figure; (Ḳzw;) each consisting of two stars, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, and Ḳzw,) of two bright stars, (Ṣ,) the apparent distance between each two stars being the measure of five cubits, (Ṣ, O, L,) or the measure of a spear; (Ḳ;) [see ciraAEN and rumoHN; the former pair consists of the stars a and b of Pegasus; and the latter, of g in Pegasus together with the bright star in the head of Andromeda; as is shown by what here follows:] the Arabs name Ald-alowu the four bright stars in Pegasus which form a square, or four-sided figure; i. e., that at the extremity of the neck, which is called matonu Alfarasi, and that which is called manokibu Alfarasi, and that which is called janaAHu Alfarasi, and the star that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda: (Ḳzw, descr. of Pegasus:) [these two pairs of stars are what are commonly known as the farogaAni; and are plainly indicated by the periods assigned to the auroral settings thereof: but the periods assigned to their auroral risings would lead us to apply the appel-lation of the frgAn to some other stars, not easily determinable, in Aquarius: see nawoCN: and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The pl. Alfuruwgu is said to be applied to The farogaAni with the stars around them: (O, TA:) and (accord. to El-Jumahee, O, TA) Alfuruwgu [in the CK erroneously written Alfaruwgu] signifies [The constellation called] AljawozaMCu. (O, Ḳ, TA. [But see furuwEu AljawozaMCi, in art. frE.])
farogN also signifies A vessel in which is [the exuded, or expressed, juice termed] dibos, (O, Ḳ,) and Saqor. (O.)
Also Land affected with drought, or barrenness. (IB, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
firogN: see faArigN.

cahaba damuhu firogFA and farogFA↓ mean His blood went for nothing, as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and retaliation for it was not sought: (Ṣ, O:) and in like manner one says, cahabato dimaAWuhumo firgFA [Their bloods went for nothing,, &c.]. (Z, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur xxviii. 9, accord. to one reading, waOaSobaHa fuWaAdu Oum-i muwsaI firogFA (Ksh and Bḍ) i. e. And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became [as though it were] a thing that was lost, or that had gone away. (Ksh. [See faArigN.])
farigN: see faArigN, first quarter.

furugN i. q. mufar-agN [Made empty, vacant, void,, &c.]: (O, TA:) so in the phrase UinaMCN furugN [An emptied vessel]: (TA:) and so in the saying [in the Ḳur xxviii. 9], accord. to the reading of Kh, waOaSobaHa fuWaAdu Oum-i muwsaI furugFA [And the heart of the mother of Moses became rendered void of patience, or of anxiety, &c.: see faArigN]. (O, TA.)
Applied to a bow, as also firaAgN↓, it means Without a string: or, as some say, without an arrow. (TA.)
farogaAn [whether with or without tenween is not shown] A wide, or capacious, vessel. (TA.)
faraAgN [generally mentioned as an inf. n., and much used as such; but accord. to the Mṣb, a simple subst.: as a simple subst., it means Emptiness, vacancy, or vacuity,, &c.:]
[and vacancy, or freedom, from business, &c.; or contr. of XugolN, as is said in the Ḳ, in art. Xgl: and cessation from an affair:]
[bayotu AlfaraAgi means The privy.]

hom.sense: firaAgN A great bowl, that cannot be carried: pl. OaforigapN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
A wide, or capacious, large, watering-trough, of hides. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.)
A vessel (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ) of any kind. (IAạr, T, O.)
An udder. (O.)
The half of a load, such as is on either of the two sides of a camel: (AA, O, Ḳ:) so in the dial. of Teiyi. (AA, O.)
See also farogN, second sentence.
[As a pl.,] Valleys, or torrent-beds: from IAạr, who has not mentioned a sing. thereof, nor the derivation. (TA.)
And [probably as pl. of fariygN↓, agreeably with analogy,] Broad niSaAl [or arrow-heads; the word nSAl being app. understood]. (O, Ḳ.)
[As a sing. epithet,] A she-camel having no brand, or mark made with a hot iron. (TA.)
Also A she-camel having much milk, ample in the integument of the udder. (AZ, O, L, Ḳ.)
And A bow of which the arrowhead makes a wide wound: or of which the arrow goes far. (O, Ḳ.)
See also furugN.
And see the next paragraph, in two places.

fariygN Broad, or wide. (TA.) See firaAgN. [Hence,] DarobapN fariygN (Ṣ) or fariygapN (O, Ḳ) ‡ A wide [wound made by a] stroke, or blow; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket: (TA:) and TaEonapN farogaMCu↓, likewise, signifies ‡ a wide [wound made by a] piercing [with a spear, &c.], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) of which the blood flows. (TA.)
And fariygapN ‡ A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] that takes in much water; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as though having farog, i. e. width. (TA.)

And friygN signifies also ‡ Land, or ground, that is even, or flat, as though it were a road, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and wide: (TA:) or that is marked by much treading: to such Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee likens the whiteness of the Oavor, i. e. firinod, of a sword. (O, TA.)
Also Sharp, applied to an arrow, and likewise to a knife. (TA.) And † Sharp-tongued, applied to a man. (TA.)

entry.sense: furaAgapN The sperma of a man. (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ.)

faArigN Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xaAlK; as in the phrase UinaMCN fArigN [an empty vessel]: (O, TA:) and likewise applied to a man, (O, TA,*) meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also farigN↓: (O, Ḳ, TA:) [and often, used elliptically, meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, &c., and care or anxiety or disquietude; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure:] and Oaforagu↓ is syn. with faArigN; (O, Ḳ;) as in the phrase, of Ru-beh, maA AlmaXoguwlu mivolu AlOaforagi [The busied is not like the free from business]: (O, TA:) [fur-aAgN is pl. of faArigN: and] firogN↓ is syn. with fur-aAgN; (O, Ḳ; [in the former, as is often the case, the sign of teshdeed in this word has been carelessly omitted; and in the CK, Alfragu is put for Alfur-aAgu, and has been erroneously supposed to be for AlfaraAgu;]) for ex., Tuleyhah Ibn-Khuweylid El-Asadee says, in relation to the slaying of his brother's son, Hibál Ibn-Selemeh Ibn-Khuweylid,
famaA Zan-ukumo biAlqawomi Uico taqotuluwnahumo
OalayosuwA waUino lamo yusolimuwA birijaAli
faUino taku OacowaAdN OuSibona wanisowapN
falano tacohabuwA firogFA biqatoli HibaAli
[And what is your opinion of the party when ye slay them? Are they not (though they have not become Muslims) men? And if some small numbers of camels have been smitten (and carried off). and some women, ye will not go away free from care by reason of the slaying of Hibál]. (O, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxviii. 9], waOaSobaHa fWaAdu Oum-i muwsaI faArigFA, meaning And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became devoid of patience: or devoid of everything except remembering of Moses: or devoid of anxiety; because of God's having promised to restore him to her, (O, TA,) by words in the next but one of the preceding verses. (O.) [See also another reading voce firogN; and another, voce furugN.]
And it is said in a form of prayer, Aall-ehum-a Uin-iI OasoOaluka AlEayoXi Alr-aAfigi waAlmaAla AlfaAriga [O God, I ask of Thee ample, or abundant, and pleasant, or good, means of subsistence, and cattle free from labour]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN faArigN maXoguwlN, meaning † Such a one is devoted to that which is unprofitable. (TA in art. Xgl.) And hecaA kalaAmN faArigN ‡ [This is empty talk or language]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Oaforagu [More, and most, empty, &c.: and more, and most, free from business, &c.]. Oaforagu mino fuWaAdi Oum-i muwsaI [More void than the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses] is a prov. (Meyd. [See faArigN, latter half.]) See also another prov., voce Haj-aAmN.
Also i. q. faArigN, q. v.: (O, Ḳ:) fem. farogaMCu: see fariygN.
maforagN A place of pouring out or forth: (O, TA:) and [particularly] the part of the leathern bucket that is next to the fore part of the wateringtrough. (TA.) See farogN, second sentence.
Also i. q. sylAn [app. sayalaAnN i. e. The flowing of water, &c.; as an inf. n. of fariga said of water]. (TA.)

dirohamN muforagN A dirhem [cast, i. e.] poured into a mould; not maDoruwb [coined or minted]. (TA.) And HaloqapN muforagapN A ring that is solid (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) in the sides [that compose the round], (Ṣ, O,) and [continuous,] not cut. (TA.) One says, humo kaQloHaloqapi Almuforagapi laA yudoraI Oayona TarafaAhaA [They are like the solid and continuous ring, of which it is not known where are the two ends]: (A, TA:) a prov., applied to a company of men united in words and action. (TA in art. Hlq.)
muforagN is also an inf. n. of Oaforagahu [q. v.]. (O.)

entry.sense: musotaforigapN A she-camel having much milk. (O, Ḳ. [See also firaAgN.])
And musotaforigN ‡ A horse that does not reserve aught of his run [i. e. of his power of running, for the time of need; that exhausts his power thereof]. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

farofaxN (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and farofaxapN↓, (L,) [the former app. a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un., Purslane, or garden purslane;] the herb called Albaqolapu AlHamoqaMCu, (Ṣ, A, L,) which does not grow in Nejd, (L,) also called farofiynN, (Ṣ, A,) i. q. rijolapN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) an arabicized word, from the Pers. ParoPahon, which signifies “broad-winged.” (AḤn, L, Ḳ.)
Also, the former, The kaEaAbir [which are things that are taken forth, or picked out, and thrown away, in the clearing] of wheat. (Ḳ.)
farofaxapN: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. faraqa bayona AlX-ayoYayoni, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yaforuqu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) and in one dial. _i, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. farogN and furoqaAnN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of which has a more intensive signification, (TA,) He made a separation, or a distinction, or difference, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) between the two things, (Ḳ,* TA,) or between the parts of the two things: (Mṣb:) relating alike to objects of sight and to objects of mental perception: (TA:) IAạr, by exs. that he mentions, makes it to relate particularly to objects of the mind, such as sayings; and fr-q↓, to persons, or material things: (Mṣb: [and it is stated in the Mgh that the same distinction is mentioned by Az:]) others, however, state that the two verbs are syn.; but that the latter has an intensive signification. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [v. 28], faQforuqo bayonanaA wabayona Qloqawomi AlfaAsiqiyna [Therefore decide Thou, or make Thou a distinction, between us and the unrighteous people]: accord. to one reading, faQforiqo. (Mṣb, TA.) fiyhaA yuforaqu kul-u OamorK HakiymK, in the Ḳur [xliv. 3], means [Wherein] is made distinct [every firm decree]: (Lth, TA:) or is decided; (O, Ḳ, TA;) thus expl. by Ḳatádeh. (O, TA.) And in the phrase waqurMnFA faraqonaAhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) in the same [xvii. 107], (Ṣ, O, TA,) by faraqonaAhu is meant We have made it distinct, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and rendered it free from defect, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and explained the ordinances therein: (TA:) but some read far-aqonaAhu↓, meaning We have sent it down in sundry portions, in a number of days. (Ṣ, TA.) waUico faraqonaA bikumu QlobaHora, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in the Ḳur [ii. 47], (O, TA,) means And when we clave because of you the sea; i. q. falaqonaAhu: (O, Ḳ, TA:) another reading, far-aqonaA↓, meaning we divided into several portions, is mentioned by IJ; but this is unusual. (TA.) It is also said that Alfaroqu is for rectification; and Alt-aforiyqu↓, for vitiation: and IJ says that Uin-a Ql-aciyna far-aquwA↓ diyonahumo, in the Ḳur [vi. 160, and the like occurs in xxx. 31], means Verily those who have divided their religion into sundry parts, and dismembered it, and have disagreed respecting it among themselves: but that some read faraquwA diyonahumo, without teshdeed, meaning, have severed their religion from the other religions [app. by taking it in part, or parts, therefrom]; or this, he says, may mean the same as the former reading, for sometimes faEala has the same meaning as faE-ala. (TA.) IJ also says that faraqa lahu Eani AlX-aIoCi signifies He made the thing distinct, or plain, to him. (TA.)

faraqa AlX-aEora biAlmuXoTi, aor. _u {yaforuqu} and _i {yaforiqu}, inf. n. faroqN, He separated his hair with the comb: and far-aqa↓ raOosahu biAlmuXoTi, inf. n. taforiyqN, He separated the hair of his head with the comb. (TA.) [And it is implied in a trad. cited in the O and TA that faraqahu signifies the same as the latter of the two phrases in the next preceding sentence.]

faraqa lahu AlT-ariyqu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. furuwqN, (Ḳ,) The road presented itself to him divided into two roads: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or [it means] an affair presented itself, or occurred, to him, and he knew the mode, or manner, thereof: (TA, as from the Ḳ: [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:]) and hence, in a trad. of I’Ab, faraqa liI raOoIN An idea, or opinion, appeared [or occurred] to me: (TA:) [or] one says, faraqa liI hecaA AlOamoru, inf. n. furuwqN, This affair became, or has become, distinct, apparent, or manifest, to me: and hence the saying, faUino lamo yuforuqo liloUimaAmi raOoIN [And if an idea, or an opinion, appear not, or occur not, to the Imám]. (Mgh.)
faraqato said of a she-camel, and of a she-ass, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaforuqu}, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. furuwqN, She, being taken with the pains of parturition, went away at random in the land. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
faraqa, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaforuqu}, (Ḳ,) He voided dung; syn. caraqa [which is said of a bird, and sometimes of a man]. (O, Ḳ. [See also Oaforaqa.])
And He possessed a firoq [q. v.] (O, Ḳ, TA) of sheep or goats: (O, TA:) accord. to the Ḳ, of date-stones with which to feed camels: but the former explanation is the right. (TA.)
faraqahaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. faroqN, (TA,) He fed her (i. e. a woman) with fariyqap [q. v.]; as also AfrqhA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiforaAqN. (TA.)
faAraqaniI↓ fafaraqotuhu, aor. _u {yaforuqu}, [He vied with me in fear and] I exceeded him in fear. (Lḥ, L, TA.)
See also 2, last sentence.

fariqa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaforaqu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. faraqN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, or frightened. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, fariqotu minoka [I feared thee, or was in fear of thee]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:*) but you should not say, fariqotuka: (Ṣ, O:) Sb [however] mentions fariqahu, suppressing mino. (TA.) And you say also, fariqa Ealayohi [He feared for him]. (TA.)
And fariqa, aor. _a {yaforaqu}, He entered into a wave, [which is termed firoqN,] and dived therein. (Ḳ.)
And the same verb accord. to the Ḳ, but accord. to Ṣgh [in the O] it seems, from the context to be faraqa, (TA,) He drank (O, Ḳ) the measure called faraq, (O,) or with the faraq. (Ḳ, TA.)

2. fr-qhu, inf. n. taforiyqN and taforiqapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He separated it [into several, or many, portions]; disunited it [i. e. a thing, or a collection of things]; or dispersed, or dissipated, it; or did so much [or greatly or widely]; syn. bad-adahu. (Ḳ.) And fr-q bayona AlOaXoyaMCi [He made, or caused, a separation, &c., or much, or a wide, separation,, &c., between the things]. (Mgh.) [And fiyhimo fr-qhu and Ealayohimo He scattered, or distributed, it among them, and to them.] See 1, former half, in five places. It is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, far-iquwA Eani Almaniy-api waQjoEaluwA Alr-aOosa raOosayoni, (Mgh, O,*) meaning Separate ye your cattle by way of preservation from death, [and make the one head two head,] by buying two animals with the price of one, that, when one dies, the second may remain. (Mgh, O.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the poor-rate, laA yufar-aqu bayona mujotamiEK walaA yujomaEu bayona mufotariqK There shall be no separating what is put together, nor shall there be a putting together what is separate. (TA. [The reason is, that by either of these acts, in the case of cattle, the amount of the poor-rate may be diminished.])
yufar-iquwna bihi bayona QlomaroCi wazawojihi [in the Ḳur ii. 96, meaning Whereby they might dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle, the state of union subsisting between the man and his wife, in respect of affairs and of the expression of opinion, or, briefly, whereby they might cause division and dissension between the man and his wife,] is from Altaforiyqu as meaning taXotiytu AlX-amoli waAlkalimapi. (El-Iṣbahánee, TA.) One says also, fr-q AlOamora, meaning Xat-atahu [i. e. He discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, the state of affairs]. (Ṣ in art. Xt.) And fr-q EalayonaA AlkalaAma [lit. He scattered speech (app. meaning he jabbered) at us, or against us]. (Ḳ in art. bq: see R. Q. 1 in that art.) In the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 130 and iii. 78], laA nufar-iqu bayona OaHadK minohumo [We will not make a distinction between any of them], the verb is allowably made to relate to AHd because this word [in negative phrases] imports a pl. meaning. (TA. [See p. 27, 3rd col.]) See, again, 1, near the middle.

fr-qhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. taforiyqN, (O, Ḳ, TA,) also signifies He made him to fear, or be afraid; put him in fear; or frightened him: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) and Oaforaqotuhu↓ minohu I made him to fear, or be afraid of, him, or it: (Mṣb:) and Lḥ mentions faraqotu↓ AlSabiI-a as meaning I frightened the boy, or child; but ISd says, I think it to be far-aqotu. (TA.)

3. fArqhu, inf. n. mufaAriqapN and firaAqN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) He separated himself from him, or it; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him, or it: or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: syn. baAyanahu; (TA;) and qaATaEahu, and faArazahu; (A in art. frz;) and tarakahu. (Mṣb in art. trk.) And fArq QmoraOatahu He separated himself from his wife. (TA.)

faAraqotu fulaAnFA mino HisaAbiI EalaI kacaA wakacaA I released such a one from my reckoning with him on such and such terms agreed upon by both: and so SaAdarotuhu EalaI kacaA wakacaA. (TA.) And fuwriqa EalaI maAlK yuWad-iyhi He (an agent) was released from being reckoned with on the condition of his paying certain property for which he became responsible. (TA in art. Sdr.)
faAraqaniI fafaraqotuhu: see 1, last quarter.
4. AfrqwA Uibilahumo They left their camels in the place of pasture, and did not assist them in bringing forth, nor have them got with young. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And Afrq ganamahu He made, or caused, his sheep, or goats, to stray; and neglected them, or caused them to become lost, or to perish. (TA.)
And Afrq He lost a portion of his sheep or goats. (IKh, TA.)
And His sheep, or goats, became a fariyqap [q. v.]. (IKh, TA.)

Afrq He recovered; (Lth, Aṣ, Az, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or recovered, but not completely; (Aṣ, O, Ḳ;) to which IKh adds, quickly; (TA;) i. e., a sick person from (mino) his sickness; (Aṣ, Az, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and one fevered from his fever; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and one smitten with the plague: (Lth, TA:) or (Ḳ) it is not said except in the case of a disease that does not attack one more than once, as the small-pox, (O, Ḳ,) and the measles. (O.)
Afrqt She (a camel) had a return of some of her milk. (O, Ḳ.)
Afrq said of a man, and of a bird, and of a beast of prey, and of a fox, He voided dung, or thin dung. (Lḥ, TA. [See also 1, last quarter.])
And Afrqhu He, or it, caused him to void dung; syn. Oacoraqahu. (Ḳ. [But I do not find Acrq mentioned except as an intrans. v.]) See also firoqapN, last sentence.
AfrqhA: see 1, last quarter.
Oaforaqotuhu minohu: see 2, last sentence.

entry.sense: 5. tfr-q, inf. n. tafar-aqN (O, Ḳ) and tifir-aAqN, (Ḳ, TA,) with two kesrehs, but accord. to the “Nawádir” of Lḥ taforiyqN, (TA,) [and in the CK taforAq,] It was, or became, separated, or disunited: or separated much, or greatly, or widely, or into several, or many, portions; or dispersed, or dissipated: contr. of tajam-aEa: and Aftrq↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) and so does Anfrq↓: (TA:) all are quasi-pass. of far-aqotuhu: (Ṣ,* TA:) [or rather the second and third have the former of the meanings mentioned above: and tfr-q has the latter of those meanings:] or AifotaraqaA↓ is said of two sayings, as quasi-pass. of faraqotu bayonahumaA: and tafar-aqaA, of two men, as quasi-pass. of far-aqotu bayonahamaA: (Mgh,* Mṣb, TA:) so says IAạr: (Mṣb:) [but] one says also, Aftrq Alqawomu [The party, or company of men, became separated; or they separated themselves:] (Mṣb:) and Esh-Sháfiʼee has used AifotaraqaA↓ as relating to two persons buying and selling; (Mṣb, TA;) and so have Aḥmad [Ibn-Hambal] and Aboo-Ḥaneefeh and Málik and others. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Albay-aEaAni biAlxiyaAri maA yatafar-aqaA i. e. [The buyer and seller have the option to annul their contract] as long as they have not become separated bodily; (Mgh, Mṣb;) originally, maA lamo yatafar-aqo OabodaAnuhumaA; for this is the proper meaning. (Mṣb.) tafar-aqato bihimu AlT-uruqu [properly The roads became separate with them,] means every one of them went one [separate] way. (TA.) [And one says, tfr-qt AlOagoSaAnu (Ṣ in art. Xcb, &c.,) The branches were, or became, or grew out, apart, one from another; divaricated; diverged; forked; straggled; or spread widely and dispersedly. And tfr-q Oamoruhu His affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, so that he considered what might be its issues, or results, saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus: see OajomaEa; and Xat-a: and Aftrq↓ signifies the same: see an ex. voce faXaA, in art. fXw. And tfr-qt kalimatuhumo (Ḳ voce XaAla, in art. Xwl,) Their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: and tfr-qt MraAWuhumo Their opinions were, or became, so.]
6. tfArqwA They separated themselves, one from another; or left, forsook, or abandoned, one another. (TA.)

7. Anfrq, of which munofaraqN may be an inf. n. [like AinofiraAqN], as well as a n. of place, It was, or became, separated, or divided. (O, Ḳ.) See also 5. [Hence,] Anfrq Alfajoru i. q. Ainofalaqa [The dawn broke]. (TA.)
8. Aftrq: see 5, first sentence, in three places: and also in the last sentence but one.

hom.sense: faroqN [is originally an inf. n.: but is often used as a simple subst. meaning A distinction, or difference, between two things.]

[Hence,] The line [or division] in the hair of the head: (Ḳ: [see also maforaqN:]) or, as some say, the part, of the head, extending from the side of the forehead to the spiral curl upon the crown: an ex. occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce maTorabN. (TA.)
[And app. A blaze on a horse's forehead. (See an ex. voce muEotadilN.)]

And [hence, perhaps,] one says, baAnato fiI qacaAlihi furuwqN mina AlX-ayobi i. e. OawoDaAHN [app. meaning There appeared in the back of his head portions of white, or hoary, hair, distinct from the rest]. (TA.)

One says also of the female comber and dresser of the hair, tamoXuTu kacaA wakacaA faroqFA i. e. [She combs and dresses the hair] with such and such a mode or manner [app. of combing and dressing or of dividing]. (L. [But the last word, which seems to be in this case an inf. n., is there written without any vowel-sign.])
Also A certain bird or flying thing; (TaAYirN O, Ḳ;) not mentioned by AḤát in “the Book of Birds.” (O, TA.)
And Flax. (Ḳ.)
See also faraqN, in nine places.

entry.sense: Alfuroqu: see AlfuroqaAnu.
It also signifies A certain vessel with which one measures. (TA. [See also faraqN.])

And [it is said that] AlfuroqaAni signifies qdHAn mftrqAn [app. meaning Two separate bowls, or milking-vessels, supposing the former word to be qadaHaAni; the latter word being mufotariqaAni]. (TA. [This is app. said in explanation of furoqaAni ending a verse in which it means “milkingvessels:” but it is said in the Ṣ, and in one place in the TA, that it is in that instance pl. of faroqN or faraqN, q. v.])

hom.sense: firoqN A piece, or portion, that is split from a thing, or cleft therefrom; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) whence its usage in the Ḳur xxvi. 63: (Ṣ, O:) and a portion of anything (Ḳ, TA) when it is separated; and the pl. is firaqN: (TA:) or a portion that is separated, or dispersed, of a thing; and thus it is said to mean in the Ḳur ubi suprá; and the pl. is OaforaAqN, like OaHomaAlN as pl. of HimolN. (Mṣb.) See also firoqapN.
And A set of boys. (O, Ḳ.) An Arab of the desert said of some boys whom he saw, heWulaMCi firoqu sawoCK [These are a bad set of boys]. (O.)
And A distinct quantity of date-stones with which the camel is fed. (Ḳ.)
[And app. Any feed for one's beast: see an ex. in art. jl, conj. 4.]
Also A mountain. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) And A [hill, or mountain, or the like, such as is termed] haDobap. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And A wave, billow, or surge. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
And Alfiroqu is the name applied by the Arabs to The star [a] upon the right shoulder of Cepheus. (Ḳzw.)

faraqN Wideness of the space between the two central incisors, (IKh, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) of a man: (TA:) and likewise between the two toe-nails of the camel. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And A division in the Eurof [or comb] of the cock: and likewise in the forelock, and in the beard, of a man: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. OaforaAqN. (Ṣ, O.) And sparseness, or a scattered state, of the plants, or herbage, of a land. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

In a horse, The state of the hips when one of them is more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or a deficiency in one of the thighs, in comparison with the other: or a deficiency in one of the hips. (TA.)

Also The dawn: or Alfaraqu signifies falaqu AlS-uboHi: (Ḳ:) or what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn; of the dawn that rises and spreads, filling the horizon with its whiteness; (maA Qnofalaqa mino Eamuwdi AlS-uboHi [which is one of the explanations of Alfalaqu in the Ḳ];) because it has become separated from the blackness of the night: (TA:) one says, Oaboyanu mino faraqi AlS-uboHi a dial. var. of falaqi AlS-uboHi [i. e. More distinct than what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* TA.)
It is also the inf. n. of fariqa [q. v.: when used as a simple subst., signifying Fear, or fright]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)

Also, and faroqN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latte accord. to the usage of the relaters of traditions, (Az, Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA,) but the former accord. to the usage of the Arabs, (Az, Mgh, O,* TA,) or the former is the more chaste (Ḳ, TA) accord. to Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà and Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, (TA,) A certain vessel, (T, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) a measure of capacity, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) of large size, (TA,) well known, (Ṣ,) in El-Medeeneh, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) holding three MSuE [a pl. of SaAEN], (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or, (Ḳ, [app. referring to faroqN↓ only,]) which is the same quantity, sixteen pints, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) i. e. twelve times the quantity termed mud- by the people of El-Ḥijáz: (TA:) or, accord. to El-Ḳutabee, the faroq↓ is sixteen pints, and the SAE is one third of the faroq; but the faraq is eighty pints: or the faroq↓, he adds, is, as some say, four pints: (Mgh:) or it is four OarobaAE [pl. of ruboEN, q. v.]; (Ḳ, TA;) thus accord. to AḤát: and IAth says, the faraq is said to be five OaqosaAT; [or six; (see qisoTN;)] the qisoT being the half of a SAE: but the faroq↓ is a hundred and twenty pints: (TA:) in the “Nawádir” of Hishám, on the authority of [the Imám] Moḥammad, the faroq↓ is said to be thirty-six pints; but [Mṭr says] this I have not found in any of the lexicons in my possession; and so what is said in the Moḥeeṭ, that it is sixty pints: (Mgh:) the pl. is furoqaAnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ, TA,) which is of faroqN↓ and of faraqN; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, TA;) and OaforuqN occurs in a trad. as a pl. [of pauc.] of faraqN meaning the measure thus called. (TA.) ʼÁïsheh is related to have said that she and the Prophet used to wash themselves from a vessel called the faroq↓. (O, Mṣb.) [In a verse of which a hemistich is cited in the Ṣ and TA, the pl. furoqaAn is used as meaning Milking-vessels. (See also Alfuroqu.) Respecting a modern signification of faroq↓ (A bale, or sack, of merchandise), see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii., 378-9 and 382.]

entry.sense: faruqN: see faruwqapN, in two places.

hom.sense: fariqN is applied to plants, or herbage, (nabotN,) as meaning [In a sparse, or scattered, state; or] small, not covering the ground: (AḤn, Ḳ, TA:) or (Ḳ) fariqapN is applied to land, (OaroDN,) meaning of which the plants, or herbage, are in a sparse, or scattered, state; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) not contiguous: (Ṣ, O, TA:) thus used, it is a possessive epithet, having no verb. (TA.)
See also faruwqapN, in two places.

entry.sense: furoqapN the subst. from faAraqahu; (Ṣ, MA,* TA;) or from Aifotaraqa, (Mṣb,) [i. e.] a quasi-inf. n. used in the sense of AifotiraAqN; (TA;) signifying Separation, disunion, or abandonment; (MA, KL, PṢ;) and faraAqN↓ is syn. therewith, whence the reading [in the Ḳur xviii. 77], hecaA faraAqu bayoniI wabayonika [This shall be the separation of my and thy union]; and so is firaAqN↓, (O,* Ḳ, TA,) which [is an inf. n. of fArqh, and], in the Ḳur lxxv. 28, means the time of the quitting of the present world by death. (TA.)

hom.sense: firoqapN A TaAYifap [or party, portion, division, sect, or distinct body or class,] of men, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of other things; as also firoqN↓; (Mṣb;) and so, accord. to IB, fariyqN↓: (TA: [but see this last word:]) [and a separate herd or the like of cattle:] pl. firaqN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaforaAqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) is pl. of firaqN (O, Ḳ) and OafaAriyqu is pl. of OaforaAqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and OafaAriqapN occurs in poetry; (O, Ḳ;) or OafaAriyqu may be of the class of OabaATiylu, a pl. without a sing. (O, TA.)
And A skin that is full [of milk], that cannot be agitated to make butter Hat-aI yuforaqa↓ OaIo yucoraqa [app. a tropical phrase meaning until it is made to void some of its contents]. (Ḳ.)
furoqaAnN, originally an inf. n. (Mṣb. [See 1, first sentence.]) Anything that makes a separation, or distinction, between truth and falsity. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Hence, (TA,) AlfuroqaAnu signifies The Ḳur-án; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Alfuroqu↓. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And The Book of the Law revealed to Moses, (Az, O, Ḳ,) in which a distinction is made between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden. (O.)
And Proof, evidence, or demonstration. (O, Ḳ.)
And The time a little before daybreak: (AA, O, Ḳ:) or the dawn. (O, Ḳ.) One says, TalaEa AlfuroqaAnu [The dawn rose]. (O.)

And Aid, or victory: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) so, accord. to IDrd, in the phrase yawoma AlfuroqaAni in the Ḳur [viii. 42]: (O:) or by this phrase is meant The day of Bedr, (O, Ḳ,) in which a distinction was made between right and wrong. (O.)
And The cleaving of the sea: so it means [accord. to some] in the Ḳur ii. 50. (O, Ḳ.)
And Boys: (O, Ḳ:) such the people of the olden time used to make witnesses [in law-suits or the like]. (O.)
It is also pl. of faroqN (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and of faraqN. (Ṣ, Mgh, O.)

entry.sense: faraAqN and firaAqN: see furoqapN.

hom.sense: faruwqN: see faruwqapN, in two places:
and Oaforaqu, last sentence but two.

fariyqN A TaAYifap [or party,, &c.,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) more in number, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or larger, (Mṣb,) than a firoqap: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaforiqapN and [of mult.] OaforiqaMCu and furuwqN (Ḳ, TA) and furuqN: (CK:) see also firoqapN, in two places; and see firoqapN: AḤei says that it is itself a quasi-pl. n., applied to few and to many: ʼAbd-el-Hakeem, that it occurs in the sense of a TaAYifap [or party,, &c.], and in the sense of a single man: and El-Iṣbahánee, that it signifies a company of men apart from others [i. e. a party of men]: (MF, TA:) or [simply] a company [of men]. (O.)
And A separator of himself. (IB, TA.) Hence the saying, huwa OasoraEu mino fariyqi Alxayoli i. e. [He is swifter] than the outgoer, or outrunner, of the horses. (TA.)

niy-apN farayqN means mufar-iqN [i. e. A place to which one purposes journeying that separates widely]: a poet says,
OaHaq-N Oan-a jiyoratanaA Qsotaqal-uwA
faniy-atunaA waniy-atuhumo fariyqu
[Is it true that our neighbours have gone away, so that the place to which we purpose journeying and the place to which they purpose journeying are such as separate widely]: he says fariyq in like manner as one applies [the epithet] SadiyqN to a company of men. (Sb, TA.)
Also A palm-tree (naxolapN) in which is [app. meaning out of which grows] another. (AA, AḤn, O, TA.)

faruwqapN, applied to a man and to a woman, (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and having no pl., (Ṣ, O,) and far-uwqapN↓, applied to a man (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) and to a woman, (Ḳ,) and faAruwqapN↓, applied to a man (O, Ḳ,) and to a woman, or, as epithets applied to a man, faruwqapN, (Ḳ,) and far-uwqapN↓, (CK,) and faAruwqapN↓, and faruwqN↓, (Ḳ,) but this last is also applied to a woman, (IB, TA,) and far-uwqN↓, and faAruwqN↓, One who fears much, or vehemently; [or rather the epithets with the affix p are doubly intensive, meaning one who fears very much;] (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ, TA;)
and fariqN↓ and faruqN↓ signify the same as the other epithets above; or faruqN↓ signifies fearing, or fearful, by nature; and fariqN↓, [simply,] fearing a thing. (Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., rub-a EajalapK tahabu rayovFA warub-a faruwqapK yudoEaI layovFA warub-a gayovK lamo yakuno gayovFA [Many an act of haste causes (lit. gives) slowness, and many a very fearful man is called a lion, and many a collection of clouds has not been productive of rain]: (Ṣ,* O:) said by Málik Ibn-ʼAmr Ibn-Mohallam, when Leyth, his brother, looked hopefully at the clouds from afar, and desired to avail himself of the benefit thereof; whereupon Málik said to him, “Do not, for I fear for thee some of the troops of the Arabs:” but he disobeyed him, and journeyed with his family; and he had not stayed [away] a little while when he came [back], and his family had been taken. (O. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 535.])

And Alfaruwqapu signifies AlHuromapu [meaning Honour, or reputation; or that which one is under an obligation to respect and defend]: (O, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK AlHuzomapu:]) so Sh was told: and [so, app., Alfaruwqu↓, for] he cites as an ex.,
maA zaAla Eanohu Humoquhu wamuwquhu
waAll-uWomu Hat-aI Qnotuhikato faruwqahu
[His foolishness and his stupidity quitted him not, and meanness, so that his honour,, &c., was violated]. (O, TA.)
And The fat of the kidneys: (O, Ḳ:) so says AʼObeyd, on the authority of El-Umawee; but Sh disallowed this meaning, and knew it not. (O, TA.)
fariyqapN: see firoqN.

Also Some (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) one or two or three (Ṣ, O) of a flock or herd, of sheep or goats, becoming separate therefrom, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) being shut out from the rest by the like of a mountain or a space of sand or some other thing, as is said in the “Kitáb Leysa,” (TA,) and going away, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) in the “Kitáb Leysa” straying, (TA,) in the night, from the main aggregate. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,)

And Dates cooked with fenugreek (Hulobap), for the woman in the state following childbirth: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or fenugreek (Hulobap) cooked with grains (Hubuwb) [or kernels?], (O, Ḳ, TA,) such as maHolabo [q. v.], and byr [app. a mistranscription], and other things, (TA,) for her: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to IKh, a soup that is made for him who is affected with a chronic disease, or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (TA.) [See also faliyqapN.]

entry.sense: far-uwqN: see faruwqapN, first sentence.
far-uwqapN: see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

faAriqN [act. part. n. of faraqa, q. v.]. AlfaAriqaAtu, mentioned in the Ḳur lxxvii. 4, means Those angels that descend with what makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (Fr, O, Ḳ:) or that distinguish between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden: (Th, TA:) or that make a distinction between things according as God has commanded them. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also, faAriqN, A she-camel, and a she-ass, in consequence of her being taken with the pains of parturition, going away at random in the land; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so faAriqapN, as in the “Mufradát:” or a she-camel that separates herself from her mate, and brings forth alone: or a she-camel that runs (taXotad-u), and then casts her young one by reason of the pain that befalls her; thus expl. by IAạr: (TA:) pl. fawaAriqu and fur-aqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and furuqN (Ḳ) and fur-aAqN, which is thus used by El-Aạshà, applied to she-camels, and mafaAriyqu↓ is [an irreg. pl.] likewise applied to she-camels as syn. with fawaAriqu. (TA.)

And hence, as being likened to such a she-camel, applied to a cloud (saHaAbapN) as meaning ‡ Apart from the other clouds; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) cut off from the main aggregate of the clouds: (ISd, TA:) or an isolated cloud, that will not break its promise [of giving rain], and sometimes preceded by thunder and lighting: (TA:) thus applied, also, having for pl. fawaAriqu and fur-aqN [&c.]. (O.)

hom.sense: faAruwqN A thing that makes a distinction between two things: and a man who makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (TA:) or one who makes a distinction between affairs, or cases. (Mṣb.) AlfaAruwqu is an appellation that was given to ʼOmar Ibn-El-Khattáb, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) the second of the Khaleefehs; (TA;) because a distinction was made by him between truth and falsity. (Ibráheem El-Ḥarbee, O, Ḳ,* TA.)

tiroyaAqN faAruwqN, (O,) or Alt-iroyaAqu AlfaAruwqu, (Ḳ,) The most approved sort of theriac, (O, Ḳ,) and the most esteemed of compounds; because it makes a distinction between disease and health: (Ḳ:) called by the vulgar tiroyaAqa faAruwqiI-. (TA.)
See also faruwqapN, first sentence.

entry.sense: faAruwqapN: see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

Oaforaqu, applied to a man, Having a wide space between the two central incisors: (IKh, TA:) [or] i. q. Oafolaju [app. as meaning the same, or having a similar meaning]: (Ḳ, TA: [but the CK has AlOafolaHu instead of AlOafolaju:]) or, accord. to Lth, the Oaforaq is like the Oafolaj, except that the Aflj is such as has been rendered so, and the Afrq is such naturally. (O, TA.) And A camel having a wide space between the two toe-nails. (Yaạḳoob, TA.) And Having a wide space between the buttocks. (TA.) And A he-goat having a wide space between his horns. (IKh, TA.) And A ram, or he-goat, having a wide space between his testicles: and [the fem.] faroqaMCu a ewe, or she-goat, having a wide space between the two teats. (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA.)
A camel having two humps. (TA.)

A man whose forelock is as though it were divided; and in like manner, whose beard is so. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*) A cock whose Eurof [or comb] is divided: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and (accord. to Lth, O) a white cock: (O, Ḳ:) or, as some say, having two combs (cuw Eurofayoni). (O.)

A horse having one of the hips more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or having a deficiency in one of his thighs, in comparison with the other: or having a deficiency in one of the hips: or, accord. to the T, a beast having one of his elbows prominent, and the other depressed. (TA.) And A horse having one testicle. (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA.) The pl. is furoqN. (TA, in which it is here mentioned: also mentioned in the Ḳ after Oaforaqu as applied to a ram or he-goat: in the CK [erroneously] furuqN) And faruwqN↓ applied to a horse signifies the same as Oaforaqu. (O, TA.)
TariyqN Oaforaqu A road that is distinct, apparent, or manifest. (TA.) And sayolN Oaforaqu A torrent that is as though it were the firoq [app. as meaning wave, billow, or surge]. (TA.)

tafaAriyqu [Sundry, or separate, or scattered, portions or things: and sundry times]. You say, Oaxacotu Haq-iI minohu biAlt-afaAriyqi (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA) i. e. [I took my right, or due, from him in sundry portions: or] at sundry times. (TA.) And Dam-a tafaAriyqa mataAEihi i. e. [He put together] what were scattered [of his household goods, or furniture and utensils]. (TA.)
Uin-aka xayorN mino tafaAriyqi AlEaSaA
[Verily thou art better than the several portions of the staff], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) which is a prov., (O,) was said by a poet, (Ṣ,) or by Ghaneeyeh, (O,) or Ghuneiyeh, (Ḳ,) El-Aarábeeyeh, to her son; for he was evil in disposition, [EAzimFA in the CK is a mistake for EaArimFA,] very mischievous, notwithstanding his weakness, (O, Ḳ,) and slenderness of bone; (O;) and he assaulted one day a young man, who thereupon cut off his nose, and his mother took the mulct for it; so her condition became good after abasing poverty; then he assaulted another, who cut off his ear; and another, who cut off his lip; and his mother took the mulct for each; and when she saw the goodness of her condition, (O, Ḳ,) the camels and the sheep or goats and the household goods that she had acquired, (O,) she said thus: (O, Ḳ:) for from the staff (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) when it is broken (Ṣ) is made a saAjuwr [q. v.], and from this are made tent-pegs, and from the tent-peg is made an EiraAn [q. v.], and from this are made tawaAdK [pl. of tawodiyapN, q. v.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

maforaqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and maforiqN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) The middle of the head; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) the place where the hair of the head is separated: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. mafaAriqu; which is used also in the sense of the sing., as though the sing. applied to every part thereof: (Ṣ, O:) one says, XaAbato mafaAriqu raOosihi [meaning The place (lit. places) of the separation of the hair of his head became white, or hoary]. (Mgh voce cakarN.) [See also faroqN.]
Also The place, of a road, where another road branches off: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) both words are used in this sense likewise: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

And [hence] one says, waqafotuhu EalaI mafaAriqi AlHadiyvi ‡ [I made him to know] the modes, or manners, [of the narrative, or discourse,] or the manifest, plain, or obvious, modes or manners [thereof]. (TA.)
muforiqN A she-camel whose young one has become separated from her, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) as some say, (TA,) by death: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) pl. mafaAriyqN↓. (TA. [Thus in my original, not mafaAriqu.])
And A she-camel that tarries two years, or three, without conceiving. (TA.)
And A she-camel having a return of some of her milk. (TA.)
And Anyone recovering from his disease. (Lḥ, TA.)
And Deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right. (TA.)

And muforiqu Aljisomi, (thus accord. to the Ḳ, there said to be like muHosinN,) or mufar-aqu↓ Aljisomi, (thus in the O,) A man (O) having little flesh: or fat, or plump: (O, Ḳ:) two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)
mufar-aqu Aljisomi: see what next precedes.

mufar-iqu Aln-aEami [The disperser of the camels or cattle;] the [small, stinking beast called] ZaribaAni; because when it emits a noiseless wind from the anus among the cattle, they disperse themselves. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
mafaAriyqu: see muforiqN:
and faAriqN, latter half.
munofaraqN is a n. of place, as well as an inf. n. [of Ainofaraqa]: (O, Ḳ:) and is used by Ru-beh as meaning A place where a road divides. (O.)

hom.sense: And Alfaroqadu (O, L, Ḳ) and Alfuroquwdu↓ (O, Ḳ) † The asterism (najom) by which one directs his course (O, Ḳ) by sea and by land; (O;) two stars [b and y of Ursa Minor]; (L, Ḳ;) also called (in poetry, O, Ḳ, [and generally in prose,]) AlfaroqadaAni; (O, L, Ḳ;) thus in a verse cited voce Uil-aA; (O;) they are two stars near the quTob [or pole-star]; (Ṣ, L;) two stars that never set, revolving round the jadoI [or pole-star], both in Ursa Minor; (L;) the two bright stars of the four that form the angles of a quadrilateral figure in Ursa Minor; (Ḳzw;) also called by the Arabs AlfaraAqidu [which is the pl. of Alfaroqadu]. (L.)
And faroqadu signifies also A level, or an even, land. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

entry.sense: furoquwdN: see above, first and second sentences.

hom.sense: Q. 1. faroqaEa AlOaSaAbiEa i. q. naq-aDahaA, (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ, [in copies of the Ḳ written naqaDahaA, but correctly with teshdeed, as is shown by what here follows,]) inf. n. faroqaEapN i. q. tanoqiyDN (Ṣ, O) and tafoqiyEN, (TA,) [He cracked the joints of his fingers;] i. e. he pressed his fingers so that a sound was heard to proceed from their joints: (TA:) the doing of which is forbidden, (O, TA,) in prayer. (TA. [See also 2 in art. fqE.]) And one says, samiEotu faroqaEapF lirajulK and SaroqaEapF [I heard a cracking of the joints of the fingers of a man]: both signify the same. (TA.)
And faroqaEapu He twisted his (a man's, Ḳ) neck. (O, Ḳ.)
faroqaEa [as an intrans. v.], (O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He ran vehemently, (O, Ḳ, TA,) going back, or retreating: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
And firoqaAEN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faroqaEa, TḲ) signifies The emitting of wind from the anus with a sound: (O, Ḳ:) mentioned by IDrd as from some one or more of the Arabs. (O.)
See also faroqaEapN in what next follows.

entry.sense: Q. 2. tafaroqaEato AlOaSaAbiEu The fingers produced a sound or sounds [by their joints' being cracked]; (O;) quasi-pass. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AiforanoqaEat↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. AiforinoqaAEu and [quasi-inf. n., being app. the inf. n. in this case of furoqiEat,] faroqaEapN↓, (TA,) [and this is app. what is meant by its being said that] AlAiforinoqaAEu↓ is [syn. with] AlfaroqaEapu. (Ḳ.)
Accord. to IDrd, tafaroquEN signifies The sounding of two things striking against each other. (O.)
And tfrqE Alr-ajulu The man drew himself together, or shrank; like taqaroEafa [which is mentioned in the Ḳ in the same sense, as also taqarofaEa]. (L, TA.)
Q. 3: see Q. 2, in two places.
AlfuroqaEapa The Aisot [here app. meaning anus (see 1)]; (Lth, IAạr, Ḳ;) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (O:) also called AlqurofuEapu. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. farokN, as expl. by Lth, signifies (O, TA) primarily (TA) One's rubbing, or rubbing and pressing, a thing [with the hand] so that its integument becomes stripped off (O, TA) from its kernel; as, for instance, a [shelled] walnut. (TA.) One says, faraka Als-unobula, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaforuku}, inf. n. farokN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the ears of corn (Ḳ, TA) with his hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA.) And faraka Alv-awoba (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the garment (Ḳ, TA) with his hand [to remove a soil]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA.) And faraka AlmaniI-a mina Alv-awobi (Mgh, O, Mṣb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He rubbed, (Mṣb,) or rubbed and pressed, (Mgh,) with his hand, the [dry soil of] sperma, so that it crumbled, and came off from the garment; (Mgh, Mṣb;) like Hat-ahu: and in like manner AlT-iyna [i. e. the dry mud]. (Mṣb.) [And faraka Alqamolapa He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the louse, between his finger and thumb, or otherwise, to kill it. (See the pass. part. n., below.)]

farikato zawojahaA, and farikahaA zawojuhaA, aor. _a {yaforaku}; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and farakatohu, and farakahaA, aor. _u {yaforuku}, but this form of the verb is extr.; (Ḳ;) inf. n. firokN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and farokN and furuwkN; (Ḳ;) She hated her husband, and her husband hated her; (Ṣ, O;) or she hated her husband vehemently, and her husband hated her vehemently: (Ḳ:) the verb has not been heard otherwise than as relating to the husband and wife: (Ṣ, O:) Lḥ has mentioned farakatohu, aor. taforukuhu; but it is not well known: (TA:) all of the nouns mentioned above as inf. ns. signify [hatred, or] vehement hatred, in a general sense, as also furuk-aAnN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) which is [app. a simple subst.] mentioned on the authority of Seer, and also mentioned as with two kesrehs and the teshdeed [i. e. firik-aAnN↓]: (TA:) or all relate peculiarly to the hatred of the husband and wife; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., to the man's hating his wife; or to her hating him, which is the better known: it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mesʼood, Uin-a AlHub-a mina Qll-ehi waAlfiroka mina AlX-ayoTaAni [Verily love of the husband is from God, and hatred of the husband is from the Devil]: A'Obeyd says that Alfiroku signifies the woman's hating her husband; that it relates peculiarly to the wife and the husband, and that it had not been heard by him as used in relation to any but them two: and IAạr says that the sons of a man by a wife who hates him, which sons are termed OawolaAdu Alfiroki, possess generosity, because the sons thus called are most like to their fathers, and do not resemble her: and when the husband hates the wife, one says SlfhA [i. e. SalafahaA or SalifahaA] and Slft Endh [i. e. Salifato Einodahu]. (TA.)

farikati AlOucuni, aor. _a {yaforaku}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. farakN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) The ear had a flaccidity in its OaSol [or base, meaning the part surrounding the entrance of the meatus auditorius]. (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. taforiykN [inf. n. of fr-k] The causing to be hated, or much hated. (O.)

3. fArkhu, (AZ, O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. mufaArakapN, (TA,) i. q. taArakahu [i. e. He left, forsook, or abandoned, him; or he did so being left, &c. by him]; (AZ, O, Ḳ, TA;) namely, his companion; (AZ, O;) said by IF to be formed by substitution [of f for t]: (O, TA:) expl. in the A as meaning faAraqahu [which is syn. with tArkh]. (TA.)

4. Afrk Als-unobulu The ears of corn became fariyk↓, i. e. in the state in which they were fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand [so as to divest the kernels of their husks], and then to be eaten: (Ṣ, O:) and Afrk Alz-aroEu, (TA,) and AlHab-u, (Ḳ,) The seed-produce, and the grain, attained to the state in which it was fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (Ḳ, TA,) with the hand: or the grain became hard, or firm, and attained to its utmost state of growth; before which it is forbidden to sell it. (TA.)
5. tfr-k He (an effeminate man, O) affected languor, or languidness, (takas-ara) in his speech, (O, Ḳ,) and in his walk: (Ḳ:) so says IDrd. (O.)

7. Anfrk Als-unobulu The ears of corn were rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (Ḳ, TA,) with the hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (TA.) And Anfrk Alv-awobu The garment became rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (Ḳ, TA,) with the hand [to remove a soil]. (TA.) [See 1.]

And Anfrk Almanokibu The shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: (Ṣ,* TA:) or Anfrk manokibuhu, (Lth, O, Ḳ,*) as also Anfrkt waAbilatuhu, (Lth, O,) signifies the waAbilap [or head] of his humerus became dislocated (Lth, O, Ḳ) from the Sadafap [or socket] of the scapula, so that the shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: but when the like thereof happens in the wAblp of the femur, one does not say Anfrk, but Huriqa, and the epithet maHoruwqN is applied to it [i. e. to the hip-joint]. (Lth, O.)
And Anfrk Eano Eahodihi He became released from his compact, engagement, or promise; syn. Ainofak-a. (TA.)

10. Astfrk AlHab-u fiI Als-unobulapi The grain became full (samina [q. v.]), and hard, or firm, [as though demanding to be rubbed with the hand so as to be divested of the husks, and eaten,] in the ear of corn. (Ḳ,* TA.)
farokN: see what next follows.

farikN, (O, Ḳ,) like katifN, (Ḳ,) or correctly, as written in the L and A. farokN↓, (TA, [but this I think doubtful,]) [A fruit or the like] of which the integument becomes rubbed off [with the hand]: (O, Ḳ: [I read Almunofariku qiXoruhu, as in the CK, for Almutafar-iku qiXoruhu in other copies of the Ḳ and in the O:]) thus applied to an almond, and likewise to a peach. (TA.)
See also what next follows.
OucunN faroqaMCu An ear having a flaccidity in its OaSol [or base]; as also farikapN↓. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See 1, last sentence.])
furuk-aAnN and firik-aAnN: see 1, latter half.
firaAkN a term for HayoDN [or Menstruation]: mentioned by MF. (TA.)
faruwkN: see faArikN, first sentence.

hom.sense: fariykN, applied to grain (Hab-), i. q. maforuwkN↓ [i. e. Rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand, so that the integument becomes stripped off from the kernel]: (Ḳ:) or wheat (bur-) that is rubbed,, &c., and picked, or cleared. (O.) See also 4.
And Wheat rubbed,, &c., and moistened with clarified butter, &c.; (Ḳ, TA;) also termed maforuwkapN↓. (TA.)
The fariykaAni, or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, fariykataAni↓, (TA,) Two bones [app. the two greater cornua of the os hyoides] in, or at, (fiI,) the root of the tongue. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: fariykataAni: see what next precedes.

faArikN A woman hating, or who hates, her husband; [app. accord. to the Ḳ, vehemently;] as also faruwkN↓ [but app. in an intensive sense]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. of the former fawaArikN. (O,* TA.) Dhur-Rummeh says, (O, TA,) describing camels, (TA,)
UicaA All-ayolu Eano naXozK tajal-aI ramayonahu
biOamovaAli OaboSaAri Aln-isaMCi AlfawaAriki
[When the night clears away from an elevated piece of ground, they cast at it the like of the eyes of the women that hate their husbands]: (O, TA:) he likens them to the women that hate their husbands because these raise their eyes towards men, not confining the look to the husbands: he says, these camels enter upon the time of dawn, having journeyed all their night; and whenever an elevated piece of ground becomes within their view, they cast their eyes at it by reason of sprightliness and strength for the journeying. (TA.)

mufar-akN [Caused to be hated, or to be much hated: see its verb. And] A man hated by women: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) such was Imra-el-Ḳeys: (Ṣ, O:) [and accord. to Freytag, maforuwkN↓ occurs in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer.] And mufar-akapN A woman hated by men. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Also Left, forsaken, or abandoned, and hated. (Fr, TA.)

hom.sense: maforuwkN: see fariykN. One says also qamolapN maforuwkapN [A louse rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, between the finger and thumb, or otherwise, to be killed]. (Ṣ, O.)

Applied to a camel, (En-Naḍr, O, Ḳ,) it means Such as is termed Oafak-u [q. v.]; (En-Naḍr, O;) whose shoulder is slit [so I render Ainoxarama, but I incline to think that it here means is splayed, or dislocated, as though rent without being separated (see taxar-ama)], and the EaSabap [which I suppose to signify in this case either tendon or ligament] that is in the interior of the Oaxorama [q. v., app. here meaning the glenoid cavity of the scapula] detached. (En-Naḍr, O, Ḳ. [See also Anfrk manokibuhu.])
And A garment, or piece of cloth, (TA,) strongly dyed (Ḳ, TA) with saffron, &c. (TA.)
See also mufar-akN.

entry.sense: maforuwkapN, as a subst.: see fariykN.

2. taforiymN [as an inf. n. of which the verb is far-amat] signifies A woman's contracting her faloham (or qubul, TA) [i. e. vulva or vagina] with the stones of raisins [which were supposed to have an astringent property, or with some other medicament: see faromN: and see also 10]: and so taforiybN. (IAạr, T.)

3. firaAmN [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is faAramat] signifies A woman's menstruating, and stuffing her vulva with a piece of rag: and one says of her who has done this, Aifotaramat↓ [and app. also faAaramat]. (T, Ḳ.) [See also firaAmapN.]
It occurs in a trad. [as an inf. n.] used in the sense of mujaAmaEap [meaning ‡ The act of compressing]. (IAth, TA.)
4. Afrm He filled (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) a watering-trough (T, Ḳ) or a vessel: (Ṣ:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, Ṣ.)
8. Aifotaramat, said of a woman: see 3.

10. Aisotaforamat She (a woman) applied a medicament to her vulva, or vagina, to contract it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or she stuffed her vulva, or vagina, (T, TA,) with the stones of raisins, and the like: (TA:) the women of [the tribe of] Thakeef, having a wideness in that part, made this use of the stones of raisins, desiring thereby to contract it: (M, TA:*) [see also 2: and see faromN:] the epithet faromaMCu↓ is applied to her who does thus; as also musotaforimapN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

And [hence] one says of a mare, Aisotaforamato biAlHaSaI, meaning † She caused the pebbles to enter her vulva by her vehement running. (TA. [And the same is implied in the Ṣ by an ex. and explanation of the part. n.])
