faromN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and faromapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and firaAmN↓, (M, Ḳ,) A medicament, or remedial application, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) such as the stones of raisins, (T, M,) used by a woman for the purpose of contracting her vulva, or vagina. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

faramN The rag that is used on the occasion of menstruation: (IAth, TA:) and mafaArimu↓ signifies the rags used on the occasion thereof; and [may be an irreg. pl. of faramN, like as maXaAbihu is held to be of XabahN, but it is said that it] is a pl. having no sing.: (M, TA:) [in the Ḳ, in art. HXw, the mafaArimu↓ (there in the CK erroneously written maqaArim) are said to be used by the musotaHaADap: see 8 in that art.]
faromapN: see faromN.
faromaMCu: see 10.

hom.sense: firaAmN: see faromN:
and see also the next following paragraph.

entry.sense: Oaforamu A man (TA) whose teeth become much broken. (Ḳ, TA.)

muforamN Filled with water (T, M), &c.: (M:) mentioned by AʼObeyd, as applied to a wateringtrough: (T:) and applied also to a XiEob [or road in a mountain, &c.,] as meaning filled with men, or people: (M:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, M.)
mafaArimu: see faramN, in two places.
musotaforimapN: see 10.

furonN [app. from, or cognate with, the Latin “furnus”] An oven, (IDrd,* Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,)
syn. maxobazN, (M, Ḳ,) [or one] in which one bakes bread such as is termed furoniI-; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) differing from the tan-uwr [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) a word of the dial. of Syria: (M:) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic [in origin]: (TA:) pl. OaforaAnN. (M.)

furoniI-N Thick, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) round, or circular, (Ḳ,) bread; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so called in relation to its place [in which it is baked, i. e. the furon]: (Ṣ:) or (Ḳ) a sort of bread having a raised and pointed, or hollowed, head, the lateral portions thereof being drawn together to, or towards, the middle, (M, Ḳ,) and being intermingled, one part thereof in another, (M,) roasted, or fried, (Ḳ,) then well moistened with milk and clarified butter and sugar: (M, Ḳ:) n. un. furoniy-apN↓: which signifies also a round, or circular, great cake of bread: (M:) [whence, app.,] faUicaA hiIa mivolu Alfaroniy-api AlHamoraMCi [And lo, she, or it, was like the red frny-p; but to what this refers I know not]: a saying of some of the Arabs. (Ṣ, TA.)
And (as being likened thereto, TA) ‡ A thick, bulky, man: (M, Ḳ, TA:) and (Ḳ) a bulky dog. (IB, Ḳ, TA.)
furoniy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
far-aAnN: see furoniI-N, last sentence. [It is applied in the present day to A baker of bread and of meat, &c.]
faArinapN A female baker (T, Ḳ) of the bread termed furoniI-. (T.)
fironibN A rat, or mouse; syn. faOorapN: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) or the young one generated between it and a jerboa: (Ḳ:) or [as a coll. gen. n.] the rat, or mouse; syn. faOorN. (T.) [See also qaronabN.]
Alfiranoju, n. un. firanojiI-N: see what follows.

AlUiforanojapu (O, Ḳ) [and AlUiforanoju, which is the more common,] and Alfiranoju↓, (MF, TA, [but in the Commentary of MF written without any of the syll. signs,]) in which last manner it is correctly written accord. to the sheykhs of El-Andalus, who are the nearest to, and the best acquainted with, the country of the people thus called, and so written by Suh, (MF,) A certain people; [the Franks; an appellation given originally, by the Arabs, to the French; and afterwards to all Europeans except those of the Turkish Empire:] an arabicized word from Uiforanok, (Ḳ,) or AfrnG, (O,) or from frnk [or firanoG]: (Suh, MF:) accord. to general analogy, it should be AlUiforinojapu, with kesr to the r: (O, Ḳ:) so called because the seat of their dominion is [named] frnjp or frAnsp [i. e. France]; and their king is called AlfrnsPs, [more properly AlfaranosiyosiI-u,] which is likewise an arabicized word. (Suh, as cited by MF.) [The n. un., or appellation given to a single person of this people, is UiforanojiI-N and firanojiI-N.]
firinodN A sort of cloth, or garment, (Lth, T, O, Ḳ,) well known: (Ḳ:) an adventitious word, (Lth, T, O,) [from the Pers. Paranod,] arabicized. (O, Ḳ.)

And [hence, app.,] firinodu Als-ayofi, (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and Uiforinoduhu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, grain, or water, of the sword; syn. waXoyuhu, (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and jawoharuhu, (T, O, Ḳ,) and rubaduhu [q. v.], (Ṣ, O,) and maAWuhu Al-aciI yajoriI fiyhi, (T, O,*) and TaraAYiquhu, (T, O,) i. e. safaAsiquhu. (T.)
And Alfirinodu signifies The sword itself. (M, L, Ḳ.)
And The Hawojam; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. (TA) the red rose. (M, TA.)
And The grains of the pomegranate. (AA, O, Ḳ.)
fironidN i. q. OabozaArN [Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food;, &c.]: pl. faraAnidu. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
firinodaApN A qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
Uiforinodu Als-ayofi: see firinodN, second sentence.

dictScrap.label: For words mentioned in some of the lexicons under this head, see art. frs.

hom.sense: Q. 2. tafaronaqa He was, or became, bad; (Ḳ, TA;) said of a camel: (TA:) and so tafaronaqat said of a sheep or goat (XaAp). (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
And Oucunuhu tafaronaqato His ear became raised. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: furonuqN Bad; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) applied to the Eariyf [or chief, superintendent, or manager of the affairs,] of a people or party: and so mutafaroniqu↓ applied to a camel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

furaAniqN The bariyd, i. e., (IDrd, Ṣ, O,) the warner before the lion; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) a certain beast of prey, [sometimes called by us the lion's provider,] that cries out before the lion, as though warning men of his presence; said to resemble the jackal (Aibonu MwaI); (IDrd, TA;) and said to be the jackal [itself]; but some say otherwise: (TA voce bariydN:) a Pers. word, (IDrd, Ṣ, O,) arabicized, (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) originally farowaAnahu [or ParowaAnah], (IDrd, TA,) or originally ParowaAnak: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) said by AḤát to be [also] called the waEowaE. (TA.)
And (hence, TA) The guide of the messenger on a beast of the post. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And sometimes The guide of an army was thus called. (Ṣ, TA.)
And, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to some, (O,) it signifies The lion [himself]. (O, Ḳ.)
mutafaroniqN: see furonuqN.
1. faruha, aor. _u {yaforuhu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN (Ḳ) [and app. also furuwhapN, expl. below as a simple subst.], He was, or became, skilled, or skilful. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And faruha and faraha, aor. of each _u, [inf. n. app. furuwhapN and faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN, expl. below as simple substs.,] said of a horse or similar beast, &c., He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light. (Mṣb.)
[And faruha, inf. n. faraAhapN, (of which see an explanation below,) probably signifies He was, or became, beautiful, comely, pretty, or elegant; like SabuHa, inf. n. SabaAHapN.]

And fariha, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaforahu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. farahN, (TḲ,) He exulted, or rejoiced above measure; or he exulted greatly, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the h in this verb, accord. to Fr, is substituted for the H in fariHa, which has this meaning. (TA.)
2: see what next follows {4}.

4. Oaforahat She (a camel) brought forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (Ṣ) or fur-ahN (Ḳ) [i. e. such as were brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light]; as also fr-ht↓, inf. n. taforiyhN. (Ḳ.)
And She (a woman) brought forth beautiful children. (TA.)
And Afrh He (a man) took for himself a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave,] such as is termed faArihN (IAạr, Ḳ) meaning beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAạr, TA.)

10. huwa yasotaforihu AlOaforaAsa means yasotakorimuhaA [i. e. He seeks the horses, or mares, that are of generous race]: (aK, TA:) and the like is said in the A, but with Ald-awaAb-a in the place of AlAfrAs. (TA.)

farihN [part. n. of fariha, meaning Exulting, or rejoicing above measure;, &c.]. In the Ḳur xxvi. 149, some read farihiyna, from fariha, signifying as expl. above: others reading faArihiyna, which is from faruha: (Ṣ, TA:)
but farihN is also syn. with faArihN, as an epithet applied to a youth, or young man, or male slave; and thus the reading of farihiyna in the Ḳur has been expl. as meaning Possessing skill. (TA.)
furaAhN i. q. furaAtN, as an epithet applied to water, signifying Sweet,, &c.: both are chaste forms, and well known, like taAbuwhN and taAbuwtN: so in the Towsheeh. (MF and TA in art. frt.)
faraAhapN [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n. is also expl. as a simple subst.]: see furuwhapN.
Also Beauty, or comeliness. (Mṣb, TA.)
furuwhapN [app. an inf. n., but mentioned as a simple subst., meaning] Skilfulness. (Ḳ.)

And furuwhahN and faraAhapN↓ and faraAhiyapN↓ denote a quality of a hackney and of a mule and of an ass, (Ṣ,) or of a horse, or similar beast, &c., (Mṣb,) all signifying Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, activity, agility, or lightness. (Mṣb, TA.*)
faraAhiyapN [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n.]: see what next precedes.

faArihN Skilful, or possessing skill; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) part. n. of faruha, irregularly formed, for by rule it should be fariyhN: (Ṣ:) accord. to Z, it is applied to a man; and also, without p, to a qayonap [i. e. female slave, or slave-songstress]. (Mṣb.)

And it is applied as an epithet to a hackney, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and a mule, (Ṣ,) and an ass, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or to a horse, or similar beast, (Az,) meaning Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light; (Az,* Mṣb;) sharp; strong; that goes, or journeys, much; a great goer: (Az, TA:) it is not applied to a faras, (Az, Ṣ,) i. e. to an Arabian horse; (Az, Mṣb;) such being termed jawaAdN, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and raAYiEN: (Ṣ:) 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd has applied it to the latter; but Aṣ has charged him with error in so doing; saying that he possessed not knowledge of horses: (Ṣ:) the pl. is furohN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like buzolN and HuwlN pls. of baAzilN and HaAYilN, (Ṣ,) or furuhN, like kutubN, (Ḳ,) and farahapN, with two fet-ḥahs, (Mṣb,) or furohapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but this is held by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (ISd, TA,) and fur-ahN, like ruk-aEN, and fur-ahapN, like suk-arapN, (Ḳ,) as in the A, but MF says that no pl. of this measure is known. (TA.)

Also, applied to a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave], Beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAạr, TA.) And [the fem.] faArihapN signifies A beautiful, or comely, girl, or young woman: (Ḳ:) [and] so farohaMCu↓, [of which the masc. is Oaforahu, and] of which the pl. is furohN; but Az says, I do not think that they use this word in relation to girls, or young women, though they may apply it peculiarly to female slaves like as they apply faArihN and faArihapN peculiarly to hackneys and mules and jades, exclusively of Arabian horses. (Mṣb.)

And faArihapN is also syn. with fatiy-apN [i. e. A youthful females, or one in the prime of life]: (thus accord. to several copies of the Ḳ and accord. to the TA:) or qayonapN [i. e. a female slave, or a slave-songstress: see the first sentence of this paragraph]. (Thus in the CK.)
And it signifies also [A woman] who eats vehemently: (Ḳ:) and faArihN applied to man, A vehement eater. (IAạr, TA.)
Oaforahu: see its fem., farohaMCu, in the next preceding paragraph.
fulaAnN Oaforahu mino fulaAnK means Such a one is more beautiful, or comely, than such a one. (Mṣb.)
muforihN and muforihapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mufar-ihapN (Ṣ) are epithets applied to a she-camel, meaning Bringing forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (Ṣ) or fur-ahN. (Ḳ.) [See 4.]
Q. 2. tafarohada, said of a boy, or youth, not of a man, He became fat. (TA. [See also furohudN, and mufarohadN.])
farohadN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

furohadN (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ) and furohuwdN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) A boy, or youth, (L,) fat, or compact in make, (HaAdirN,) and thick; (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ;) as also farohadN↓: (O:) and soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (M, O,* Ḳ:) some assign this meaning to qurohadN, but others say that this is a corruption, and it is correctly with f: and one says also gulaAmN fulohudN, meaning a plump boy or youth: (L:) also, (Ḳ,) or furohudN [only], (TA,) or furohuwdN↓, (IDrd, O,) a boy, or youth, (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA) not a man, (IDrd, O,) plump (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA) in body, (TA,) and beautiful (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA) in face; (TA;) as also farohadN↓: (Ḳ:) and furohudN and farohadN↓ signify a boy, or youth, that has nearly attained to puberty. (O. [See also falohadN and fawohadN.])

Also, i. e. the first and second, (L, Ḳ,) or furohuwdN↓, which is of the dial. of Azd, (O,) The whelp of a lion; (O, L, Ḳ;) of the dial. of 'Omán: the pl. [of furohuwdN↓, or] of furohudN, accord. to Kr, is faraAhiydN; but ISd distrusts his authority on a matter of this kind. (L.)
furohuwdN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
Also A young mountain-kid. (L, Ḳ.)
And [the pl.] faraAhiydu signifies Young lambs or kids. (O, Ḳ.)
mufarohadN A fat boy or youth. (TA.)
[2. fr-I Aljub-apa, inf. n. taforiyapN, He furred, or lined with fur, the garment called jub-ap: see the pass. part. n., below.]
4. AfrI He was, or became, abundant in cattle, or other property: like OavoraI. (M in art. vrw. [See farowapN, last sentence.])
8. AftrI farowFA He wore farow [i. e. fur]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [and so, app., AftrI alone: see mufotarK, below.]

farowN signifies A certain thing that is worn; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also farowapN↓: (Mṣb:) each of these is a word of well-known meaning: (M:) [but the former is properly a coll. gen. n., and farowapN↓ is its n. un.; agreeably with what here follows:] Alfarowu is well known [as being fur]; and farowapN↓ is the appellation applied when it is [a furred garment] like the jub-ip: (Lth, T:) and signifies also a skin, but not unless having upon it wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair,] or wool: (T:) [in general,] this latter word signifies, (Ḳ, TA,) and some say the former also, (TA,) a kind of garment, well known, (Ḳ, TA,) lined with the skins of various species of animals, the most highly esteemed whereof is the sam-awr [or sable], tanned, and sewed together; this garment being worn for preservation from the cold: (TA:) firaMCN is the pl. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA) of mult., and the pl. of pauc. is OaforK: so says Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee. (TA.)

hom.sense: farowapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

Also The scalp, or skin of the head: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or farowapu Alr-aOosi signifies the scalp, or skin of the head, with the hair thereof, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) of a man, and of other than man: (M:) or the upper part of the head: (M, TA:) and one says, Darabahu EalaI Oum-i farowatihi meaning [He struck him upon] his haAmap [crown,, &c.]. (TA.) [Hence,] it is metaphorically applied, in a trad., to ‡ The skin of the face. (TA.)
And ‡ A woman's [head-covering such as is called] ximaAr, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) or [such as is called] qinaAE; occurring in a trad.; (Mgh, TA;) metaphorically applied thereto. (Mgh.)
And † A crown, such as is worn by a king: (Z, Ḳ,* TA:) [said to be] so called because made of skins. (TA.)
And A [garment of the kind called] jub-ap of which the two sleeves have been tucked up. (Ḳ.)
And The half of a [garment such as is called] kisaMC made of the soft hair of camels; (Ḳ, TA;) now known by the appellation of jbp [evidently a mistranscription, app. for xib-ap, q. v.]. (TA.)

And A [bag such as is termed] wafoDap [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,) [i. e.] like the xariyTap, made of skin, (TA,) in which the beggar puts his alms. (Ḳ, TA.) And hence, (TA,) cuw Alfarowap means The beggar. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A portion of herbage collected together and dry. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Waste, or uncultivated, land, having in it no herbage (T, Ḳ) and no baraX [or maculæ, or spots differing in colour from the rest]. (T.)

Oabuw farowapK signifies The bal-uwT [here meaning chestnut, which is called in Egypt Abw frwp in the present day]; of the dial. of Egypt: it is thus called because within its husk is what resembles the soft hair of camels. (TA.)

entry.sense: far-aMCN A manufacturer of firaMC [i. e. furs, or furred garments]:
and A seller thereof. (TA.)
jub-apN mufar-aApN [A furred jb-p;] a [garment of the kind called] jb-p upon which is a farowap [or fur, i. e., that is lined therewith].
mufotarK [act. part. n. of 8]. AlmufotariI laA yajida Albaroda [The wearer of fur will not feel the cold] is a saying of the Arabs. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. farowaza see in art. frz.

hom.sense: 1. faraAhu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yaforiyhi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. faroIN, (Ḳ,) He slit it, or cut it lengthwise, ill, or improperly; or well, or properly; as also fr-Ahu↓ and AfrAhu↓ [both relating to both of the foregoing explanations]: (Ḳ:) or he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper; as also fr-Ahu↓: or, accord. to the sound lexicologists, the former has this meaning: but AfrI↓ signifies he slit, or cut lengthwise, and made good, or proper: (M:) or AfrAhu↓ (M, Ḳ) signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) he made it good, or proper: or he ordered [another] to make it so: (M, Ḳ:) as though he removed from it unsoundness, or imperfection: but some say that this signifies he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper: and when you mean he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper, you say faraAhu, inf. n. faroIN: (M:) [thus, accord. to J,] faraI, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he cut a thing in order to make it good, or proper: (Ṣ:) or he cut a skin, or hide, in a good, or proper, manner: (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb:) and AfrI↓ he cut it in a bad, or an improper, manner: (Ks, Ṣ:) or this signifies he slit much, in a bad, or an improper, manner: and AfrI Aljiloda, accord. to Aṣ, he rent, tore, or slit, the skin, and made holes in it, and spoiled it: and AfrI signifies also he slit a thing (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) of any kind; (M; [as also fr-Ahu↓:]) thus you say, AfrI AlOawdaAja he slit the AwdAj [or external jugular veins], (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb,) and made what was in them, of the blood, to come forth; (T, Mgh, Mṣb;) and in like manner one says of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a jul-ap [or receptacle for dates, made of palm-leaves woven together]; (T;) or he cut the AwdAj: (Ṣ:) IAạr alone mentions faraI OawodaAjahu and AfrAhA↓: (M:) [but it is also said that] faraI signifies he cut a niTaE [or the like]: (Ḳ in art. xlq: [see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of that art.; also cited in the T after the first of the explanations here following, and in the M after the second thereof:]) or faraI, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he measured, and worked, or manufactured, and made good, or proper, a thing, such as a sandal, or a niTaE [q. v.], or a water-skin, and the like: (T:) or he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper: (M:) and he measured and manufactured a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he sewed, and made well, or properly, a mzAdp: (T:) [it is said that] the difference between AlUiforaQCu↓ and AlfaroIu is this, that the former signifies the cutting so as to render bad, or improper, and the slitting like as the slaughterer and the wild beast slit [their victims]; and the latter, the cutting so as to make good, or proper, like the act of cutting of the sewer of the hide, or of leather: but faraI sometimes occurs in the sense of AfrI: (Mgh:) one says, Oaforayotu↓ raOosahu, meaning I split, or clave, his head with a sword; like Oaforarotuhu: (Yz, T, &c. in art. fr:) and AfrI AljuroHa he slit the wound: (T:) and AfrI Alc-iYobu baTona AlX-aApi [the wolf slit, or rent, the belly of the sheep, or goat]: (Ṣ:) and one says, qado Oaforayota wamaA farayota i. e. thou hast done ill, or improperly, and hast not done well, or properly. (A, TA.)
faraAhu, aor. as above, [and so the inf. n.,] is sometimes metonymically used [as meaning ‡ He slaughtered him, or butchered him; i. e.] as denoting vehemence, or excess, in slaying. (TA.)
And it means also † He cut him with censure, or satire: (TA:) and AfrI↓ means he blamed, or censured, a man. (M, Ḳ.)
And you say, farayotu AlOaroDa ‡ I traversed, or crossed, (lit. travelled and cut,) the land, or country; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) inf. n. as above. (TA.)

huwa yaforiI AlfariI-a↓ means † He effects what is wonderful in his deed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) maA yaforiI fariy-ahu↓ OaHadN, thus, with teshdeed [to the I in fryh] as related by AʼObeyd, is said of a courageous man [as meaning No one does his deed, or the like]: but it is said [by Kh] to be correctly faroyahu, [as an inf. n.,] without teshdeed. (M. [See, however, what follows.]) They say, tarakotuhu yaforiI AlfariI-a↓, meaning [I left him] doing well, or excellently, in a deed, or in watering: [an explanation relating to what here follows:] the Prophet said, respecting ʼOmar, whom he saw in a dream drawing water at a well with a great bucket, falamo Oara Eaboqariy-FA yaforiI fariy-ahu↓ [And I have not seen a chief of a people do his deed,, &c.]: (T:) or, as some relate it, he said faroyahu: (TA:) [but] AʼObeyd says, this is like thy saying yaEomalu Eamalahu and yaquwlu qawolahu; and Fr cited to us [as an ex.]
qado kunoti taforiyna bihi Alfariy-aA↓
meaning [Verily] thou didst multiply and magnify thy words respecting it: (T: and in like manner this hemistich [which shows, by the measure, that Alfariy-aA cannot be here a mistake for AlfaroyaA,] is expl. in the Ṣ:) it is said that fariI-↓ thus used is of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from faraI signifying “he cut” [or “cut lengthwise” or “slit”] a hide, or leather; (Ḥar p. 257; [where see more;]) [and this assertion is corroborated by the fact that] one says of a man strenuous, or vigorous, in an affair, and strong, tarakotuhu yaforiI AlfariI-a↓ wayaqud-u [lit. I left him slitting, or cutting, the slit, or cut, thing, and shaping]. (T.)
faraI is also synonymous with AftrI: see the latter, in two places.
faraI Albaroqu, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies The lightning shone, or glistened, or shone with flickering light, and continued, in the sky. (T, TA.)

fariIa, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yaforaI, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. farFI, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, but omitted in the CK,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; syn. bahita, (T,) and dahiXa, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and taHay-ara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and baTira: (Skr, on the verse here following:) El-Aạlam El-Hudhalee says,
wafariytu mino fazaEK falaA
OaromiI walaA wad-aEotu SaAHibo
[And I became confounded,, &c., by reason of fright, so that I did not shoot an arrow, nor bade I farewell to a friend]: (T, M:) or, accord. to Aṣ, fariIa, aor. yaforaI, signifies he looked, and knew not what he should do: (T:) and fariytu signifies also I wondered; from AlfariI-u↓ meaning “that which is wonderful.” (Skr, on the verse above-cited.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first quarter, in three places.
4: see 1, former half, in seven places:
and also {1} in the latter half, near the middle of the paragraph.

5. tfr-I It became slit, or cut lengthwise; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AnfrI↓; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) both said of a skin, (M,) or of a thing: (Ṣ:) or it became much slit, or rent; said of the sewing of a leathern water-skin. (T.) And tfr-I Eanohu vawobuhu His garment became much slit, or rent, from him. (T.) And tfr-t AlEayonu ‡ The spring of water burst forth: (Ḳ, TA:) or tfr-t AlOaroDu biAlEuyuwni ‡ The earth, or ground, burst with the springs. (Ṣ, M, A, TA.)

[Hence,] the saying of Kabeesah Ibn-Jábir,
tafar-aI bayoDuhaA Ean-aA fakun-aA
baniI AlOajolaAdi minohaA waAlr-imaAli
i. e. † Its eggs (the pronoun in byDhA denoting the earth) burst from us [so as to disclose us], so that we were the sons of the hard tracts thereof and of the soft tracts, or plains, [or of the sands,] means only their numerousness, and the wide extent of their districts. (Ḥam p. 341.)
And tfr-I All-ayolu Eano SuboHihi ‡ [The night became distinct, as though cleft, from its dawn]. (TA.)
7: see the next preceding paragraph {5}.

8. AftrIkacibFA He forged, or fabricated, a lie, or falsehood; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) you say, AftrI Ealayohi kacibFA [he forged against him a lie]; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and faraI↓ kacibFA signifies the same, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaforiI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. faroIN; (M;) and this verb likewise is followed by Ealayohi: (Mṣb:) faraI↓ in this sense is mentioned as said by Lth; others saying AftrI. (T.) AftrI is used in the Ḳur in relation also to the attributing a copartner to God: thus in the saying [in iv. 51], wamano yuXoriko biQll-ehi faqadi QfotariI UivmFA EaZiymFA [And whoso attributeth a copartner to God, hath devised an enormous sin]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
faroyapN Clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises. (M, Ḳ, TA. [AlHalobapu in the CK is a mistake for Aljalabapu.])
firoyapN A lie, or falsehood; (Ṣ,* M, Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) a subst. from AifotaraI: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and meaning [also] a defamation: (Mgh:) pl. firFI. (TA.)
And An affair, or a case, of great magnitude or moment or gravity. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: friI-N Slit, or cut lengthwise; applied to a skin (jilodN): and so fariy-apN [app. as applied to a qirobap or the like, as being fem. of fariI-N]. (M, TA.)
And A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]; (M, Ḳ;) as though it were slit; (M;) as also fariy-apN. (Ḳ.)

And A thing forged, or fabricated; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) thus [or rather as hence meaning unknown, or unheard of,] in the saying, laqadojiYoti XayoYFA fariy-FA, in the Ḳur [xix. 28], (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. [Thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange: (Bḍ:) or a thing of great magnitude or moment or gravity; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and thus it is said to mean in the phrase above cited: (Ṣ, TA:) or wonderful; (T, TA;) thus as expl. by Er-Rághib; (TA;) and thus it is also said to mean in that phrase. (T, TA.)
See also 1, latter half, in eight places.
Also, applied to a man, A forger, or fabricator, of lies; and so miforFI↓. (Lḥ, M, TA.)
And Milk of the time when it is milked. (Ḳ.)

And they say, AlfariI-a AlfariI-a, meaning AlEajalapa AlEajalapa [i. e. Haste: haste: used in an imperative sense; as inf. ns. are often thus used; but they are] both like ganiI- [in measure]: mentioned by Ṣgh. (TA.)

entry.sense: OaforaI AlfiraI occurs in a trad. as meaning The most lying of lies: AlfiraI is the pl. of firoyapN. (TA.)
mifor-aI: see fariI-N.
maforiy-apN A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] made in a good, or proper, manner; well made. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faz-a, (A, O, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yafozizu}, inf. n. faz-N, (TA,) He (a gazelle) was, or became, frightened, or afraid. (A, O, Ḳ.)
faz-a qalobuhu His heart heaved by reason of fear. (O.)
faz-a Eanohu He (a man, O) turned away from him. (A, O, Ḳ.) And He separated himself from him, and became alone. (A, O, Ḳ.)
faz-a,, aor. _i {yafozizu}, inf. n. fazaAzapN and fuzuwzapN, He (a man, O) became excited with ardour, or eagerness. (O, Ḳ.)

faz-a fulaAnFA Eano mawoDiEihi, (A, O,* Ḳ,) inf. n. faz-N, (O,) He disturbed, removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place: (A, O,* Ḳ:) or he frightened, and disturbed, or removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away: (IDrd, TA:) and [in like manner] Oafaz-ahu↓ he frightened him; (Ḳ;) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, he disturbed or disquieted him; (TA;) or he frightened him, and disturbed or disquieted or unsettled him, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away. (Ṣ, O.*) [See also 10.]

faz-a, aor. _i {yafozizu}, inf. n. faziyzN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and faz-N, (TA,) said of a wound, It became moist, and flowed, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) discharging its contents; and so faS-a: and in like manner it is said of water [app. as meaning it oozed forth]: (TA:) and of sweat, meaning It exuded; and so faS-a. (TA in art. fS.)

entry.sense: 2. fz-zhu He (a man) rendered him powerful, or strong, and made him to overcome. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
4: see 1, latter half.
8. Aftz- He (a man, O) overcame; (Ḳ;) or was, or became, powerful, or strong, and overcame: (O:) and Abtz- and Abtc- signify the same: so in the Nawádir. (O, TA.)

10. Astfz-hu It (fear, Ṣ, A, O) excited him to lightness and unsteadiness; unsettled him. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.) waQsotafozizo mani QsotaTaEta minohumo biSawotika, in the Ḳur [xvii. 66], is expl. by Fr as meaning And excite thou to lightness and unsteadiness, or unsettle thou, when thou canst, with thy voice. (O, TA.) And in like manner, waUino kaAduwA layasotafiz-uwnaka mina AlOaroDi, in the same [xvii. 78], is expl. by him (O, TA) as meaning, And verily they were near to unsettling thee from the land: (TA:) but some say the meaning is, they were near to frightening thee so as to excite thee to promptness of flight from the land. (O, TA.) And Astfz-hu Eano raOoyihi He incited him, or excited him, to ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct, and levity, or unsteadiness, so as to make him swerve from his right sentiment, opinion, or judgment; like Aisotaxaf-ahu En rOyh. (Az and TA in art. xf.)
He incited him, or excited him, to be promptly obedient and submissive to him and to that which he desired of him; like Astxf-hu. (Ksh in xliii. 54.)

He expelled him (Jel in xvii. 105, and Ḳ) from the land, (Jel,) or from his abode, and disturbed, or disquieted, or unsettled, him, (Ḳ,) so as to excite him to lightness and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 1, latter half.]
He, or it, deceived him, or beguiled him, so as to cast him into destruction. (TA.)
He slew him: so the verb is expl. by some in the Ḳur xvii. 78, quoted above. (TA.)
faz-N A light, or an active, man. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.)
And The offspring of the cow; (Ṣ;) [meaning,] of the wild cow: (O, Ḳ:) because of its restlessness: (TA:) pl. OafozaAzN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
faz-apN A leap with disquietude [or fright]. (TA.)
qaEada musotafaz-FA [so in a copy of the Ṣ, but without the vowel-signs: in two other copies of the same, musotawofizFA, which belongs to art. wfz:] He sat in an uneasy posture. (Ṣ.)

farasN musotafiz-N lilowavobi waAlEadowi [so in two copies of the Ṣ, in art. Tmr; in the O, in that art., musotafiz-u Alwavobi waAlEadowi; probably a mistake for musotafaz-; app. meaning, A horse in a state of excitement to leap and run.]

hom.sense: 1. fazara, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yafozuru}, (M, O, TA,) or _i, (Mṣb,) inf. n. fazorN, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,) He rent, or slit, a garment, or piece of cloth: (Ḳ:) he dissundered (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb) the same. (Ṣ, O.)
He split, slit, or cracked, a thing. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
He struck a man's nose with a thing so as to split it. (O,* TA.)
He struck one with a stick, or staff: (TA:) or he struck him with a stick, or staff, on his back, (Ḳ, TA,) so as to break it. (TA.)
He separated, disunited, sundered, or dispersed, a thing. (TA.)
He separated, or divided, a thing from another thing. (TA.)

He broke [a thing]. (Sh, O, Mṣb.) Sh says, I was in the desert, and, seeing some small round tents (qibaAb) pitched, I said to an Arab of the desert, “To whom belong these qbAb” and he answered, libaniI fazaArapa fazara Qll-ehu Zuhuwrahumo: whereupon I said to him, “What meanest thou by it?” and he answered, “[To Benoo-Fezárah:] may God break [their backs].” (TA.)
He crumbled, or broke into small pieces, a jul-ap [or round piece of camel's or similar dung]; as also fz-r↓, (TA,) and Afzr↓. (O, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AlHul-ap is put for Aljul-ap.])
See also 5.
Also, as implied in the Ḳ, but correctly fazira, aor. _a {yafozaru}, inf. n. fazarN [q. v.], He was, or became, such as is termed Oafozar [expl. below]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. faz-ara: see 1, last signification but one.
4: see 1, last signification but one.

5. tfz-r It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit; (Ḳ;) as also Anfzr↓; (O,* Ḳ;) and fazara↓, inf. n. fuzuwrN; (Mṣb; [but see fazarN, below;]) and so the like thereof; (Mṣb;) and the same is said of a wall: (TA:) and it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became dissundered, ragged, tattered, or shabby, and old and worn out; (Ṣ, TA;) as also Anfzr↓. (TA.)
7: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: fazorN inf. n. of the trans. v. fazara. (Mṣb.)
[And app. used as a simple subst., having for its pl. fuzuwrN: see fizarN.]
[Also] A man possessing little, or no, good, or goodness; or little, or no, wealth; like nazorN. (AZ, TA in art. nzr.)

fizorN A flock of sheep, or herd of goats: (Ṣ, O:) or a flock of sheep from ten to forty: (AZ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or from three to ten; thus in the copies of the Ḳ; but in the L, to twenty: (TA:) and two, and more: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and hence, (Ṣ, O,) Alfizoru was a surname of Saạd Ibn-ZeydMenáh: he came to the mawosim [or fair, and place of meeting, app. of the pilgrims,] with some goats, and allowed them to be taken as spoil, saying, “Whoso takes of them one, it shall be his, but a fizor [i. e. a pair or more] of them shall not be taken;” fizorN here meaning two and more: whence the prov., laA Mtiyka miEozaI Alfizori, meaning [I will not come to thee] until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together; and [that means never, for] those goats will never become gathered together: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to ISd, this surname was given to him because he said to his sons, one after another, “Pasture ye these goats,” and they were incompliant to him; so he called to the people, “Collect yourselves together;” and they did so; and he said, “Take ye them as spoil; but I do not allow to any one more than one;” therefore they separated them at once, and they became scattered in the country: this was the origin of the prov.: and one of their provs. relating to leaving a thing undone is the saying, laA OafoEalu calika miEozaI Alfizori [I will not do that until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together.] (TA.) Accord. to AO, (Ṣ, O, TA,) fizorN means The kid (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) itself: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and one says, laAOafoEaluhu maA nazaA fizorN [I will not do it as long as a kid leaps]. (TA.)

And The male young one of the namir [or leopard]: (TA:) or the male young one of the [beast of prey called] babor [q. v.], (O, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, bayor,]) as is said in the T, and likewise in the Tekmileh: (TA:) and fizorapN signifies the female young one thereof; (O, Ḳ, TA;) or, as some say, the sister thereof: (TA:) and fazaArapN↓ signifies the female of the babor; (O, Mṣb, TA;) thus says IAạr, (O,) [and] thus is said in the T: (TA:) or the mother of the babor is called fzArp; and also the female of the namir; (Ḳ, TA;) thus says IAạr. (TA.)
Also The OSol [or origin,, &c.,] (O, Ḳ) of a thing. (O.)

And A small thing, (O, Ḳ,) like a naboxap [or blister], in the root of the thigh, (O,) below the extremity of the pubes, resembling a gud-ap [or ganglion], from an ulcer that comes forth in a man, (O, Ḳ,) or from a wound. (O.)

fazarN an inf. n. [of which the verb, accord. to a general rule, is fazira], A garment's being old and worn out; and rent, or slit. (KL. [See also 5, with which the verb fazara, inf. n. fuzuwrN, is mentioned in a similar sense.])
And [app. The being open, or wide, or broad,] meaning in Pers. frAx Xdn. (KL.)
Also The being such as is termed Oafozar [expl. below]. (Ṣ. [See 1, last sentence.])

entry.sense: fizarN Slits, rents, or fissures: (Ḳ:) but this word perhaps occurred to the author of the Ḳ mistranscribed; for it is said in the L that fuzuwrN [a pl. of which the sing. is app. fazorN, originally an inf. n.,] signifies slits, rents, or fissures, and clefts, or cracks. (TA.)

hom.sense: fuzorapN: see faAzirN.
Also A great protuberance upon the back, or upon the chest. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: fazaArapN: see fizorN, last quarter of the paragraph.

hom.sense: faAzirN A wide road; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also fuzorapN↓: (O, Ḳ:) or a wide and conspicuous road: or, accord. to ISh, a road that passes over the [eminences termed] nijaAf [pl. of najafN] and the [hills, or small mountains termed] quwr [pl. of qaArapN], and cleaves them as though it made furrows upon their heads: you say, OaxaconaAAlfaAzira and OaxaconaATariyqa AlfaAziri, meaning [We took] the road that made a track upon the heads and the base of the mountains. (TA.) And faAzirapN↓ [or TariyqN faAzirapN] signifies A road taking its course in a tract of sand amid sands that are compact and cleaving to the ground, (Ḳ, TA,) and soft; appearing like an extended, long, natural cleft in the ground: (TA:) the same meaning is also assigned to faArizapN. (Ḳ * and TA in art. frz.)
Also A species of ants, (O,) black ants, (Ḳ,) in which is a redness: (O, Ḳ:) mentioned also among words of which the final radical is z [as being called faArizN]. (TA.)
And The round black thing [app. a species of animalcule] found in [dried] dates. (O.)

entry.sense: faAzirapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oafozaru and mafozuwrN↓ A man humpbacked; (Ṣ, O;) having a great protuberance upon his back; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or having such a protuberance upon his chest: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, the former signifies the same as OaqoEasu [having a protuberant breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back]. (O. [See also Oaforazu.])
And [the fem. of the former] fazoraMCu A female, (Ḳ,) or girl, or young woman, (TA,) full of fat and flesh: or that has nearly attained to puberty. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: mafozuwru AlOanofi A man having his nose struck with a thing so as to be split. (TA.)
See also Oafozaru.

1. faziEa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and fazaEa, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafozaEu}, of the former verb, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the latter also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. fazaEN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the former verb, (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb, TA,) and [of the latter verb] fazoEN [fazaEFA in the CḲ being a mistake for fazoEFA] and fizoEN (Ḳ, TA,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, frightened, or terrified; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so tfz-E↓: (TA in art. rwE:) you say, faziEa minohu he feared him, or it; or was, or became, in fear,, &c., of him, or it: (MA, Mṣb, TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, fazaEN signifies a shrinking, and an aversion, that comes upon a man, from a thing causing fear or fright; and is a kind of jazaE [q. v.]; and one should not say faziEotu mina Qll-ehi like as one says xifotu minohu: or, as Mbr says, in the “Kámil,” its primary signification is the fearing, or being in fear or afraid or frightened or terrified: then, by a metonymical application, it signifies a people's going forth quickly to repel an enemy, or the like, that has come upon them suddenly; and this meaning has become [conventionally regarded as] proper. (TA.)

fazaEN signifies also The seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour: (Az, Ḳ, TA:) and the aiding, or succouring; (Az, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) this latter being likewise a signification of UifozaAEN↓: (Ṣ, O:) an ex. of the former word (Ṣ, O, TA) in the latter sense (O, TA) occurs in the saying of the Prophet to the Ansár, Uin-akumo latakovuruwna Einoda AlfazaEi wataqil-uwna Einoda AlT-amaEi [Verily ye are many on the occasion of aiding, or succouring, and ye are few on the occasion of coveting, or greed]; (Ṣ, O, TA;) or in this saying the implied meaning may be, on the occasion of men's betaking themselves to you in fear (Einoda fazaEi Aln-aAsi Uilayokumo) in order that ye may aid or succour them [which is virtually the same as their seeking your aid or succour]: (TA:) thus [it is said] fazaEN has two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) and both of these significations are expressed by the verb faziEa: (O:) you say faziEa Uilayohi and faziEa minohu; (Ḳ in continuation of what has been last cited therefrom above, and TA; [app. meant to indicate that both of these phrases signify he sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, of him; and he aided, or succoured, him; or that the former phrase has the former signification; and the latter phrase, the latter signification; though accord. to the TḲ, both phrases have the former signification, and the former phrase has also the latter signification;]) but you should not say fazaEahu, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. like manaEahu: (TA:) [or] from AlfazaEu as signifying “fear,” or “fright,” you say faziEotu Uilayoka and faziEotu minoka; [app. meant to indicate that the former phrase signifies I betook myself to thee in fear, which is a meaning thereof well known, and nearly agreeing with an explanation of the verb followed by Uilayohi which will be found below in this paragraph; and that the latter phrase signifies I feared thee, or I was, or became, in fear,, &c., of thee, the only meaning, of this phrase, for which I find any explicit authority, and one for which I have given three authorities in the first sentence of this art.;] but you should not say faziEotuka: (Ṣ: [thus in my copies, faziEotuka, not fazaEotuka:]) or faziEa Uilayohimo signifies he sought, or demanded, of them, aid, or succour; and fazaEahumo and faziEahumo signify he aided, or succoured, them, syn. OagaAvahumo [in the CK AaEAnahumo] and naSarahumo, like OafozaEahumo↓: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to IB, faziEotuhu meaning Oagavotuhu is originally faziEotu lh [primarily signifying I feared, or became in fear, &c., for him]; then the l was dropped; for one says faziEotuhu and faziEotu lahu: (TA:) or faziEa, like fariHa, signifies AinotaSara: (Ḳ: [thus in the copies of the Ḳ, and hence in the TA, app. a mistranscription for AisotanoSara, he sought, or demanded, aid, or aid against an enemy:]) and faziEa Uilayohi he betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, or preservation, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of fear, or fright, (Ṣ,) and sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, by him, or it; whence, in a trad. respecting the eclipse of the sun, faQfozaEuwAUilaI AlS-alaAp i. e. Then betake yourselves,, &c., to prayer, and seek, or demand, aid, or succour, by it. (TA.)

faziEa mino nawomihi means He became roused from his sleep; (O, Ḳ;) because he who is roused is not free from some fear, or fright: occurring in a trad. in this sense. (O.) And one says, faziEotu bimajiIoCi fulaAnK, meaning I prepared [or roused] myself by reason of the coming of such a one, by a change of state, or condition, like as the sleeper passes from the state of sleeping to that of waking. (TA.)
fazaEahu in the phrase faAzaEahu↓ fafazaEahu means He exceeded him in fear, or fright. (TA.)
fuziEa Eano quluwbihimo: see the next paragraph {2}.

entry.sense: 2. fz-Ehu: see 4.
[It also app. signifies He made a fearful event, or fearful events, to befall him: see its pass. part. n. below.]

faz-aEa Eanohu He removed from him fear, or fright: (O, in two places:) it is implied by the context in the Ḳ that AfzE↓ Enh has this meaning; but in the O and other lexicons it is faz-aEa. (TA.) And fuz-iEa Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoziyEN, (Ḳ,) Fear, or fright, was removed from him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It is said in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 22], Hat-aI UicaAfuz-iEa Eano quluwbihimo, meaning Until, when fear, or fright, shall be removed from their hearts: (Ṣ, O:) this is the common reading: another reading is faz-aEa, i. e. faz-aEa Qll-ehu: and El-Ḥasan reads fuziEa↓: and he says that in this reading and the first, the prep. with its noun are [regarded as supplying the place of the agent and therefore virtually] in the nom. case, as in the phrase siyra Eani Albaladi: (TA:) some read fur-iga [q. v.]: (O and TA in art. frg:) and ʼEesà Ibn-ʼOmar is related to have read UicaA QforanoqaEa. (TA in art. frqE.)
3. fAzEhu fafazaEahu [He vied with him in fear, or fright,] and he exceeded him therein. (TA. See 1, last sentence but one.)

4. AfzEhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UifozaAEN, (Ṣ, O,) He made him to fear, or to be afraid; frightened him; or terrified him; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also fz-Ehu↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoziyEN. (Ṣ, O.) And you say, yufozaEu minohu [One is made to fear, or be afraid of, or is frightened, or terrified, at, it, or him], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and mino Oajolihi [on account of him, or for the sake of him], (O, Ḳ,) and bihi [by him, or by means of him]. (O.)
[Hence,] He housed him from his sleep. (Ḳ, TA. [See 1, last quarter.])
Also He aided, or succoured, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 1, former half; and again, in the latter half.
See also 2.
5: see 1, first sentence.
fazaEN Fear, or fright: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) originally (Ṣ) an inf. n.; but notwithstanding this, (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ,) sometimes, (Ṣ, O,) having a pl., which is OafozaAEN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
[And, as seems to be indicated by an explanation of mufaz-aEN (q. v.), A fearful event: pl. as above.]

faziEN Fearing; being afraid or frightened or terrified; (Er-Rághib, MA, Mṣb, TA;) thus in a verse cited voce ZunobuwbN; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and mufaAziEN↓ is syn. therewith: (O, Ḳ:) and one says also rajulN faAziEN↓, pl. fazaEapN; and mafozuwEN↓; meaning a man put in fear; made afraid; frightened, or terrified. (TA.) And In a state of disquiet, disturbance, or agitation: whence an extraordinary reading, of four readers, in the Ḳur xxviii. 9, [i. e. faziEFA] for faArigFA, relating to the heart of the mother of Moses, meaning in a state of disquiet,, &c., almost quitting its pericardium. (TA.) It has no broken pl.; its only pl. being faziEuwna. (TA.)

Also Seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour; and Ṣgh thus explains it [in the O] as used in the verse above mentioned; but Er-Rághib says that this is an explanation of the intended meaning, not of the literal signification: (TA:) and it has also the contr. meaning, aiding, or succouring; thus being trans., though of the measure faEilN; but it may be altered from faAziEN↓, like as HacirN is [said to be] altered from HaAcirN. (IB, TA,)
fazoEapN: see fazaEapN.

fuzoEapN A man whom one is made to fear, of whom one is made afraid, or at whom one is frightened: (O, Ḳ:) [like mafozaEapN as expl. by Lth and others:] and by whom, or by means of whom, one is made afraid, or frightened. (O.)

fazaEapN sing. of fazaEaAt in the phrase fazaEaAtu Alr-uwEi [app. meaning The fears, or frights, of the heart]. (TA. [The sing., as well as the pl., is there said to be thus, biAlt-aHoriyk; but if the former be, as I think it is, an inf. n. un., it should by rule be fazoEapN↓.])
fuzaEapN One who fears men, or is frightened at them: (Ḳ:) or one who fears, or is frightened, much, or often; (O;) [and] so faz-aAEapN↓. (TA. [But see what next follows.])
faz-aAEapN One who makes men to fear, or frightens them, much, or often. (O, Ḳ.) See also fuzaEapN.
faAzigN: see faziEN, in two places.

mafozaEN i. q. malojaOo [as meaning A refuge, i. e. a place to which, or a person to whom, one betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation,] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) on the occasion of the befalling of an affliction or a calamity; (TA;) applied to a sing. and a pl. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and a dual (Ṣ, O) and a masc. and a fem.; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) one says, fulaAnN mafozaEN liln-aAsi Such a one is a refuge to men when an event comes upon them suddenly, and humaAmafozaEN liln-aAsi, and humo mafozaEN, &c.; (Ṣ, O;) and mafozaEapN↓ is the same in signification and in its applications; (Ḳ;) expl. by IF as signifying a place to which one who is in fear, or frightened, betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation: (TA:) or mafozaEN signifies one of whom aid, or succour, is sought, or demanded: (Ḳ:) and mafozaEapN↓, [a cause of fear or fright; being a word of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN; i. e.] a thing that one is made to fear, or at which one is frightened; (Ṣ;) or a person whom one is made to fear, or at whom one is frightened; [like fuzoEapN;] or on account of whom, or for the sake of whom, one is made to fear, or is frightened: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) you say, fulaAnN lanaA mafozaEapN [Such a one is to us a person whom we are made to fear,, &c.], and in like manner you say of a female, and of a pl. number. (O.)
mafozaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

mufaz-aEN Cowardly; (Fr, O, Ḳ;) as being made to fear, or to be frightened at, everything: (Fr, O:) and courageous; (Fr, O, Ḳ;) as being one the like of whom fearful events are made to befall (bimivolihi tunozalu AlOafozaAEu). (Fr, O. [But what here follows suggests another reason, and I think a better, for the latter meaning.]) mufaz-aEapN applied by ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib as an epithet to his Aisot, in replying to a threat of El-Ash-'ath, who had said to him, lawo danawota laOuDar-iTan-aka, means Secure from being overcome by fear, or fright, and [therefore] not lax so as to break wind [in consequence of fear]; being from faz-aEa Eanohu meaning “he removed fear, or fright, from him;” or it may be for the same reason as that for which mufaz-aEN is applied to a courageous man. (O.)
mafozuwEN: see faziEN, first sentence.
mufaAziEN: see faziEN, first sentence.
fisofisapN i. q. fiSofiSapN, i. e. raTobapN: (Ḳ:) the second of these is more known than the first; both of which are arabicized, from the Persian UisoPisot [or Uisofisot]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. fasaOahu: see 2.

Also, (M, Ḳ,) or fasaOahu biAlEaSaA, (AZ, O,) aor. _a {yafosaOu}, inf. n. fasoCN, (M,) He struck, or beat, (AZ, M, O, Ḳ,) him, (O,) or his back, (AZ, M, Ḳ,) with the staff, or stick; (AZ, M, O, Ḳ;) as also tfs-Ohu↓, (Ḳ,) or tfs-Ohu bAlESA. (O.)
And fasaOa fulaAnFA Eanohu He restrained, withheld, or debarred, such a one from him. (O,* Ḳ.)
fasiYa, aor. _a {yafosaOu}, [inf. n., app., fasaON, q. v. infrà,] He was, or became, such as is termed OafosaOu [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

5. tfs-O, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) It became ragged, or dissundered, (Ṣ, O,) and worn out: (Ṣ:) like tqD-O, or tfS-O: (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ: the latter in the L:) or it became rent. (M, O.)
tfs-O fiyhimo, (Ḳ,) or bihimo, (O,) said of a disease, It spread among them, (O, Ḳ,) and became common among them: (TA:) like tfX-O. (O, Ḳ.)
tfs-O: see 1.

entry.sense: 6. tfAsO, and tfAsI, (M, O, TA,) He (a man) protruded (M, O, TA) his posteriors, (M,) or his back, (O,) or both. (TA.)
fasaON a subst. signifying The state of such as is termed OafosaOu [q. v.]: (M, TA:) or a hollowness, or incurvity, of the spine. (TA in art. fqO.) [See also 1, last sentence.]

OafosaOu i. q. Oabozaxu [i. e. Having a protuberant breast, or chest, and hollow back;, &c.]: or having a protuberant breast, or chest, and the lower part of the belly prominent: (M, Ḳ:) fem. fasaMCu: (M:) and (M, in the Ḳ “or”) he who, when he walks, is as though his posteriors were in pain (in the M tawojaEu; in some copies of the Ḳ tawaj-aEu [as though for tatawaj-aEu], and in some yrjE); as also mafosuwoCN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or he who, when he sits, cannot rise but with an effort: (O, Ḳ:) or whose spine enters into [or turns inwards between] his haunches. (Ḳ.)
mafosuwoCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fusotaAtN, also written fisotaAtN: see fusoTaATN.
fusotaATN, also written fisotaATN: see fusoTaATN, in art. fsT, to which it belongs; for the t is a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or for the [latter] s in fis-aATN. (M and TA in art. fsT.)

fusotuqN and fusotaqN, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter the more agreeable with the original, (O,) which is Pisotah, (O, Ḳ,) a Pers. word, (O,) for from this each is arabicized; (O, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) [The pistachio-nut, pistacia vera of Linn.;] a certain fruit; (O;) [in the Mṣb bql; perhaps a mistranscription for nql, i. e. naqolN, a certain fruit that is eaten with wine;] well known: (Ḳ:) said in a verse of Aboo-Nukheyleh to be mina Albuquwli: thus, and thus only, with b, the phrase is related: if it were mn Aln-uquwli, the mistake would be removed: (O:) Az says that the fstqp [which is the n. un.] is a fruit of a well-known tree: and AḤn says, “It has not come to my knowledge that it grows in the land of the Arabs:” (TA:) it is good for the liver, and the mouth of the stomach, and the colic, and the odour of the mouth. (Ḳ. [In the CK, Aln-ahakapi is put for Aln-akohapi.]) The vulgar pronounce the word with fet-ḥ [to the f, saying fasotuq: and many of them say fisotuq]. (Mṣb.)
vawobN fusotuqiI-N [meaning A garment of the colour of the fusotuq] is [thus] with damm [to the f and t]. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. fasuHa, (MA, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK fasaHa, a misprint,]) with damm, (Mṣb,) like karuma, (Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yafosuHu},] inf. n. fusaAHapN, (L,) or fasaAHapN [for which the former is app. a mistranscription] and fusoHapN, (MA,) It (a place) was, or became, spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; (MA, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AfsH↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tfs-H↓, and AnfsH↓. (Ḳ.)

fasaHa lahu, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafosaHu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. fasoHN (MA, Mṣb, TA) and fusuwHN; (TA;) as also tfs-H↓, (A, Ḳ,) and AfsH↓; (A;) He made room, or ample room, for him, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fiI Almajolisi (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb) in the sitting-place, or in the assembly. (MA.) You say, tafas-aHuwA↓ fiI Almajolisi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) and tafaA saHuwA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Make ye room, or ample space, [in the sitting-place, or in the assembly,] syn. tawas-aEuwA: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) both of these verbs have nearly the same signification: [each may be rendered, but the latter more properly, make ye room, or ample space, one for another:] the latter occurs, accord. to the reading of El-Ḥasan, and the former accord. to that of others, in the Ḳur lviii. 12. (Fr, TA.)
And AifosaHo Ean-iI Remove thou, withdraw, or retire to a distance, from me. (Ksh and Bḍ in lviii. 12.)

fasoHN [as inf. n. of fasaHa] also signifies The making wide steps; and so fayosaHaI. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] AifosaHi AlxuTaI, said by an Arab of the Desert, of the Benoo-'Okeyl, to one who was sewing for him a water-skin, and mentioned in the T, as heard by its author, meaning † Make wide the spaces between each two punctures of the needle, lest the punctures should rend. (L.)
And fasaHa lahu AlOamiyru fiI Als-afari means The commander, or governor, wrote for him a fasoH [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. fs-H He made a place spacious, roomy, wide, or ample. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1, first and second sentences.
5: see 1, in three places.
[tfs-H also signifies He expatiated, or ranged at large: and he had ample room or scope: see mutafas-aHN.]
6: see 1, third sentence.
7: see 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] AnfsH muraAHuhumo [lit. The nightly resting-place of their camels was, or became, spacious,] means † their camels became numerous. (TA.)
And AnfsH Sadoruhu † His bosom became dilated [with joy]. (Ṣ, A.)
And AnfsH Tarofuhu † His eye had an unobstructed view, nothing hindering its seeing far. (L.)
Q. Q. 2. tafayosaHa: see tafayoHasa, in art. fHs.
fasoHN A writing like a jawaAz [or traveller's pass]. (Ḳ.) [See 1, last sentence.]
fusuHN: see fasiyHN, in three places.
fusoHapN Spaciousness, roominess, width, or ampleness; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) [particularly, or generally,] with respect to the ground. (L.) [In the MA it is mentioned as an inf. n. of fasuHa.]
And [Ample scope for action, &c.] in an affair. (Mṣb in art. rxw.) [And A state in which is ample scope for acting, &c.: see nafasN.]
AlfusoHataAni signifies The two spaces without hair on the two sides of the hair that grows immediately beneath the middle of the lower lip. (L.)

hom.sense: fusoHumN: see fasiyHN, in two places.
fulaAnN Qbonu fusoHumK is a phrase mentioned by Lḥ, thought by him to be from AlfusoHapu and AlAinofisaAHu, but the meaning is unknown. (L.)
Also The glans of the penis. (Ḳ in art. fsHm; where the word is mentioned again in the Ṣ likewise.)

entry.sense: fusaAHN: see the paragraph here following.

fasiyHN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fusaAHN↓, (Ḳ,) like TawiylN and TuwaAlN, (TA,) Spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; applied to a place; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also fusuHN↓ and fusoHumN↓: (Ḳ:) or fusuHN↓ signifies thus applied to a sitting-place: (Ṣ:) and fusoHumN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the m is augmentative, (Ṣ,) signifies (Ṣ, Ḳ) also (Ḳ) waAsiEu AlS-adori [meaning free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as does also fusuHN↓ [in the CK in this sense written fusoHN]; both being applied in this sense to a man. (Ḳ.)
sayorN fasiyHN [means A pace in which the steps are wide: see 1, latter half].
jamalN mafosuwHu AlD-uluwEi i. q. masofuwH [i. e. A camel wide in the ribs]. (TA.)
maA laka fiI hecaA mutafas-aHN [There is not for thee ample scope (lit. a place in which one has ample scope) in this]. (A.)
munofasaHN waAdK [The place of expanding of a valley]. (JK and Ḳ in art. xrq, &c.)
muraAHN munofasiHN † A nightly resting-place of camels, or of camels and other cattle, in which they are numerous. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. fasaxa, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafosaxu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. fasoxN; (Ṣ, L;) and fs-x↓; (L; [but this has an intensive signification;]) He dislocated, luxated, or disjointed, (A, L, Ḳ,) one's arm, or hand, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) or a limb, without breaking: (L:) [and] fasaxotu AlmafoSila Eano mawoDiEihi I removed the joint from its place. (Mṣb.)
And the former v., aor. and inf. n. as above, He removed a stick, or twig, or branch, from its place with his hand. (Mṣb.)

And the same v., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (Ḳ,) He cast, or cast off, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a garment, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or his garments. (A.) You say, fasaxotu Ean-iI vawobiI I cast, or cast off, from me my garment. (Ṣ.)
And the same v., (L, Mṣb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He separated, disunited, sundered, dissundered, or dispersed, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing. (L, Mṣb.)

Also, the same verb, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He undid, dissolved, or annulled, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a sale, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (Ṣ,) and a marriage, (Ṣ, A, L,) and a contract, compact, or covenant, and an affair. (Mṣb.)
And the same v., (L, Mṣb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (L, Ḳ,) † He (a man, Mṣb) corrupted, or disordered, the judgment, or opinion. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

fasixa, aor. _a {yafosaxu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. fasaxN; (L;) or fasaxa, this v. being intrans. as well as trans.; (Mṣb;) † It (the judgment, or opinion,) was, or became, corrupt, or disordered. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[And, accord. to the TḲ, fasixa, (but this I think to be a mistake for fasaxa,) inf. n. fasoxN, signifies DaEufa († He was, or became, weak, app. in intellect and in body; see fasoxN below); said of a man: and jahila (app. intrans., meaning † He was, or became, ignorant; but accord. to the TḲ trans., meaning he knew not a thing).]

In the conventional language of the philosophers, Alfasoxu [as an inf. n.] signifies † The transmigration of the rational soul of a human being from his body to [some one of] the inanimate, not increasing, bodies, such as the minerals, or metals, and the simple elements: (Dict. of Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans:) or, to a plant: the former meaning being that of Alr-asoxu. (So in a marginal note in a copy of the TḲ.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, first sentence.
3. fAsxhu AlbayoEa ‡ [He agreed with him in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A. [See 6.])
4. Afsx AlquroMna † He forgot the Ḳur-án. (Fr, Ṣ.)
5: see 7, in two places.

tfs-x AlX-aEaru Eani Aljilodi The hair fell off and became scattered from the skin, peculiarly of a dead body: (L, Ḳ:) and in like manner, All-aHomu Eani AlEaZomi the flesh from the bone. (A, L.) And tafas-axati AlfaOarapu fiI AlmaMCi The rat, or mouse, became dissundered, [or fell in pieces, through putrefaction,] in the water. (Ṣ.)

tfs-x taHota AlHimoli Alv-aqiyli, said of a [young camel such as is termed] rubaE, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) He was, or became, weak beneath the heavy load, (Ḳ,) and unable to bear it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] one says of a man, tfs-x taHota AlEiboCi Alv-aqiyli. (A.)

6. tfAsxwA AlEaqoda † They agreed together in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the contract, compact, or covenant. (Mṣb.) And tfAsxA AlbayoEa ‡ [They two agreed in dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A.)
And tfAsxt AlOaqaAwiylu ‡ The sayings annulled, or contradicted, one another. (TA.)

7. Anfsx It (a limb, L, such as an arm, or a hand, A, L) became dislocated, luxated, or disjointed; (A, L;) as also tfs-x↓. (L.) One says, waqaEa fulaAnN faQnofasaxato qadamuhu Such a one fell, and his foot became dislocated. (L. [And the like is said in the A.])
It (a stick, or twig, or branch,) became removed from its place by the hand. (Mṣb.)
It (flesh) became dissundered by putrefaction; as also tfs-x↓. (L.)

And, said of a sale, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a marriage, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) [and a contract, compact, or covenant, (see 1,)] and an affair, (L,) ‡ It became undone, dissolved, or annulled. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
Also said of a weak man, [app. as meaning † He became unnerved,] on an occasion of difficulty. (L: see fasiyxN.)

hom.sense: And † Ignorance: (Ḳ:) which is referrible to weakness of intellect. (TA.)
And † Weak in intellect and in body; as also fasoxapN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also fasiyxN.

entry.sense: fasixN † A corrupt, or disordered, judgment, or opinion. (L.)
fasoxapN: see fasoxN, in two places.
fasiyxN [applied to flesh-meat, Parting in pieces, and easily resolvable, by reason of much cooking. (Golius, from Meyd.)]

hom.sense: [vawobN faAsixN † A faded garment: so in the language of the present day: perhaps post-classical]. (A in art. rmd.)
[AlfaAsixu is a name given by the Jews to their festival of The Passover: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 291, and p. 97 of the Ar. text: and see also AlfiSoHu.]

entry.sense: 1. fasada, aor. _u {yafosudu}, (Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) which is the aor. commonly known, (TA,) and _i, (IDrd, M, O, L, Ḳ,) which is of weak authority; (IDrd, O, TA;) and fasuda, aor. _u {yafosudu}; (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ;) inf. n. fasaAdN (Ṣ. M, A, O, L, Ḳ) and fusuwdN, (M, O, L, Ḳ,) the former being inf. n. of fasada, aor. _u {yafosudu}, (Ṣ, A, O,) and so the latter, and the former being also inf. n. of fasuda, (O,) or the former is of fasuda and the latter is of fasada, (TA,) or the former is a simple subst., and the latter is the inf. n.; (Mṣb;) It (a thing, Ṣ, A, O) [and he (a man)] was, or became, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin; (MA, KL, PṢ, &c.;) and so Astfsd↓: (KL:) contr. of SalaHa: (M,* L, Ḳ:) it became altered in its state [for the worse]: and it became null, void, of no force, or of no account; or it came to nought, or perished; accord. to the explanation by most of the expositors of the ex. in the Ḳur xxi. 22. (MF.)
2: see 4, first sentence.

3. fAsdhu He became at variance with him; he cut, severed, or broke, the tie of friendship [or kindred] with him. (L in art. kXH.) And fulaAnN yufaAsidu rahoTahu [Such a one cuts the ties of friendship, or kindred, with his people, tribe, or near kinsfolk]. (A.)

4. Afsd, (Ṣ, M, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UfosaAdN and [quasi-inf.n.] fasaAdN; (L;) and fs-d↓, (O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafosiydN; (O, Ḳ;) He, or it, made, or rendered, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; deprived of virtue, or efficacy; corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected; [constituted, disposed, arranged, or qualified, ill, wrongly, or improperly;] disordered, or disturbed, [disorganized,] destroyed, annihilated, consumed, wasted, or ruined; (MA, KL, &c.;) contr. of OSolaHa. (M, L, Ḳ.) One says, Afsd AlmaAla [He rendered the property in a bad state; marred, impaired, consumed, or wasted, it]. (L.) [And Afsd Ealayohimo He corrupted, perverted, or marred, their state, case, affair, scheme, plot, or the like; Oamorahumo, or the like, being understood. And Afsdhu EalaI-a He corrupted him and rendered him disaffected towards me.] UifosaAdu SabiI-K, occurring in a trad., means The injuring a child by rendering its mother pregnant while she is suckling it and so vitiating her milk: which act is also termed Algiylahu. (L.) [And Afsd as contr. of OaSolaHa signifies also He acted in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; acted ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; or did evil, or mischief; Uilayohi to him: and he created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrel-ling; or made, or did, mischief; bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or party. (See also 10.)]
6. tfAsdwA They became at variance, one with another; (M, L;) they cut, severed, or broke, the tie of kindred, (M, L, Ḳ,) and of friendship, (L,) one with another. (M, L, Ḳ.)
7. Anfsd [as quasi-pass. of Oafosadahu] is not allowable, (Ṣ, L,) or has not been heard. (Ḳ.)

10. Astfsd contr. of AisotaSolaHa. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.) [Hence, He regarded, or esteemed, a thing, or man, as bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest;, &c.: see 1.]
[And] He wished, or desired, [a thing, or man,] to be bad, evil, corrupt,, &c. (KL.)
[And He sought to render bad, evil, corrupt,, &c.]

[And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render disaffected, or rebellious.] One says, AlOamiyru yasotafosidu raEiy-atahu [The prince, or governor, treats his subjects in such a manner as to render them disaffected, or rebel-lious]. (A.) And AstfsdAls-uloTaAnu qaAYidahu The Sultán provoked the leader of his forces to rebel-lion by his evil conduct to him. (L.)

[And He sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; to act ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, or dishonestly.] One says, Astfsd fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK [Such a one sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner, or to act ill,, &c., to such a one]. (M.)
[And He sought discord, or dissension.]
[And It (an event) happened in a bad, or an evil, manner.]
See also 1.

fasaAdN an inf. n. of 1: (Ṣ, M, A, &c.:) or a simple subst.: (Mṣb:) [as a subst. signifying] Badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness, wrongness, wrongfulness, impropriety, unrighteousness, wickedness, vitiousness, depravity, or dishonesty; the state of being devoid of virtue or efficacy; a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, deteriorated, or tainted, state; a state of disorder or disturbance, or of destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PṢ, &c.:) contr. of SalaAHN. (Lth, M, Mṣb.)
And it is also [frequently used as a quasi-inf. n.] syn. with UifosaAdN [signifying The making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt,, &c.: (see 4:) and, oftener, the acting ill, corruptly, wrong, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; doing evil, or mischief; and creating, or exciting, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling]: (L:) and [particularly] the taking property wrongfully. (O, Ḳ.) [Hence,] Harobu AlfasaAdi [The war of evildoing]: thus was termed a war that happened between [the two sub-tribes] banuwXk [in which the latter word is app. a mistranscription for XibokK] and gawov, of the tribe of TaI-iC: it was so termed because one party patched their sandals with the cars of the other, and one party drank wine out of the skulls of the other. (MF.)

Also Drought, barrenness, dearth, or scarcity of good: (M, L, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur [xxx. 40], Zahara QlofasaAdu fiI Albar-i waQlobaHori i. e. Drought,, &c., hath appeared in the land, and in the cities that are upon the rivers; (M, L, TA;) accord. to Zj; (M;) or accord. to Ez-Zejjájee. (L, TA.)
fasiydN: see the next paragraph.

faAsidN, (Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) part. n. of fasada; (Ṣ, M, A, &c.;) and fasiydN↓, (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) part. n. of fasuda; (Ṣ, O;) Bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PṢ, &c.: [contr. of SaAliHN and SaliyHN, as is indicated in the Ṣ and M, &c.:]) pl. (of the former, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, [dev. from general analogy, and of the latter agreeably therewith,]) fasodaI, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to a people, (Ṣ, M, O,) like as they said saAqiTN and saqoTaI; (Ṣ, O;) the pl. being made of the same form as halokaI because these two words are nearly the same in meaning. (Sb, M.)

Oafosadu is [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees] from AlfasaAdu; as in the prov., Oafosadu mino bayoDapi Albaladi i. e. [More corrupt, or unsound,, &c.,] than the egg that the ostrich leaves in the desert, not returning to it, in consequence of which it becomes corrupt, or unsound, &c.: and, anomalously, from AlUifosaAdu; as in the prov., Oafosada mina AljaraAdi [i. e. More corrupting, or marring,, &c., than the locust], because it strips the trees and the herbage; and as in other provs. (Meyd.)

mafosadapN A cause, or means, or an occasion, of fasaAd [i. e. badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness,, &c.; or making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt,, &c.]; (M, A;) contr. of maSolaHapN: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. mafaAsidu. (A, Mṣb.) One says, hecaA AlOamori mafosadapN likacaA [This affair, or event, is cause of evil,, &c., to such a thing]. (M.) And humo mino Oaholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who do actions that are causes of evil, not actions that are causes of good]. (A.)

1. fasara, aor. _i {yafosiru} (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yafosuru}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. fasorN; (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and fs-r↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafosiyrN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which latter is the more common; (IḲṭṭ;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) He discovered, detected, revealed, developed, or disclosed, a thing that was concealed or obscured; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) or a meaning perceived by the intellect: (B:) he rendered a thing apparent, plain, or clear; explained, expounded, or interpreted, it: (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Th (O, Ḳ, TA) and IAạr, (TA,) tafosiyrN↓ and taOowiylN signify the same; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so these and maEonFI: (O, TA:) or tfsyr↓ signifies the discovering, detecting, revealing, developing, or disclosing, what is meant by a dubious expression; and tOwyl signifies the “reducing one of two senses, or interpretations, which an expression bears, or admits, to that which suits the apparent meaning:” (O, L, Ḳ, TA:) or the latter, the “turning a verse of the Ḳur-án from its apparent meaning to a meaning which it bears, or admits, when the latter is agreeable with the Ḳur-án and the Sunneh:” for instance, in the phrase in the Ḳur [vi. 95, &c.], yuxoriju QloHaI-a mina Qlomay-iti, if the meaning be [thus explained], “He produceth the bird from the egg,” this is tfsyr↓: and if the meaning be [thus explained], “He produceth the believer from the unbeliever,” or “the knowing from the ignorant,” this is tOwyl: (KT:) or tfsyr↓ signifies the expounding, explaining, or interpreting, the narratives that occur collected without discrimination in the Ḳur-án, and making known the significations of the strange words or expressions, and explaining the occasions on which the verses were revealed; and tOwyl, the “explaining the meaning of that which is mutaXaAbih, [or what is equivocal, or ambiguous,] i. e., what is not understood without repeated consideration.” (TA.)

Also fasara, inf. n. fasorN; and fs-r↓, inf. n. tafosirapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like tacokirapN; (TA;) or tafosirapN has the last of the significations assigned to it below as a subst.; (O, Ḳ, TA;) or it is post-classical; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) He (a physician) examined, or inspected, urine, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, [but the inf. ns. only are mentioned,]) that he might judge, by its colour, of the disease of the person from whom it came. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in six places.
5: see the next following paragraph {10}.
10. Astfsrhu kacaA He asked him to explain, expound, or interpret, such a thing to him: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and tafas-urN↓ is like AisotifosaArN. (TA.)
tafosirapN Anything by which is known the explanation and meaning of a thing: (O, TA:) or anything which interprets, or explains, the state, or condition, of a thing. (B, TA.)

Urine by means of which, (M, O, Ḳ,) or by means of the colour of which, (TA,) one seeks to obtain an indication of the disease (M, O, Ḳ, TA) of a patient: (O, TA:) or it is an inf. n., as mentioned above. (O, Ḳ.) [See 1, last sentence.]
Oaworada kalaAmahu gayora mufas-arK: see EaAhinN.

fusoTaATN and fisoTaATN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fus-aATN and fis-aATN and fusotaATN and fisotaATN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the t in the last two, as it is not found in the pl., being a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or rather for the [latter] s in fs-AT, because it is more regular to change the latter of two identical letters than to change the former, and because the two identical letters in fs-AT are together, whereas the two identical letters in fsTAT are separated, (M,) and fusotaAtN and fisotaAtN, (Ḳ,) altogether eight different forms, but MF observes that Esh-Shiháb El-Kastalánee gives twelve, [which, however, he does not transcribe, the remaining four being probably with fet-ḥ to the f,] (TA,) A tent of hair [-cloth]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a great tent: (Mgh:) or a kind of structure (M, Z) used in travelling, less than the suraAdiq: (Z:) or the kind of structure called suraAdiq: (Ḳ:) pl. fasaATiyTu; (M, Mṣb, TA;) for which they did not say fasaAtiyTu. (M, TA:)

Hence fusoTaATN is applied to A city: (Z, TA:) any city: and particularly a city in which is the general place of assemblage of people: (TA:) a populous, or comprehensive, city; accord. to some: (Mṣb:) the place of assemblage of the people of a kuwrap [which means a city, and a district, or region], (Lth, Az, Ḳ,) around their general mosque: (Az, TA:) or you say, fusoTaATu AlmiSori, meaning the place of assemblage of the people of the mSr [or city], around their congregational mosque. (M.) fusoTaATu [so in two copies of the Ṣ] is [a name of] The city of miSor [the metropolis of Egypt]: (Ṣ:) or AlfusoTaATu is also the proper name of miSoruAlEatiyqapu, (Ḳ, TA,) the city so called, (TA,) which was built by ʼAmr Ibn-El-'Ás; (Ḳ, TA;) the city of mSr in old times; as also AlfisoTaATu: (Mṣb:) and AlbaSorapu. (TA.)

1. fasaqa is said to signify primarily It (a thing) went forth, from another thing, in a bad, or corrupt, manner. (Mṣb.) One says, fasaqati Alr-uTabapu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or fasaqati Alr-uTabapu Eano qiXorihaA, (Ḳ,) The fresh ripe date came forth from its skin; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Anfsqt↓: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) and in like manner fasaqa is said of anything as meaning it came forth from its integument: so says Es-Sarakustee. (Mṣb.)

[Hence] fasaqa, aor. _u {yafosuqu} and _i {yafosiqu}, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) the latter aor. mentioned by Akh, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. fusuwqN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fisoqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and likewise fasuqa, like karuma, (Ḳ, TA,) mentioned by Lḥ, but not known by Ks; (TA;) He went forth from, departed from, or quitted, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the right way, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or the way of truth, (Ḳ,) and the limits of the law, (Mgh,) [or the bounds of] obedience; (Mṣb;) he forsook, relinquished, or neglected, the command of God; he disobeyed; (Ḳ;) or i. q. fajara [meaning as above; or he transgressed; or acted unrighteously, sinfully, wickedly, vitiously, or immorally]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See also fisoqN below.])
fasaqa Eano Oamorirab-ihi (in the Ḳur [xviii. 48], O, TA) means He departed (xaraja) from the command of his Lord: (Th, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or from the obeying [of the command] of his Lord: (Fr, O, TA:) and Akh says that this phrase is like Ait-axama En AlT-aEAmi, (Ṣ, O,) meaning Eano maOokalihi, (Ṣ,) or Eano Oakolihi AlT-aEaAma; but Th says that there is no need of this [explanation]: or, accord. to AO, it means he declined, or deviated, from obeying the command of his Lord: (O:) for fasaqa signifies also he declined, or deviated: (Ḳ:) and hence the saying, fasaqati Alr-ikaAbu Eano qaSodi Als-abiyli i. e. [The ridden camels] declined [from the right direction of the way]. (TA.) Sometimes fusuwqN may mean The believing in a plurality of gods: and it may mean the committing sin. (AHeyth, O.) And it is said to mean The calling one another by names of reproach: (Zj,* Mgh, TA:) or the saying “O Jew,” and “O Christian,” after one has become a believer: thus in the Ḳur xlix. 11. (TA.)

One says also, fasaqa fiI Ald-unoyaA, inf. n. fisoqN, meaning He had a wide, or an ample, range in respect of worldly things, and made them light and easy to himself, being without restraint in his management of them, not making them strait to him. (Ḳṭr, Sh, TA.)
And fasaqa maAlahu He made away with his property; and disposed of it, or spent it. (TA.)

2. tafosiyqN is the contr. of taEodiylN: (O, Ḳ, TA:) one says fs-qhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. tafosiyqN, (TA,) He (the judge) pronounced him to be characterized by fisoq [q. v.]: (O, TA:) he attributed to him fisoq. (TA.)
7: see 1, second sentence.
[Hence,] Anfsq mina Alxayori, said of the faAsiq, He divested himself, or became divested, of good. (IDrd, O.)

fisoqN is an inf. n., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or a simple subst., (Mṣb,) from fasaqa [q. v]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) unless as signifying [simply] A going forth, or a departure, it is said to be a word unknown before El-Islám, and to have become so much used in its legal acceptation as to be, when so used, conventionally regarded as proper (MF, TA:) [thus used,] it signifies a going forth, or departure, from the right way, (Ḳ, TA,) which is said to be the primary meaning, (TA,) or from the way of truth; (Ḳ, TA;) or from the truth, or that which is right, as in the phrase waUin-ahu lafisoqN, (O, Ḳ, [in the CK lafasiqN, a strange mistake,]) in the Ḳur [vi. 121]; (O;) or a relinquishment, or neglect, of the command of God; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) and an inclining to disobedience; (Lth, O;) or also disobedience [itself]; (Ḳ;) or i. q. fujuwrN [meaning as above; or transgression; or unrighteous, sinful, wicked, vitious, or immoral, conduct]: (O, Ḳ:) it is said by El-Iṣbahánee to be a more general term than kuforN; applying to few sins, misdeeds, transgressions, or acts of disobedience, or to little thereof; and also, to many, or much thereof; but is commonly known as applying to the latter: and it is related on the authority of Málik that in the Ḳur vi. 146 it means such as is slaughtered: (TA:) [being used as a subst.,] it sometimes has a pl., which is fusuwqN. (TA.)
fusaqN (Lth, O, Ḳ) and fis-iyqN↓, (Lth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) applied to a man, Always characterized by fisoq. (Lth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

yaAfusaqu means yaA Oay-uhaA AlfaAsiqu [O thou faAsiq]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like yaA xubavu, meaning yaA Oay-uhaA Anxabiyvu; fusaqu being determinate, as is shown by their saying yaA fusaqu Alxabiyvu, thus prefixing Al to xbyv: (Ṣ, O:) and to a woman they say yaA fasaAqi↓, like qaTaAmi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) meaning yaA faAsiqapu (Ḳ) [or rather yaA Oay-uhaA AlfaAsiqapu].

fasoqiy-apN, with fet-ḥ, [often pronounced fisoqiy-ap,] a post-classical word, [arabicized, from the Lat. “piscina,”] i. q. mutawaD-aON [properly A place, here meaning a tank, or basin, in which the ablution termed wuDuwoC is performed: now commonly applied to a basin, or shallow pool, of water, in the court of a house, or in a room, generally having in the centre a fountain that throws up water:] pl. fasaAqiy-u. (TA.)
fasaAqi: see fusaqN
fis-iyqN: see fusaqN
