fuluj-N, [thus in the L,] accord. to Sb, A sort of men: one says, Aln-aAsu fuluj-aAni The people, or men, are two sorts; [for ex.,] consisting of entering and going out: [but I think it most probable that fuluj-N and fuluj-aAni are mistranscriptions for filojN and filojaAni, for] Seer says that flj signifying “a half” and “a sort” is derived from filojN syn. with qafiyzN: thus he makes filojN an Arabic word. (L.) See also falojN.

filojaAnN, [said to be] from filojN signifying “a certain measure of capacity,” [but app. from the Pers. finojaAn,] A [small porcelain or earthenware] cup out of which coffee, &c. is drunk; commonly pronounced by the vulgar finojaAn and finojaAl [from the Pers. PinoGaAn and PinoGaAl, and also called filojaAnapN↓, vulgarly finojaAnap; and fiyaAlajap↓: (see sawomalapN:) pl. falaAjiynu and fanaAjiynu and fanaAjiylu]. (TA.)
filojaAnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
faliyjN: see the paragraph here following.

falyijapN One of the oblong pieces of cloth of a tent: (TA:) or, of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) Aṣ says, I know not in what part it is: (TA:) faliyjN↓ appears to be used for it by poetic license; or the word may be one of those pronounced with and without p; or without p it may be a pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is with p: (M, TA:) [or] faliyjN signifies a single oblong piece of a bijaAd [q. v.]; and its pl. is fulujN: (L and TA in art. bjd:) and [in like manner] falojapN↓ signifies a piece of a bijaAd. (TA in the present art.)
See also faliyHapN, with H.
fal-uwjN A writer. (Ibn-Jembeh, O, Ḳ.) And A manager and reckoner: from the phrase huwa yafoluju AlOamora, expl. above. (TA.)

fal-uwjapN Land that is put into a right, or proper, state for sowing; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) good, clear, land prepared for sowing: (TA:) pl. falaAliyju. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And [hence, app.,] Any one town, or village, of the Sawád: (O, Ḳ:*) pl. as above. (O.)

hom.sense: rajulN faAlijN fiI Huj-atihi A man who succeeds, or overcomes, in his argument, plea, allegation, or the like; as also falojN↓. (TA.) And Als-ahomu AlfaAliju The arrow that is successful: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the winning arrow in the game called Almayosir: or it may mean the arrow that is successful in a contest at archery. (TA.)
See also filojN, in four places.

faAlijN (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ) and falojN↓ (L) also signify A large, or bulky, camel, with two humps, that is brought from Es-Sind for the purpose of covering: (Ṣ, O,* Ḳ:) or a camel with two humps, between the Bukhtee (AlbuxotiI-) and the Arabian: so called because his hump is divided in halves, or because his two humps have different inclinations: (L:) pl. of the former fawaAliju. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ; all in art. Sr.)

And AlfaAliju signifies [Palsy, or paralysis, whether partial or general; hemiplegia or paraplegia:] a disease arising from a flaccidity in one of the lateral halves of the body; (A;) or a flaccidity in one of the lateral halves of the body, (Ḳ, TA,) arising suddenly, (TA,) occasioned by an efflux of a phlegmatic humour, and causing the passages of the spirit to become obstructed; (Ḳ, TA;) this being its first effect; it deprives the patient of his senses and his motion; and is sometimes in one member: (TA:) or a flatus (riyHN Ṣ, O, L, TA) which attacks a man, and deprives him [of the use] of one lateral half of the body; (thus in the L, and the like is said in the ʼEyn; TA;) whence it is thus called: (IDrd, Ṣ, O:)
or a disease that arises in one of the lateral halves of the body, occasioning the loss of the senses and of motion, and sometimes in both lateral halves, and sudden in its attack; on the seventh [day] it is dangerous; but when it has passed the seventh, its acuteness ceases; and when it has passed the fourteenth, it becomes a chronic disease: (Mṣb:) it is called in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh daMCu AlOanobiyaMCi [the disease of the prophets]: and is said by Et-Tedmuree, in the Expos. of the Fṣ, to be a disease that attacks a man when the venters (buTuwn) of the brain become filled with certain moistures, or humours, occasioning the loss of sensation and of the motions of the members, and rendering the patient like a dead person, understanding nothing. (TA.)
OanaA mino hecaA AlOamori faAliju bonu xalaAwapa, or kafaAliji boni xalaAwapa, is a saying expl. in art. xlw.

entry.sense: fiyaAlajapN: see filojaAnN. [fayaAlijap occurs in art. qz in the TA, as its pl.; being there expl. as meaning small cups (fanaAjiyn) in which wine (XaraAb) is drunk: but I think that this may be taken from a mistranscription for fiyaAlajap.]

Oafolaju, (TA,) or Oafolaju AlOasonaAni, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, and falojaMCu AlOasonaAni applied to a woman, (Ṣ, O,) for the teeth must be mentioned, (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [but MF disputes this,] and mufal-aju↓ AlOasonaAni, applied to a man, accord. to one reading of a trad., (TA,) Having the teeth separate, one from another: (TA:) or, distant, or wide apart, one from another: (Mgh,* Ḳ:) or having the medial and lateral incisors distant, one from another, or wide apart. (Ṣ, O.) [See also Oaforaqu.] And mufal-aju↓ Alv-anaAyaA A man having an interstice between the middle pair of teeth; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also faliju↓ Alv-anaAyaA; (A;) contr. of mutaraAS-u Alv-anaAyaA. (Ṣ, O.) And mutafal-ijapN↓ A woman that makes open spaces between her front teeth, for the purpose of improving their appearance. (L, from a trad., in which a curse is pronounced against her who does this.) And vagorN Oafolaju Front teeth that are separate, or distant, or wide apart, one from another; and mufal-ajN↓ signifies the same [app. when they are rendered so artificially: see falajN]. (TA.)

And Oafolaju applied to a man, Having a crookedness, or curvature, [or bowing outwards,] in the arms: when it is in the legs, the person is termed OafoHaju: (L:) or wide between the arms: (O, Ḳ:) or wide between the paps; (Ṣ, L;) which last explanation is said in the Ḳ to be erroneous; but he who is wide between the paps is also wide between the arms. (MF.)
hinN Oafolaju A vulva, of a woman, whereof the labia majora are wide apart. (L.)
farasN Oafolaju A horse having the prominent parts of the haunch-bones wide apart. (IDrd, O, L.)
[OafolajiI-N Having the fingers wide apart. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
mufolajN [Rendered] successful, or victorious; and safe, or secure. (KL.) [See also its verb.]
mufal-ajN: see Oafolaju, in three places.
OamorN mufal-ajN An affair not rightly disposed or directed. (O, Ḳ.)
mafoluwjN Having the disease termed AlfaAlijN. (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
mutafal-ijapN: see Oafolaju.

hom.sense:
1. falaHa, aor. _a {yafolaHu}, inf. n. faloHN, He clave, split, slit, or cracked; and he cut: (Ḳ: [compare falaja, and falaqa, and falaca:]) he clave, and cut, iron. (T, Mṣb.) Hence, the saying of a poet, (T, TA,)
Uin-a AlHadiyda biAlHadiydi yufolaHu
Verily iron with iron is cloven, and cut. (T, Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ.*) And falaHa raOosahu, inf. n. as above, He clave, split, or cracked, his head. (TA.) And falaHa Xafatahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He slit, or cracked, his lip. (L.) And falaHa AlOaroDa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mṣb.) He furrowed, or ploughed, the land, to cultivate it; he tilled the ground. (Ṣ, Mṣb. [And falajahaA has a similar meaning.])

Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He acted with artifice, fraud, or guile; (Ḳ, TA;) and so fl-H↓, inf. n. tafoliyHN. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, fl-H↓ bihimo He acted with artifice, fraud, or guile, towards them, and said what was not true. (TA.) And fl-H↓ bihi He mocked at him, or derided him, and acted with artifice, fraud, or guile, towards him. (L, Ḳ.*)

And, aor. as above, inf. n. faloHN and falaAHapN, He defrauded him in a sale; syn. of the inf. n. baxosN fiI bayoEK: (so in the CK:) or he bade high for an article of merchandise in order to inveigh another into purchasing it at a high price: syn. of the inf. n. najoXN fiI bayoEK. (So in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the L and TA.) You say, falaHa bihi [He so acted towards him in a sale]: this is when one trusts to thee, and says to thee, “Sell to me a slave,” or “an article of merchandise,” or “buy it for me,” and thou comest to the merchants, and buyest it at a high price, and sellest by defrauding, and obtainest something from the merchant: or, accord. to the T, faloHN signifies a hirer's exceeding [in an offer] in order that another may do so; thus inciting him. (L.)
faliHato Xafatuhu Als-ufolaI, [aor. _a {yafolaHu},] inf. n. falaHN, His under lip was slit, or cracked. (MA.) See also falaHN below.

entry.sense: 2: see 1, former half, in three places.

4. AflH He prospered; was successful; attained, or acquired, that which he desired or sought, (MA, L, Mṣb,) or what was good, or felicity, or that whereby he became in a happy and good state: (L:) he was, or became, fortunate, happy, or in a happy and good state. (MA.) It is commonly known as an intrans. verb; but Talhah Ibn-Musarrif and ʼAmr Ibn-ʼObeyd, read qado OufoliHa QlomuWominuwna, [the first verse of ch. xxiii. of the Ḳur-án,] with the verb in the pass. form. (MF.) [See also 10.]
He was, or became, in a state of safety. (L.)
He continued in a good, or prosperous, state, (MA, L,) and in the enjoyment of ease, comfort, or the blessings of life. (L.)

AflH biAlX-aIoCi He lived [or continued in life] by means of the thing. (Ḳ.) The saying of 'Abeed,
OafoliHo bimaA XiYota faqado yubolagu
biQlon-uwki waqado yuxad-aEu AlOariybu
means Live thou by what thou wilt: whether by stupidity or by intelligence; for [one's object is sometimes attained by stupidity, and the intelligent, or sagacious, is sometimes deluded, or much deluded; or] the stupid is sometimes supplied with the means of subsistence, and the intelligent is [sometimes] denied: (T, L:) or the meaning is prosper thou,, &c. (L.)

10. AisotafoliHiI biOamoriki, said by a man to his wife, (Ṣ,) a form of words used in divorcing (L, Ḳ) in the Time of Ignorance, (L,) Prosper thou in thy case, (AO, Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) and be independent therein: (AO, Mgh, TA:) when a man says thus to his wife and she consents, his saying so once separates her from him so that he cannot take her back: (L, from a trad.:) but as it is merely an allusive expression, intention is necessary to render it binding: as some relate the trad, it is with j [i. e. AstfljI: see art. flj]. (MF.) [See also 4, above.]

faloHN A fissure, cleft, slit, or crack: pl. fuluwHN. (Mṣb.) One says, fiI rijolihi fuluwHN In his (a man's, Ṣ) foot are fissures, or cracks, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) preduced by cold: (TA:) as also fuluwjN. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: falaHN A fissure, or crack, in the under lip; (T, Ḳ;) [or] falaHapN↓ has this meaning; (Ṣ;) or signifies the place of such a fissure or crack: (L:) [or the former is a coll. gen. n.; and the latter, its n. un.:] that which is in the upper lip is termed EalamN: (T, TA:) or falaHN signifies a fissure, or crack, in the lip: or, in the middle of the lip, less than what is termed EalamN: or a slitting, or cracking, in the lip, such as happens to the lips of the [Africans called] zanoj. (L.)
[And] The having the under lip slit, or cracked. (Ṣ. [App. an inf. n. of which the verb is faliHa↓: like as it is of faliHat said of the under lip as mentioned above.])
See also falaAHN.

entry.sense: falaHapN: see falaHN.

Also A [field, or land, such as is termed] qaraAH, (AḤn, L, Ḳ,) furrowed, or ploughed, for cultivation: its pl., falaHaAt, occurs in a verse of Hassán, as some relate it; but as others relate it, it is falajaAt, with j. (AḤn, L.)

falaAHN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and falaHN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) the latter a contraction of the former, (L,) Prosperity; success; the attainment, or acquisition, of that which one desires or seeks, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of that whereby one becomes in a happy and good state. (L.) And Safety, or security. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) And Continuance, or permanence, in a good, or prosperous, state, (A, L, Ḳ,) and in the enjoyment of ease, comfort, or the blessings of life; and the continuance of good: (L:) and simply continuance, permanence, lastingness, duration, or endurance. (ISK, Ṣ, L.) There is not in the language of the Arabs any word more comprehensive in its significations of what is good in the present life and in the final state than AlfalaAHu. (TA.) HaI-a EalaI AlfalaAHo, in the call to prayer, means Come ye to the means of the attainment of Paradise, and of permanence therein: (IAth, L:) or hasten to the attainment of everlasting life: (L:) or come to safety, or security: (Ṣ:) or come ye to the way of safety and prosperity: (Mṣb:) or come to the continuance of good. (L.) And you say, laA OafoEalu celika falaAHa Ald-ahori I will not do that while time lasts. (L.) A poet says,
walekino layosa lild-unoyaA falaAHu
meaning [But there is not to the present state of existence] lastingness, or endurance. (Ṣ, L.)

Also (both words) ‡ The [meal, or food, called] saHuwr [that is eaten a little before daybreak previously to commencing a day's fast]: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) so called because thereby is the continuing of the fast; (Ṣ, A;) or because of the lastingness of its utility. (L.)
falaAHapN: see what next follows.

filaAHapN, (thus in my copies of the Ṣ, and in the L and Mṣb,) with kesr, (Mṣb,) [agreeably with general analogy,] or falaAHapN↓, with fet-ḥ, (Ḳ, [but I think that fet-ḥ is here a mistake for kesr, because falaAHahN deviates from general analogy, and because it is a general rule of the author of the Ḳ to omit the mention of the vowel of a word when it is fet-ḥ,]) Agriculture; or the art, work, or occupation, of ploughing, tilling, or cultivating, land. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
faliyHapN The pericarp (sinofap) of the [tree called] marox, when it splits: (Ḳ, TA:) also mentioned as with j [i. e. faliyjapN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: fal-aAHN A plougher, tiller, or cultivator, of land; [a peasant;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) because he cleaves (yafolaHu i. e. yaXuq-u) the land: (TA:) [pl. fal-aAHuwna:] coll. gen. n. fal-aAHapN. (A, TA.)
And [hence, as being likened to a plougher,] A seaman, or sailor; (Ḳ, TA;) a servant of ships or boats. (TA.)
And One who lets asses, or other beasts, on hire; syn. mukaArK: (T, Ḳ, TA:) so called as being likened to the plougher, &c., of land. (TA.)
And One who defrauds in a sale, in the manner described in the explanation of the phrase falaHa bihi. (L.)

entry.sense: OafolaHu Having a fissure, or crack, in the under lip: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or a man having what is termed falaHN in his lip: fem. faloHaMCu. (L.) 'Antarah El-'Absee was surnamed AlfaloHaMCu because of a fissure in his under lip; the fem. form of the epithet being used because AlX-afapu (the lip) is fem.; (Ṣ, L;) or because his name is fem. (L.) [See also OaEolamu.]

qawomN OafolaAHN [i. q. mufoliHuwna] A people prospering; successful; attaining, or acquiring, that which they desire or seek, or what is good, or that whereby they become in a happy and good state: AflAH is a pl. of which ISd says, “I know not any sing. of it.” (L.)

mafolaHapN A cause, or means, of prosperity or success; or of the attainment, or acquisition, of that which one desires or seeks, or of what is good, or of that whereby one becomes in a happy and good state. (L, from a trad.)
rajulN mutafal-iHu AlX-afapi, and Alyadayoni, and Alqadamayoni, A man having the lip chapped, or cracked, much, by cold, and so the hands, and the feet. (L.) [See also 5 in art. flj.]

1. falaca, aor. _i {yafolicu}, inf. n. falocN, He cut, or cut off. (Mṣb.) One says, falaca lahu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off for him a portion of the property: (T:) and falacotu lahu mino maAliI, (Ṣ, M, O, L,) aor. as above, (M, L,) and so the inf. n., (M, L, Ḳ,) I cut off for him [a portion] of my property: (Ṣ, O, L:) or gave him [a portion] of it at once: or gave him [a portion] of it without delay, and without promising: or gave him much thereof. (M, L, Ḳ.*)
See also the next paragraph {2}, in two places.

2. fl-c, (T, L,) inf. n. tafoliycN; (T, O, L, Ḳ;) as also falaca↓, inf. n. falocN; (L, TA;) He cut in pieces (T, O, L, Ḳ) flesh-meat. (T, L.) Hence, in a trad., Uin-a Alfaraqa mina Aln-aAri falaca↓ kabidahu [Verily the fear of the fire of Hell cut in pieces his liver; but perhaps falaca is here a mistranscription for fal-aca]; said, by the Prophet, of one who had died from fear of the fire [of Hell]. (L.)

3. fAlc Aln-isaMCa, inf. n. mufaAlacapN, He bandied words, or held colloquies, with women. (O,* Ḳ.) One says, fulaAnN cuw muTaAraHapK wamufaAlacapK Such a one has a habit of bandying words,, &c., with women. (Ḳ,* TA.)

8. Aftlc minohu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off, or took, for himself, from him, a part, or portion, of the property. (T.) And Aifotalacotu minohu Haq-iI I cut off, or took, for myself, from him, my right, or due. (A, TA.) And Afotalacotuhu AlmaAla I took from him a part, or portion, of the property. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)
filocN The liver of a camel: (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ:) pl. OafolaAcN [also said to be a pl. of filocapN, q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, O, L.)

filocapN A piece, or portion, of liver, (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) cut in an oblong from, (O,) and of flesh-meat, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) and of property, (Ṣ, O, L,) and of gold, and of silver, (M, L, Ḳ,), &c.: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) a piece of flesh-meat cut in an oblong form: (Aṣ, T, M, L:) pl. [of mult.] filacN (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OafolaAcN, (T, M, L, Ḳ,) the latter irregular, as though the augmentative letter [in the sing.] were elided; or filocN may be a dial. var. of filocapN, and so this pl. may be regular. (M, L.)

OafolaAcu AlOaroDi, (M, L, Ḳ,) or OafolaAcu kabidi AlOaroDi, occurring in a trad., (Aṣ, T, A, L,) relating to the signs of the day of resurrection, accord. to different relations thereof, (L,) means ‡ The buried treasures of the earth, (Aṣ, T, M, L, Ḳ,) and its riches. (L.)
And OafolaAcu kabidi mak-apa means ‡ The principal and choicest persons of the inhabitants of Mekkeh; of the tribe of Kureysh: so called because the liver is one of the noble parts of the body. (L.)

AlfilacaAtu [(not to be mistaken for Alfiliz-aAtu) is a pl. of Alfilocapu, and] signifies AlOajosaAmu Als-aboEapu [i. e. † The seven material substances; namely, the four elements, (fire, air, earth, and water,) and the three products composed of these (which are minerals, vegetables, and animals)]. (MF. [But in the copy of his work which I use, AlAjsAd is erroneously put for AljsAm.])

faAluwcN (T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ) and faAluwcaqN↓, but, accord. to Yaạḳoob, not faAluwcajN↓, (Ṣ, O, L,) or this is the proper form, because the h in the original Pers. word is regularly changed into j, (MF,) [the word being] arabicized, (T, Ṣ, O, L,) from the Pers. (M, O,* L) baAluwdah [or faAluwdah or PaAluwdah], (O,) A kind of sweet food, (M, O,* L, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) prepared of the purest substance of wheat (lub- AlHinoTap), (T, L,) or of starch, (TA in art. nXw,) [with water and honey:] pl. fawaAliycu [of which see an ex. in the next paragraph]. (A.)
Also i. q. fuwlaAcN, q. v. (M, L, Ḳ.)

fuwlaAcN, (T, M, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) an arabicized word, (T, O, Mṣb,) from the Pers. buwlaAd [or fuwlaAd or PuwlaAd], (O,) and faAluwcN↓ also, (M, L, Ḳ,) Steel; i. e. purified and refined iron; or the pure part of iron; (T, M, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which is added in other iron: (M, L:) pl. fawaAliycu. (A.) One says, AlD-arobu biAlfawaAliyci xayorN mina AlD-arobi fiI AlfawaAliyci [The smiting with the weapons of steel in battle is better than the thick white honey in the sweet messes of the kind called fAlwc]. (A.)
faAluwcajN and faAluwcaqN: see faAluwcN, above.
mafoluwcN A sword made of fuwlaAc [i. e. steel]. (O, Ḳ.)

filiz-N (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ, &c.) and filaz-N and fuluz-N, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) the first of which is what is commonly known, (TA,) White copper (nuHaAs OaboyaD [app. a sort of bronze in which the relative quantity of the tin is unusually large]) whereof are made cast cooking-pots (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA) of large size, and mortars in which substances are pounded: (TA:)
or the metals; gold and silver and copper and the like: (AʼObeyd, A, O, Ḳ:*) or the substance [i. e. recrement] that is removed [or blown away] by the blacksmith's bellows from molten metals: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the dross, or recrement, of iron, (O, Ḳ,) that is removed [or blown away] by the blacksmith's bellows: (O:) or stones: (O, Ḳ:) its primary meaning is [said to be] hardness, and ruggedness. (IDrd, O.) Alfiliz-aAtu [pl. of Alfiliz-u (not to be mistaken for AlfilacaAtu)] signifies The seven metals; namely, gold, silver, copper, iron, lead, tin [thus I here render AlOusorub-], and tutenag [thus I render AlxaArSiyniI, following De Sacy and others]. (Ḳzw.)

And hence, as being likened to the flz- above described, (TA,) ‡ A strong, hard, and thick, or coarse, man. (Ḳ,* TA.) And ‡ A niggard: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA:) as though he were hard iron, upon which nothing would make any impression. (TA.)
And A thing upon which swords are tested by striking it therewith. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. fl-shu, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoliysN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a judge) proclaimed him. (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,) or pronounced him, (O, Ḳ,) to be, or to have become, in a state of UifolaAs [meaning bankruptcy, or insolvency], (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) or to have become mufolis [meaning bankrupt, or insolvent], and paraded him among the people as such. (Mṣb.)
And [hence] one says, ful-isa mino kul-i xayorK [app. meaning He was pronounced destitute of all good, or of all property]. (TA.)

[ful-isa It was marked with spots differing in colour from the rest, resembling fuluws, or small copper coins. (See mufal-asN.)] tafoliysu All-awoni [used as a subst. properly so termed] signifies Spots in a colour, differing therefrom in colour, resembling fuluws. (M.)

4. Afls, [inf. n. UifolaAsN,] He became mufolis [which in the common legal acceptation means bankrupt, or insolvent]: (Ṣ:) or he had no property remaining: (O, Ḳ:) as though his daraAhim [or pieces of silver] had become fuluws [or small copper coins], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and base money: like as Oaxobava signifies “his companions, or friends, became bad, wicked, or deceitful:” (Ṣ, O:) or he became in such a state that it was said he had not a falos [or small copper coin]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like as Oaqohara signifies “he became in a state in which to be overcome, or subdued:” (Ṣ, O:) or as though he became in a state in which to be overcome, or subdued: (Mṣb:) or he became a possessor of fuluws after he had been a possessor of daraAhim: (M, Mṣb:) but properly, [so in the Mṣb, but I would rather say secondarily, or tropically,] he became reduced from a state of ease, or competence, or richness, to a state of difficulty, or poverty. (Mṣb.)
Afls Alr-ajula He sought the man and missed his place. (AA, O.)

entry.sense: falosN [A small copper coin;] a thing well known, (M, A, Ḳ,) used in buying and selling; (Mṣb;) the forty-eighth part of a dirhem: [i. e., about half a farthing of our money:] so in Egypt: (Ibn-Fadl-Allah, cited by Es-Suyootee in his Husn el-Mohádarah:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ, O) OafolusN, and (of mult., Ṣ, O) fuluwsN. (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [The dim. of the former of these pls. is OufayolisN↓: see an ex. below, voce mufolisN. The pl. fuluws is the common term for Money in Egypt and some other parts in the present day.]
[Hence, Anything resembling a small coin: as]
[A counter of metal:]
[and A scale of a fish: as Ṣgh says,] fuluwsu Als-amaki signifies what are on the back of the fish, resembling the [coins called] fuluws. (O.)
And The seal of the jizoyap [or tax paid by the free non-muslim subject of a Muslim government], (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which was hung upon the neck, (T, Ṣ, TA,) or upon the throat. (O, Ḳ.)

Alfilosu A certain idol which belonged to the tribe of Teiyi, (IDrd, M, O, Ḳ,) in the Time of Ignorance; which ʼAlee, being sent by Moḥammad, destroyed, taking away the two swords, mixocamN and rasuwbN, that El-Hárith Ibn-Abee-Shemir had given to it. (O, TA.)

falasN, from Oafolasa, [app. signifying Bankruptcy or insolvency: or a state of indigence or destitution: and] lack of obtainment: (Ḳ, TA:) and failure of finding him whom [or that which] one seeks. (TA.) You say, waqaEa fiI falasK XadiydK [He fell into a severe state of indigence or destitution]. (TA.) And one says, fiI Hub-ihaA falasN, meaning With her love, or the love of her, is no obtainment: and the phrase Hub-uhaA falasN, occurring in a verse of El-Mo'attal El-Hudhalee, or of Aboo-Kilábeh, [in which the love thus described is afterwards termed Hub-u mufolisN↓, so that falasN is here used for mufolisN, or the phrase is elliptical,] Her love, or the love of her, is such that nothing is obtained from it. (O.)
fal-aAsN A seller of fuluws, pl. of falosN. (M, O, Ḳ.)
OufayolisN: see falosN and mufolisN.

mufolisN act. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]: pl., (Mṣb,) or quasi-pl. n., (A,) mafaAliysu↓; (A, Mṣb;) like as mfaATiyru is of mufoTirN, [and mayaAsiyru of muwsirN;] or pl. of mifolaAsN↓ [which signifies the same as mafolisN but in an intensive degree]. (A, TA.) [The dim. is mufayolisN↓.] You say, fulaAnN mufayolisN maA nahu Uil-aA OufayolisN [Such a one is nearly a bankrupt, or nearly destitute; he has nothing but a few small copper coins]. (A, TA.)
See also falasN.

hom.sense: mufal-asN Proclaimed [or pronounced] by the judge to be in a state of UifolaAs. (A.) [See 2.]

Also, (Mgh,) or mufal-asu All-awoni, (O, Ḳ,) A horse, (Mgh,) or other thing, (O, Ḳ,) having upon his skin spots differing in colour from the rest, resembling fuluws [or small copper coins]. (Mgh, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mifolaAsN: see mufolisN.
mafaAliysu, a pl. or quasi-pl. n.: see mufolisN.
Q. 2. tafalosafa He was, or became, a fayolasuwf [or philosopher]. (M.)
He affected to be a philosopher. (PU.)
falosafapN, a foreign word, Science; (M;) [philosophy; or] love of science: from the word here following. (O and Ḳ in art. swf.)
fayolasuwfN A man of science; (M;) [a philosopher;] a word meaning in Greek a lover of science. (O and Ḳ in art. swf.)

Q. 1. faloTaHa He expanded, and made broad, or wide, a round cake of bread; (Ḳ, TA;) as also faroTaHa; both mentioned by Abu-l-Faraj: [see art. frTH: both are app. correct; but the former seems to be the more approved:] and he made broad, or wide, anything. (TA.)
filoTaAHN: see the following paragraph.

mufaloTaHN A cake of bread [expanded, and made broad, or] wide: (IAạr, TA.) and a thing [of any kind (see the verb)] having breadth and width. (TA.) HasakapN mufaloTaHapN occurs in a trad. [meaning A broad, or wide, head of a thistle or the like]. (TA.) And raOosN mufaloTaHN means A broad, or wide, head; as also filoTaAHN↓. (Ḳ.)

UicaA Dan-uwA Ealayohi baAlmufaloTaHapi, occurring in a trad., is expl. by El-Khaṭṭábee as meaning [If they be niggardly, to him, of] the expanded cake of bread: and it is also expl. as meaning the dirhems [or money]: (TA:) or the phrase [accord. to one relation] is UicaA Dan-uwA Ealayoka biAlmuTalofaHapi, in which both of the meanings above mentioned are assigned to the last word. (L and TA in art. TlfH.)

1. falaEahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafolaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. faloEN, (Ṣ,) He clave, split, or rent, it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., a thing; (Ṣ;) or it signifies, or signifies also, (accord to different copies of the Ḳ,) he cut it, (Ḳ,) with a sword, &c.; and he broke, or crushed, it; like as one does the hump of a camel, with a knife: (TA:) and one says also fl-Ehu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoliyEN; (Ṣ;) meaning the same; (Ḳ:) or this has an intensive signification. (O, TA.)
And falaEotuhu [also] signifies I made it apparent, or manifest; or exposed it to view. (Sh, TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
5: see the paragraph next following {7}, in three places.

7. AnflE (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [in an intensive sense] tfl-E↓ (Ḳ) It became cleft, split, or rent;, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, AnflEt AlbayoDapu, and [in an intensive sense] tfl-Et↓, The egg became cleft, split, or cracked asunder. (IF, O.) And tfl-Et↓ qadamuhu His foot became cleft in several, or many, places; or cracked, or chapped; syn. taXaq-aqat. (Ṣ.)
faloEN and filoEN↓ A fissure, or crack, in the foot, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,), &c.: (Ḳ:) pl. fuluwEN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like fuluwHN and fuluwjN. (O.)
filoEN: see what next precedes.
filoEapN A piece of the hump of a camel: (O, Ḳ, TA:) pl. filaEN. (TA.)

laEana Qll-ehu filoEatahaA (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) is a foul phrase, (Ṣ,) a phrase used in reviling; (O, Ḳ;) or, as in the T, one says in reviling a female slave, qabaHa Qll-ehu filoEatahaA, meaning [May God remove far from all that is good] her rima vulvæ; or what is cleft, or cracked, or chapped, of her heel: or, as Kr says, falaEatahaA↓, app. meaning farojahaA [her vulva]; for falaEapN, [thus] muHar-akap, means the faroj. (TA.)
falaEapN: see what next precedes.
faluwEN A very sharp sword; one that cuts much: pl. fuloEN. (Ḳ. [See also mifolaEN.])
faAliEapN A calamity, or misfortune: pl. fawaAliEu. (O, Ḳ.)
mifolaEN A sharp, or cutting, sword. (TA. [See also faluwEN.])
mazaAdapN mufal-aEapN [A leathern water-bag composed] of several pieces of skins sewed together. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. falaqahu, aor. _i {yafoliqu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. faloqN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) He split it, clave it, or divided it lengthwise; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also fl-qhu↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoliyqN; (Ṣ;) or the latter has an intensive signification [or relates to a number of objects]. (O,* Mṣb.) ʼAlee used often to swear by saying, waQl-aciI falaqa AlHab-apa wabaraOa Aln-asamapa [By Him who clave the grain, making it to germinate, and created, or produced, man, or the soul]. (TA.)
[Hence,] falaqa AlS-uboHa, (Ṣ,) or Alfajora, (TA,) said of God, (Ṣ,* TA,) He made the dawn [to break, or] to appear. (TA.)
flqt Aln-axolapu [app. falaqat, the part. n. being faAliqN, q. v.,] means The palm-tree split, or clave, from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] the spathe. (TA.)
And falaqa fiI AlOaroDi, aor. _i {yafoliqu}, inf. n. faloqN, He ment far into the land; like galaqu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O and TA in art. glq.)

And faloqN, (Ḳ,) as inf. n. of falaqa in the phrase falaqa Suwfa Aljilodi, (TḲ,) signifies The plucking of the wool of the bide when it has become stinking; like maroqN. (Ḳ, TA. [kAlmaraq-i, in the CK, is a mistake, for kAlmaroqi.])

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, first sentence.

4. Aflq He did, or performed, or he uttered, what was admirable, or wonderful; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) said of a man, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and (TA) of a poet, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in his poetry; (TA;) as also Aftlq↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [From filoqN, q, v.]

And He brought to pass that which was a calamity; (Ḳ;) as also Aftlq↓. (Lḥ, TA.) One says to a man, OaEolaqota waOafolaqota i. e. jiYota biEulaqa fulaqa, meaning [Thou hast brought to pass] that which is a calamity. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)
And Aflq fiI AlOmori He was, or became, skilled in the affair. (TA.)

5: see 7, first sentence. [Hence] one says, taSad-aEati AlbayoDapu walamo tatafal-aqo [The egg cracked, or rather cracked in several places, but did not split apart, or did not split much]. (Az, Ṣ in art. qyD.) And of milk such as is termed raAYib [q. v.] one says tfl-q meaning It became dissundered, or curdled, by reason of intense sourness: or, as heard by Az from some of the Arabs, it, being collected in a skin, and smitten by the heat of the sun, became dissundered, or curdled, so that the milk [or curds] became separate [from the whey]: and of such milk they loathe the drinking. (TA.)
And tfl-q AlS-aboHu: see 7.
tfl-q said of a boy: see Q. Q. 2.
See also 8, in two places.

7. Anflq It became split, cleft, or cloven, or divided lengthwise; it split, clave, or clave asunder; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tfl-q↓; (Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ;) [or] the latter signifies taXaq-aqa [i. e. it became split,, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several or many places]. (O, Mṣb.) The former occurs in the Ḳur xxvi. 63, said of the sea [as meaning It clave asunder]. (O.)
[Hence,] Anflq AlS-uboHu (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. ETs) and tfl-q↓ (TA in the present art.) The dawn broke. (TA in explanation of the latter.)

8. Aftlq He (a man, TA) strove, or exerted himself, so that he excited wonder by reason of his vehemence in running; as also tfl-q↓ and tafayolaqa↓. (Ḳ.) One says, mar-a yafotaliqu fiI Eadowihi, (Ṣ, O,) and yatafal-aqu↓ fiyhi, and yatafayolaqu↓, (O,) He passed along doing what was wonderful by reason of his vehemence in his running. (Ṣ, O.) See also 4, in two places.
Q. Q. 2. tafayolaqa, said of a boy, He became big, or bulky, and fat, or plump; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as also tfl-q↓; both mentioned in the “Nawádir.” (TA.)
See also 8, in two places.

hom.sense: faloqN, (AHeyth, TA,) or falaqN↓, (Ṣ, O, TA,) the former said by AHeyth to be the more correct, (TA,) A split, fissure, cleft, or longitudinal division; syn. Xaq-N: pl. fuluwqN: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and falaqN↓ (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA) [or faloqN?] signifies also [particularly] a fissure, or cleft, (Xaq-N) in a mountain; (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA;) and so faAliqN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and a XiEob [app. meaning gap, or ravine, or pass]. (TA.) One says, mararotu biHar-apK fiyhaA fuluwqN, meaning XuquwqF [i. e. I passed by a stony tract such as is termed Har-ap in which were fissures, or clefts]. (Ṣ, O.) And fiI rijolihi fuluwqN i. e. XuquwqN [In his foot, or leg, are fissures or clefts]. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O,* Ḳ.) And kal-amaniI mino faloqi fiyhi (Lḥ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and filoqi↓ fiyhi, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more known, (TA,) meaning mino Xaq-ihi [He spoke to me from out the fissure of his mouth, i. e., with his lips, not by means of a spokesman]. (Ḳ.) And Drabahu EalaI faloqi raOosihi He struck him on the place where his hair was separated, the middle of his head. (TA.)
See also falaqN.
And see the paragraph here following, last quarter.
filoqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
See also filoqapN, in two places.

Also A rod, or branch, that is split in two, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [i. e., in halves,] and of which are then made two bows, each whereof is termed filoqN, (Ṣ, O,) [or] each half (kul-u Xiq-K [in the CK Xaq-K]) of what is thus split is termed filoqN: (Ḳ, TA:) and thus is termed a bow that is made of the half of a branch, (Ḳ, TA,) the branch being split in two; and it is also termed qawosN filoqN, the latter word being thus used as an epithet, on the authority of Lḥ: or, as AḤn says, the bow termed filoqN is one of which the wood whereof it has been made has been previously split in two, or three, pieces: and he also says that faliyqN↓ [app. for qawosN faliyqN] signifies a bow of which the piece of wood has been split in two pieces. (TA.) [See also XariyjN, in two places: and see faroEN.]

Also A wonderful thing or affair or case; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also faliyqN↓, (Ḳ,) and fayolaqN↓, (TA,) and faliyqapN↓, (O,* TA,) of which last an ex. occurs in the prov.,
yaA EajabiI lihecahi AlfaliyqahN
halo tagoliban-a AlquwabaMCu Alr-iyqahu
[O my wonder at this wonderful thing! Does the ringworm indeed overcome the spittle?]: AA says, the meaning is, that he was in wonder at the alteration of usual occurrences; for the spittle usually dispels the ringworm, so he spat upon his ringworm, but it did not become healed: AlqwbMC is made an agent; and Alryqp, an objective complement. (O, TA.)

And A calamity, or misfortune; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also filoqapN↓, (Ḳ, TA, accord. to the CK faloqN↓,) and faliyqN↓, (O, Ḳ,) and faliyqapN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and faloqaI↓ (Ḳ, TA) or falaqaI↓, (TA,) and fayolaqN↓, (O and CK,) and mafolaqapN↓. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.) The Arabs say, yaA lilofaliyqapi↓ O [come with succour] to the calamity. (Ṣ, O.) And jaMCa biEulaqa fulaqa↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) imperfectly decl., (Ṣ, O,) i. e. [He brought to pass] that which was a calamity: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:)
and biEulaqF fulaqK↓: (O, Ḳ:) or this means a very wonderful thing. (TA.)
falaqN: see faloqN, first sentence, in two places.

Also The daybreak, or dawn; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also faloqN↓, mentioned by Z and others; (TA;) and thus the former has been expl. as signifying in the Ḳur cxiii. 1: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or what has broken (Anflq) of the Eamuwd of the dawn; (Fr. Ḳ, TA;) i. e. [of the bright gleam of dawn; of the dawn that rises and spreads, filling the horizon with its whiteness; or] the extending light that is like the [long tent called] Eamuwd: (TA:) or [simply] the light of daybreak or dawn: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or the appearing of the daybreak or dawn: (Zj, TA:) and falaqu AlS-uboHi signifies the light, and shining, or bright shining, of the daybreak or dawn: (TA:) one says, huwaOaboyanu mino falaqi AlS-uboHi and faraqi AlS-uboHi [It is more distinct than what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn]. (O, TA.)
And [hence,] The plain appearing of the truth after its having been dubious. (TA.)

Also A law, or depressed, place of the earth, between two kills, or elevated grounds; (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also faAliqN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and faAliqapN↓, (Ḳ,) which last is said by Aboo-Kheyreh, or some other, of the Arabs of the desert, to be in the midst of mountains, giving growth to trees, a place where people alight and where camels, or other cattle, remain during the cold night, saying that the faAliq↓ is of hard, or hard and level, ground; (TA:) and the pl. of falaqN is fuloqaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and OafolaAqN also: (TA:) or falaqN, (Ḳ,) or faAliqN↓, (TA,) signifies a wide tract of land or ground, between two extended tracts of sand; (Ḳ, TA;) and the pl. of the latter word is fuloqaAnN, like as HujoraAnN is pl. of HaAjirN. (TA.)
And Alfalaqu signifies Hell; syn. jahan-amu: (Ḳ:) or a certain well (jub-N) therein. (Es-Suddee, O, Ḳ.)
And The whole creation; all the beings, or things, that are created. (Zj, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) This, accord. to some, is the meaning in the Ḳur cxiii. 1. (Ṣ, O.)

And What remains, of milk, in the bottom of the bowl; whence one says, (in reviling a person, attributing to him meanness, TA,) yaA Qbona XaAribi Alfalaqi [O son of the drinker of what remains, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And The milk that is in a dissundered, or curdled, state, by reason of sourness; as also mutafal-iqN↓. (Ḳ.)

And The miqoTarap of the keeper of a prison; (Ṣ, O,* Ḳ;) i. e. [a kind of stocks;] a piece of wood in which are holes of the size of the shank, wherein men are confined, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. thieves and waylayers, (TA,) in a row: (Ḳ, TA:) whence the saying of Z, baAta fulaAnN fiI AlX-afaqi waAlfalaqi mina AlX-afaqi UilaI Alfalaqi i. e. [Such a one passed the night] in fear and the mqTrp [from the time of the redness of the region of sunset after the setting of the sun until the dawn]. (TA.) See also falaqapN.

entry.sense: jaMCa biEulaqa fulaqa: and biEulaqK fulaqK: see filoqN, last sentence.

Alfaloqapu A certain brand, beneath the ear of a camel, (O, Ḳ,) in the form of a ring in the middle of which is a perpendicular line dividing it [from top to bottom, and, in some copies of the Ḳ, extending downwards so that about half of its length is below the ring]. (O, Ḳ.* [In some copies of the latter it is figured, but somewhat differently in different copies.])
See also falaqapN.

hom.sense: filoqapN A piece [properly that has been split off] (Mgh, Mṣb, KL) of a thing; as also filoqN↓: (KL:) or a fragment, or piece broken off, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) of bread, or of a [bowl such as is termed] jafonap, (TA,) or of this latter the half, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) as in the saying OaEoTiniI filoqapa Aljafonapi [Give thou to me the half of the bowl, perhaps meaning, of its contents], (Ṣ, O, TA,) or, as some say, one of the divided halves thereof: (TA:) the pl. of filoqapN is filaqN: (Mgh, TA;*) and [filaAqN↓ is app. a pl., like OafolaAqN, (and perhaps fuluwqN, mentioned voce fulaAqN,) and fulaAqN↓ a quasi-pl. n., of filoqN↓, all agreeably with analogy; whence] one says, SaAra AlbayoDu filaAqFA↓, and fulaAqFA↓, meaning OafolaAqFA, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. e. [The eggs became fragments; or it means, became cleft in pieces; or] became much cleft, or cleft in many places. (Ḳ, TA. [See also falaAqN and filaAqN below.])
See also filoqN, last quarter.

entry.sense: falaqapN [signifies, in the present day, A thick staff, to the ends of which are attacked the two ends of a rope, by means whereof a man's legs are secured, between the rope and the staff, when he is bastinaded; and it is also called falaqN↓: this may perhaps be meant by its being said in the TA, on the authority of Lḥ, that Alfalaqapu signifies AlxaXabapu; as also Alfaloqapu↓].
faloqaI, or falaqaI: see filoqN, last quarter.
faloqaMCu AlD-ar-api A ewe, or she-goat, (XaApN,) wide, or ample, in the udder. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
fuloqaAnN A sheer, or an unmixed, lie. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) [It is also a pl.: see falaqN, in two places.]
fulaAqN: see filoqapN, in two places.

Also, (O, Ḳ,) and fuluwqN, (thus in the O,) or faluwqN↓, like SabuwrN, (thus in the Ḳ, [but this I think questionable,]) Milk becoming, or become, like cheese: (O, Ḳ:) [or fulaAqN may be here a quasi-pl. n. of filoqN (q. v. voce filoqapN), so that the meaning may be, that has become cleft portions of curd; and fuluwqN may also mean thus as a pl. of filoqN. See also the next paragraph.]
filaAqN: see filoqapN, in two places.

Also The state of milk's becoming thick and sour, so that it curdles, or becomes dissundered: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) [or it may be here a pl. of filoqN (q. v. voce filoqapN), for in a verse cited by IAạr the milk in this case is termed cuw filaAqK, so that it may mean the separate portions of curd of milk that has become thick and sour; though it is said in the TA that its pl. is fuluwqN, for this I think very questionable. See also the next preceding paragraph]
faluwqN: see fulaAqN.

hom.sense: faliyqN: see filoqN, former half.

Also The depressed place in the jiraAn [or under part of the neck] of the camel, where is the passage of the windpipe: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Lth, the part that is [as though it were] cleft, of the interior of the neck of the camel: (O, TA:) or, as some say, the part between the [two sinews called the] EilobaAwaAni, when the fur between these is [as though it were] cleft: and it is not said in relation to a human being. (TA.)

And Alfaliyqu also signifies [The cephalic vein;] a certain vein in the upper arm, (O, Ḳ,) that runs to the [cartilage called] nugoDi of the shoulder-blade: it is the vein of the waAhinap; and is [also] called AljaAYifu [q. v., and see also Alwariydu.] (O.) And A certain vein that swells up in the neck. (Ḳ.)
See, again, filoqN, in two places.

entry.sense: fulaAqapu Mjur-K A piece of baked brick: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) pl. filaAqN. (So in copies of the Ḳ. [Probably a mistranscription for fulaAqN↓, which, if correct, is properly a coll. gen. n.])

hom.sense: faliyqapN: see filoqN, in three places.

Also A quantity collected together, (faliylapN, Ḳ, TA, in the O without any point to the first letter,) or a small quantity, (qaliylapN, thus in some copies of the Ḳ,) of hair: (O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád. (O, TA.)

And A sort of broth; thus termed by the people of El-Medeeneh; occurring in a trad. as related by Ibráheem El-Ḥarbee; (O;) or a pottage (qidorN) that is cooked, and into which fragments (filaq, i. e. kisar,) of bread are crumbled: (TA:) but accord. to AA, it is called fariyqapN only. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: ful-uwqN: see mufal-aqN.
ful-ayoqN: see mufal-aqN.

faAliqN Splitting, cleaving, or dividing lengthwise. (TA.) faAliqu QloHab-i waQln-awaI, (O, Ḳ,*) in the Ḳur [vi. 95], (O,) means The Cleaver of the dry grain so as to produce therefrom green leaves [and of the date-stone]: or, as some say, the Creator thereof. (O, Ḳ.*) And hence the saying of Áïsheh, Uin-a AlbukaMCa faAliqN kabidiI [Verily weeping is cleaving my liver]. (TA.)
Hence, also, in the Ḳur [vi. 96], faAliqN AlUiSobaAHi He who causeth the dawn to break: in which instance, also, fAlq has reference to the meaning of Creator: (O, TA:) so says Zj. (TA.)
naxolapN faAliqN means A palmtree splitting, or cleaving from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] the spathe: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) pl. fuloqN. (TA.)
AlfawaAliqu as pl. of AlfaAliqu signifies The veins that divide [so as to form ramifying veins (thus I render AlEuruwqu Almutafal-iqapu↓)] in the human being. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
See also faloqN, first sentence.
And see falaqN, former half, in three places.

xal-ayotuhu bifaAliqapi↓ Alwarikapi, or, as in the T, bifaAliqi AlwrkMC, [thus in the TA, but I think that Alwrkp and AlwrkMC are evidently mistranscriptions, and that the right reading is AlwadokaMCi, with dAl,] meaning [I left him in the low, or depressed, tract in the midst of] the sand [called El-Wedkà]. (TA.)

hom.sense: fayolaqN An army; a military force: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a great [military force such as is termed] katiybap: (Ḳṭ, Mṣb, TA:) this is the primary signification, and the only one known to Ḳṭ: (TA:) pl. fayaAliqu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, ramaAhumo bifayolaqK XahobaMCa, meaning [He assailed them] with a formidable [great] katiybap. (TA.)

And A great, big, or large, man: (O, Ḳ:) occurring in this sense in a trad., as an epithet applied to Ed-Dejjál: Ḳṭ doubted whether it were thus or fayolamN; but Az affirms that both have this meaning. (O.) And one says, buliIa fulaAno biQmoraOapK fayolaqK, meaning [Such a one was tried, or afflicted, with a woman, or wife,] cunning, evil, and clamourous. (TA.)
See also filoqN, in two places.
Also [The cocoon of a silk-worm;] the thing from which qaz- is obtained; an arabicized word. (Mṣb voce fayolajN, q. v.: mentioned also in the Mgh, in art. frX.)

entry.sense: faAliqapN, as a subst.: see falaqN, former half: and see also faAliqN, last sentence.
futila fulaAnN Oafolaqa qitolapK means Such a one was slain with the hardest, or most violent, sort of slaughter. (Lḥ, TA.)
And maA raOayotu sayorFA Oafolaqa mino hecaA I have not seen a journey further in extent than this. (Lḥ, TA.)
mufoliqN A poet who poetizes admirably, or wonderfully. (Ṣ, O.)
mafolaqapN: see filoqN, last quarter.

mufal-aqN, applied to a peach, and an apricot, and the like, that splits, or cleaves, from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] its stone, and becomes dry: and fal-uwqN↓, with damm to the f, and also to the l, with teshdeed, signifies such as does not become dry: (Mṣb:) or ful-ayoqN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) with damm and [then] teshdeed, (Ṣ,) like qub-ayoTN, (O, Ḳ,) signifies, applied to a peach, that splits, or cleaves, from [around] its stone: and mufal-aqN, such as becomes dry. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mifolaAqN A man low, ignoble, or mean, and poor, or destitute: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) or one who possesses no property: pl. mafaAliyqu: and to such is likened such as possesses no knowledge nor understanding of a juridical decision. (O.) And A man who does, or utters, evil, or disliked, or hateful, things. (TA.)
mafoluwqN A camel marked with the brand termed faloqap [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)
mutafal-iqN: see falaqN, last quarter:
and see faAliqN.
faloqasN: see the following paragraph, latter sentence.

falanoqasN One whose mother is Arab, but not his father: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) or one whose father is such as is termed mawolFI [i. e. a freedman under the patronage of his emancipator], and whose mother is Arab; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) thus says AʼObeyd, (Ṣ, O,) and thus Sh: (TA:) or one whose father and mother are Arabs, and whose two grandmothers are slaves; (O, Ḳ;) thus accord. to AZ and AHeyth (O) and ISk, and this is [said to be] the right explanation: (TA:) or one whose father is a mwlI [expl. above], and his mother the like, i. e. a mawolaAp; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) thus accord. to Abu-lGhowth. (Ṣ, O.)
Also, (O, Ḳ,) and faloqasN↓, (Ḳ,) Niggardly, or a niggard; and vile, or ignoble. (O, Ḳ.*)
1: see the next paragraph {2}, in two places.

hom.sense: 2. fl-k, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafokiykN, (Ṣ,) said of a girl's breast, It became round, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) like the falokap [or whirl (of a spindle)], but less than is denoted by nuhuwdN [inf. n. of nahada, q. v.]; (TA;) as also tfl-k↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and Aflk↓, (Th, O, Ḳ,) and falaka↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
See also falokapN, second sentence.

Alt-afokiyku also signifies The pastor's making, of course hair (hulob), a thing like the falokap (AA, T, Ṣ, O, TA) of the spindle, (AA, T, TA,) and inserting it into the tongue of the young unweaned camel, (AA, T, Ṣ, O, TA,) having perforated the tongue [for that purpose], (AA, T, TA,) in order that he may not such: (AA, T, Ṣ, O, TA:) accord. to Lth, fal-akotu AljadoIa signifies I put a twig around the tongue of the kid in order that it might not suck: but Az says that the right explanation of Altfkyk is that of AA [given above]. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. jr, and 4 in art. lhj.]
And fl-k, inf. n. as above, He (a man) persisted, or persevered, (laj-a,) in an affair; (Ḳ, TA;) and so Aflk↓. (TA.)
And fl-kt She (a bitch) desired copulation, and discharged blood from the womb; syn. AjElt wHADt. (O, Ḳ.)
4: see 2, first sentence:
and falokapN, second sentence:
and see also 2, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: 5: see 2, first sentence.

hom.sense: fulokN A ship: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.:) [also particularly applied to the ark of Noah; as in the Ḳur-án vii. 62, &c.:] the word is generally thus only; but some say fulukN↓ also, with two dammehs; and it is held that this may be the original form; and that fulokN may be a contraction, like as EunoqN is [of gunuqN accord. to Sb]: (MF, TA:) it is masc. and fem., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) and sing. and pl., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and Ibn-ʼAbbád says that it has fuluwkN also for a pl.: (O:) [it is said that] it may be sing., and in this case masc.; and pl., and in this case fem.: (IB, Mṣb:) [but see what here follows:] it occurs in the Ḳur-án in the following (and other) places: in xxvi. 119, &c.; where it is sing. and masc.: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and in [xvi. 14 and] xxxv. 13; where it is pl. [and fem.]: (TA:) and in ii. 159; where it is fem., and may be either pl. or sing.: it seems that, when it is sing., it is regarded as meaning the marokab, and is therefore made masc.; or the safiynap, and is therefore made fem.: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or, (Ḳ,) as Sb used to say, (Ṣ, O, TA,) the fulok that is a pl. [in meaning] is a broken pl. of that, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. of the fulok, (IB, O, Ḳ, TA,) that is a sing. [in meaning]: and it is not like Aljunubu, which is sing. and pl. [in meaning], and the like thereof (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) among substs., such as AlT-ifolu, &c.; (Ṣ, O, TA;) for fulokaAni has been heard from the Arabs as dual of fulokN, but not junubaAni [or the like] as dual of junubN [or the like]; and they say that what has not been dualized is not a pl. [form], but [is, or may be,] a homonym, and what has been dualized [is, or may be,] a pl. [form]: (MF, TA:) Sb then says in continuation, (TA,) for fuEolN and faEalN share in application to one thing [or meaning], as AlEurobu and AlEarabu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,), &c.; (Ṣ, O, TA;) and as it is allowable for faEalN to have for its pl. fuEolN, as in the instance of OasadN and OusodN, so too fuEolN may have for its pl. fuEolN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) fulokiI-N↓ is a dial. var. of fulokN; and Abu-d-Dardà read, [in the Ḳur x. 23,] kunotumo fiI QlofulokiI-i [When ye are in the ships; where others read fI Alfuloki; and where the context shows that the pl. meaning is intended]. (IJ, TA.)
[It may also be a pl. of the word next following].

entry.sense: Alfalaku The place of the revolving of the stars; (O, Ḳ, TA;) [the celestial sphere: but generally imagined by the Arabs to be a material concave hemisphere; so that it may be termed the vault of heaven; or the firmament:] the astronomers say that it is [a term applied to every one, by itself, of] seven OaTowaAq [by which they mean surrounding spheres], exclusive of the samaMC [or sky, as meaning the region of the clouds]; wherein have been set the seven stars [i. e. the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn], in every Tawoq [or surrounding sphere] a star, some being higher than others; revolving therein: (TA:) [it is also commonly imagined that above these is an eighth sphere, called by the astronomers falaku Alv-awaAbiti (the sphere of the fixed stars), and by others falaku AlkurosiI-i; and above this, a ninth, called falaku AlOaTolasi and falaku AlEaroXi, and also called AlOaviyru (q. v.):] the pl. is OafolaAkN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and fulukN (Ḳ, TA) and fulokN may be another pl., like as OusodN and xuXubN are pls. of OasadN and xaXabN (Ṣ, O, TA. [Thus accord. to both of my copies of the Ṣ, as well as the O and TA: but it may be that OusodN and xuXobN are mistranscriptions for OusudN and xuXubN; and therefore that for fulokN (which is not mentioned as a pl. of falakN in the Ḳ) we should read fulukN.]) And falaku Als-amMCi signifies The pole of heaven; [generally the north celestial pole;] likened to the pivot, or axis, of the mill-stone. (TA.)
Also (i. e. Alfalaku) The revolving of the heaven [or celestial sphere]. (TA.)
And falakN signifies also The circuit, and main part, of any- thing. (Ḳ.)

And Waves of the sea in a state of commotion, (O, Ḳ, TA,) circling, (TA,) and going to and fro. (O, TA.) This, (O, TA,) or what is next mentioned, (TA,) or the place of revolving of the stars, (O,) or the pole of heaven, (TA,) is meant in a trad. where it is said of a horse smitten by the [evil] eye, that he was as though he were turning in a falak. (O, TA.) And Water put in motion by the wind, (O, Ḳ, TA,) going to and fro, in a state of commotion: (O, TA:) mentioned by Z. (TA.)

Also A hill, or mound, of sand, having around it a wide expanse of land: (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA:) or falakN mina Alr-amoli signifies rugged, round Oajowibap [app. a pl. of jawobap (though I do not find it mentioned as such), and meaning depressed and clear places], of the sands, like [tracts of] what are termed kac-aAn [or soft stones resembling dry pieces of clay], hollowed out by the gazelles. (TA.)

And Pieces of land, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or of sand, (Ṣ,) having a circular form, and elevated above what is around them, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) with ruggedness and evenness; (TA;) one whereof is termed falokapN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) with the l quiescent; pl. filaAkN; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. [this is pl. of falokapN,] like qaSoEapN and qiSaAEN: (TA:) in [the book entitled] El-Ghareeb El-Musannaf, [by Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, we find] falakapN↓ and falakN, [each] biAlt-aHoriyk; [accord. to which, falakapN is a n. un., and falakN is a coll. gen. n.;] but in “the Book” of Sb, [agreeably with the Ḳ, we find] falokapN↓ [as a sing.] and falakN [as a quasi-pl. n.], like HaloqapN and HalaqN. (IB, TA.)
See also falokapN, in two places.

falikN A slave (AA, O) having a buttock like the falokap [or whirl] of a spindle (AA, O, Ḳ) in shape; (AA, O;) resembling the Zenj; (Ḳ;) [for] the buttocks of the Zenj are round: (AA, O:) or large in the buttocks. (TA.) And (O, Ḳ) it is said to signify (O) Thick, or coarse of make, in the joints: (O, Ḳ:) and loose in the bones; (Ḳ;) or weak, loose in the bones, and flaccid; thus expl. by Ibn-ʼAbbád: (O:) and having a pain in his patella (fiI falokapi rukobatihi). (O, Ḳ.)
fulukN: i. q. fulokN, q. v.
And a pl. of falakN. (Ḳ, TA.)

falokapN The whirl of a spindle: (MA:) [this is what is meant by the saying that] the falokap of the migozal is well known; (Ḳ;) [and] is thus called because of its roundness: (Ṣ, O:) [it is a piece of wood, generally of a hemispherical form, or nearly so, through the middle of which the upper part of the spindle-pin is inserted:] also pronounced filokap↓: (O, Ḳ:) the pl. [of the former] is falakN↓ [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and [that of the latter sing. is] filakN. (TA.)

And A thing that is made round, or hemispherical, (yufal-aku↓, or yufolaku↓, accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) like the falokap of the spindle, of coarse hair (hulob), then the tongue of the young unweaned camel is perforated, [and this thing is inserted into it, (see 2, and see also 4 in art. lhj,)] in order that he may be prevented from sucking. (Ḳ. [For ftaxoriqu lisAnu AlfaSiyli in the CK, I read fayuxoraqu lisaAnu AlfaSiyli, as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA: after these words, the copies of the Ḳ have fayuEoDadu bihi, app a mistranscription for some phrase meaning fayujoEalu fiyhi, which is necessary to complete the explanation.])

And An [eminence such as is termed] OakamahN [formed] of one mass of stone; (Ḳ, TA;) accord. to ISh, [of] the smaller of the [eminences termed] UikaAm, compact in its head, as though this were the falokap of a spindle, not giving growth to anything, in height of the measure of two spears or a spear and a half. (TA.)
See also flakN, near the end, in two places.
Also Anything circular, (Ḳ.)

And [particularly] The joint [or cartilaginous disk] between the two vertebræ [i. e. between any one of the vertebrœ and that next to it] of the camel: (Ḳ, TA:) and the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] thereof, in this sense and in the last two of the sense following, is falakN↓. (TA.)
[And The cap of the knee; (see falikN;) falokapu Alr-ukobapi signifying the patella: so in the present day.]

And The small thing (Alhanapu [app. the foramen cæcum, from its round form, for, though the TA adds the epithet Aln-aAXiYapu, which means “rising,” I think that this addition may be conjectural,]) upon the head of the root of the tongue. (Ḳ.)

And The side of the [portion of the breast called the] zawor [q. v.], and the part thereof that is round, or circular. (Ḳ. [But see balodapN: where it is said that “the falak of the zawor of a horse are six in number:” what they are I have been unable to determine: I incline to think that they may be spiral curls, such as are termed dawaAYir, pl. of daAYirapN.])
filokapN: see falokapN, first sentence.
falakapN: see falakN, near the end.
fulokiI-N: see fulokN, last sentence but one.
falakiI-N [Of, or relating to, the falak as meaning the celestial sphere.]
[And] One who occupies himself [as an astronomer, or astrologer] with the science of the stars. (TA.)
fulayokapN [dim. of fulokN, which is sometimes fem. when used as a sing. as well as when used as a pl.,] A small ship: the vulgar say flwkp [i. e. faluwkap; whence the Italian “feluca”]. (TA.)

faAlikN and mufal-ikN↓ A girl whose breast is becoming round, (Ḳ, TA,) like the falokap [or whirl (of a spindle)]. (TA.) [And the former is also applied as an epithet to the breast: for] AA says that [the pl.] fawaAliku is applied to breasts (vudiI-) that are less than such as are termed nawaAhidu. (TA.)

hom.sense: fayolakuwnN The Xuwbaq [or baker's rolling-pin: see the latter word]: (O, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, Als-awiyqu is erroneously put for AlX-uwbaqu:]) Az holds both of these words to be arabicized. (O.)
And (TA) The barodiI- [or papyrus]. (Ṣ; and Ḳ in art. flkn.)
And Tar, or pitch; syn. qaArN, or zifotN. (Ḳ. n art. flkn.)
And qawosN fayolakuwnN A great bow. (TA in art. flkn.)

entry.sense: Oafolaku One who goes round about the falak, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) i. e. the hill, or mound, of sand that has around it a wide expanse of land. (IAạr, O.)
AlUifoliykaAni Two portions of flesh which border, on each side, the lahaAp; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) i. e. they are the gunodubataAni [q. v.]. (IDrd, O.)
mufal-ikN: see faAlikN.

fulaAnN is a substitute for the proper name of a human being, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA,) i. e. of a male; (Ṣ, TA;) and in like manner fulaAnapu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) for that of a female; (TA,) each without Al; (Mṣb:) [the former may be rendered Such a one, or Such a man; and the latter, Such a woman:] and AlfulaAnu and AlfulaAnapu↓ for other than a human being, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. for a [particular] camel, (Lth, TA,) or for a [particular] beast, as in the saying, rakibotu AlfulaAna [I rode such a beast, i. e. such a male beast], and Halabotu AlfulaAnapa↓ [I milked such a beast]: (Mṣb, TA:) fulaAnN has no dual nor pl.: (IB, TA:) [but] sometimes one says to a single person, masc., yaA fulu; and to two, yaA fulaAni; and to a pl. number, yaAfuluwna: and in the fem., yaA fulapu;, &c.; (Ḳ: [see more in art. fl:]) accord. to Kh, fulaAnN is of the measure fuEaAlN; and its dim. is fulayonN↓: (TA:) or, as some say, it is of the measure fulaAnN, [originally fulowaAnN,] with w rejected, therefore its dim. is fulay-aAnN↓ [originally fulayowaAnN]; (T, L, TA;) like as UnosaAnN is [said by some to be] UnosiyaAnN, of which the I is rejected. and therefore its dim. is OunyosiyaAnN. (T, L.)
fuliyonN: see the preceding paragraph.
fulaAnapu and AlfulaAnapu: see fulaAnN, in three places.

fulaAniI-N the rel. n. of fulaAnN: it is rendered indeterminate by the affix I; and by means of the article Aalo, it becomes determinate; therefore you say fulaAnN AlfulaAniI-u [meaning Such a one, the person named in relation to such a one], (TA,)
fulay-aAnN: see fulaAnN, near the end.
fulohuwdN: see the preceding paragraph.
mufalohadN: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. falaAhu, (M, Ḳ,) first pers. falawotuhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yafoluwu}, (TA,) inf. n. falowN, (M, Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ, and filaMCN accord. to the M, or falaMCN accord. to the Ḳ, (TA,) He withdrew him from sucking; namely, a colt, (M, Ḳ,) and a young ass, (M,) and a child; (M, Ḳ;) as also AflAhu↓, and AftlAhu↓: (M, Ḳ:*) or he weaned, or ablactated, him, as also AflAhu↓, and AftlAhu↓: (Ḳ:) or falaAhu Eano Oum-ihi and AftlAhu↓ signify thus; relating to a colt and a young ass: (Ṣ: [and in a similar manner both are expl. in the T, on the authority of ISk:]) or falaAhu, (M,) or falaAhu Eano Oum-ihi, relating to a colt and a young ass, (T,) signifies thus; (T, M;) but AftlAhu↓, (M,) or AftlAhu linafosihi, (T,) signifies he took him for himself [app. from his mother]: (T, M:) or falawotuhu and Oafolayotuhu↓ signify I separated him from him mother; namely, a colt: and fuliyat is said of a filly [meaning she was separated, &c.]. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] the falaAp↓ [q. v.] is [said to be] thus called liOan-ahaA fuliyato Eano kul-i xayorK, [Because it is as though it were weaned, and removed, from everything good]. (M.)

And falawotuhu I reared him, or brought him up; [namely, a youth, or boy;] as also Aifotalayotuhu↓: a poet says,
walayosa yaholiku min-aA say-idN OabadFA
Uil-aA QfotalayonaA gulaAmFA say-idFA fiynaA
[And a chief of us does not ever perish but we rear a youth to be a chief among us]. (Ṣ.)

falaAhu biAls-ayofi, (M, Ḳ,) first pers. falawotuhu and falanotuhu, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. falowN and faloIN, (M in this art. and in art. flI,) He struck (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) him, (Ḳ,) or his head, (Ṣ, M,) with the sword: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or he struck, or cut, it, i. e. one's head, with the sword. (T * and M in art. flI.)
And falawotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people; like falayotuhumo. (T, TA.)
falaA as intrans., said of a man, He journeyed, or went forth to journey. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
And He became intelligent after being ignorant. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
4: see 1, first sentence, in three places.

Aflt said of a mare, (M, Ḳ,) and of a she-ass, (M,) means She was one whose colt had attained to the age for his being weaned, (M, Ḳ.) And the phrase qado Oafolayona OamohaAraA, ending a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, and referring to wild animals, means, as expl. by AḤn, that had become in the state in which their young ones were full-grown and in no need of their mothers. (M.)
And AflI Alqawomu The people, or party, came to the falaAp [or desert,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or, as Z says, entered it; which is nearly the same as the former explanation. (TA.)
8: see 1, in six places:
and see also art. flI.

entry.sense: falFA [a coll. gen. n.]: see falaApN.
yaA fulaA and yaA fulaApu: see yaA fulu, in art. fl.
filowN: see faluw-N.

falaApN A [desert such as is termed] qafor; (M, Ḳ;) so called for a reason mentioned above, in the first paragraph, q. v.; (M;) or [such as is called] mafaAzap; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) in which is no water; or, in the fewer cases, in which there is an interval of two days with a portion of the day preceding them and of the day following them between the waterings of camels and of one day between the waterings of asses and of sheep or goats (liloUibili riboEN waliloHamiyri waAlganami gab-N): (M, Ḳ:) or a land in which is no water: (Mṣb:) or a wide [desert such as is termed] SaHoraMC: (M, Ḳ:) pl. falawaAtN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (TA,) and falFA↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which falaApN is the n. un.,] and fuliI-N, (M, Ḳ,) or this is pl. of falFA, (Ṣ,) and [so are] filiI-N (M, Ḳ) and fuluw-N [which is the original of fuliI-N and filiI-N], (CK,) OafolaMCN is [likewise] pl. of falFA. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
[Oaxuw AlfalaApi A man of the desert: or one who travels in the desert or deserts.]
And Aibonu AlfalaApi The HirobaMC [or male chameleon]. (T in art. bnI.)
filaMCN, mentioned in the paragraph here following as a pl. of faluw-N, signifies also Bones. (TA.)

faluw-N (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fuluw-N (M, Ḳ) and filowN↓ (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) A colt, (Ṣ, Mgh,) because he is weaned; (Ṣ;) or a colt, and a young ass, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) when weaned, (M, Ḳ,) or separated from his mother: (Mṣb:) or when a year old; (Ḳ;) or faluw-N signifies also a colt that is a year old: (M: [see qaAriHN:]) and a light, or an active, ass: (IAạr, TA voce yaEofuwrN:) and sometimes (Ṣ) the female is called faluw-apN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the pl. is OafolaMCN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like OaEodaACN as pl. of Eaduw-N, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and like OaHobaArN as pl. of HiborN, (TA,) and also falaAwaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and fulowN, mentioned by Fr, (M, TA,) and filaMCN is mentioned as a pl. of faluw- signifying a colt by Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee. (TA.)
badawiy-apN falawiy-apN are epithets applied to a woman [each signifying Of, or belonging to, the falaAp, or desert]. (TA.)
mufolK and mufoliyapN A mare having a faluw-. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. falaI rOosahu, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and viyaAbahu, (Mgh,) [aor. _i {yafoliIu},] inf. n. faloIN; (M, Mgh;) and fl-I↓ raOosahu also; (Ḳ; [but not in my copy of the TA;]) He searched his head, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and his clothes, (Mgh,) for lice: (M, Mgh, Ḳ:) [and it appears from an explanation below (see 8) that AftlI raOosahu perhaps signifies the same:] or one says, falayotu raOosahu mina Alqamoli [I searched his head for lice]: (Ṣ:) or falayotu raOosiI, aor. as above, and so the inf. n., signifies I cleared my head of lice. (Mṣb.) [See also AlfilaMCu, below.] In the saying of ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-kerib,
taraAhu kaAlv-agaAmi yugal--u misokFA
yasuwoCu AlfaAliyaAti UicaA falayoniI
[Thou seest it (meaning the white hair intermixing with black) like the thagham (the plant so called) inserted in musk, grieving the lousing women when they louse me], falayoniI is for falayonaniI, (T, Ṣ,) the two n being deemed difficult of utterance; (T;) as Akh says, he has rejected the latter n because it is merely a preservative to the verb [lest its affix should be supposed to form an essential part of it], whereas the former n may not be rejected, because it is the pronoun of the verb. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] falaI AlX-iEora, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He considered, and endeavoured to understand, the poetry, and elicited its meanings, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and what was strange of it: (ISk, Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to the A, he investigated the meanings of the poetry: one says, Aifoli hecaA Albayota faUin-ahu SaEobN ‡ [Investigate thou the meaning of this verse, for it is difficult]. (TA.) [Freytag has mentioned falaA, in art. flw, as signifying “Disquisivit,” and as followed by En; from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.] And falaI AlOamora † He considered, or examined, the various modes of the affair, or case, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of them, and looked to its result. (T, TA.) And falayotu Alquwma biEayoniI † [I examined the people, or party, with my eye, in order to know them]: and falayotu xabarahumo † [I examined their state, or case, in order to know it]. (TA.) And falaAhu fiI Eaqolihi, (T, M, Ḳ, TA,) aor. as above, (T, TA,) and so the inf. n., (M, TA,) ‡ He looked, or examined, to see what was his intelligence: (T, TA:) or he tried, or tested, him, in respect of his intelligence. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

falayotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people; (T, TA;*) as also falawotuhumo; (T;) and so Oafolayotuhumo↓. (TA.) And falaI AlmafaAzapa He passed through the mfAzp [i. e. desert, or waterless desert]. (TA.)
faliIa i. q. AinoqaTaEa [It, or he, was cut, or cut off,, &c.]. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see the first sentence above {1}.
4: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.
5. tfl-I He applied himself, as to a task, to the act of searching his head for lice. (T,* M, TA.)
6. tfAlt AlHumuru The asses scratched, scraped, or rubbed, one another; as though they were lousing one another. (M, TA.)
See also 10.

8. yafotaluwna AlfalaApa, (T,) or AlmakaAna, (Ḳ,*) ‡ They depasture the herbage (T, Ḳ *) of the flAp [or desert, or waterless desert,, &c.], (T,) or of the place, (Ḳ,) and seek for the portions of herbage that are beginning to dry up therein; like as [is done when] the head is searched for lice (kamaA yufotalaI Alr-aOosu or kmA yufolaI AlrOs accord. to two transcripts from the T). (T in arts. flw and flI of the TT.) [This meaning of the verb is expl. (imperfectly) in art. flw, to which it does not belong.]

hom.sense: 10. AstflI raOosahu, and tfAlI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. tfAlI huwa [not tfAlI rOsh], (Ṣ,) He desired that his head might be searched for lice. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And AstflAhu He exposed himself to have his head struck and cut with the sword: (M, TA:) a poet says,
OamaAtaraAniI raAbiTa AljanaAni
Oafoliyhi biAls-ayofi UicaA QsotafolaAniI
[Dost thou not see me to be strong of heart? I will strike and cut his head with the sword when he exposes himself to be so struck, &c.]

entry.sense: [filoyapN, mentioned in this art. by Freytag, with falaAliI-N as its pl., is taken by him from a mistranscription in the CK in art. fl: see fil-iy-apN in that art.]

AlflaMCu, like kisaMC [in measure], means flMC AlXEr, [evidently, I think, filaMCu AlX-aEara, or the first word may be a mistranscription for faloIu,] i. e. Axck mA fyh [lit. Thy taking what is in it, in which “it” refers to the XEr: app. a euphemism for the taking of lice from the hair: if so, it may be an inf. n., like faloIN; (see 1, first sentence;) or it may be a simple subst., like what here follows]: mentioned by IAmb, from his companions. (TA.)
filaAyapN [The act of searching the head for lice;] the subst. from falaI raOosahu signifying “he searched his head for lice.” (Lth,* T,* Ḳ.) [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

[faAlK act. part. n. of 1: fem. faAliyapN.] faAliyaAtN and fawaAlK [are pls. of faAliyapN and] signify Women who search the head for lice. (T, TA.) See an ex. of the former pl. in the verse cited in the first paragraph.

faAliyapu AlOafaAEiI (in which the former word is a pl. [in meaning], M, TA) signifies [lit. The lousers of the vipers; meaning,] accord. to the A, certain species of the kind [of beetles] called xanaAfis [pl. of xunofasaMC], speckled, found at the holes of the serpents, which they louse: (TA:) or a certain xnfsMC, speckled (M, Ḳ) with [the colour termed] SuHomap, which is found at the holes [of serpents, &c.], and is the mistress of xanaAfis; (M;) which is familiar with scorpions and serpents; so that when it comes forth from a hole [thereof], it makes known their existence [therein]: (Ḳ:) or certain small things like xnaAfs, speckled; which are familiar with scorpions and serpents; so that when they are seen in the hole [thereof] it is known that behind them are scorpions and serpents: (T:) or certain insects (dawaAb-u) that are found at the holes of the [lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of Dab-u]; so that when they come forth, it is known that the Dab- is coming forth inevitably. (M.) Hence one says, Attkm faAliyapu AlOafaAEiI, (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,*) meaning † The beginning of evil to be looked for [has come to you], (IAạr, T,) or the beginnings of evil [hare come to you]; (Ḳ;) which is a prov. (IAạr, T.)
And [hence] Aibonu AlfawaAliI means The jaAn-; i. e. the serpent [so called]. (T in art. bnI.)
faAliyapN [fem. of faAlK, q. v.]
[And also] A knife. (T.)

hom.sense:
famN The mouth: (MA, KL, &c.:) it is originally fawahN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Mṣb in art. fwh,) with two fet-ḥahs, (Mṣb in that art.,) or fawohN; (so in some copies of the Ṣ;) the h being cut off from it, the w is not susceptible of declension, because it is quiescent, therefore m is substituted for it; but when you form the dim. or the pl., you restore it to its original state, saying [in the former case] fuwayohN and [in the latter case] OafowaAhN, and not OafomaMCN [in some of the copies of the Ṣ not OafomaAmN]: but when you form the rel. n., you say famiI-N↓; and, if you will, famawiI-N↓, combining the substitute and the letter for which it is substituted, like as they say in the dual famawaAni; this being held to be allowable because of there being therein another letter rejected, i. e. the h, as though they made the m in this case to be a substitute for the h, not for the w: (Ṣ, TA:) and one says also famayaAni, which, like famawaAni, is anomalous; (IAạr, Ḳ in art. fwh;) but one says famaAni also, as well as famawaAni: (Mṣb in art. fwh:) it has three forms, famN and fumN and fimN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and some decline it doubly; saying in the nom. case fumN, accus. famFA, and gen. fimK; (Ṣ, TA;) like AimoruWN and AibonumN, which have been said to be the only other instances of the kind: (TA:) when it is prefixed to the [pronominal] I, one says fiI-a and famiI: but when to [a pronoun] other than the I, it is declined with the letters w and A and I, so that one says fuwuhu and faAhu and fiyhi; but one also says famuhu: (Mṣb. in art. fwh:) and sometimes the m is musheddedeh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in poetry, as in the saying, (Ṣ, TA,) of Moḥammad Ibn-Dhu-eyb El-'Ománee El-Fukeymee, the rájiz, (TA in this art. and in art. Tsm,) addressing Er-Rasheed, or, accord. to IKh, said in relation to Suleymán Ibn-ʼAbd-El-Melik and ʼAbd-El-'Azeez. (TA in art. Tsm,)
yaA layotahaA qado xarajato mino fum-ihi
Hat-aI yaEuwda Almuloku fiI OusoTum-ihi ; (Ṣ, TA) or OuTosum-ihi i. e. [O, would that it had gone forth from his mouth, so that the dominion might return] to its rightful owner; (Ṣ in art. sTm, and TA in art. Tsm;) and it would have been allowable, (Ṣ, TA,) accord. to ISk, (Ṣ,) or accord. to Fr, (TA,) if he had said mn fam-ihi↓, with fet-ḥ to the f: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. of fm, with teshdeed, is OafomaAmN; and its dim. is fumayomN↓, mentioned by Lḥ. (TA.) MF says that many of the expositors of the Tes-heel have collected the dial. vars. of this word, compounded and uncompounded, and they have exceeded twenty; that with fet-ḥ, they say, being the most common and the most chaste. (TA.) [See more in art. fwh.]
[Hence,] Alfm is metonymically applied to ‡ The teeth. (Ḥam p. 242.)
[Hence also,] famu AlHuwti † The star [a] in the mouth of Piscis Australis. (Ḳzw, &c.: see art. Hwt.) And famu Alfarasi † The star [e] upon the lip of Pegasus. (Ḳzw.)
[And famuAlr-aHimi † The mouth of the womb.]
And famu Aln-ahori † The mouth of the river. (MA.)
And [hence likewise,] famN is also used as meaning † Branch; opposed to AisotN meaning “root.” (TA in art. sth; in which see AisotN, last quarter.)
famN mina Ald-ibaAgi means The quantity that is used at one time, of tan; (Fr, Ḳ,* TA;) like nafosN minohu. (Fr, TA.)

entry.sense: famiI-N and famawiI-N: see the preceding paragraph, near the beginning.

fum-a a dial. var. of the conjunction tum-a [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) or the f in the former is a substitute for the v in the latter: one says, raOayotu EamorFA fum-a zayodFA and vum-a zayodFA, both meaning the same [i. e. I saw ʼAmr: then Zeyd]: (TA:) and in like manner one says fum-ata and fum-ato, meaning tum-ata and tum-ato. (M and TA voce vum-a.)
fum-N and fam-N: see the first paragraph, latter half.
fumayomN: see the first paragraph, latter half.
1. fan-ahu, (M,) or fan-a AlUibila, (T, Ṣ,) aor. _u {yafonunu}, (T, M,) inf. n. fan-N, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He drove away (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ *) him, (M,) or the camels. (T, Ṣ.)

And [fan-ahu also signifies He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, in the matter of his debt, by promising time after time to pay him; for] one of the significations of Alfan-u is AlmaTolu. (T, Ḳ.)

And fan-ahu,, aor. _u {yafonunu}, (M,) inf. n. fan-N, (M, Ḳ,) He cheated, deceived, overreached, or defrauded, him; or made him to suffer loss or damage or detriment; syn. of the inf. n. gabon-N. (M, Ḳ.)

And He caused him to suffer difficulty, distress, or trouble; or fatigue, or weariness; syn. Ean-aAhu; (M;) or the syn. of Alfan-u is AlEanaMCu [which is the subst. from Ean-aAhu; and signifies difficulty, distress, or trouble]. (T, Ḳ.)
[And He, or it, adorned. or decorated, him, or it; for] Alfan-u signifies Alt-azoyiynu. (Ḳ.)
2. fn-n Aln-aAsa He made the men, or people, to consist of different sorts, or of a medley, not of one tribe. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

fn-n AlHadiyva He diversified the narrative, or discourse. (MA.) And fn-n AlkalaAma [He diversified the speech, or language: or] he branched off into one mode after another [in speech]: and so tfn-n↓ [alone, this verb being intrans.]. (T, TA.) And fn-n raOoyahu He varied his opinion, not keeping steadily to one opinion. (T, TA.)

And [the inf. n.] tafoniynN signifies The mixing or confusing [a thing or things]; or a state of confusion or disorder; syn. taxoliyTN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence, as inf. n. of fun-ina,] in a garment, or piece of cloth, [the having] streaks differing from the rest: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the state of becoming dissundered, (T, M,) one part from another, (T,) when old and worn out, without becoming much rent: (T, M:) or difference (M, Ḳ) in its make (M) or in its texture, (Ḳ,) by thinness in one place and thickness in another: (M, Ḳ:) or Alt-afoniynu signifies [there being] what is a thin, or flimsy, unseemly place in the garment, or piece of cloth, that is [in other parts] thick, or compact. (T.)
And fn-n signifies also He sought many [or various] things. (Ḥar p. 612.)

hom.sense: 5. tfn-n It was, or became, of various sorts, or modes, or manners. (KL.)

See also 2. You say likewise tfn-n fiI AlkalaAmi [He practised, or took to, various modes, or manners, in speech; he diversified therein]. (TA in art. Trq, conj. 3. [Thus used, it is like Aftn-, q. v.])
And tfn-n fiI AlEuluwmi He was, or became, possessed of various acquirements in the sciences. (MA.)
Also It was, or became, in a state of commotion: thus expl. by some; others add, like the fanan [or branch]. (M.)

entry.sense: 8. Aftn- He began, commenced, or entered upon, various sorts of speech. (M, Ḳ.) And Aftn- fiI Hadiyvihi and fiI xuTobatihi He produced, or gave utterance to, various sorts and ways of speech, [i. e. he diversified,] in his narration, or discourse, and in his oration, or harangue: (Ṣ, TA:) it is like AiXotaq-a [meaning he branched off in it]. (Ṣ. [See also 5.]) And Aftn- fiI xuSuwmatihi He expatiated, and practised versatility, in his altercation, or disputation, or litigation. (TA.)
And Aftn- AlHimaAru biOutunihi The he-ass betook himself to driving away his she-asses to the right and to the left and in a direct and an indirect course. (TA.)
10. Astfn-hu He incited, urged, or made, him to practise various sorts, or modes, or manners, of pacing. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. fanofana He (a man, IAạr, T) caused his camels to become dispersed, by reason of indolence and remissness. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

fan-N A sort, or species, syn. DarobN, (T, M, Ḳ,) or nawoEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of a thing; (Mṣb;) as also OufonuwnN↓ [in this sense and in the senses here following; in the CK, erroneously, Aafonuwn]: (M, Ḳ:) and a state, or condition; syn. HaAlN: (M, Ḳ:) [and a way: (see what follows:)] and a mode, or manner: (MA:) pl. [of mult.] funuwnN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OafonaAnN. (T, M, Ḳ.) One says, raEayonaA funuwna Aln-abaAti [We pastured our cattle upon the various sorts of herbage]: and OaSabonaA funuwna AlOamowaAli [We obtained the various sorts of possessions]: and a poet says,
qado labisotu Ald-ahora mino OafonaAnihi
kul-u fan-K naAEimK minohu Habiro
[I have enjoyed of the various sorts of fortune, every pleasant, soft, sort thereof]. (T.) [OufonwunN↓ has for its pl. OafaAniyonu, which may also be regarded as pl. of OafonaAnN pl. of fan-N like as it is said to be a pl. pl. of fananN: and] OafaAniynu [alone], (Ṣ,) or OafaAniynu kalaAmK, (TA,) signifies kinds [or sorts], and ways, or modes, or manners, [i. e. diversities, or varieties,] of speech; (Ṣ, TA,* PṢ;) like OasaAliybu [pl. of OusoluwbN]. (Ṣ, TA.) And funuwnN signifies Different sorts of men, or a medley thereof, not of one tribe. (M.)
Also A wonderful thing or affair or case. (Ṣ, TA.)
