huwa fin-u EilomK He is [a good student of science, i. e.] one who occupies himself well with science. (Ḳ.)

A particular period of time; [or a particular time;] as also fayonapN. (T, Ḳ.*) The Arabs say, kunotu biHaAli kacaA wakacaA fan-apF mina Ald-ahori and fayonapF minaAld-ahori [I was in such and such a state, or condition, at, or during, a particular time]. (T.)
fun-apN Much, or abundance, of herbage. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

fananN A branch of a tree: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or such as is of just proportion in length or in breadth: (T:) said to be syn. with guSonN; but this latter signifies “such as has been cut off” i. q. qaDiybN meaning maqoDuwbN: (M:) pl. OafonaAnN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said by Sb to be its only pl.; (M;) occurring in the Ḳur lv. 48; where some explain it as pl. of fan-N, and meaning “sorts,” or “species”; others, as pl. of fananN: (T, Bḍ:) and OafaAniynu is a pl. pl., (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. pl. of OafonaAnN. (T, Ṣ.)

And as a branch shelters like as does darkness, a poet uses it metaphorically, saying,
OagaAva Xariydahumo fananu AlZ-alaAmi
‡ [The shelter of the darkness aided him, or them, who fled]. (M.)

And [in like manner also] the pl. pl. is used in a trad. describing the inmates of Paradise, as meaning ‡ Locks of hair; these being likened to branches: and El-Marrár says,
OaEalaAqapF Oum-a Alwaliydi baEodamaA
OafonaAnu raOosika kaAlv-agaAmi Almuxolisi
‡ [Dost thou feel attachment of love to Umm-El-Weleed after that the locks of thy head have become like the hoary thaghám?]; meaning the locks of the hair of his head when he had become hoary. (T. [See vagaAmN.])
faniynN A humour in the armpit [of a camel], with pain. (M, Ḳ.)
And A camel having the tumour thus called; as also mafonuwnN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

XajarapN fan-aMCu and fanowaMCu, which latter is anomalous, A tree having branches; (Ṣ;) the latter thus expl. by AA; but by rule it should be fan-aMCu: (AʼObeyd, T:) or the latter, which is anomalous, signifies having long branches: (M:) or both signify having many branches. (Ḳ.)
And [hence] AimoraOapN fanowaMCu † A woman having much hair: but in this case, as in the former, the epithet, by rule, should be fan-aMCu. (M.) [See also fayonaAnN.]
fan-aAnN A wild ass that has various sorts, or modes, of running: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) used in this sense in the poetry of El-Aạshà. (Ṣ.) [See also mifan-N.]

XaEarN fayonaAnN † Hair having locks [lit. branches (OafonaAn)] (M,* Ḳ) like the OafonaAn of trees; [the latter word properly signifying having many branches, (see Ḥam p. 622,) of the measure fayoEaAlN, not faEolaAn;] therefore it is perfectly decl.: so says Sb: (M:) or it signifies long and beautiful hair; the latter word being of the measure fayoEaAlN from Alfananu, and the I augmentative. (T.)

And one says also, agreeably with analogy, rajulN fayonaAnN, (M,) and AimoraOapN fayonaAnapN, (M, Ḳ,) meaning [A man, and a woman,] having much hair; (Ḳ;) for fayonaAn is perfectly decl., derived from OafonaAnu AlX-ajari: IAạr has mentioned AimoraOapN fayonaI meaning [a woman] having much hair; and if the phrase be thus, fayonaAn must be imperfectly decl.; but [ISd says] I regard this as a mistake of IAạr. (M.) [See also art. fyn.]

hom.sense: OufonuwnN: see fan-N, in two places.
Also A tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, branch. (T, Ḳ.)
And Obscure, indistinct, or confused, speech, (T, Ḳ,) of a foolish, stupid, or dull, person. (T.)
And A mixed, or confused, run, of a horse and of a she-camel. (T, Ḳ.)
Also A serpent. (T, M, Ḳ.)

And An old woman: so some say: (M:) or an old woman advanced in age: (T, Ḳ:) or one who is flaccid, or flabby: (Ḳ:) Yaạḳoob has explained it as having the first of these three meanings; but IB regards this as improbable, because a verse of Ibn-Aḥmar which is cited as an ex. thereof is preceded by what shows that it is applied to his beloved. (TA.) [It is said in the M to be also the proper name of a certain woman; and as such it may be used by Ibn-Aḥmar.]
And i. q. daAhiyapN [A calamity, or misfortune,, &c.]: (M, Ḳ:) so some say. (M.)
And The first part of youth, or youthfulness; and of clouds. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mifan-N A man who has various sorts, or modes, [i. e. diversities, or varieties,] of speech; (T, TA;) and so mutafan-inN↓: (Ṣ:) or a man who utters, or performs, wonderful things: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) fem. with p {mifan-apN}. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A horse that performs various sorts, or modes, of running. (TA.)
mufan-anN A garment, or piece of cloth, diversified; not uniform. (M, TA.)
And Old, and evil in disposition, as an epithet applied to a man: (M:) and so with p {mufan-anapN} applied to a woman. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, with p {mufan-anapN}, A she-camel that seems to one to have been ten months pregnant, vum-a tanokaXifu mana AlkiXaAfi [app. meaning then suffers, or exposes, herself to be compressed; from AlkiXaAfu as inf. n. of kaXafat said of a she-camel: compare tnkXf as here used with takotaXifu said of a woman]. (Ḳ.)
mafonuwnN: see faniynN.
mutafan-inu: see mifan-N.

funotuqN A xaAn of the way or road; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of funoduqN [q. v.]; disapproved by El-Khafájee; but heard by Fr from a desertArab of Ḳuḍáʼah, as meaning a funoduq, i. e. xaAn. (TA.)
finojaAn and finojaAnap: see filojaAnN, in art. flj.

1. fanaxa, aor. _a {yafonaxu}, (L,) inf. n. fanoxN, (L, Ḳ,) He bruised a bone without splitting, or cleaving, it, and without causing to bleed: (Ḳ:) or fanaxa raOosahu biXaIoCK he bruised the bone of his head with a thing without making an apparent cleft or causing blood to flow: or he struck his head with a thing, meaning a staff, or stick, cleaving it or not cleaving it. (L.) And fanaxa raOosahu, and fn-xhu↓, He broke his head, and rendered him submissive, or abased him. (L.) And fanaxahu, aor. _a {yafonaxu}, inf. n. fanoxN and funuwxN, He weakened him, rendered him languid, or enervated him. (L.) And fanaxahu, (Ṣ, L,) aor. _a {yafonaxu}, (L,) inf. n. fanoxN; (L, Ḳ;) and fn-xhu↓, inf. n. tafoniyxN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and tfn-xhu↓; (L;) He, or it, (an affair, or event, Ṣ,) overcame him, overpowered him, subdued him, and rendered him submissive, or abased him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or did so in the worst, or most abominable, manner. (L.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.
5: see 1, last sentence.

faniyxN A man overcome, overpowered, subdued, and rendered submissive, or abased: or overcome,, &c., in the worst, or most abominable, manner. (L.) And An old man: (L:) [a man] flaccid, or flabby, and weak. (L, Ḳ.)

mifonaxN A man who abases his enemies, and breaks their heads, much, or often. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In explaining this word, J uses raOosahumo for zuWuwsahumo; and the author of the Ḳ does the same, though in art. slE he charges J with error for using a similar expression. (MF.) [Or, perhaps, the meaning here intended may be, and defeats their head, or chief.]
gayoru mafonuwxK, occurring in a trad., applied to a [garment of the kind called] burod, means Not old and worn out, nor weak. (TA.)

1. fanida, aor. _a {yafonadu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. fanadN; (Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Ḳ, TA;) or fnd, [perhaps fanada, not fanida,] inf. n. funuwdN; (IḲṭṭ, TA;) and Afnd↓, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, L,) inf. n. UifonaAdN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue: (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, A, O, L, Ḳ:) this is [said to be] the primary signification. (L.) qawolK UifonaAdK↓ is used by a poet for qawolK ciI UifonaAdK [A saying having, or characterized by, lying, or falsehood]. (M, L.)

And fanida. aor. _a {yafonadu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. fanadN, (M, O, Ḳ,) He erred, or committed a mistake or mistakes, (M, O, Ḳ, TḲ,) in extreme old age, (O,) in speech, or in judgment, or opinion: (M, Ḳ, TḲ:) and Afnd↓ he made many mistakes in his speech. (Aṣ, TA in art. shb.)

And fanida, aor. _a {yafonadu}, (IḲṭṭ, TA, TḲ,) inf. n. fanadN; (T, Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, A, O, L, Ḳ;) and Afnd↓; (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, L;) He became weak in judgment by reason of extreme old age (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, A, O, L;) or he became unsound in mind, (M, L, Ḳ,) [in such a state that] his intellect, or intelligence, was denied, or disapproved. (T, M, Ḳ, TḲ, Alfanadu being expl. in the T and M and Ḳ by UinokaAru AlEaqoli, and fanada in the TḲ by Ankr Eqlh [meaning Ounokira Eaqoluhu], and in like manner Afnd [of which see the part. n., mufonidN, below, as expl. in the A],) by reason of extreme old age, (T, M, Ḳ, TḲ,) or disease; (M, Ḳ, TḲ:) primarily thus restricted to the case of old age, but sometimes used without the being so restricted: (M:) and Afnd↓ is also expl. as signifying he became weak in intellect, or doted: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) and as signifying he became extremely aged, because he who has become so speaks perverted language; from the same verb as signifying he lied. (L,)
[And fanida, inf. n. fanadN, app. signifies also He was, or became, impotent: and unthankful for the favour of God: see finodN.]

hom.sense: 2. fn-dhu, inf. n. tafoniydN, He pronounced him to be a liar, an utterer of falsehood, or a sayer of what was untrue. (Fr, M, Ḳ.)
See also 4.

He blamed him, (Ṣ, O, L,) and pronounced his judgment to be weak: (Ṣ, A, O, L:) or he pronounced him, (Fr, T,) or it, i. e. his judgment, (IAạr, T,) to be weak. (Fr, IAạr, T.) And He pronounced him to be impotent, or lacking in ability. (Fr, M, L, Ḳ.)

fn-d farasFA He acquired, or got for himself, a horse: (T, O, TA:) so says Hároon Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah, as mentioned by Sh: but (Az says) I know it not in this sense: thus in the T: (TA:) or [rather] he took him for the purpose of tying him, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier, (T, TA,) and as a refuge to which to have recourse (T, O, TA) when suddenly attacked by the enemy; (T, TA;) from finodN, (T, O, TA,) signifying “a XimoraAx,” (O,) or “a great XmrAx,” (T, TA,) “of a mountain,” (T, O, TA,) or as signifying “a great mountain:” (O:) or i. q. Dam-arahu [as meaning he made him light of flesh for military service], (O, Ḳ, TA,) so as to be like the branch of a tree, termed finod. (O, TA.)
fn-d fiI AlX-araAbi He kept constantly, or perseveringly, to be beverage, or wine. (AḤn, M, Ḳ, TA.)
And fn-d (inf. n. tafoniydN, TA) He sat upon a finod, (T, L,) i. e. a XimoraAx of a mountain. (T, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 4. Afnd, inf. n. UifonaAdN, as intrans.: see 1, in five places.
Afndhu (inf. n. as above, TA) He charged him with error in judgment, or opinion; as also fn-dhu↓. (M, Ḳ.)
And It (old age) rendered him weak in judgment, or unsound in mind: (L:) or it (extreme old age) caused him to have little understanding; [or to be] like a stone. (A.)
5. tfn-d He repented, (Ḳ, B, TA,) minohu [of it]. (T, Ḳ.)
tfn-dhu: see 2, near the end.

entry.sense: 8. Aufotunida He was caused to perish by reason of extreme old age. (O.)
fanodN: see the next paragraph, first sentence.

finodN (T, Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Ḳ) and fanodN↓ (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) A great mountain: (IF, O, Ḳ:) or a mountain apart from others: (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed, TA:) or a portion of a mountain, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or a great portion thereof, (M, TA,) having tallness, or length, [app. the former,] (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and some add, with slenderness: (TA:) or a head, or round and tall and slender head, or peak, (XimoraAx,) of a mountain: (T, A:) or a great peak or head (XmrAx, T, L, or raOos, M, L,) of a mountain: (T, M, L:) or a rukon [i. e. a side, or an outward part, or the strongest side or outward part,] of a mountain: (L:) pl. OafonaAdN. (M, L.) One says of a bulky and heavy man, kaOan-ahu finodN, meaning As though he were a head, or peak, (XimoraAx,) of a mountain. (A.)
And the former (finodN) is the sing. of OafonaAd in the phrase OafonaAdu All-ayoli, (T,) which means The component parts, or portions, of the night. (T, O, Ḳ, TA.)

And A congregated party (T, O, Ḳ, TA.) of men. (T, O.) One says, humo finodN EalaI HidapK They are a party by itself. (T, TA.) And it is said in a trad., (T.) respecting the Prophet, (T, O, Ḳ,) that, when he died, (O.) Sal-aI Aln-aAsu Ealayohi OafonaAdFA OafonaAdFA i. e. [The people prayed for him, or invoked blessing upon him,] one by one, without an Imám; (Th, T, O, Ḳ;) or companies after companies: (O, Ḳ:) and they were computed to be thirty thousand, with sixty thousand angels; two angels to every one (T, O, Ḳ) of the believers. (T, O.)
And the Prophet said, (T, O, Ḳ,) after announcing that he would be among the first that should die, (T, O,) tat-abiEuwniI OafonaAdFA OafonaAdFA yuholiku baEoDukumo baEoDFA, meaning [Ye will follow me] in scattered companies, company after company; [killing one another;] OafonaAdFA being pl. of finod; (Nh, TA;) and in like manner is expl. a similar phrase in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh: (T, TA:) or the former means cawiI fanadK↓ i. e. [impotent; and unthankful; lit] having impotence; and unthankfulness for [God's] favour. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And A sort, or species: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. OafonaAdN: one says, jaAWuwA OafonaAdFA They came being diverse sorts. (TA.)
And A branch of a tree. (T, O, Ḳ.*)
And Land upon which rain has not fallen; (T, O, Ḳ;) also termed findyp↓ [app. finodiy-apN]. (T.)
fanadN [inf. n. of fanida, q. v.: as a subst.,] i. q. fuHoXN [app. as meaning Exorbitance in speech]; and error in judgment: pl. OafonaAdN. (Ḥam p. 112.)
See also finodN, near the end.
finodapN A complete branch from which a bow is made. (O.)
findyp [app. finodiy-apN]: see finodN, last sentence.
finodaOowapN (in the O and CK without hemz) A sharp qaduwm [or adz]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And A bold, or fearless, she-camel. (IAạr and Sh, TA in art. EdO.)
finodaOoyapN An adz, or an axe, or a hoe; syn. faOosN: (I'Aar, T, L:) or a broad-headed fOs: (M, L:) pl. fanaAdiydu, which is anomalous. (IAạr, T, L.)

faAniydN A sort of sweetmeat, made of concrete juice of the sugar-cane (qanod, q. v.,) and starch (naXFA): a foreign word; for the measure faAEiylN is not found in Arabic; and therefore the lexicographers have not mentioned it: (Mṣb:) it is also written with c; (MF;) and is an arabicized word, from [the Pers.] PaAniydo [or PaAniyco]: (Ḳ voce faAniyc:) but is more properly with d. (MF.)

mufonidN, (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or mufan-adN↓, [meaning Weak in judgment, or unsound in mind,, &c., (see 1,) by reason of extreme old age, or disease,] an epithet applied to a man only: you do not use the fem. form, with p {mufonidapN}, applying it to an old woman, because [it is held that] she has not possessed judgment (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) in her youth (T, Ṣ, M, L) or at any time: (Ḳ:) or both mufonidN and mufan-adN↓ signify [as above: or] one whose intellect, or intelligence, is denied, or disapproved, (Oanokira Eaqoluhu,) by reason of extreme old age: or who confounds [things] in his speech: (A:) or the former, or ↓the latter, signifies loquacious by reason of unsoundness of mind: (Aṣ, T:) and the former signifies weak in intellect: (L:) [and extremely aged: (see 1:)] and the same, (T,) or ↓the latter, (L,) weak in judgment; notwithstanding he may be strong in body: and weak in body; notwithstanding he may be right in judgment: and weak in judgment and in body. (Fr, T, L.)
mufan-adN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
fanodarN and funodurN, applied to a boy or youth, Plump: and wanting in courage and generosity; stupid and heavy. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
finodiyrN and finodiyrapN↓ (Ḳ in this art., and Ṣ in art. fdr,) A great mass of rock that becomes detached (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the head (Ṣ) or from the side (Ḳ) of a mountain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. fanaAdiyru. (TA.)
And, both words, A large lump of dates (Ḳ, TA) compacted together; as also fidorapN. (TA.)
The anus. (IAạr, T, O, TA.)
finodiyrapN: see finodiyrN.

dictScrap.note: Accord. to some, the n in the words mentioned in this art. is augmentative. (O.)

hom.sense: funoduqN The fruit of a certain tree, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) the same as the bunoduq, which has been mentioned before, [i. e. hazel-nut, or hazel-nuts,] (Ḳ,) or round, like the bunoduq, having a covering which, being removed, discloses a kernel (Hab-), like the fusotuq. (Lth, O.)

And, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) in the dial. of the people of Syria, A [building of the kind called] xaAn [q. v.], where men alight and lodge, [and in which they deposit their goods,] of the xaAnaAt that are in the roads, (Lth, O, Ḳ,*) and in the cities: (Lth, O:) [said to be] a Pers. word, [app. from the Greek πανδοχεῖον occurring in Luke x. 34, as remarked by Golius,] mentioned by Sb: pl. fanaAdiqu. (TA.)

entry.sense: funodaAqN A register of accounts: (O, Ḳ:) thought by Aṣ to be an arabicized word: but the word commonly known [in this sense] is with q [i. e. qunodaAqN]. (TA.)

fanozajN A leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding; and so fanozajapN↓: (L:) or the game, or sport, called dasotabanod, [or dasutobanod, a Pers. word,] meaning the dance of the Magians, (Lth, O, L,) or a dance of the Persians (AlEajam), (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the performers hold one another by the hand; (Lth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) arabicized from [the Pers.] Panojaho [app. as meaning “a gripe with the hand”]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a game, or sport, of the Nabathæans, 1. called in Pers. PanojaGaAno [app. from Panojaho and GaAno, from the joining of hands]; (ISk, O;) a game, or sport, played by the Nabathæans in joyous exultation: (IAạr, O:) occurring in a saying of El-ʼAjjáj cited in art. Ekf. (TA. See 1 in that art.)
And, as some say, The five embolismal, or supplementary days, which are added at the end of the twelfth month of the Persians [and called by them PanojahCi duzodiydaho]. (IDrd, O, L.)
fanozajapN: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: finoTAsN [The bottom of the hold of a ship or boat; i. e.] the part of a ship or boat where the water that is drawn out therefrom collects: (AA, O, Ḳ, TA:) this is the primary signification: (O, TA:) pl. fanaATiysu. (TA.)
Hence, (O,) A tank made of boards, (O, Ḳ,) and tarred, (O,) borne in sea-going vessels, (O, Ḳ,*) and containing sweet water for drinking. (O,* Ḳ.)

And, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to IAạr, (O,) A bowl (O, Ḳ) of wood, the exterior of which is coloured with yellow and red and green, (O,) with which the sweet water is distributed (O, Ḳ) among the ship's crew. (O.)
It is also applied to a nose, as signifying Broad. (IDrd, M, TA. [See also what next follows.])
finoTiysN A nose wide in the nostril, and expanded in the end: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) pl. fanaATiysu. (Ḳ. [See also what next precedes.])
And, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) A man broad in the nose. (O, Ḳ.)
And Low, ignoble, or ungenerous, (O, Ḳ, TA,) accord. to some, in an absolute sense, (TA,) or in respect of birth; (O, Ḳ, TA;) thus accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád: pl. as above. (O.)
Also The penis; (O, Ḳ;) and so firoTiysN: accord. to some, peculiarly of the swine. (TA.)

entry.sense: finoTiysapN The snout of the swine: (O, Ḳ: [mentioned also in art. fTs; the n being held by some to be augmentative:]) and so firoTiysapN. (TA.) And The nose of the wolf. (O.) And one says, Uin-ahu lamaniyEu AlfinoTiysapi (O, Ḳ *) and AlfiroTiysapi, (O,) meaning † [Verily he is] one who defends, or guards, from encroachment, or invasion, or attack, what is in his possession, or occupation; who refuses to submit to wrongful treatment: (O, Ḳ:) thus mentioned on the authority of Aṣ; and Aboo-Saʼeed [meaning Aṣ] says that his finoTiysap and firoTiysap [properly] signify his nose. (TA.)

1. faniEa, aor. _a {yafonaEu}, (Ṣ, O,* Ḳ,) inf. n. fanaEN, (Ṣ, O,) He abounded, and increased, in wealth. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) mano qaniEa faniEa is a prov., (O, TA,) meaning [He who is contented] is free from want, or is rich. (TA.)

hom.sense: fanaEN [as a simple subst.] Increase, and abundance, of wealth: (Ṣ:) increase (O, Ḳ, TA) in wealth and in what is little in quantity: (TA:) and i. q. xayorN [good, moral or physical; wealth, or much wealth; prosperity, welfare, or wellbeing;, &c.]: and generosity: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and large, or ample, liberality or bounty or munificence: (TA:) and excellence; (O, Ḳ;) or much, or abundant, excellence. (TA.) One says maAlN cuw fanaEK and fanaOK, but the former is more common and more known, i. e. Abundant wealth. (TA.) And farasN caw fanaEK fiI sayorihi A horse having increase [in his rate of going], or having excess [therein]. (TA.)
And Strength of odour of musk. (Ḳ.) misokN cuw fanaEK means Musk of which the odour is strong. (Ṣ, O.)
And Good report. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.) And The spreading, or diffusion, of eulogy. (TA.)

entry.sense: See also fanaEN, last sentence.
faniyEN: see faniEN:
and see also fanaEN, last sentence.
mifonaEN A man (AʼObeyd, O) having a good report. (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ.)

2. fn-qhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tafoniyqN; (O, Ḳ;) and fAnqhu↓, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. finaAqN; (TA;) He made him to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
3: see the preceding paragraph {2}.

4. Afnq He (a man, O) enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty; after straitness of the means of subsistence. (O, Ḳ.) [See also what next follows {5}.]
5. tfn-q He (a man, Ṣ) enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And tafan-aqotu fiI OamorikacaA I affected daintiness, nicety, or refinement, and cleanliness, in such an affair. (TA.)

funuqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and mifonaAqN↓ (O, Ḳ, TA) A woman, (Ṣ,) or young woman, (O, Ḳ, TA,) that has been made to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) large in body, beautiful, and youthful: Aṣ says that the former, applied to a woman, signifies having little flesh; but Sh knew not this, and he cites El-Aạshà as applying this epithet to a woman whom he describes as one whose elbows are unapparent, and such, he says, is not one having little flesh: IAạr says that it is applied to one who is as though she were a stallion-camel such as is termed faniyq. (TA.)
And the former, applied to a she-camel, signifies Youthful, fat or plump, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) fleshy, and bulky. (TA.)
See also faniyqN.
It is also pl. of afniyqN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
funaAqN: see fanaqN.

faniyqN A stallion, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [i. e.] a stallioncamel, (IAạr, TA,) that is highly regarded, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and is not molested, because of the high estimation in which he is held by his owner, or owners, nor is ridden: (O, Ḳ:) it is said by AZ to be one of the names for such a stallion: (Ṣ, TA:) or it is an epithet applied to a camel, meaning such as is acquired for covering: (TA:) the pl. is funuqN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) accord. to AZ, and OafonaAqN accord. to IDrd, (Ṣ,) or the latter is pl. of the former pl.: (O, Ḳ:) and funuq↓ is applied as an epithet to a [single] camel, like faniyqN. (TA.)

faniyqapN A [sack such as is called] giraArap [q. v.]: (AA, O, Ḳ:) or a small grArp: or a receptacle smaller than the grArp: (TA:) [said by Meyd to be a sack in which clay, or mud, is carried away: (Golius:)] pl. fanaAYiqu. (O, Ḳ.)
EayoXN mufaAniqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and some say mufaAnaqN, (TA,) A life that is plentiful, and pleasant or easy, and soft or delicate; or a life of ease and plenty. (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ, TA.)
mifonaAqN: see funuqN.
1. fanaka biAlmakaAni, [aor. _u {yafonuku}, (TḲ,)] inf. n. funuwkN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (El-Umawee, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

fanaka fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) aor. as above, (Ṣ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, O,) He persisted, or persevered, in the affair; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;*) as also Afnk↓. (Ḳ.) [See also fataka; and see other explanations below.] And fanaka fiI Alkacibi He persisted, or persevered, in lying: asserted by Yaạḳoob to be formed by transposition from fakana: and Aboo-Tálib says that fAnk↓ and fn-k↓, of which latter the inf. n. is tafoniykN, signify he persisted, or persevered, in lying, and in evil; not in good; and denote the like of consecutiveness. (TA.) [See also fanokN, which may be an inf. n. of fanaka in this sense, and in others.] And fanaka Ealayohi, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies [in like manner] He kept, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it; as also Afnk↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

And fanaka fiI AlT-aEaAmi, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, O,) He continued constantly, uniformly, or regularly, in the eating of the food, not loathing aught thereof; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also fanika, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) with kesr, (Ṣ, O,) like Ealima, (Ḳ,) inf. n. funuwkN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so fAnk↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) and faAnakotu↓ AlT-aEaAma waAlX-araAba signifies [simply] I kept continually, or constantly, to the food and the beverage: and also I loathed them, or turned away from them with disgust. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

And fanaka fiI AlOamori [not fAnk as in the lexicons of Golius and Freytag, the latter of whom gives both forms of the v. in the sense here following, as does also the TḲ,] signifies also He entered into the affair. (Ḳ.)
And He mastered the affair, and overcame it. (O.)

fanakota fiI lawomiI, and Afnkt↓ fyh, (both in the TA, but the latter only in the O,) Thou wast, or hast become, skilled in the blaming, or censuring, of me, and profuse, or immoderate, therein: so says Fr. (O, TA.)
And fanakato and Oafonakato↓ She (a woman) blamed, or censured, and kept continually, or constantly, to blaming, or censuring, or to some other thing [or act]. (Lth, O, TA.*)
And the former, said of a girl, or young woman, She cared not for what she did nor for what was said to her. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) This meaning has also been assigned to fatakato. (TA.)
And fanaka, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He lied, or said what was untrue; as also Afnk↓. (Ḳ.)
2: see above {1}, near the beginning.
3: see 1, first quarter: and near the middle, in two places.
4: see 1, in five places.

hom.sense:
fanokN i. q. EajabN: (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA:) [it app. means A wonderful thing: for] IAạr cites as an ex.,
walaA fanoka Uil-aA saEoIu EamorKw warahoTihi
bimaA QxotaXabuwA mino miEoDadK wadadaAni
[And there is not anything wonderful except the conduct of ʼAmr and his near kinsfolk in their having taken without selection a sword commonly used for lopping trees, and one that was blunt]: (TA:) and fanakN↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also Persistence, or perseverence; or the act of persisting, or persevering. (TA.) [In this and the following senses, it seems to be an inf. n. of which the verb is fanaka; as is indicated in the TA.]
And The act of overcoming. (O, Ḳ, TA. [Accord. to the TA, from IAạr; but said in the O to be from another, not there named.])
And The acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA.)
And The lying, or saying what is untrue. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: fanakN A certain beast, (Kr, O, Ḳ,) of the skin of which the furred garment is made; (Kr, Ṣ, O;) [the marten;] the furred garment whereof is the best sort of such garments, and the highest in estimation, and the most equable, and is suitable to all temperate constitutions: (Ḳ:) it is said to be a species of the Turkish fox's cubs; and therefore Az and others say that the word is arabicized; some of the travellers relate that it is applied to the young-one of the jackal (Aibon MwaI) in the country of the Turks: (Mṣb:) it is also said to mean a certain skin that is worn; and to be an arabicized word: [in Pers. a furred garment is called fanak:] IDrd says, “I do not think it to be Arabic:” and MF mentions faniykN↓ as signifying an animal like the fox; an arabicized word; from [a work entitled] gaAyap AlbayaAn; and he says that it appears to be the fanak that is mentioned in the Ḳ. (TA.)
See also fanokN.

hom.sense:
Alfaniyku The majomaE [or part in which is the symphysis] of the laHoyaAni [or two lateral portions of the lower jaw], (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) in the middle of the chin, (Lth, O, TA,) of a man; (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA;) this is when the word is used in the sing. form; (Lth, O; [see also Alfak-u;]) and it is also called AlUifoniyku↓; (Lth, O;) [and in like manner Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee explained what is meant by the upper faniyk as is stated by IF and in the O:]
or the extremity [of each] of the laHoyaAni, at the place of the Eanofaqap [or tuft of hair that is between the lower lip and the chin;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) also called AlUifoniyku↓; but Ks knew not this: (Ṣ:) or the faniykaAni are the two extremities of the Eanofaqap: (O:) or (Ḳ, TA, in the CK “and”) the sing. signifies a bone [beneath the temple,] to which the shaving of the head reaches (EaZomN yanotahiI Uilayohi Haloqu Alr-aOosi): (Ḳ, TA:) and accord. to Lth, the dual signifies the two extremities of the [lower] jaw, of whatever has a jaw, that move in the act of chewing, below the temples: (O:) or, accord. to Sh, the two thin, rising bones, [app. the two coronoid processes of the jaw,] lower than the ears, between the temple and the ball of the cheek. (TA.) The lower faniyk is [app. The symphysis of the pubes; being] said by Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee to be the part where the two hip-bones meet together: (IF, O:) [hence, perhaps, and therefore it may be erroneously,] the fnyk is said by AA to be the root, or base, of the tail: (TA:) and it signifies, as also AlUifoniyku↓, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) the zimik-aI, (Ḳ,) or zimij-aI, [i. e. the place of growth, or the root, or the whole, of the tail, of a bird, or] of a young bird; as they assert; (IDrd, O;) but IDrd says, “I will not pronounce it to be correct:” (O:) and the dual signifies two bones cleaving together: when, in the female pigeon, they are broken, she does not retain her eggs [sufficiently], but excludes them prematurely. (Lth, O.)
See also fanakN.

entry.sense: AlUifoniyku: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
mutafan-ikapN A foolish, or stupid, woman. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
finowN, said to be sing. of OafonaMCN: see the latter, below.

hom.sense: fanFA: see the next paragraph:
and see also fanFI, in art. fnI.

entry.sense: fanaApN A bull or cow; syn. baqarapN; (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) [i. e.] a baqarap waHoXiyap [or wild bull or cow; an antelope of the bovine kind]: so says Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee: (TA:) it occurs in a verse of Lebeed; and is said, as on the authority of IAạr, to be qanaAp, with q: (TA in art. qnw:) pl. fanawaAtN (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [coll. gen. n.] fanFA↓. (Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee, TA.)

XaEarN OafonaI i. q. fayonaAnN [i. e. Hair having locks like the branches of trees; or long and beautiful hair]; (M, Ḳ, TA;) [or] meaning long hair. (TA.) [The fem. of OafonaI is fanowaMCu. Hence,] AimoraOapN fanowaMCu A woman having much hair: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:) and XajarapN fanowaMCu A tree having OafonaAn [or branches]; (AA, T, Ṣ, M;) or a tree having wide shade: (Ḳ:) by rule it should be fan-aMCu [q. v. in art. fn]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

OafonaMCN mina Aln-aAsi means Mixed sorts of men or people; like OaEonaMCN: and the sings. are [said to be] finowN and EinowN: (IAạr, T:) one says, huwa mino OafonaMCi Aln-aAsi when it is not known of whom he is: (Ṣ:) or rajalN mino OafonaMCi AlqabaAYili, meaning a man such that one knows not of what tribe he is: but some hold that one says only, qawomN mn AfnMC AlqbAYl; not rajulN; and that there is no sing. of OafonaMC: (M in art. fnI:) accord. to AHeyth, one says, heWulaMCi mino OafonaMCi Aln-aAsi, meaning these are of the strangers from this and that place: but one does not say, speaking of one person, rajulN mn AfnMC AlnAs: and Umm El-Heythem knew not a sing. of OafonaMC. (T in art. fnI.)

1. faniIa, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yafonaI; (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and fanaI, aor. yafonaI, (M, Ḳ,) which is extr., mentioned by Kr, and said by him to be of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab; (M;) the former of the two verbs being that which is commonly known; (TA;) inf. n. fanaMCN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) which is of both of the verbs; (TA;) It (i. e. a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) passed away and came to an end; vanished away; became spent, or exhausted; failed entirely; ceased, perished, or came to nought; or was, or became, transitory, evanescent, or non-existent; the inf. n. being syn. with nafaAdN; (Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee, TA;) contr. of baqaMCN; (M, TA;) and the pret. being syn. with Eudima: (Ḳ, TA:) it is said of every created thing that it is subject to AlfanaMC. (Mṣb.) [Hence] daAru AlfanaMCi [The abode of transitoriness, evanescence, or perishableness,] means the present world. (T in art. dwr.)

And, said of a man, (T, M, Ḳ,) i. e. faniIa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) ‡ He was, or became, extremely aged; or old and infirm; syn. harima: (M, Ḳ:) or he became on the verge of death by reason of extreme age or of age and infirmity. (T.) Lebeed says,
HabaAYiluhu mabovuwvapN bisabiylhi
wayafonaI UicaA maA OaxoTaOatohu AlHabaAYilu , (T, M,) meaning [His snares are spread in his way, and when the snares fail to catch him] he becomes old and infirm and so dies: (T:) or it means, when death misses him he becomes old and infirm. (M.)

3. fAnAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. mufaAnaApN, (T, TA,) He (a man, Ṣ, M) soothed, or coaxed, him: (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and, (M,) accord. to El-Umawee, (T, Ṣ,) he stilled, or quieted, him. (T, Ṣ, M.) El-Kumeyt says, (Ṣ, M,) mentioning anxieties, (M,)
tuqiymuhu taArapF watuqoEiduhu
kama yufaAniI AlX-amuwsa qaAYiduhaA
[They rouse him at one time, and at another time they render him sedate like as her leader soothes, or coaxes, or like as he stills, or quiets, the refractory mare]. (Ṣ, M: in the T, accord. to the TT, the verse ends with raAYiduhaA [her pastor], instead of qaAYiduhaA.) Accord. to IAạr, fAnAhu signifies wAijAhu [app. a mistranscription for waAxaAhu, originally MxaAhu, He fraternized with him; or acted with him in a brotherly manner]. (TA.) [Hence the phrase] OufaAniI AlOay-aAma i. e. Ouzaj-iI Alz-amaAna [meaning I make the time to pass away easily; as though beguiling it]. (Ḥar p. 607.)

And one says, banuw fulaAnK maA yuEaAnuwna maAlahumo walaA yufaAnuwnahu i. e. The sons of such a one do not tend, or take care of, their cattle, or camels, or [other] property, and do not manage the same well. (T.)

4. AfnAhu He, or it, caused it, or him, to pass away and come to an end; to vanish away; to become spent, or exhausted; to fail entirely; to cease, perish, or come to nought; he, or it, did away with, destroyed, or annihilated, it, or him; (T, Ṣ,* M, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) trans. of faniIa. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The saying of a rájiz, (T, TA,) namely, Abu-n-Nejm, (TA,) describing a pastor of sheep or goats,
yaquwlu layota Qll-eha qado OafonaAhaA , (T, TA,) may mean an imprecation against them, i. e. He says, would that God had destroyed them: (T:)
or it means, would that God had made to grow for them [the plant called] AlfanaI, i. e. Einabu Alv-aEolabi; so that they might have abundance of milk, and become fat. (T, TA.)

6. tafaAnawA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or tfAnwA qatolFA, (M,) They destroyed one another, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [or they shared, one with another, in destruction, (see an ex. in a verse cited voce daq-a,) by slaughter,] in war, or battle. (Ṣ.)

AlfanaI, thus, with I, in the M, and thus it should be written accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee, in the T and Ṣ with A, and in like manner in the Ḳ, in which it is [mentioned in art. fnw, and] written without the article Al (fanFA), and said to be a pl., of which the sing. is AlfanaAp↓, (TA,) [The plant called] Einabu Alv-aEolabi; [see art. vElb; and see also AlOafaAniI, in this art.;] (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) whereof one is called fanaApN↓: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, another plant; (T;) [i. e.,] as some say, a species of trees, or plants, (XajarN,) having red berries, (Hab-), (Ṣ,) of which necklaces are made, (Ṣ,) or the unbroken of which are made use of as qaraAriyT [meaning carat-weights] with which to weigh, every berry (Hab-ap) being a qiyraAT: and some say that it is a herb that grows in rugged places, rising from the ground to the height of the measure of a finger, and less, and depastured by the cattle. (M.)

hom.sense: fanaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places:
and see also art. fnw.

entry.sense: finaMCN A yard, or an exterior court, i. e. a wide space, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in front, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or extending from the sides, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of a house: (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. OafoniyapN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and funiI-N: (Ḳ:) and vinaMCN [q. v.] signifies the same. (T, M.)
faAnK part. n. of faniIa [i. e. signifying Passing away and coming to an end;, &c.]. (T.)

And ‡ An old man extremely aged, or old and infirm; (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) so called because of his nearness to passing away, or perishing: (Mṣb:) or an old man whose faculties have entirely failed. (Mgh.) And faAniyapN occurs in a trad., applied to a she-camel, or to camels, as meaning † Advanced in age. (TA.)
[faAnK fiI Qll-ehi, in the language of the mystics, means † Lost in contemplation of God, and insensible to all else.]
OafonaMCN mina Aln-aAsi is expl. in art. fnw.

AlOafaAniI [without the article OafaAnK] is the name of A species of plant, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) yellow, and red; (T;) [said to be so called] while fresh and succulent; (Ṣ;) accord. to AA, (T,) when it has dried up, it is called AlHamaATu; (Ṣ, T;) but this is a mistake; for AlAfAnI signifies a particular species of plant by itself, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, termed cukuwr, which dries up, and becomes scattered; whereas the HmAT is the Halbp [a mistranscription for Halamap], and this does not dry up, because it is of the [kind called] janobap and Eurowap (T:) the n. un. is OafaAniyapN, (T, Ṣ.) like vamaAniyapN [in measure]. (Ṣ.) And it is said to signify also [The plant called] Einabu Alv-aEolabi. (Ṣ. [See also AlfanaI, above.])

mafonaApN A land (OaroDN) suitable to those who alight and abide therein: (Ḳ, TA:) it occurs, in a verse of Keys Ibn-El-'Eyzár El-Hudhalee, with q, [as some relate that verse,] but Aṣ says that in the dial. of Hudheyl it is with f. (TA in art. qnI.)

1. fahiha, (Ḳ,) [or perhaps fah-a, but originally fahiha], like fariHa, (Ḳ,) sec. pers. fahihota, [aor. _a {yafohahu},] inf. n. fahahN (Ṣ, TA) [and app. fah-apN and fahaAhapN], He (a man, Ṣ) lacked power or ability. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And fah-a, inf. n. fahaAhapN and fah-apN, He made a slip, or committed a fault, from lack of power or ability, &c. (TA.) And fah-a fiI xuTobatihi, and Huj-atihi, He (a man) failed of being thoroughly effective [in his discourse, or oration, or harangue, and his argument, or plea, or evidence]. (TA.)

And fahihotu AlX-aIoCa I forgot the thing. (ISh, Ḳ,* TA. [In the Ḳ the third pers. is mentioned, as being fahiha; but I think it should be contracted (agreeably with a general rule), as in what here follows.]) And fah-a Eani AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. fah-N [probably, I think, a mistake for fah-apN], He forgot the thing. (TA.) See also 4.
2: see what next follows {4}.
4. Afh-hu He (i. e. God) made him to lack power or ability; as also fh-hhu↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [The former is omitted in one of my copies of the Ṣ.])

And He (another person) made him to forget. (TA.) One says, xarajotu liHaAjapK faOafah-aniI fulaAnN EanohaA Hat-aI fahihotu↓ i. e. [I went forth for a needful affair, and such a one] made me to forget it [so that I did forget it]. (Ṣ, TA. [Or Afh-nI may be here better rendered agreeably with the explanation next following.]) Accord. to IDrd, Oafah-aniI Eano faHaAjatiI signifies He busied me so as to divert me [from my needful affair, or the object of my want]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. fahofaha He fell from a high station to a lower one. (IAạr, TA.)

fah-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a man. (Ṣ.) Lacking power or ability; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also fahihN↓, (CK, but omitted in other copies of the Ḳ,) and fahiyhN↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and fahofahN↓, (Ḳ,) which last is mentioned by IDrd as signifying dull of tongue, lacking power. or ability, to accomplish the object of his want: (TA:) and fh-ap is applied, in the sense first mentioned, to a woman (Ṣ;) or as meaning lacking power, or ability, to accomplish the object of her want. (TA) And kalimapN fah-apN means [A word, or a sentence,, &c.,] having fahaAhap [i. e. a lack of power,, &c.]. (TA.)
fah-apN and fahaAhapN↓ [each of which has been mentioned above as an inf. n.] Lack of power or ability; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also fahofahapN↓ (Ḳ.)

The first signifies also A case, or an instance, of fahaAhap: and [a case, or an instance, of] unmindfulness or forgetfulness: (TA:) and a slip, or fault: and a case, or an instance, of ignorance; and the like thereof. (AʼObeyd. Ṣ. TA.*)
fahihN: see fah-N.
fahiyhN i. q. fah-N, q. v.: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or unable to speak. (KL. [See fakiyhN.]) One says safiyhN fahiyhN [Lightmitted, lacking power or ability] (Ṣ, TA.)
fahaAhapN: see fah-apN.
fahofahN: see fah-N.
fahofahapN: see fah-apN.
huwa fahofaAhN EalaI AlmaAli means He is a good manager or tender or superintendent [of the camels or cattle, &c.] (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. fahida, (Ṣ, A, O, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafohadu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. fahadN, (L.) He (a man. Ṣ, A, O) resembled the fahod [or lynx] (Ṣ, A, O, L, Ḳ) in his stretching himself and his sleeping. (L, Ḳ,) or in his much sleeping, and stretching himself. (Ṣ, A, O.) And He slept, and was, or feigned himself, heedless of what was requisite, or necessary to be done. (L, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, (Ṣ, L,) of a woman describing her husband, as related in the story of Umm-Zarạ, (L,) Uino daxala fahida waUino xaraja Oasida walaA yasoOalu Eam-aA Eahida, (Ṣ,* L,) i. e. If he come in and be with me in the tent, or house, he is gentle and quiet like the fahod, which is described as sleeping much; and is, or feigns himself, heedless of the things that are amiss therein, and that I ought to put into a right, or proper, state; such is his generosity, and goodness of disposition; and if he go out, and see his enemy, he is like the lion [in boldness; and he will not ask respecting what he has ordered]. (L.) And one says, fahidota Ean-iI, inf. n. fahadN, Thou wast, or hast been, heedless, or negligent, of me. (A.)
fahada lahu, (O, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yafohadu}, (Ḳ,) He did well, or kindly, in his affair in his absence; (O, L, Ḳ:) like faOada, and mahada. (O, L.)

entry.sense: fahodN [The lynx; lupus cervarius;] a well-known beast of prey; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) with which one hunts; and which sleeps much; (L;) called in Pers. yuwzo: (Mgh:) fem. fahodapN: (L. Mṣb:) pl. of the masc. fuhuwdN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OafohudN (O, L, Ḳ) which is a pl. of pauc.; (O:) and the pl. of the fem., accord. to analogy, is fahadaAtN (Mṣb.) Oanowamu mina Alfahodi [More sleepful than the lynx] is a proverb. (A.)

And A nail in the wAsiT [or fore part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (O, L, Ḳ;) also termed kalobN [q. v.]. (L.) To the creaking sound of this nail the similar sound of a stallion-camel's tushes is likened.

fahidN and fihido [A man] resembling the fahod [or lynx] in his stretching himself and has sleeping [or in his doing thus much, or often]: and [a man] being. or feigning himself, heedless of what is requisite, or necessary to be done. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: fahodapN fem. of fahodN [q. v.] (Mṣb.)
The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (L, Ḳ.)
A small piece of butter. (L in art. nhd.)

AlfahodataAni, (Ṣ, A, O.) or fahodataA Alfarasi, (L, Ḳ,) or fahodataA Sadori Alfarasi, (AO, TA,) Two prominent portions of flesh in the [part of the breast called] zawor [q. v.] of the horse, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) like two stones of the kind termed fihor: (Ṣ, O:) or the prominent flesh in the breast of the horse, on its right and left (L:) or two positions of flesh on the right and left of the breast of the horse. (AO, TA.)
And fahodataA AlbaEiyri Two protuberant bones behind the ears of the camel; (O, L, Ḳ;) the same that are termed AlxuXaXaAwaAni. (O, L.)

entry.sense: fah-aAdN The owner, or master, of a fahod [or lynx]: (L:) or one who trains the fahod for hunting. (T, O, L, Ḳ.)

fawohadN A fat boy or youth, (AA, Ṣ, O, L,) that has nearly attained to puberty; (AA, Ṣ, L;) i. q. vawohadN; (O, Ḳ;) [and farohadN and furohudN:] and falohadN; (AA, L;) as also OufohuwdN↓: (O, Ḳ:) Yaạḳoob asserts that the f in fwhd is a substitute for the v in vwhd, or that the converse is the case; and both signify a boy perfect in make; or, accord. to AA, soft and plump: or both signify perfect, and soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (L:) fem. fawohadapN. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ).
OufohuwdN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. fahara, aor. a, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. fahorN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and faharN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;)
and Afhr↓, (IAạr, O,* Ḳ,) inf. n. UifohaArN; (TA;) He compressed a woman, (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) one of his young women, (IAạr,) without consummating the act, i. e. without UinozaAl, (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) and then removed to another and consummated the act (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) with the latter, (IAạr, O, Mṣb,) who was with him in the house, or chamber; (IAạr;) the doing of which is forbidden (Ṣ, O, Mṣb) by the Prophet: (O:) and ↓the latter verb signifies also He was alone with one of his young women, (Ḳ, TA,) liqaDaMCi HaAjatihi, (TA,) when another of them heard the sound proceeding from him, which [sound] is termed Alwajosu, (Ḳ, TA,) and Alr-ikozu, and AlHafoHafapu; (TA;) which [also] is forbidden. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. fh-r, inf. n. tafohiyrN, He compressed without consummating the act, i. e. without UinozaAl, by reason of weariness and languor. (Mṣb in art. Ezl. [See also 1.])

Also, inf. n. as above, He (a man) was, or became, weary, or fatigued. (Ṣ, TA.) Said of a horse, as also fayohara↓ and tafayohara↓, He was, or became, out of breath by reason of fatigue or running; (Ḳ, TA;) and interrupted, or stopped short, in running; and jaded: (TA:) or he fell back by degrees from running, by reason of weakness, and being interrupted, or stopped short, in running: (Ḳ, TA:) or the first deficiency of the rate of running of the horse is termed Alt-araAd-u [the falling back by degrees]; the next, Alfutuwru [the becoming languid]; and the next, Alt-afohiyru. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
Afhr baEiyruhu His camel became jaded, and broke down with him, or perished, so that he was unable to prosecute his journey. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)
And Afhr (said of a man, TA) His flesh became compacted and lumpy (O, Ḳ *) and wrinkled by reason of fatness: (O:) when such is the case, it is the ugliest sort of fatness. (O, Ḳ.)
Also He was present at the festival of the Jews, (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA,) called Alfuhor: (TA:) or he came to their synagogue: (Ḳ, TA:) or it signifies also he was present in their synagogue. (IDrd, O.)
And Oufohirato, said of a girl, She was circumcised. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tfh-r fiI AlmaAli He became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in wealth, or in camels, or the like; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also tafayohara↓; (Ḳ;) as though the former verb were formed by substitution from tabaH-ara: or it may mean he was, or became, weary, fatigued, or jaded, and languid, or remiss. (Ṣ, O.) And tfh-r fiI AlkalaAmi He took a wide, or an ample, range in speech. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. fayohara: see 2.
Q. Q. 2. tafayohara: see 2:
and see also 5.

Alfuhoru, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or fuhoru Alyahuwdi, (Ṣ, Mgh, O,) The synagogue of the Jews, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in which they assemble (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) for prayer (Mṣb) on the occasion of their festival: (Ḳ:) or a certain day on which they eat and drink: (Ḳ:) or it signifies also a certain festival of the Jews: (O:) [app. the feast of Purim (written in the Book of Esther פּוּרִים pl. of פּוּר)]: accord. to AʼObeyd, (O, Mṣb,) a Hebrew word, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or Nabathæan; (Mṣb;) arabicized; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) originally buhor; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and the Christians say fuxor. (TA.)

fihorN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) masc. and fem.; (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or, accord. to Lth, the Arabs in general made it fem.; but it occurs in the Ḳ as masc.; (TA;) A stone such as fills the hand: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a stone of the size of that with which one crushes walnuts (Ḳ, TA) and the like: (TA:) or a round stone with which one bruises, or brays, perfume: (Ḥam p. 643:) or a stone, absolutely: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OafohaArN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and [of mult.] fuhuwrN: (O, Ḳ:) Aṣ used to say fihorN and fihorapN↓, (Ṣ, O,) [indicating the former to be a coll. gen. n. and the latter to be the n. un.,] like sidorN and sidorapN: (O:) the dim. is fuhayorapN↓. (Ṣ, O.)
fihorapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

fahiyrapN Pure, unmixed, milk, into which heated stones are put; and when it boils, flour is sprinkled upon it, and it is mixed, and stirred about, and beaten, therewith; and is then eaten: (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) it has also been mentioned as with q. (TA.)
fuhayorapN [dim. of fihorN and of fihorapN]: see fihorN.
naAqapN fiyoharapN and fayoharN, (O, Ḳ,) the former mentioned by IDrd, and the latter by Ibn-ʼAbbád, A she-camel that is hard and strong, (O,) or hard and large. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN mafoharapN Land having in it [stones such as are termed] OafohaAr [pl. of fihorN]. (O, TA.)
mafaAhiruka, (Ḳ, TA,) thus we find it, with fet-ḥ, but in some copies of the Ḳ with damm, (TA,) The flesh of thy breast. (Ḳ, TA.)

dictScrap.note: IF says that there is not in the original language [of the Arabs] more than one word having in it the letters f and h and r, and that is Alfihoru. (O.)

entry.sense: Q. 1. fahorasa Alkutuba [He made, or wrote, a catalogue of the books or writings], (O,) or fahorasa kitaAbahu [he made an index, or a table of contents, to his book or writing], (Ḳ,) inf. n. fahorasapN. (TA.) See what follows.

fihorisN A book, or writing, in which [the names or titles or descriptions] of [other] books, or writings, are collected; [i. e. a catalogue of books or writings: but more commonly, accord. to modern usage, the index, or table of contents, of a book or writing; in an Arabic book, generally placed at the beginning:] an arabicized word; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) from [the Pers.] fihorisot: (O, Ḳ:) pl. fahaArisu. (TA.)

1. fahimahu, aor. _a {yafohamu}, inf. n. fahomN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and fahamN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the more chaste, (Ḳ,) but the former is a dial. var. [more] extensively obtaining, or, as some say, it is a subst. used as an inf. n., (Mṣb,) and fahaAmiyapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and fahaAmapN and fihaAmapN, (Ḳ,) He understood it, or knew it with the mind; he apprehended its meaning; syn. Eaqalahu, (JK,) and Ealimahu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Earafahu biAlqalobi. (Ḳ.) And fahima Eanohu [He understood what he (another) said]. (A in art. xrs;, &c.) [See also fahomN below.]
fahuma, meaning He was, or became, such as is termed fahiym [i. e. one having much understanding], is like Ealuma, meaning “he was, or became, such as is termed Ealiym.” (TA.)
2: see what next follows {4}.
4. Oafohamotuhu and fah-amotuhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. of the latter tafohiymN, (Ṣ, TA,) I made him to understand, or know, a thing; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) syn. jaEalotuhu yafohamuhu. (TA.)
5. tfh-mhu He understood it, or knew it, (fahimahu,) one thing [or one particular thereof] after another; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, speech, or language. (Ṣ.)

[And He endeavoured to understand it. (See its inf. n. as used in the former half of the second paragraph {1} of art. dbr.)] And Alt-afaAhumu↓ signifies the same as Alt-afah-umu [app. as meaning The endeavouring to understand; or the affecting, or pretending, to understand]. (TA.)
6: see what next precedes {5}.
7. Anfhm, (Ḳ, TA,) as quasi-pass. of fah-amahu, inf. n. tafohiymN, [or of Oafohamahu, i. e. as meaning He was made to understand, or know,] (TA,) is an incorrect word, (Ḳ, TA.)
10. AisotafohamaniI AlX-aIoCa He sought, or desired, of me, the understanding of the thing [i. e., that he might be made to understand it]; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) syn. Talaba min-iI fahomahu. (TA.)

fahomN is an inf. n. of 1, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) or a subst. used as an inf. n.: (Mṣb:) [see 1, first sentence:] it is expl. as signifying The conception of the meaning from the word, or expression: or the quickness of the transition of the mind from extrinsic to other [i. e. intrinsic] things: or a condition of the mind whereby it ascertains what is approvable: or, as in the “Ahkám” of El-Ámidee, excellence of intelligence in respect of its readiness to apprehend quickly subjects of inquiry that present themselves to it. (TA.)
fahimN, an epithet applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Quick of understanding; syn. sariyEu Alfahomi. (Ḳ.)
fah-aAmapN: see what next precedes.
faAhimN [act. part. n. of fahima; Understanding, or knowing, a thing].
mafohuwmN [pass. part. n. of fahima; Understood, or known.]
[And hence, lafoZK mafohuwmN The acceptation of a word or an expression; i. e. the meaning, or sense, in which it is understood: see also maEonFI, in art. EnI].
1. fahawotu Eanohu, (JK, Ḳ,) aor. Oafohuw, inf. n. fuhuw-N, (JK,) I was unmindful, forgetful, or neglectful, of it. (JK, Ḳ.)

ISd says, fahaA fuWaAduhu is like hafaA, [which, said of the heart, accord. to explanations in the TA in art. hfw, means It fluttered, or palpitated: and it was flurried by reason of grief or of beating:] and no inf. n. of it has been heard, therefore I think it to be formed by transposition. (TA.)
And fahaA signifies also He spoke clearly, or distinctly, after doing the contrary thereof. (TA.)
3. fAhAhu, inf. n. mufaAhaApN; i. q. fAwhhu, inf. n. mufaAwahapN; i. e. He talked, or discoursed, with him: and he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence. (TA in art. fwh.)
4. AfhI He was weak, or erroneous, in his judgment, or opinion. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)

faAhK, formed by transposition from faAYihN, A man who reveals, or discloses, everything that is in his mind; like faAwuwhapN; (Fr, in Ṣ and TA, art. fwh;) and so faAhN: (Fr, in TA ibid.:) and faAhK bijuwEihi one who reveals his hunger. (TA ibid.)
[AlAfhyAni, said by Freytag to signify The elephant and the buffalo, is a mistranscription for AlOaqohabaAni.]
OafohaMCN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] i. q. bulohN [pl. of Oabolahu; signifying Heedless; or heedless of evil by reason of their goodness;, &c.]. (IAạr, TA.)

hom.sense: fuw, with the w quiescent, [Valerian;] a certain medicine, (Ḳ, TA,) a diuretic, (CK,) beneficial as a remedy for pain of the side and for alopecia. (Ḳ, TA.)
As a prefixed noun, signifying The mouth, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

entry.sense: fuw-apN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like quw-apN [in form], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [Madder; the species thereof used by dyers; rubia tinctorum;] certain roots (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of a plant (M) which are extracted from the earth, (Lth, T, M,) with which they dye (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) clothes, or garments: (Lth, T:) AḤn says, red roots of a plant which rises slender, having upon its head berries intensely red and having much juice used for writing therewith and variegating: (M:) called in Pers. ruwyan: (PṢ: [in a copy of the T ruwayn or duwayn: and in my copies of the Ṣ rwaynh and ruwyanahN:]) it is [also used as] a medicine, having the property of causing abortion, (Ḳ,) producing a flow of the urine and of the men strual discharge, (Ḳ,* TA,) aperient, clearing the complexion or skin, clearing the skin from every mark of the ringworm and of the white [species of leprosy termed] yahaq: (Ḳ:) it has been mentioned also in the Ḳ as ending with [a radical] h [i. e. written fuw-apN, in art. fwh]; but, as is said by Lth, [and in the T,] the final letter is that which denotes the fem gender. (TA.)
mufaw-FI Dyed with fuw-ap; applied to a garment; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and to a hide. (M.)

And mufaw-aApN A land (OaroDN) abounding with fuw-p: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) or having in it fuw-p: (M:) and mufab-aApN signifies the same: (TA in art. gbI:) or you say ArD mafwAp mn AlmfAwiI [i. e. mafowaApN↓, of which the pl., without the article, is mafaAwK]; (T;) AlmafaAwiI signifying the lands (AlOaraDuwna) that give growth to fuw-ap. (TA.)

1. faAta AlOamoru, aor. yafuwtu, inf. n. fawotN and fawaAtN, originally signifies faAta waqotu fiEolihi [i. e. The time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, of the affair passed, passed away, elapsed, or escaped, neglected by him, without his doing it or performing it]; and hence the phrase faAtati AlS-alaApu, meaning The time of prayer passed, passed away, elapsed, or escaped, without his performing it therein (Mṣb:) and AftAt↓ is syn. with faAta. (M, O.) [And both of these verbs are trans.:] one says faAtahu AlX-aIoCu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or AlOamoru, (M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (O,) and so the inf. ns.; (Ṣ,* M, O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AftAthu↓: (Ḳ;) The thing, or affair, passed, or passed away, from him [neglected by him]; (M, Ḳ;) [or the time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, thereof passed, or passed away from him neglected by him;] or the thing escaped him, [or became beyond his reach,] so that he was unable to attain it, or to do it, or to accomplish it. (Mṣb.) But this explanation is not applicable except in the case of prayer, and the like: in other cases, faAtahu signifies He, or it, preceded him; was, or became, or got, before him; outwent him; passed beyond him; or had, got, or look, precedence of him: and went, or passed, away from him: and the like. (MF, TA.) One says, faAtaniI kacaA, meaning sabaqaniI [i. e. Such a thing preceded me,, &c., app. so as to become beyond my reach]: and fut-uhu OanaA [I preceded it,, &c.]: (T:) and jaArayotuhu Hat-aI fut-uhu I ran with him until I passed beyond him, or outwent him: (A, TA:) and faAtahu fulaAnN biciraAEK Such a one preceded him, or outwent him, by a cubit. (Mṣb.) falaA fawota, in the Ḳur xxxiv. 50, means falaA fawota lahumo min-FA [And there shall be for them no escaping from us], i. e. laA yafuwtuwnanaA [they shall not escape us]. (Jel. [And Bḍ says the like; adding, “by flight, or fortifying themselves.”]) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI lA yufaAtu walaA [expl. in art. lyt] (T.) And they assert that a man went forth from his family, and when he returned, his wife said to him, “If thou hadst been present with us, we would have related to thee what hath happened;” whereupon he said to her, lamo tufaAtiI fahaAtiI (M, Meyd) i. e. It has not escaped thee [lit. thou hast not been escaped], so adduce what thou hast [to tell]: the saying is a proverb. (Meyd.)
See also 5: and see 8, in three places.
faAta is also syn. with faAda [as signifying He died; in which sense the aor. is yafuwtu, and the inf. n. fawotN]. (A in art. fyd.) And Ofotiyta↓ signifies He died suddenly. (TA in art. fOt, q. v.)

4. AfAthu AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, MA,) or AlOamora, (Ḳ,) He made the thing, or affair, to pass, or pass away, from him [neglected by him; or he made the time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, thereof to pass, or pass away, from him neglected by him; or he made the thing to escape him, or become beyond his reach, so that he was unable to attain it, or to do it, or to accomplish it: see 1, second sentence]. (M, A, Ḳ.)

5. tfw-t Ealayohi fiI maAlihi means faAtahu↓ bihi, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) i. e. He acted exclusively of him, (M,) [or passed him over], namely, his father, (AʼObeyd, T, M, O,*) in respect of his property, (AʼObeyd, T, &c.,) i. e. his own property, (AʼObeyd, T,) by giving it away, (AʼObeyd, T, M, O,) and squandering it, (AʼObeyd, T, M.) without consulting him, or asking his permission: (O, TA:) occurring in a trad., relating to a case in which the Prophet ordered the father to cause the property to be restored to his son; and informed him that the son had no right to act thus to his father. (AʼObeyd, T, O.*)
See also 8 latter half, in two places:
and see the paragraph here following, in two places.

6. tfAwt has for its inf. n. tafaAwutN and tafaAwatN and tafaAwitN, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) the second and third of which are mentioned by AZ; the second is said by ISk (who mentions this and the third, M) to be of the dial. of the Kilábees, and the third is mentioned by El-'Ambaree; both anomalous, for the inf. n. of a verb of the measure tafaAEala is tafaAEulN. [in the copies of the Ṣ ytfAEl, and said to be so in J's handwriting,] with damm to the E except in this instance (Ṣ. O:) but Sb said that there is not among inf. ns. an instance of tafaAEalN n or of tafaAEilN. (M.) maA taraI fiI xaloqi Qlr-aHomeni mino tafaAwutK, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) or tafaw-utK↓, (T, O, Ḳ.) [the former in the CK and the latter in other copies of the Ḳ,] the latter being the reading of Hamzeh and Ks, in the Ḳur [lxvii. 3], (O,) means Thou seest not in the creation of the Compassionate, (M, O,) i. e. in his creation of the heaven, (M,) any incongruity, or discordance; (T, M, O;) or any fault, defect, or imperfection, so that the beholder might say, “If it were thus, it were better;” (T, O, Ḳ;) thus the latter reading is expl. by Es-Suddee; (T, O, TA;) and Fr says that both readings have one meaning: (T, TA:) you say of a thing tfw-t↓ and tfAwt. (M.)

And one says, tfAwt AlX-ayoMni The two things were far apart, one from the other; or widely distinct or separated; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or differed, or were different. (Mṣb.)
And tafaAwataA fiI AlfaDoli They two were distinct, or dissimilar, in respect of excellence, (Mṣb,) or fiI AlX-arafi [in eminence, or nobility]. (A.)
8: see 1, first and second sentences.

As, relating the verse of Ibn-Mukbil,
yaA Hur-a Oamosayotu XayoxFA qado wahaI baSariI
waQfotiyta maA duwna yawomi lbaEovi mino EumuriI [which may be rendered O ingenuous woman, (Hur-a being an abbreviation of Hur-apN,) I have become an old man, my sight has become weak, and what is anterior to the day of resurrection, of my life, has been passed, or has run out like water poured forth (fariga)], says, it is from Alfawotu, and AlAifotiyaAtu [app. as the inf. n. of the pass. v. Aftyt used in this verse] signifies AlfaraAgu. (T.)
See also 1, last sentence.

AlAifotiyaAtu signifies also The betaking oneself, or applying oneself, before another or others, or hastily, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) to a thing, (Ṣ, O,) or to the doing of a thing, (Mṣb,) without obeying him who should be obeyed, (Ṣ, O,) or following his own opinion only, without consulting him who had the best right to order in the case: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) you say, AftAt Ealayohi biOamori kacaA i. e. faAtahu↓ bihi [app. meaning He so betook himself,, &c., in opposition to him: or fAth bh may be here used in the sense in which it is expl. above voce tafaw-ata]. (Ṣ, O.) And you say, fulaAnN laA yufotaAtu Ealayohi Such a one, nothing is to be done without his order; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;*) and so laA yufaAtu↓ Elyh; (Ḥar p. 63;) or laA yufotaAtu Ealayohi XaIoCN duwna Oamorihi [which means the same]. (Mṣb.) OamivoliI yufotaAtu Ealayohi fiI banaAtihi, (T, M, O,) or fiI Oamori banaAtihi, (Ṣ, TA,) occurs in a trad., (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, TA,) meaning Shall such a one as I [am] have anything done in respect of his daughters without his order? (Mgh,* TA;) and was said by ʼAbd-Er-Raḥmán the son of Aboo-Bekr to his sister ʼÁïsheh, on the occasion of her having given in marriage his daughter, the elder Hafsah, during his absence, to El-Mundhir the son of Ez-Zubeyr. (T,* O, TA.*) And you say, AftAt Ealayohi fiI XaIoCK, and faAtahu↓ bXaIoCK, meaning He brought to pass a thing exclusively of him [i. e., of another person, without the latter's having any part therein]. (TA.) And AftAt Ealayohi fI kacaA, and tfw-t↓ Ealayohi fiyhi, He followed his own opinion only, exclusively of him [i. e., of another], in the disposal, or management, of such a thing: the verbs being trans. by means of EalaI because implying the meaning of Alv-agal-ub. (TA.) And AftAt Ealayohi fiI AlOamori, (M, Ḳ,* TA,) and tfw-t↓ Ealayohi fiyhi, (MA,) He decided against him in the affair. (M, MA, Ḳ,* TA.)

And AftAt biOamorihi He effected, or executed, his affair without consulting any one: thus accord. to Aṣ, without hemz: (T, TA:) and, as is related on the authority of ISh and ISk, one says, AftOt bOmrh, with hemz, meaning he was alone in his affair; and in like manner one says, biraOoyihi in his opinion. (TA. [See also art. fOt.])

And AftAt AlkalaAma He originated, or excogitated, the speech: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and he extemporized the speech; spoke it without consideration, or thought, or preparation, or without pausing, or hesitating; as also Aifotalatahu. (TA.)
fawotN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ,* M, &c.)

fawota famihi and fawota rumoHihi and fawota yadihi [lit. Beyond the reach of his mouth and of his spear and of his hand, or arm (in several copies of the Ḳ erroneously written fawotu)] mean where he sees it but will not [be able to] reach it, or attain it. (Ḳ, TA.) A man said to another, reviling him, [or rather said of him,] jaEala Qll-ehu rizoqahu fawota famihi i. e. [May God make his sustenance to be beyond the reach of his mouth,] where he shall see it and shall not attain it. (Ṣ, O. [And the like is said in the M and A.]) And one says, huwa min-iI fawota Alr-umoHi [He, or it, is] where my spear will not reach him, or it. (Ṣ, A, O.) And huwa min-iI fawota Alyadi [He, or it, is] beyond the reach of my hand, or arm: mentioned by Sb among what are peculiarly adverbial expressions. (M.) And OafolatanaA fulaAnN fawota Alyadi and fawota AlZ-ufori [Such a one escaped from us beyond the reach of a hand, or an arm, and beyond the reach of a finger-nail]. (A. [Golius, as on the authority of the A, has fuwayota↓ ZuforK, which he explains as syn. with fawota yadK; but it signifies A little beyond the reach of a finger-nail.])
OasomaEu SawotFA waOaraI fawotFA means I hear a sound, or voice, but I see not a deed, or no deed. (TA in art. Swt.)
fawotN signifies also The space between two fingers [when they are extended apart (see buSomN)]: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) pl. OafowaAtN. (Ṣ, M, O.)

And you say, bayonahumaA fawotN faAYitN↓ like as you say bawonN baAYinN [i. e. Between them two (meaning two men) is a wide distance; app. in respect of rank or estimation: the last word being in this case a corroborative, like the latter word in mawotN maAYitN and liyolN laAYilN]. (M.)
fawoAtN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ,* M, &c.)

[Hence,] mawotN AlfawaAti Sudden death: (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ:) likewise termed Almawotu AlfawaAtu and Almawotu AlfuwaAtu. (IAạr, TA.) You say, maAta mawota AlfawaAti He died a sudden death. (Ṣ, O.) The Prophet, passing by a leaning wall, quickened his pace; and being asked wherefore he did so, answered, OaxaAfu mawota AlfawaAti [I fear sudden death]. (O.)

fuwayotN One who follows his, or her, own opinion only, (M, O, Ḳ,) not consulting any one: (O:) applied alike to a man and to a woman: (M, O, Ḳ:) on the authority of Er-Riyáshee: pronounced by AZ with hemz. (O.)
See also fawotN [of which it is the dim.]
faAYitN act. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (T.)
See also fawotN, last sentence.
1. faAja, [aor. yafuwju,] said of musk, i. q. faAHa [i. e. It diffused, or exhaled, its odour]. (O, Ḳ.)
And, said of the day, ‡ It became cool. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And one says, faAjati AlX-amosu Einoda barodi Aln-ahaAri † [The sun became moderated at the cool time of the day]. (O.)

2. lasotu biraAYiHK Hat-aI Oufaw-ija means [I am not going in the evening] until I refresh myself by the coolness of the air. (Ḳ: there expl. by the words OaIo Oubar-ida Eano nafosiI [in which, for Oubar-ida, I read Ouborida]: in some copies [erroneously] EalaI nfsI.)

hom.sense: 4. AfAj, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UifaAjapN, (Ṣ,) He hastened, or went quickly; (Ṣ, Ḳ, and O and Mṣb in art. fyj:) and he ran. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And AfAj Alqawomu fiI AlOaroDi The people, or party, went away, and spread, or dispersed themselves, in the land. (L in art. fyj.)
And AfAj fiI Eadowihi He was slow in his running. (L in art. fyj.) [Thus AfAj has two contr. significations.]
Also He sent the camels to the watering-trough, or tank, drove by drove. (O,* Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. Ausotufiyja fulaAnN Such a one was desired, or incited, to be [quick, or] brisk, or prompt; syn. Ausotuxif-a. (Ḳ, and O in art. fyj.)

fawojN A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; (Ṣ, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also faAYijN↓, (L,) and faAYijapN↓, (Ḳ,) and fayojN↓, (O, Ḳ, and Mṣb in art. fyj, q. v.,) which last is said by Az to be originally fay-ijN, from faAja, aor. yafuwju, like hay-inN from haAna, aor. yahuwnu, for which they say also hayono: (O, and Mṣb * in art. fyj:) or a crowd, or dense company, &c.: (so accord. to an explanation of the first of the following pls. by Z in the Ksh and by Bḍ, both in Ḳur cx. 2:) or a company,, &c., of the followers, or dependants, of chiefs: or a great crowd of men: (L:) [and app. † a multitude of things: (see an ex. voce Oafokalu, in art. fkl:)] pl. [of pauc.] OafowaAjN [also used as a pl. of mult.] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] fuWuwjN and pl. pl. OafaAwiyju (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OafaAwiju (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and OafaAYiju, as though pl. of OafiyjapN. (O.)

hom.sense: fayojN: see the next preceding paragraph:
and see also art. fyj.
faAYijN: see fawojN. One says, mar-a binaA faAYiju waliymapi fulaAnK, meaning The company (fawoj) of those that were at the repast of such a one [passed by us]. (TA.)
It is said that faAYijN, applied to a she-camel, signifies Fat: or such as is termed HaAYil, and fat: but the word commonly known [thus used] is faAYijN [q. v.]. (TA.)
faAYijapN: see fawojN:
and see also art. fyj.

entry.sense: 1. faAHa Almisoku, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwHu and yafiyHu; (Mṣb;) or faAHato riyHu Almisoki, aor. tafuwHu and tafiyHu; (Ṣ;) inf. n. fawoHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fuWuwHN and fawaHaAnu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and fayoHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fayaHaAnN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) The musk diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or the odour of the musk diffused itself [or became exhaled]; and fAH AlT-iybu the perfume diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (Ṣ;) or this last signifies the perfume became perceptible; or it clung and remained; [in a garment or person;] syn. Eabiqa: (Mṣb in art. fyH:) the verb is not used in relation to a foul, or disagreeable odour or thing: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) of such an odour one says hab-ato: (Mṣb:) or the former verb is common to both: (Ḳ:) but this assertion is outweighed [by the other]: (TA:) fawoxN signifies the giving forth, and exhaling, a sweet, or pleasant, odour: (KL:) and the perceiving such an odour: Fr says that faAHato riyHuhu and faAxato are syn.; but AZ says the fawoxN is attended by sound. (TA.)
For other significations of this verb, see art. fyH.
4. AfAH: for this verb, see art. fyH.

6. nazalonaA fiI busotaAnK tanaAwaHato OaToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato OanowaAruhu [We alighted in a garden the birds of which warbled plaintively, one to another, and the flowers of which exhaled sweet odours, one with another]. (A.)
fawoHN AlHayoDi The chief and first portion of the menstrual discharge. (L.)
fawoHapN [A spreading, or an exhalation], of perfume. (TA in art. ESr.)

hom.sense: 1. faAxati Alr-iyHu, aor. tafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN; (Ḳ;) as also fAxt, aor. tafiyxu, (Ḳ in art. fyx,) inf. n. fayoxN and fayaxaAnN; (TA in art. fyx;) The wind, or odour, rose, or diffused itself: (Ḳ:) you say, faAxato minohu riyHN Tay-ibapN, aor. tafuwxu and tafiyxu, a sweet odour diffused itself from him, or it; like fAHt: (AO, Aṣ, Ṣ:) or fAxt Alr-iyHu, aor. tafuwxu, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. fawoxN (AZ, TA in art. fwH,) or fawaxaAnN, (AZ, TA in the present art.,) signifies the wind made a sound, or noise, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in its blowing. (AZ, TA.)
And fAx AlHar-u The heat became allayed, or assuaged. (L.)
See also the next paragraph {4}, in two places.

entry.sense: 4. AfAx, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UifaAxapN, (Lth, AZ, Ṣ, IAth,) He (a man) emitted wind, (Lth, AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a sound, (AZ, Ṣ,) from the anus; (Lth;) and fAx↓, aor. yafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN (Ḳ, TA) and fawoxN, (TA,) signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) or the former, he voided excrement with an emission of wind: (IAth, TA:) [mentioned also in art. fyx:] and he (a man, or a beast,) emitted wind in voiding urine: (ISh, Ṣ:) and fAx↓, aor. yafuwxu, it (the emission of excrement) made a sound. (L.)
AfAx bibawolihi He emitted his urine from a dilated aperture. (L.) And AfAxt She (a camel) made a sprinkling with her urine. (L.)

AfAx Alz-iq-a, inf. n. as above, He opened the mouth of the zq- [or skin for wine, &c.] to give vent to the air within it: thus accord. to Fr; who says that he heard a sheykh, of those having knowledge in the Arabic language, explain this phrase as meaning he smeared the inside of the zq- with rub- [or rob]. (L.)

Oafixo Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyrapi, (L, TA,) in the Ḳ Ean-aA, but correctly Enk, as in other lexicons, (TA,) [as also OafiH,] means Oaborido, (L, Ḳ,) i. e. Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (L, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faAda, aor. yafuwdu, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ, and T in art. fyd,) inf. n. fawodN; (AA, Ḳ, and T in art. fyd;) as also faAda, aor. yafiydu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, and T, &c. in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN; (IAạr, Ḳ, and T in art. fyd;) He died. (T, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ.)

And fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M,) inf. n. fawodN, (Ḳ,) It (property) continued, or belonged, or appertained, syn. vabata, (M, Ḳ,) liSaAHibihi to its owner; (M;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN: (Ḳ:) or (so in the Ḳ) it went away, passed away, or departed; (Ḳ;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (Ḳ in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (Ḳ. [See also art. fyd.])

fAdhu, (Aṣ, Yaạḳoob, T, M, L,) aor. yafuwduhu, (Yaạḳoob, M,* L,) inf. n. fawodN, (Ḳ,) He mixed it, (M, L, Ḳ,) namely, saffron [&c.], (M, L,) or perfume, &c., (Aṣ, T,) or moistened it with water, &c.; (L;) syn. daAfahu; (Aṣ, Yaạḳoob, T, M, L;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]: (M, L:) and so fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (L. [See also art. fyd.])
4. Oafadotuhu I killed him; destroyed him. (O, Ḳ. [See also art. fyd.])
And I gave him property. (M, L, Ḳ.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fyd [q. v.]. (L.)
See also 10.

entry.sense: 5. tfw-d fawoqa Aljabala He (a mountain-goat) ascended (OaXorafa) upon the mountain. (O,* L, Ḳ.)

6. humaA yatafaAwadaAni AlEiloma (ISh, Ḳ) is a phrase used by the vulgar, (ISh,) but the correct expression is yatafaAyadaAni, meaning They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (Ḳ:) or ytfAydAn baAlomaAli bayonahumaA They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh:) or, in the opinion of MF, each is allowable. (TA. [See also art. fyd.])

10. AstfAdhu, (M, L, Ḳ,) and AfAdhu↓, (M, Ḳ,) [respecting which latter see 10 in art. fyd,] as also tqy-d, (Ḳ, [but this belongs to art. fyd only,]) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]. (M, L, Ḳ.) [See more in art. fyd.]

hom.sense: fawodN Each of the two sides of the head: (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. OafowaAdN: (M, L, Mṣb:) one says, badaA AlX-ayobu bifawodayohi [Hoariness appeared in the two sides of his head]. (Ṣ, O, L.) And The main, or chief, portion of the hair of the head, next the ear; (M, L, Ḳ;) or of the hair that descends below the lobe of the ear, next the ear: (IF, L, Mṣb:) or fawodaAni signifies [two locks, or plaited locks, of hair, such as are termed] DafiyrataAni (ISk, Ṣ, O, L, Mṣb) of a man (ISk, Ṣ, O, L) and of a woman. (O.)

† The side (Ḳ, TA) of anything; (TA;) each of the two sides (M, L) of a thing. (L.) You say, AirofaEo fawoda AlxibaMCi ‡ Raise thou the side of the tent. (A.) And nazaluwA bayona fawodaIi AlwaAdiI ‡ [They alighted, or abode, between the two sides of the valley]. (A.)

‡ Each of the two equiponderant halves of the load of a beast: (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ, TA:) one says, qaEada bayona Alfawodayoni ‡ [He sat between the two equiponderant halves of the load of the beast]. (Ṣ, O, L, TA.) And [hence, app.,] † A [sack such as is termed] juwaAliq. (Ḳ.)

† The part that is abundant in plumage of each of the wings of the eagle: (M:) [or each of the wings; for] one says, Oaloqati AlEuqaAbu fawodayohaA EalaI Alhayovami ‡ [The eagle cast] its wings [upon, or over, the eaglet]. (A.)
One says also, jaEalotu AlkitaAba fawodayni, meaning ‡ I doubled the upper part of the letter, or writing, over the lower part, so that it became two halves. (A, O.)
And Aisotalamotu fawoda Albayoti ‡ [I touched, by kissing, or with the hand,] the corner of the House [of God; i. e., of the Kaabeh]. (A.)
Also A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; or a crowd, or dense company, &c.; or a great crowd of men; syn. fawoj: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) pl. OafowaAdN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

entry.sense: fawaAdN, (O, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ to the f, (O,) like saHaAb [in form], (Ḳ,) i. q. fuWaAdN [generally meaning The heart (see other explanations in art. fOd)]; (O, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)
faAYidapN a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, Ḳ, and L in art. fyd,) in the sense of vabata: (M, and L in art. fyd:) it belongs to this art. and to art. fyd. (TA. [See the latter art.])
mafuwdN, applied to perfume, &c., i. q. maduwfN [Mixed, or moistened with water, &c.]; (Aṣ, T;) as also mufiydN. (Ṣ and O and L in art. fyd.)
rajulN mitolaAfN mifowaAdN A destructive man; as also mifoyaAdN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. faAra, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwru, said of water; (Mṣb;) and faArato, aor. tafuwru, said of a qidor [or cooking-pot]; (T, Ṣ;) inf. n. faworN and fawaraAnN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) [the latter of which is the more common] and fuWuwrN (M, Ḳ) and fuwaArN; (M, TA;) It boiled, or estuated. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[fAr said of a liquor, It fermented. (See nabiycN.)]
[Said of blood, and of wine, It flushed, or mantled, in the cheeks or head.]
fArt nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; i. q. vArt [q. v.]. (T in art. vwr.)
fAr faAYiruhu↓ i. q. vAr vaAYiruhu (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) His anger boiled [or became roused or excited]; (Ṣ;) or he was, or became, angry. (TA.)

fAr AlEiroqu, inf. n. fawaraAnN, The vein became excited, or in a state of commotion, and flowed forth [with blood]: (M, Ḳ, TA:) to which is added in the Ḳ, waDaraba; but this is a mistake, occasioned by a false reading of the next words in the M, which are waDarobN faw-aArN ragiybN waAsiEN. (TA. [See faw-aArN.])
faworu AlEiroqi, in a horse means The vein's having inflations, or knots, [or a varicose condition,] apparent in it; which is disapproved. (ISk, TA.)
fAr said of water signifies also It welled, and came forth, from the earth, or ground: (Mgh:) it appeared, pouring forth, from the spring, or source. (TA.)
fArwA is said of men assembled in market-places [app. as meaning They bustled, or were in a state of commotion]. (TA.)
fAr Almisoku, inf. n. fuwaArN and fawaraAnN, [The odour of] the musk spread. (M, Ḳ.)
furotuhu: see 4.
Also (furotuhu) I made for it, i. e. the balance, what are termed fiyaAraAni [dual of fiyaArN, q. v.]. (Th, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. fw-r liln-ufasaMCi He made what is termed fiyrap [q. v.] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, Ḳ.)
4. Oafarotuhu and furotuhu↓ I made it to boil, or estuate. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: AlfaAru The muscles of a man: (M, Ḳ:) also mentioned in art. fOr, as written with C. (TA.) Oaborizo naAraka waUino hazalota faAraka [Put forth thy fire, that passengers may see it and be attracted by it, though thou make lean thy muscles,] is a saying meaning † give food though thou injure thy body [by doing so]. (M, L.)
See also faOorN (with which it is syn. in other senses), in art. fOr.
faworN [originally an inf. n.: see 1.] The burning, or heat, and boiling, of Hell. (TA.) And Intenseness, or vehemence, of heat; (TA;) as also faworapN↓. (Ṣ.)
faworu AlX-afaqi The remains of the redness in the western horizon after sunset: as also vaworuhu. (TA.) [See also faworapN.]

And A time: (TA:) [or rather] the present time in which is no delaying. (Mṣb.) Thus in the saying, AlX-ufoEapu EalaI Alfawori [The right of pre-emption is to be had] in the present time in which is no delaying. (Mṣb.)

And hence, A state in which is no delay. (Mṣb.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN fiI HaAjatihi vum-a rajaEa mino faworihi [Such a one came for the object of his want,] then returned immediately, or at once: or, as some say, with the same motion with which he came, not ceasing from motion after it; properly, conjoining what was before the coming with what was after it, without tarrying. (Mṣb.) And OatawoA mino faworihimo, meaning mino wajohihimo [i. e., app., They came in a headlong manner; like the phrase maDaI EalaI wajohihi]; (M, Ḳ, TA; but the M has jaAWuwA instead of OatawoA;) and this is said by Zj to be the meaning of mino faworihimo in the Ḳur iii. 121: (M, TA:) or qabola Oano yasokunuwA [before their resting, or ceasing from motion]: (Ḳ, TA:) or mino faworihimo in the Ḳur ubi suprà means in the commencement of their procedure: (O:) or in, or at, their instant of time; (Ksh, Bḍ;) i. e. [in, or at, the same instant, or] immediately: (Bḍ:) and Oatayotu fulaAnFA mino faworiI, meaning qabola Oano Oasokuna [i. e. I came to such a one before my resting, or ceasing from motion]. (Ṣ, O.)
