And you say, faEalotuhu mino faworiI, meaning I did it at once, or instantly. (T, TA.)

entry.sense: fuwrN Gazelles: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) a word having no sing.; (T, Ṣ, M, TA;) accord. to IAạr and Yaạḳoob: (TA:) or its sing. is faAYirN↓; (M, Ḳ, TA;) accord. to Kr. (TA.) One says, laA OafoEalu kacaA maA laOolaOati Alfuwru I will not do such a thing while the gazelles wag their tails. (IAạr, T, Ṣ.)

faArapN Almisoki The odour of musk: or the bag, or receptacle, [i. e. the follicle, or vesicle,] thereof: (M, L:) [Ṣgh says that] this and what next follows have been mentioned in art. fOr, [q. v.,] but should more properly be mentioned in the present art., both being from faAra, aor. yafuwru. (O.)
faArapu AlUibili means The sweet exhalation from the skins of the camels when they are moist after returning from the water. (M, Ḳ.)
faworapN: see faworN:
and fuwaArapN.
Also An ebullition of anger, rage, or passion; syn. haAYijN. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. hyj.)
And Freshness, or newness: so in the saying Oaxacotu AlX-aIoCa bifaworatihi [I took the thing in its fresh, or new, state]. (TA.)
[And hence,] faworapu Aln-ahaAri The first part, or beginning, of the day. (T, TA.) And faworapu AlEiXaMCi The time [next] after the EiXaMC [or nightfall]. (Ṣ, TA.)
faworapu Aln-aAsi The place where people congregate, and where they bustle, or are in a state of commotion, (yafuwruwna,) in their market-places. (TA.)
faworapu Aljabali The higher, or highest, part; and the elevated and hard, or elevated and plain or level, part; of the mountain. (Ḳ.)
fuwrapN i. q. fuWorapN [expl. in art. fOr] meaning A certain flatus in the pastern of a horse [&c.]. (O, Ḳ.)
And i. q. kuwfapN [A round piece, or collection, of red sand; or a piece, or collection, of sand mixed with pebbles;, &c.]. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)
fiyrapN Fenugreek (HulobapN) mixed [in the manner described voce faYiyrapN (q. v.) in art. fOr] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, Ḳ.)

fiyaArN sing. of fiyaAraAni, (T,) which signifies The two things (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) of iron (M, Ḳ) between which is the tongue of the balance: (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) originally with w in the place of the I, (M, O,) changed into I because of the kesreh before it. (O.)

fuwaArapN The froth, or foam, that boils, or boils over, of a cooking-pot: (Ṣ and Ḳ in this art.* and voce TubaAxapN:) and mafaAwiru↓ signifies the same, mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád. (O.) And [in like manner] faworapN↓ signifies The mantling foam upon the surface of wine. (TA.)
faw-aArN [an intensive epithet from faAra; signifying Boiling much;, &c.:]
[and Water, &c., welling forth abundantly; gushing].

[Hence,] DarobN faw-aArN A smiting [that inflicts a wound] such as is wide, (IAạr, M, TA,) so that the blood flows [abundantly]: (M:) a poet says,
biDarobK yuxaf-itu faw-aAruhu
waTaEonK taraI Ald-ama minohu raXiyXFA
UicaA qataluwA minokumu faArisFA
Damin-aA lahu baEodahu Oano yaEiyXaA
(IAạr, M, TA. [The text of the M as given in the TT, for taraI Ald-ama, has yurI Aldm; and for Oano yaEiyXaA, it has Aw yEyXA: and the right reading of the first hemistich seems to be, biDarobK tuxaf-itu faw-aArapK; for an inf. n. is sometimes made fem.: see an instance of Darob as fem. in the EM p. 157: the poet means, With a smiting that silences, or kills, inflicting a wide and gushing wound; and a piercing with the spear in consequence of which thou seest the blood sprinkled: when they slay a horseman of you, we are responsible for him after it that he shall live: i. e., as is said in the M, his blood shall be revenged, so that he will be as though he had not been slain: and it is also there said that by yxf-t fw-Arh is meant lnhA wAsEp fdmhA ysyl wlA Swt lh; in which the two fem. pronouns and the fem. epithet all relate to the word Darob, agreeably with what I have stated to be in my opinion the right reading of the first hemistich.])
fay-uwrN Sharp, as an epithet applied to a man; syn. HadiydN. (O, Ḳ.) See also Tay-uwrN.

faw-aArapN, (accord. to the Ḳ,) or fuw-aArapN↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) A source, or spring, of water: (M, Ḳ:) [the latter word is app. the right in this case; for] IAạr says that fuw-aArapN↓ is applied to a wave: and to a birokap [i. e. watering-trough, or the like; or basin, pool, pond;, &c.]: and faw-aArapN, to anything that is not water: and in one place he says that daw-aArapN and faw-aArapN are applied to anything that does not move nor turn round; and duw-aArapN and fuw-aArapN↓ to such as moves and turns round. (T, TA.)

faw-aArapu Alwariki, with fet-ḥ and teshdeed, signifies The hole, or perforating aperture, of the wrk [or haunch]: (Ṣ, O:) or the faw-aArap, (Ḳ,) or fuw-aArap↓, (so in a copy of the M,) is an aperture in the warik [or haunch], to the belly, or interior of the body, not obstructed by bone: (M, Ḳ:) [these two explanations plainly apply to the sacroischiatic foramen: but what here follows is consistent with what precedes, though somewhat less clear:] or the faw-aArataAni, (Ḳ,) or fuw-aArataAni↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) are [two parts, in the region of the pelvis, described as being] sik-ataAni [a word which I do not find to have any proper meaning that would be here apposite, but which seems to be applied in this case, by a kind of catachresis, to two parts through which a weapon or the like may pass,] between [each of] the haunch-bones or hip-bones (bayona Alwarikayoni) and the quHoquH [or ischium], towards the side of the warik [or hip-bone], (M, Ḳ,) not intervening as obstacles in the way to the belly, or interior of the body; and they are what become in a state of commotion in the act of walking, or going along. (M.) [See also AlfaAYilu, in art. fyl] And accord. to Lth, the term faw-aArataAni, (O, and so in a copy of the T,) or fuw-aArataAni↓, (so in another copy of the T,) is applied to Two appertenances of the kariX [or stomach, properly of a ruminant animal], having within them two small nodous lumps (gud-ataAni), which latter are not eaten, and each of which is a piece of flesh in the midst of red flesh. (T, O.)
fuw-aArapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.

hom.sense: faAYirN [part. n. of 1:]
[hence, faAra faAYiruhu]: see 1, in two places.

Applied to a beast, of the equine and other kinds, Swollen in the sinews; syn. munotaXiru AlEaSabi. (Ḳ. [In the TA, this is said to be a mistake for mntXr AlgaDabi, and thus I find it to be written in the L, and in a copy of the M accord. to the TT: but see what I have said, in the first paragraph of this art., respecting the phrase above mentioned.])
See also fuwrN.

entry.sense: mafaAwiru: see fuwaArapN.

hom.sense: 1. faAza, aor. yafuwzu, inf. n. fawozN (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mafaAzN and mafaAzapN, (TA,) He attained, acquired, gained, or won, good, or good fortune, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) or his wish or desire, or what he desired or sought; (Bḍ in iii. 182, and TA;) he met with, or experienced, that for which one would be regarded with a wish to be in the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him; he became far from what was disliked, or hated, or evil: (TA:) he succeeded, or was successful: he won, or gained the victory: (Mṣb:) [he had his arrow drawn, or] his arrow came forth [from the ribaAbap], in the game called Almayosir: and ‡ it (an arrow) won; or came forth before its fellow [or fellows in that game]. (O,* TA.) You say, faAza bihi He attained it, acquired it, gained it, or won it; (Kh, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, good, or good fortune; (Kh, O;) or reward: (A:) and he took it away, went away with it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

He became safe, or secure; he escaped. (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, faAza minhu He became safe, or secure, from it; he escaped it; (A, O, Ḳ;) namely, evil; (TA;) or punishment. (A, O, TA.) And TuwbaI limano faAza biAlv-awaAbi wafaAza mina AlEiqaAbi A happy end is his who gains reward and escapes punishment. (A.)

And faAza, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwzu, (TA,) inf. n. fawozN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ He perished: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) he died; and so faw-azN↓: (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus the former bears two contr. significations: (A, Ḳ:) but IB says that, accord. to some, the latter is not used in this sense unless preceded by another phrase such as in the following ex.: maAta fulaAnN wafaw-aza↓ fulaAnN baEodahu [Such a one died and such a one died after him]: and accord. to others, fw-z↓ signifies ‡ he became in the mafaAzap [or state of temporary safety] which is between the present life and that which is to come. (TA.) [This last signification is given in the A.]
See also 2.

2. fw-z † He went, or his course brought him, to the mafaAzap: (IAạr, TA:) or ‡ he went upon the mfAzp: (A, TA:) or † he went away. (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) or ‡ he went away into the mfAzp: (A:) and faAza↓ signifies † he traversed the mfAzp. (Mṣb.) You say, fw-z biUibilihi (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ) ‡ He entered upon the mfAzp with his camels. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
Also † He went forth from one land or country to another: and tfw-z↓ signifies the same as fw-z. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part, in three places.
And, said of a road, It was, or became, apparent: (O, Ḳ:) and Ṣgh adds. [but not in the O,] and it stopped, or came to an end. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AfAzhu bikacaA He (God, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, or a man, Mṣb) caused him to attain, acquire, gain, or win, such a thing. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
5: see 2.
faAzN: see what next follows.

faAzapN A [tent such as is called] miZal-ap, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) with two poles, (Ḳ,) or that is extended with a pole: (Ṣ; in which is added, “it is in my opinion an Arabic word:”) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] faAzN↓. (ISd, TA.)

faAYizapN ‡ A thing that rejoices one, and by which one attains good or the object of his desire: you say, faAza bifaAYizapK ‡ He attained, acquired, gained, or won, a thing that rejoiced him,, &c. (A, O,* TA.)
mafaAzN: see the following paragraph, near the end.

hom.sense: mafaAzapN A place of safety, security, or escape. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur [iii. 185], falaA taHosiban-ahumo bimafaAzapK mina AlEacaAbi [Do thou by no means reckon them to be in a place of security from punishment]: (Ṣ, A,* O:) or, accord. to Fr, the meaning here is, far from punishment. (TA.)

A cause, or means, of prosperity, or success, or of the attainment or acquisition of that which one desires or seeks, or of what is good, or of that whereby one becomes in a happy or good state; syn. mafolaHapN. (A.)
‡ [The state of temporary safety which is between the present life and that which is to come. See 1, last signification.]

‡ A place of perdition, or destruction: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or i. q. falaApN: (A:) [i. e.] a desert; syn. bar-iy-apN; any [desert such as is called] qaforN: (TA:) or a desert in which is no water: (ISh, O, Ḳ:) and a desert in which is no water for the space of a journey of two nights or more: when there is none for the space of a journey of a night and a day, it is not thus called. (ISh, O, TA:) or a tract in which two wateringplaces are so far apart that camels are kept from drinking two days, with a portion of the day preceding them and of the day following them, [accord. to that which is generally preferred of the explanations of the term riboEN which is here employed,] and other animals [that journey quicker] drink on alternate days; as also falaApN: or such as is between that in which camels are kept from drinking two days, &c. as above, and that in which other animals drink on alternate days; as also fayofaApN: (TA:) so called to prognosticate good fortune, and safety. (Aṣ, IF, Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,) as meaning a place of safety, (A,) from faAza signifying “he became safe:” (Mṣb:) or from faw-aza, (IAạr, Ṣ, O,* Mṣb,) or faAza. (AḤei, TA.) signifying “he perished,” (IAạr, Ṣ, O,* AḤei,) or “he died:” (Mṣb, TA:) AḤei condemns the former of these assertions; but Az and ISd say that it is the more commonly approved, though the latter is the more agreeable with analogy: (TA:) or it is so called because he who comes forth from it, having traversed it, is safe: (IAạr, TA:) the pl. is mafaAwizu: (Ṣ:) and mafaAzN↓ signifies the same as mafaAzapN. so in a trad. of Kaab Ibn-Málik; faQsotaqobala safarFA baEiydFA wamafaAzFA [And he saw before him, or looked forward to, a far journey and a desert, or a waterless desert,, &c.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. AlmufaAwaSapu signifies The being clear, or perspicuous, syn. AlbayaAnu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) in talk or discourse (fiI AlHadiyvi). (Ṣ. [In the O, and Ḳ, mina AlHadiyvi; and hence it is said in the TḲ that faAwaSa AlHadiyva signifies bay-anahu He made the talk, or discourse, clear, or perspicuous: but for this I do not find any authority.]) Some say AlmufaAyaSapu. (IB, TA in art. fyS.) [See also 4 in art. fyS.]
4. maA OafaASa bikalimapi: see art. fyS. [It seems to be indicated in the Ṣ that this is from AlmufaAwaSapu, expl. above: and the like of this is app. said by IB.]

6. Alt-afaAwuSu signifies Alt-abaAyunu [The being, or becoming, separated, one from another]; from Albayonu, not from AlbayaAnu: (O, Ḳ:) originally Alt-afaAyuSu; mentioned also [in a different sense] in art. fyS. (TA.) See the latter art.

2. fw-D Uilayohi AlOamora, (Ṣ, M, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafowiyDN, (Mgh, O, Mṣb,) He committed to him the thing, affair, or case; syn. rad-a (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) or Say-ara, (M,) or sal-ama; (Mgh, Mṣb;) abstaining from contention, or litigation; (Mgh;) and made him arbiter thereof. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xl. 47], (TA,) waOufaw-iDu OamoriI UilaI Qll-eh (A, TA) And I commit my case unto God, making Him arbiter thereof. (TA.)

Alt-afowiyDu fiI Aln-ikaAHi, (Ṣ, O,) or nikaAHu Alt-afowiyDi, (TA,) is The giving [a woman] in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (Ṣ, O, TA.) You say, fw-D AlmaroOapi He gave the woman in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (Ḳ.) And faw-aDato buDoEahaA UilaI zawojihaA, (Mgh,) or faw-aDato nikaAHahaA UilaI Alz-awoji, (Mṣb,) She married herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or faw-aDato signifies She gave up, or renounced, the ordinance of the dowry. (Mṣb.)

3. mufaADapN signifies The being copartner, or copartners, in everything; (O, Ḳ;) [as though each of two persons, or every one of more than two, committed all that he had to the other, or others;] as also tafaAwuDN↓. (Ḳ.) [See 6.] Hence, (TA,) Xirokapu AlmufaAwaDapi Copartnership in everything; (Lth, M, Ṣ, A,* Mgh,* TA;) in which everything is common property; (Lth, M, TA;) opposed to Xirokapu AlEinaAni, which is copartnership in one thing: (Lth:) or copartnership of two persons in all that they possess: (Mṣb:) or copartnership of two persons in all that is in their hands, or that they may afterwards acquire; which is null and void accord. to Esh-Sháfiʼee, but allowable accord. to Aboo-Ḥaneefeh and his two companions [Aboo-Yoosuf and Moḥammad]. (TA.) You say, XaArakotuhu Xirokapa mufaAwaDapK I was copartner with him in all the property that we both together possessed. (Az, TA.) Hence also, (TA,) mufaAwaDapu AlEulamaMCi The conversing and conferring of the learned on matters of science; each of two persons receiving what the other had [to communicate], and giving what he himself had to the other; as though each committed what he had to his companion. (O,* TA.)
The commixing [in social intercourse]. (A.)
The being coequal. (A, O, Ḳ.)

The competing (mujaAraApN) in an affair. (Ḳ.) You say, faAwaDahu fiI Oamorihi, (Ṣ, O, TA,) or fiI kacaA, (Mgh,) He competed with him, (jaAraAhu, Ṣ, Mgh, O, TA, [for which Golius has read jAzAh, whence he has been led to assign to fAwD a wrong meaning, which Freytag has inadvertently copied,]) and did like as he did, (Mgh,) in his affair, (Ṣ, TA,) or in such an affair. (Mgh.) And faAwaDotuhu I competed with him; syn. jaArayotuhu: and kaAna bayonahumaA mufaAwaDapN [There was, between them two, competing]. (A.)
6: see 3. You say, tafaAwaDa AlX-ariykaAni fiI AlmaAli The two partners were sharers in the property altogether: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or tfAwD AlXrykAn signifies the two partners were coequal. (A, Mgh.)
[Hence, tfAwDwA They conversed and conferred together; every one receiving what the others had to communicate, and giving what he himself had to the others: see 3.]
[And They mixed together in social intercourse: see, again, 3.]
Also, tfAwDwA fiI AlOamori They competed (faAwaDa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA, [every one doing like as the others did,]) in the affair. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
fawoDapN a subst. from mufaAwaDapN (O, TA) [signifying, app., Copartnership:, &c.].

qawomN fawoDaI A party, or company, of men who are equals, having no chief: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or separated, or in a state of dispersion; (Lth, O, Ḳ;) fwDI being pl. of faAYiDN, which is not in use: (Lth, O:) or mixed, (Ṣ, O, M, Ḳ,) one with another; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) in which sense, also, fwDI is applied to a number of ostriches: (Ṣ, O:) or having no commander, nor any to collect them together: (M:) or mixed, and having no commander over them. (A.) You say, Aln-aAsu fawoDaI fiI hecaA The people are equals in this; there is no distinction to be made between them. (Mgh.) And jaMCa Alqawomu fawoDaI The party, or company, of men came mixed together. (Ṣ.) And AlwaHoXu fawoDaI The wild animals are in a state of separation, or dispersion, (O, TA,) going to and fro. (TA.) OamowaAluhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo Their possessions are property which they share among themselves; as also fayoDuwDaMCu and fayoDuwDaI. (Ṣ.) And mataAEuhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo, and fawoDaI faDFA, Their goods are common property among them. (M.) And AlmaAlu fawoDaI bayonahumo The property is promiscuous among them: whosoever desireth of them a thing taketh it. (Mṣb.) And kaAnato xayobaru fawoDaI Kheyber was promiscuous (Mgh) common property (Mgh, Mṣb) among the Companions; not divided. (Mṣb.)

Oamoruhumo fawoDaI, and fawoDaMCu↓, (M,) or fawoDaI bayonahumo, and fayoDaI, (TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous: or is equal among them: (Lḥ, M, TA:) or Oamoruhumo fawoDaI bayonahumo, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) or fawoDuwDaMCu↓ bayonahumo, (TA,) or both, (O, TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) every one of them making free use of that which belongs to another, (Ḳ,) one wearing the garment of another, and one eating the food of another, none of them consulting his companion respecting that which he does without his order. (AZ, O.) [See a similar phrase voce maXowarapN.]
fawoDaMCu: and see fwDI, last sentence.
fawoDuwDaMCu: see fwDI, last sentence.
tafowaADapN Remains of life: (O, TA:) so in the saying, raOayotu Alt-afowaADapa lifulaAnK (O) or bifulaAnK (TA) [I saw the remains of life pertaining to, or in, such a one].

mufaw-iDapN A woman who marries herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or who gives up, or renounces, the ordinance of the dowry: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to some, the word is mufaw-aDapN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) meaning married by her guardian without the naming of the dowry: (Mgh:) or meaning having the affair of the dowry committed to her by the law, so that she may make it obligatory or annul it: (Mṣb:) or meaning married without the mention of a dowry, or on the condition of her having no dowry. (KT.)
2. fw-Thu, inf. n. tafowiyTN, He clad him, or attired him, with a fuwTap. (TA.)

fuwTapN sing. of fuwaTN, which signifies Cloths that are brought from Es-Sind, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) thick, or coarse, and short, used as waistwrappers: (Lth, O, TA:) or striped waistwrappers: (Ḳ:) Az says, I have not heard this word in aught of the language of the Arabs, and I know not whether it be an Arabic word or of the language of the foreigners, but I have seen in El-Koofeh striped waist-wrappers, which are sold, and are bought by the camel-drivers and the Arabs of the desert and the servants and the people of the lowest sort, who use them as waist-wrappers, and call them thus; sing. fuwTapN: IDrd says that it is not an Arabic word: (O, TA:) it is added in the Ḳ, or it is a word of the language of Es-Sind: Ṣgh says, (TA,) fwTh is a word of the language of Es-Sind, arabicized, from Puwtah, with a ḍammeh not fully sounded: (O, TA:) [and SM adds,] it is called with us in El-Yemen, Oazohariy-ap: and by reason of frequency of usage, they have derived from it the verb above-mentioned. (TA.) The dim. of fuwTapN is fawayoTapN↓. (Ḥar p. 294.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see. ed., i. 195.]

It (the pl.) is also applied to Short napkins, with striped extremities, woven at El-Mahalleh El-Kubrà, in Egypt, which a man puts upon his knees to preserve himself therewith [from being soiled] at meals [and with which the hands are wiped after washing]. (TA.)
fuwTiI-N Blue, but not of a clear blueness. (TA.)
faw-aATN A weaver, or seller, of fuwaT, pl. of fuwTapN. (TA.)
mufaw-aTN A man clad, or attired, with a fuwTap. (TA.)
1. faAZa, aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN and fawaAZN: see faAZa in art. fyZ.

1. maA faAfa bixayorK, (T, M, O,) or maA faAfa Ean-iI bixayorK, (Ḳ.) walaA zanojara, (T, O, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwfu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. fawofN, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) [may be rendered He did not benefit, or he did not benefit me, with what might be taken between the nail of his thumb and that of his forefinger, nor did he with what might be taken by the inside of the nail of the thumb from the extremity of the fore tooth; i. e., with a thing inconceivably small; or with anything; being] a phrase meaning one's answering (T, M, O, Ḳ) a person who has asked for a thing (T, O, Ḳ) by putting his thumb-nail upon the nail of his fore finger, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) and by taking away the inner side of the nail [of the thumb] from the extremity of the fore tooth, (T, O,) and saying “Not [even] this [will I give thee],” (T, O, Ḳ,) or “Not [even] the like of this.” (M.)
fawofN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fuwfN The whiteness that is upon the nails of young persons; (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) as also fawofN↓; (T, M, Ḳ;) the latter mentioned by Fr, but not known by IAạr; (T;) or the former is the more common: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p↓; (M, Ḳ;) meaning a portion thereof. (M.)

And The integument [or pellicle] that is upon [what is termed] the core of the heart, and the stone of the date. (EalaI Hab-api Alqalobi waAln-awaApi,) beneath the flesh [or pulpy substance] of the date: (M, Ḳ:) of the white grain [i. e. the embryo, which resembles a white grain,] in the interior of the date stone, from which the palm-tree grows forth [or germinates]: and it is said that fuwfapN↓ signifies the integument [or pellicle] that is upon the date stone (Ṣ, O:) [i. e.] the thin integument that is upon the date-stone; also called the qiTomiyr. (T.)

[Hence, or from one of the significations mentioned above,] one says, maA OagonaI Ean-iI fuwfFA i. e. [He (a man, Ṣ, O) did not avail me] aught. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And maA caAqa fuwfaA [He tasted not] aught. (T, Ḳ.)
And fuwfN signifies also Any integument; (M, Ḳ;) and so fuwfapN↓. (Ḳ)
And The bladder of an animal of the bovine kind; as also fawofN↓: (Ḳ.) mentioned by Ṣgh in the TṢ. (TA.)

Also A sort of the [garments called] baruwd of El-Yemen: (M, Ḳ:) thin, variegated, or figured, garments of El-Yemen: (IAạr, T:) and one says also fuwfiI-N↓ burodN, and vuwviI-N, which is formed by substitution, and mentioned by Yaạḳoob, and burodu OafowaAfK meaning a burod having white stripes. (M.) and so burodN mufaw-afN↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) or this last and burodu OafowaAfK signify a thin burod; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner one says Hul-apu OafowaAfK. (TA.) OafowaAfN is pl. of fuwfN: (Ṣ, O:) and accord. to Lth, the OafowaAf are of the [buruwd called] EaSob [q. v.] of El-Yemen. (O.)
Also Flowers or blossoms, syn. zahorN: [in the CK zahar;] used in this sense by Ibn-Aḥmar; being likened by him to the garments called fuwf. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
And Portions of cotton: (O, Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ:) [perhaps meaning] a white thing [resembling cotton] which is in the EuXar [q. v.]. (Ḥam p. 784.)
[And Freytag mentions its signifying The extreme portion of the penis; as on the authority of the Ḳ: but he seems to have confounded fuwfN with fuwqN.]
fuwfapN the subst. denoted by the verb faAfa: (M, TA:) [as such,] it is coupled by a poet with zinojiyr [which is similar to it is meaning: see this last word]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
Also n. un. of fuwfN. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.) See this latter word, in three places.
burodN fuwfiI-N: see fuwfN, latter half.
burodN mufaw-afN: see fuwfN, latter half.

gurofapN mufaw-afapN, the mention of which occurs in a trad. of Kaab, means [An upper chamber] whereof one brick is of gold and another of silver [i. e. constructed of gold and silver bricks alternately]. (TA.)

Anfwfl, (Ḳ, [there said to be biAlDam-i waAlfatoHi, app. indicating that it is Alfuwfulu and Alfawofalu, but accord. to the CK and TḲ Alfuwfalu, and thus only, as though it were said to be baAlD-am-i faAlafotiH.]) or XajarapN Alfawofali, (thus written in the O, [in the TT, as from the M, Xjr Alfwfl, thus, without the affix p to the former word, and without any vowel sign,]) accord. to AḤn, (M,) or Aboo-Ziyád, (O,) A palm-tree, [the areca catechu, or betel-nut palm,] like the cocoa-nut palm, that bears racemes upon which are the fwfl, resembling dates, (M, O, Ḳ,) of which some are black and some are red, not of the growth of the land of the Arabs: (O:) [in one of my copies of the Ṣ, the fwofal (thus the word is there written) is said to be a tree like the cocoa-nut: in the other copy it is not mentioned:] the fwfl is said by AḤn to be the fruit of a certain palm-tree, hard as though it were wood: (M:) in the Tedhkireh of Dáwood it is said to be a fruit like the Syrian jawoz [or walnut], of an astringent quality, found upon trees resembling the cocoa-nut: (TA:) it is good for hot and gross humours, (Ḳ, TA,) prepared as aliniment; (TA;) and for inflammation of the eye, (Ḳ, TA,) as a dressing and collyrium; and has great efficacy for drying up the seminal fluid, and as a digestive. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faAqahumo, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) derived from fawoq as signifying the contr. of taHot, (Mgh.) aor. yafuwquhumo, (Ṣ, O.) inf. n. fawoqN (O, Ḳ) and fawaAqN (Ḳ) and fawoqaAnN, (CK.) He (a man, Ṣ, O, Mṣb) was, or became, above them, or superior to them, or he excelled them, or surpassed them, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, his companions, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or others, (Mgh) in eminence, or dignity, or nobility; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and he overcame them; (Mṣb, TA:) and did so in, or by, an argument or hthe like. (Mṣb.) And fuqotu fulaAnFA I became better than such a one, and higher, and more eminent or noble; as though above him in station. (TA.) And faAqati AljaAriyapu biAljamaAli [The young woman excelled in beauty or comeliness]. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., Hub-iba UilaI-a AljamaAlu Hat-aI maA OuHib-u Oano yafuwfaniI OaHadN biXiraAki naEolK [Comeliness has been made lovely to me so that I love not that any one should excel me in the though of a sandal] (TA.)

fAq, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwqu, (O,) inf. n. fuwaAqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) means that The wind rose from his chest; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [i. e. he hiccoughed, or hickuped; a signification indicated by its being said that] fuwaAqN means the reiterating of an overpowering [or involuntary] sobbing sound: (Mṣb, TA:) and fuwaAqN↓ [as a subst.] signifies also the wind [itself] that rises from the chest (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) of a man. (Ṣ, O)

And, accord. to Az, (Mṣb,) fAq, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. yafuwqu. (Mṣb,) inf. n. fuwaAqN (Mṣb, TA) and fuWuwqN, (TA.) He was affected, or taken with a panting, or breathing [shortly, or] uninterruptedly. (Mṣb, TA.)

And fAq binafosihi, (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwqN, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. fuwuwqN [or fuWuwqN] (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and fuwaAqN. (Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ.) His spirit was about to pass forth: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or he gave up his spirit. (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ:) as also fAq [alone] aor. yfyq (IAạr, O and Ḳ in art. fyq:) or he died. (Ḳ;) or fuwaAqN↓ [is app. held by some to be a simple subst., and] accord. to IAạr signifies death itself: (TA:) or it signifies, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or signifies also, (Ḳ.) an affection [i. e. a gasping, or show catching of the breath,] incident to a man at the point of death: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and one says [of the man], fAq, aor. yafuwqu, inf. n. fwq [app. fawaqN]; the verb being of the class of Talaba [of which the inf. n. most commonly used is Talaba; or, if the saying that the verb is of the class of Talaba be not meant to indicate the form of its inf. n. as well as that of its aor., fwq may be a mistranscription for fuWuwqN or fuWuwqN] (Mṣb.)

fAqt, (O, Ḳ,) aor. tafuwqu, inf. n. fuwaAqN, (TA.) She (a camel) had in her udder the fiyqap, or milk that had collected between two milkings. (O, Ḳ, TA;) and (Ḳ) so OafaAqato↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) or the latter verb signifies she (a camel) attained to the time for the being milked: and the inf. n. is UifaAqapN and [quasi-inf. n.] fuwaAqN↓: (IAạr, TA:) or UifaAqapN in relation to the she-camel means her being driven, or led, back from the pasturing, and left until she rests, and recovers [her milk]. (ISb, TA:) and UifaAqapN Ald-ir-api signifies the returning of the milk. (Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh, TA.) [See also fuwaAqN, below.]

fawoqN signifies A bending, or [thus in the TA is from the Ḳ, but in copies of the Ḳ “and,”] a breaking, (Ḳ, TA,) in the notch (fiI Alfawqi) (Ḳ,) or in one of the two cusps of the notch, (TA.) of an arrow: (Ḳ, TA:) or its verb said of an arrow, is fAq, aor. yafaAqu, inf. n. faAqN and fawoqN, in which the w is then made movent with fet-ḥ. [so that the word becomes fawqN,] because this verb is of the class of faEila, aor. yafoEalu: (Ḳ, TA.) or one says of an arrow fawiqa, [aor yafowaqu,] inf. n. fawaqN, meaning its notch broke: (Mṣb;) and AnfAq↓ said of an arrow signifies thus; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or its notch became much broken. (O, Ḳ, TA;) or became split, or cracked. (TA.)
And fuqotu Als-hom, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. fawoqN, (Mṣb,) I broke the notch of the arrow. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And fAq AlX-aIoCa, aor. yafuwqu, He broke the thing. (TA.)
fAq in the sense of AftAq [from faAqapN] is not allowable. (Ṣ, O.)
2. fw-qhu, inf. n. tafowiyqN, He made him, or judged him, to excel, or to have excelled. (TA.)

fw-q AlfaSiyla, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, said of the pastor, (TA,) He gave to the young unweaned camel to drink the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA. [See fuwaAqN.])

And [hence] one says, faw-aqaniI AlOamaAniI-a waOaroDaEaniI OafaAwiyqa↓ bir-ihi ‡ [He made me to obtain on repeated occasions the things wished for, and nourished me with the recurrent supplies of his bounty]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, Uin-a baniI Oumay-apa layufaw-iquwnaniI turaAva muHam-adK, meaning † [Verily the sons of Umeiyeh] give to me by little and little of the property [constituting the heritage of Moḥammad]. (TA.)
See also 10.
fw-q Als-ahoma, (inf. n. as above, Mṣb,) He made to the arrow a fuwq [i. e. notch for the bow-string]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] fw-q AlmaroOapa † He slit the vulva of the woman. (TA in art. sws.)
See also the next paragraph {4}, last sentence.

4. UifaAqapN, (O, Ḳ, TA,) some say, (O, TA,) signifies A resting; (O, Ḳ, TA;) from fuwaAqN↓ signifying a resting between two milkings; (O, TA;) which latter meaning, as well as the former, the Ḳ erroneously assigns to the former word. (TA.)
And OafaAqato said of a she-camel, signifies the same as faAqato expl. above: see 1, latter half, (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And [hence, perhaps,] AfAq mino maraDihi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and mino sukorihi, (Ṣ, O,) and mino gaXoyatihi, (O, TA,) inf. n. UifaAqahu; (TA;) and AstfAq↓; both signify the same; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) i. e. He returned to a healthy, or sound, state [of body and of mind, from his disease, and from his intoxication, and from his swoon, or fit of insensibility]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or one says of the diseased, AfAq and AstfAq↓ meaning he became convalescent; or recovered, but not completely, his health and strength: and the subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] is fuwaAqN↓: (TA:) and one says of the insane, or possessed, AfAq, inf. n. UifaAqapN, meaning he recovered his intel-ligence; and of the intoxicated, likewise, AfAq, originally AfAq mino sukorihi, like as one says AisotayoqaZa mino nawomihi: (Mṣb:) [and it is said that] AlAisotifaAqapu↓ as syn. with AlUifaAqapu is derived from fawoq meaning the contr. of taHot, like as taEal-aI mino maraDihi and tamaAvala are from AlEuluw-u and Almuvuwlu: (Ḥar p. 132:) but accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-ʼEesà, AstfAq↓ signifies he sought, or desired, AlUifaAqap. (Ḥam p. 541.)
And [hence,] AfAq Alz-amaAnu ‡ The time became abundant in herbage after barrenness or drought. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

Oafaqotu Als-ahoma, (inf. n. UifaAqapN, Mṣb,) I put the fuwq [or notch] of the arrow upon the bowstring, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) to shoot with it; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) as also Oawofaqotuhu: but Oafowaqotuhu is extr., (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and should not be said, (Ṣ, O,) or, accord. to Yoo, one says Oafowaqotuhu also: (O:) and, accord. to the A, fw-q↓ Als-ahoma signifies [in like manner] he put the bow-string into the notch of the arrow on the occasion of shooting. (TA.)
5. tfw-q EalaI qawomihi He exalted himself above his people, or party. (O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
tfw-q said of a young unweaned camel, He drank [or sucked] the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And tafaw-aqahaA He milked her, namely, a camel, drawing from her the quantities of milk that had collected in her udder time after time; (O, Ḳ;) as also AstfAqhA↓. (Ḳ. [But see this latter below.])

Hence the trad. respecting Aboo-Moosà, that he was discoursing with Ma'ádh, of reciting the Ḳur-án, and said, Oam-aA OanaA faOatafaw-aquhu tafaw-uqa All-aquwHi [As for me, I draw it forth in the manner of the drawing forth of the milk of the milch camel at the times when it has collected in her udder], meaning ‡ I do not recite my set portion at once, but piecemeal, in my night and my day. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

One says also tfw-q XaraAbahu i. e. ‡ He drank his wine, or beverage, part after part. (TA.) Sb has mentioned that yatajar-aEahu and yatafaw-aqahu are said of that which is not a labouring to do a thing at once, but is an act after an act, performed in a leisurely manner. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnfAq It (a thing) broke, or became broken; quasi-pass. of faAqa AlX-aIoCa meaning kasarahu. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end.
Said of a camel, He became lean, or emaciated:
and He perished, or died. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8. AftAq He was, or became, poor, or in want, or need: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) faAqa in this sense is not allowable. (Ṣ, O.)
And He died with much fuwaAq [which may here mean either hiccoughing (which often occurs at the close of a fatal fever, &c.), or gasping, or short catching of the breath]. (O, Ḳ.)
10: see 4, in four places.

AstfAqhA: see 5. [It signifies as there explained: or it signifies, or signifies also,] He delayed the milking her, namely, a camel, until her milk collected in her udder, or in order that it might collect; and so fw-qhA↓, inf. n. tafowiyqN. (TA.) One says, Aisotafiqi Aln-aAqapa Milk not thou the she-camel before the time. (O,* Ḳ.)

And maA yasotafiyqu mina AlX-araAbi He does not abstain [from drinking wine]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or he does not drink it in the set time: or he does not appoint a time for drinking it, but drinks it always. (TA.)
faAqN A [large bowl such as is termed] jafonap, filled with food. (Lth, T, O, Ḳ.)

And Cooked olive-oil. (O, Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying of Shemmákh, (O, TA,*) describing the hair of a woman, (TA,)
qaAmato turiyka Oaviyva Aln-aboti munosadilFA
mivola AlOasaAwidi qado mus-iHona biAlqaAfi
[She stood showing to thee hair abundant and luxuriant, or abundant and long, in respect of growth, let down, like the black serpents that have been anointed with cooked olive-oil]: or, as some say, meaning AlOanofaAq, meaning fresh olive-oil [from UinofaAq, a Pers. word signifying “olive-oil”]: or, as AA relates it, the poet said, qado Xud-ixona biAlfaAqi [that have been crushed in the fAq]; and accord. to him the last word has the meaning here next following. (O, TA.)
And The desert; syn. SaHoraMCu: (O, Ḳ, TA:) so says AA: and on one occasion he says that AlfAq means a certain land: (O: a meaning also mentioned in the Ḳ:) or a certain wide land. (TA.)
It is also expl. as signifying baAn [i. e. Oil of ben]: and also A comb: on the authority of Th: and it may have either of these meanings in the verse cited above. (TA.)

And accord. to the Ḳ, it signifies Tall, and incongruous in make; and so fuwqN↓ and fuwqapN↓ and fiyqN↓ and fuwaAqN↓ and fuyaAqN↓: but these words are all correctly, in this [or a similar] sense with two káfs. (TA.)
Also, accord. to the Ḳ, A certain aquatic bird, long in the neck: but this, likewise, is correctly with two káfs. (TA.)

entry.sense:
fawoq is the contr. of taHot; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;)[primarily signifying The location that is above, or over;] and is an adv. n. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of place; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and a simple noun, indecl., [with ḍammeh for its termination, when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed, and the meaning of this is intended to be understood, but not the word itself;] but when it is prefixed to another noun [which is either expressed or itself (and not merely its meaning) meant to be understood, and when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed and neither this nor its meaning is meant to be understood,] it is declinable. (Ḳ. [For the words yakuwnu QsomFA waZarofFA maboniI-N, the reading of the Ḳ in the TA and CK, my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ (which I follow in this case) has ykwn ZrfA wAsmA mbny-A.]) One says, zayodN fawoqa Als-aToHi [Zeyd is above, or rather upon, the house-top]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And AlEimaAmapu fawoqa Alr-aOosi [The turban is above, or upon, the head]. (Mgh.) And TafaA fawoqa AlmaMCi It floated upon the water. (Ṣ, &c. in art. Tfw.) Ks has mentioned the saying, Oafawoqa tanaAmu Oamo Oasofala [Dost thou, or wilt thou, sleep in the part that is above of the house, &c., or in the part that is below? i. e., in the upper part, or in the lower part?] with fet-ḥ, as suppressing the noun to which fwq is [meant to be understood as] prefixed. (TA.) Lth says that he who uses it as a Sifap [by which (like other old writers) he means an adv. n. of place] should use the accus. case, as when one says, Eabodu Qll-ehi fawoqa zayodK ['Abd-Allah is above Zeyd]: but if you make it simply a noun, you use the nom. case, and say, fawoquhu raOosuhu [His superior (meaning upper) part is his head]; for in this instance it is the head itself, and you make each to be governed in the nom. case by the other. (TA.)
In the saying in the Ḳur [xvi. 28], faxar-a Ealayohimu Qls-aqofu mino fawoqihimo [And the roof fell on them from above them], the utility of the phrase mn fwqhm is hardly apparent, because Elyhm sometimes serves in its stead: but IJ says that mn fwqhm may here have a useful office; for EalaI is sometimes used in relation to deeds [or events] that are difficult, and deemed onerous; [for instance,] you say, qado sironaA EaXorFA wabaqiyato EalayonaA layolataAni [We have journeyed ten nights and the journeys two nights have remained as though incumbent on us];, &c.; so that if it were said fxr- Elyhm Alsqf without the adding mn fwqhm, it might be supposed to be like the saying Ealayohimo daAruhumo qado xaribato [Their abode had become in a state of ruin as a punishment upon them]; but when He [referring to God] says mn fwqhm, that meaning which was supposable ceases to be so; and the meaning becomes this, that it [the roof] fell when they were beneath it. (TA.) Uico jaAWuwkumo mino fawoqikumo wamino Oasofala minokumo [When they came to you from above you and from below you], in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 10], relates to Benoo- Kureydhah, who came to them from above them; and to Kureysh and Ghatafán, who came from the district of Mekkeh, from below them. (TA.) waQl-aciyna Qt-aquwA fawoqahumo yawoma QloqiyaAmapi, in the Ḳur [ii. 208], means † [But those who have been careful of their religious duties] shall be above them in station [on the day of resurrection]. (O.) And one says, [agreeably with what has been stated in the first sentence of this paragraph, Oaxacahu mino fawoqu, and] Oaxacahu mino fawoqK, [meaning † He overcame him, or overpowered him, and in like manner OataAhu mn fwq, as expl. in the Ḥam p. 128., i. e. qaharahu,] namely, his adversary; and so a hawk, his pr? or quarry. (M and Ḳ in an expl. of Oadal-a Ealayoh, in art. dl.) And [in a similar manner] fawoq is metaphorically used as denoting excess, (Mgh, Mṣb.) and excellence: (Mṣb:) thus one says, AlEaXarapu fawoqa Alt-isoEapi (Mgh, Mṣb) i. e. ‡ Ten is above nine; meaning ten exceeds nine: (Mṣb:) and hecaA fawoqa caAka (Mgh, Mṣb) i. e. ‡ [This is above, or superior to, that;] meaning this is more excellent than that; (Mṣb:) and hence, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in the Ḳur [ii. 24], (Ṣ, O,) baEuwDapF famaA fawoqahaA i. e. ‡ [A gnat and] what exceeds it (Mgh, Mṣb) in smallness, or in largeness; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) what is smaller than it, (AO, Ṣ, O,) or what is larger than it, by the latter being meant the fly [mentioned in the Ḳur xxii. 72] and the spider [mentioned in xxix. 40], (Fr, Ṣ, O,) and the phrase as expl. in the former sense being like the reply to him who says “Such a one is small” celika wafawoqa i. e. † And smaller than that: (AO, O:) hence also, in the Ḳur [iv. 12], faUino kun-a nisaMCF fawoqa Qvonatayoni (Mgh, Mṣb) i. e. ‡ [And if they are women,] exceeding two. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: fuwqN The part, of the arrow, which is the place of the bow-string; [i. e. the notch thereof;] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also fuwqapN↓: (Mṣb, Ḳ;) the former is masc., and also, like the latter, fem. (IAmb, Mṣb:) and AlfuwqaAni signifies the zanamataAni [or two cusps of the fuwq, between which is put the bow string]; (O, Ḳ;) thus these are termed by the tribe of Hudheyl; but a poet who has used the dual form is said by AO to has mead thereby a single fuwq: (O:) the pl. [of mult.] is fuwaqN and [of pauc.] OafowaAqN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, accord. to ISk, these are pls. of fuwqapN; (TA;) and qufFA also is a pl., formed by transposition; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce EuroquwbN;] (Ḳ, TA;) one says fuqowapN and fuqFA [for fuwqapN and fuwaqN]. (TA.) sahomN cuw fuwqK means An arrow rendered complete by its having a fuwq:

and hence caA fuwqK occurring in a trad. [as meaning † A complete share; for sahomN signifies “a share” as well as “an arrow”]. (AʼObeyd, O.) And OaEolaAhumo fuwqFA, meaning ‡ He, or they, of them, haring the largest share of religion, is a metaphorical phrase, from the fuwq of the arrow. (TA.)

And they say, Oaqobilo EalaI fuwqi nabolika, [or, app., fuwaqi nabolika, for nabolN is a coll. n., meaning “arrows,” or “Arabian arrows,”] meaning † Betake thyself to thy affair, and that which concerns thee. (TA.)
And ramayonaA fuwqFA, (O, Ḳ,) or fuwqFA waAHidFA, (TA,) meaning riXoqFA [i. e. ‡ We shot in one direction; or we shot one bout, in one direction], (O, Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] one says, kAn fulaAnN liOaw-ali fuwqi, meaning ‡ Such a one was [for the first discharge from the bow, i. e.,] the first shot and dying. (A, TA.)

And [hence, perhaps.] fuwqN signifies also ‡ A mode, or manner, of speech: (A, O, Ḳ:) pl. fuwaqN. (TA) One says to a man when he enters upon a mode, or manner, of speech, xaco fiI fuwqi OaHosana minohu ‡ [Enter upon a mode, or manner, of speech better than it]. (A, TA.)
And ‡ The first way (AA, O Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence. app.,] they say, AirojaEo Uino XiYota fiI fuwqK ‡ Return thou if thou wilt, to state of close, or loving, communion in which we were. (Ibn-’Abbád, Z,O, TA.)

And the Arabs say, in imprececating, laA rajaEa fulaAno UilaI fuwqihi i. e. † May such a one die: so says AA; and he cites the following verse of El-’Uleykim El-Kindee,
maA baAlu EirosiI Xariqato biriyqihaA
wum-ata laA yarojiEo lahaA mino fuwqihaA
meaning † [What is the case of my wife that she is choked by her spittle? Then, or afterward,] may it (her spittle) not return to its channel [i. e. her throat, the way whence it came; so that she may be suffocated]. (O.)
And one says (O, Ḳ) of a man when he has gone away, (O,) maA Qrotad-a EalaI fuwqihi, meaning † He went away and he did not return [to the place whence he departed] (O, Ḳ)

fuwqN also signifies, (O, Ḳ.) accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, (O, TA.) † The vulva of a woman: (O, Ḳ. TA:) but Aṣ says that this is with q [in the place of the f]: (TA:) [it is, however, also said that] fuwqu Alr-aHimi signifies ‡ the rima of the vulva, by way of comparison [to the notch of the arrow]. (TA, in the supplement to this art.)
[And app. † The front edge of the lobe of the ear: see 1 in art Hrm, when it is mentioned in such a manner as seems to preclude its being a mistranscription for qawf]

And (as Ibn-ʼAbbád says, O) † The place of opening (maforaj, O, TA, in the Ḳ, erroneously, maxoraj, TA, and jawobap, O, Ḳ, TA) of the mouth: or (as some say, O) the extremity of the tongue. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And † The uppermost part of the penis, (En-Naḍr, O, Ḳ, TA,) or of the glans thereof. (TA.)
And, accord. to the Ḳ, A certain bird; mean ing a certain aquatic bird: but this is correctly [quwqN,] with two káfs. (TA.)
See also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fiyqN [originally fiwoqN]: see fiyqapN.
Also, as mentioned in this art and in art. fyq, in the Ḳ: see faAqN, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: fayaqN and fiyaqN: see mufiyqN.
faAqapN Poverty, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) want, or need. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, huwa cuw faAqapK He is one who is in [poverty or] want or need. (Mṣb.) [See 8.] It has no [unaugmented] verb. (TA.)

hom.sense: fuwqapN: see fuwqN, first sentence.
And see also faAqN, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: fawaqapN: see faAYiqN [of which, as a part. n., it is a pl.].
fayoqapN: see what next follows.

fiyqapN, (Ṣ, O, &c.,) originally fiwoqapN, (TA,) the w having become I because of the kesreh before it, (Ṣ, O, TA,) The milk that collects (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) in the udder (Ḳ) between two milkings: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and srAj [or this is a mistake for Aibon Als-ar-aAj] has mentioned fayoqapN↓ Aln-aAqapi, with fet-ḥ: but ISd says, “I know not how that is:” (TA:) pl. fiyqN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. and faAqapN is its n. un.,] and fiyqN (IB. Ḳ) and fyqaAtN (Ḳ.) and OafowaAqN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) or this may be pl. of the pl. fiyaqN. (IB. TA.) and OafaAwiyqa, (Ṣ. O, Ḳ,) which is a pi pl. (O, Ḳ) [or pl of OafowaAqN]. [See also EuraAkapN.]
See also above, conj. 2, an ex. of OafaAwiyq in a tropical sense.
OafaAwiyqu also signifies ‡ The water that has collected in the clouds and then falls in rain. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) time after time. (Ṣ, Ḳ. TA.)

Also, i. e. OafaAwiyqu, ‡ The greater part of the night: (Lḥ, O, Ḳ, TA) so in the saying, xarajnaA baEoda OafaAwiyqa mina All-ayoli [We went forth] after the greater part of the night had passed: (Lḥ, O:) or, accord. to Th, after pertions (OaqoTaAE) of the night. (TA.)
fiyqapu AlS-uHaI means ‡ The period of the [early portion of the forenoon called the] DHI when the sun has become high: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Z, the first part of the DHI. (TA.)

fawoqaAniI-N [Of, or relating to, the location that is above, or over; superior; upper;] rel. n. of fawoq, like as taHotaAniI-N is of taHot: A and n being very often added in the rel. n. (TA. in art. tHt.)

And [hence, but more commonly fawoqaAniy-apN,] A garment worn by a man over that which is next the body; [an upper-coat; generally long, reaching to the heels, ample in width, and with long sleeves: it seems to have been formerly peculiar to men of the learned professions:] of the dial, of Mekkeh: posts-classical. (TA [See Dozy's Dict. des Noms des Vétements chez les Arabes p. 343.])
fawaAqN The returning supply of milk after sucking or milking. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in three places.

hom.sense: fuwaAqN: see 1, former half, in two places:
and see 1 again, latter half:
and 4, in two places.

Also ‡ The time between two milkings; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) for the she-camel was milked, and then left a little while for her young one to suck her in order that she might yield her milk copiously, after which she was milked again; (Ṣ, O;) and likewise the time between two suckings; (Ksh in xxxviii. 14;) and fawaAqN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, (Mṣb, TA,) accord. to IF, (Mṣb,) the fwAq of the she-camel is the retuning of the milk into the udder after the milking: (Mṣb, TA:) or fuwaAqN signifies the time between the opening of one's hand and the grasping with it the udder (Ḳ, TA) of the camel: or when the milker grasps the udder and then lets it go, in milking: (TA:) the pl. is OafowiqapN and MfiqapN; (O, Ḳ;) and Fr says that fwAq has for its pl. OafiyqapN, originally OafowiqapN, the kesreh of the w being transferred to the f, and the w being then changed into I because of the kesreh before it; and OafowiqapN has for its pl. OafowiqaAtN. (TA.) One says, maA OaqaAma Einodahu Uil-aA fuwaAqFA ‡ [He did not remain at his abode save as long as the time between two milkings]. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlEiyaAdapu qadoru fuwaAqi Aln-aAqapi † [The period of the visiting of a sick person is the space of time between the two milkings of the she-camel]. (Ṣ.) And in a trad. of ʼAlee occurs the saying, qaAla lahu AlOasiyru OanoZironiI fuwaAqa naAqapK i. e. † [The captive said to him,] Grant thou me a delay, or respite, as long as the time between two milkings [of a she-camel]. (TA.) maA lahaA mino fawaAqK↓ and fuwaAqK in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 14], accord. to different readings, (Ṣ,) the latter the reading of the Koofees except 'Ásim, and the former that of the rest, (O,) means † [There shall not appertain to it] any postponement, or delay, and resting: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to AO, the latter is the meaning of the former reading; and the latter reading means, any waiting, or expecting: (TA:) or [both mean] any pausing as much as the time between two milkings, (Ksh, Bḍ,) or two suckings: (Ksh:) or any returning, and repeating; (I’Ab, Ksh, Bḍ;) from OafaAqa “he (a sick man) returned to a healthy, or sound, state”; and the fwAq of the she-camel, when the supply of milk returns to her udder; (Ksh;) or because in it [i. e. the fwAq] the milk returns to the udder; (Bḍ;) i. e. the blast [to which the words refer] shall be one only; it shall not be repeated. (Ksh.) The saying (Mgh, O, TA) of the Prophet, (O,) related in a trad., (O, TA,) qasama ganaAYima xayobara Eano fuwaAqK, (Mgh,) or qasama AlganaAYima yawoma badorK Eano fawaAqK↓ (O, TA) and fuwaAqK, (TA,) means † He divided the spoils [of Kheyber, or on the day of Bedr,] in the space of the rest between two milkings of a she-camel: (TA:) or quickly; (Mgh, O;) En fwAq meaning SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK [i. e. qasomFA SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK with a dividing proceeding from quickness]: (Mgh, O:*) or, as some say, the meaning is, making some of them [i. e. of those who composed his army] to be more highly distinguished (Oafowaq↓) than others (O, TA *) in the proportion of their spoils and of the trial undergone by them. (TA.)
See also faAqN, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: fuyaAqN, mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see faAqN, last sentence but one.

hom.sense: faAYiqN Superior, excellent, or surpassing: (Mgh, Mṣb:*) anything excellent, or choice, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and pure, in its kind. (TA.) You say, huwa faAYiqN fiI AlEilomi [He is superior, excellent, or surpassing, in knowledge], and fiI AlfinaI [in wealth,, &c.]. (Mgh.) And jaAriyapN faAYiqapN [A young woman excelling in beauty, or comeliness]. (Mṣb.) And fawaqapN [an irreg. pl. of faAYiqN, like as xawanapN is of xaAYinN, for by rule these pls. should be faAqapN and xaAnapN,] signifies Elegant scholars, and orators. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
Also The place of junction of the neck with the head: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) therefore when this is high, the neck is long. (Ṣ, O.)
Oafowaqu: see fuwaAqN, last sentence but one.

Also An arrow of which the fuwq [or notch] is broken: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) [and] an arrow having no fuwq: (L voce Oaqac-u:) pl. fuwaqN [perhaps a mistranscription for the regular form of pl., i. e. fuwoqN; or it may be that the w is with fet-ḥ to distinguish it from fuwqN signifying “a notch” of an arrow]: but IAạr explains this as signifying arrows of which the heads have fallen. (TA.) One says, rajaEa fulaAnN biOafowaqa naASalK † Such a one returned with an arrow having a broken notch and without a head upon it; meaning, with an incomplete share of good fortune: (Ṣ, O:) or, disappointed of attaining what he desired, or sought: a proverb. (TA.) And radadotuhu biOafowaqa naASilK † [I turned him back, or away, with a paltry benefit; or] I made his share of good fortune to be little, or incomplete. (TA.) And maA balilotu mino fulaAnK biOafowaqa naASilK, expl. in the first paragraph {1} of art. bl.

maHaAlapN fawoqaMCu [A large sheave of a pulley] of which every sin- [or tooth, perhaps meaning cog, though I do not remember to have met with any description of a cogged mHAlp,] has two cusps (fuwqaAni), (O, Ḳ,) like the fwqAn [of the notch] of the arrow. (O.) [The strangeness of this explanation induces me to think that fawoqaMCu is here a mistranscription for fawohaMCu, (see maHaAlapN fawohaMCu, in art. fwh,) and that the explanation is partly conjectural.]
And kamarapN fawoqaMCu A glans of a penis whereof the extremity is tapering in form, (O, Ḳ,) like that which is termed HawoqaMCu. (O.)

mufiyqN and mufiyqapN A she-camel having in her udder the milk that had collected between two milkings: (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) pl. mafaAwiyqu (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and mafaAwiqu, (Akh, TA,) and fuyuqN↓ also is pl. of mufiyqN signifying as expl. above, mentioned by AA in the third vol. of his “Nawádir,” and said by IB to be, accord. to analogy, pl. of fuwuwqN, and to be originally fuwuqN; but accord. to one relation of a verse in which it occurs, it is fiyaq↓, which is more agreeable with analogy. (TA.)
And the former, applied to a poet, is syn. with mufoliqN [i. e. One who poetizes admirably, or wonderfully.]. (Aboo-Turáb, Ḳ. [But its verb is mentioned in the O and Ḳ in art. fyq.])
mufaw-aqN ‡ Food, and beverage, that is taken by little and little. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA. [See its verb.])
Applied to an arrow, [Having a notch made for the bow-string. (See 2.)]
[And] Having the bow-string put into its notch on the occasion of shooting: [see 4, last sentence:]

whence the saying, laA zilota Alxayori muwaf-aqFA wasahomuka fiI Alkarami mufaw-aqFA † [Mayest thou not cease to be rightly disposed in beneficence, and thine arrow made ready with the bow-string put into its notch in generosity]. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: musotafiyqN A man who sleeps much: (O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by IAạr; but this is strange.

fuwlN [Beans; or the bean; faba sativa of Jussieu; vicia faba of Linnæus; i. e.] i. q. baAqil-FI [q. v.]: (T, IF, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or i. q. Him-aS [i. e. chick-peas; or the chick-pea]: (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ: [in most of the copies of the Ṣ, this word is mentioned at the end of art. fyl; but in the older of my copies, before that art.:]) or a certain grain, or seed, (Hab-,) like the Him-aS: but with the people of Syria [and of Egypt], i. q. baAqil-FI: or (as some say, M) specially the dry [thereof]: n. un. with p {fuwlapN}: (M, Ḳ:) mentioned by Sb. (M.)
faw-aAlN A seller of fuwl. (TA.)
fuwlaAcN: see art. flc.
2. faw-amotu Alxuboza I made bread, or the bread. (IJ, M.) [And] faw-imuwA lanaA Make ye bread for us: (T, Ṣ:) a phrase said by Fr to have been heard from the Arabs as meaning thus. (T.)

fuwmN, a word occurring in the Ḳur ii. 58, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) is expl. as signifying the same as vuwmN [which generally means Garlic; but is said to have also the meaning here next following]; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said to be a dial. var. of the latter word, but app. [if meaning “garlic”] formed, as IJ says, by the substitution of f for v; (M;) and ʼAbd-Allah [Ibn-Mesʼood] read [in the Ḳur ubi suprà] wavuwmihaA [instead of wafuwmihaA]: (Fr, T, Ṣ:) it is also expl. as signifying wheat; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which is said by Lḥ to be a meaning of vuwm and fuwm; and if Ibn-Mesʼood read the word as vwm, the meaning is fwm, i. e. “wheat;” (T;) accord. to Fr, it is an old word, signifying thus, (T, Ṣ,*) and also bread; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;)
Zj says that there is no difference of statement among the lexicologists as to its having the former of these two meanings, that it is said to have the latter also, and that it also signifies the other grains, beside wheat, whereof bread is made [which last meaning is also mentioned in the Ḳ]; (T;) and IJ holds that it is rightly expl. as having the first of these three meanings (i. e. “wheat”) and the last of them: (M:) another meaning assigned to it is Him-aSN [i. e. cicer arietinum; or chick-peas]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is of the dial. of Syria: (Ṣ:) and it signifies also any Euqodap [app. meaning head of a plant, such as that] of an onion, or of a garlic: or a great gobbet of food: (Ḳ: [for Oawo luqomapK EaZiymapK in the CK, I read Aw luqomapN EaZiymapN as in other copies of the Ḳ:]) in the dial. of Azd-es-Saráh, it is applied to ears of corn; and fuwmapN↓ is its n. un.; (M;) this latter signifying an ear of corn, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) as expl. by IDrd: (TA:) fuwmN has fuwmaAnN [of the measure fuEolanaAnN] for a pl., this being [virtually] a pl. pl.; mentioned by IJ, who says that the ḍammeh in fuwmN is different from the ḍammeh in fuwmaAnN. (M, TA.)
fuwmapN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.
Also A thing that one carries between his two fingers. (Ḳ.)
qaTaEuwA AlX-aApa fuwamFA fuwamFA (M, Ḳ,*) means [They cut the sheep, or goat,] into a number of pieces; (M;) like fuWamFA. (Ḳ.)

faAmiI-N, altered from fuwmiI-N, A seller of fuwm [app. in any of its senses, but accord. to the TA as meaning wheat, or chick-peas]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or] a seller of fruit: (MA:) accord. to Az, (TA,) AlfaAmiI-u means Als-uk-ariI-u, (Mgh, TA,) who is called by the vulgar Albay-aAEu [generally signifying the seller, or vender; perhaps here meaning the seller of sugar, though I do not anywhere find Als-uk-ariI-u thus explained]; (Mgh;) but he says, “I do not think it genuine Arabic.” (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faAha bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yafuwhu (Ṣ, Mṣb) and yafiyhu also, (ISd, TA,) inf. n. fawohN, (MA,) [and inf. n. of unity fawohapN, (see Ḥar p. 434,)] He uttered it, or pronounced it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, a saying; (Ṣ;) as also tfw-h↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, maA fuhotu bikalimapK, and mA tafaw-ahotu↓, i. e. I opened not my mouth with a word, or sentence. (Ṣ.) faAha lisaAnN, a phrase used by El-Ḥareeree, the Arabs did not say: they only said, fAh Alr-ajulu bikacaA [The man opened his mouth with such a thing, i. e., with such a saying, &c.]. (Ḥar p. 191.) And hecaA OamorN maA fuhotu Eanohu, inf. n. fuwuwhN [or fuWuwhN], is a saying mentioned by Fr, as meaning This is a thing, or an affair, which I mentioned not, or have not mentioned. (TA.)
See also 2.

fawiha, aor. yafowahu, [inf. n. fawahN,] He (a man) had what is termed fawahN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) which means width of the mouth, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and largeness thereof: (TA:) or protrusion and length of the upper central incisors: (Ṣ, TA:) or length of all the teeth; length of the upper central incisors being termed rawaqN: (IB, TA:) or protrusion of the teeth from the lips, with length thereof. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. fw-hhu He (i. e. God) made him to be Oafowah [or wide in the mouth,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Xad-a maA faw-ahota fiI hecaA AlT-aEaAmi, [thus accord. to the TA, but an explanation of mufaw-ahN seems to show that the right reading is fuw-ihota, in the pass. form,] and tafaw-ahota↓, and fuhota↓, means Xad-a maA Oakalota [app. Much indeed, or greatly indeed, didst thou eat, or hast thou eaten, of this food; see Xad-a: and see also 10]. (TA.)

3. fAwhhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. mufaAwahapN; (TA;) and faAhaAhu, [formed from the former by transposition,] (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. mufaAhaApN; (TA;) He talked, or discoursed, with him: [see also 6:] and he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tfw-h He spoke. (KL.) See also 1, first and second sentences.
And see 2.
tfw-h AlmakaAna † He entered the fuw-ahap of the place; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., the mouth thereof; likened to the fam [properly thus called] as being the first place of ingress to the interior thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tfAwhwA They talked [app. one to another: see 3]. (Ḳ.)

10. AstfAh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AisotifaAhapN and AisotifaAhN, (Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by Lḥ, (TA,) He (a man, Ṣ) ate, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or drank, (Ḳ,) vehemently, after scantiness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or after weakness; (so in a copy of the Ṣ;) but seldom used in relation to drinking: or you say, AstfAh fiI AlT-aEaAmi, meaning he ate much of the food: so says IAạr, not particularizing the act as being after scarcity or not. (TA.) [See also 2.]
And He quenched his thirst by drinking. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: faAhN: see what next follows: and see the next paragraph again, in the latter half:
and the same word, and faAhK, (the latter in two places,) see voce faAwuwhapN.

fuwhN and faAhN↓ and fiyhN↓ (Ḳ, TA) and, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, fuwhapN, [or, as in the CK, fawohap,] but correctly fuw-ahapN↓, (TA,) and famN, all signify the same [i. e. The mouth]: (Ḳ, TA:) the pl. is OafowaAhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) pl. of fuwhN, (Ṣ, TA,) and as such its case is plain; as pl. of fiyhN, it is like OarowaAHN as pl. of riyHN; as pl of faAhN, it is allowable as having w for its original medial radical; but as pl. of fuw-ahapN, it is anomalous: (TA:) and another pl. is OafomaAmN, (Ḳ, TA,) said by some to be pl. of fum-N or fam-N, with teshdeed, of which an ex. occurs in a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. fm; but some disallow this pl.; and accord. to some, (TA,) it has no sing. (Ḳ, TA) agreeable with rule, (TA,) for famN is originally fawahN, (Ḳ, TA,) with the w movent by fet-ḥ, or [fawohN, as in some copies of the Ṣ,] with the w quiescent, on the authority of IJ; (TA;) the h is elided, and the w becomes a movent final, therefore it must be changed into A, because of the fet-ḥah preceding it, so the word becomes fA; but a noun may not be of two letters whereof one is [the n of] the tenween, (Ḳ, TA,) thus the passage is expressed in the M, but MF remarks that correctly we should say whereof one is the A, (TA,) and therefore a hard letter is substituted for it, one similar to it in kind, which is m, for they are both labials, and in the m is a sort of humming sound (hawiI-N, in the CK huwiI-N,) in the mouth, [or rather in the nose,] resembling [the sound of] the prolongation of the w: (Ḳ, TA:) [several similar disquisitions, added in the TA, respecting the change from fwh to fm, I omit, regarding them as needless: what is said on this subject in the Ṣ, in art. fm, I have mentioned in that art.:] in the present art., J says that the m of fm is a substitute for the h, not for the w, of fwh; but this is a mistake: (IB, TA:) the dual of famN is famaAni and famawaAni (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and famayaAni, the second and third of which are anomalous: (IAạr, Ḳ:) of the second, which occurs in a verse of El-Farezdaḳ, [and respecting which see the first paragraph {1} of art. fm,] Sb says that it is used by poetic license. (TA.) In using it as a prefixed noun, in the phrase hecaA fuwhuhu, they deemed the combination of the two h s difficult in respect of utterance; therefore they suppressed the [radical] h thereof [in this case, and then in other, similar, cases], and said, hecaA fuwhu, and fuw zayodK, and raOayotu faA zayodK, and mararotu bifiI zayodK: and when prefixing it to [the pronoun denoting] thyself, thou sayest, hecaA fiI-a; and this thou dost alike in using it in the nom. case and in the accus. and in the gen., because the w [of fuw] is changed into I and is then incorporated [into the pronominal I]: (Ṣ, and the like is said in the Mṣb:) and sometimes, though rarely, they did the like in other cases, when not prefixing it; for instance, faA occurs at the end of a verse of El-ʼAjjáj, without an affix, in this case for faAhaA. (Ṣ.)

In the saying kal-amotuhu faAhu UilaI fiI-a, meaning I spoke to him, his mouth being near to my mouth, fAh is in the accus. case as a denotative of state: (Ṣ, TA:*) or by reason of the derivative [mukal-imFA] meant to be understood: or, as Sb says, it is an instance of one of the nouns that are put in the place of inf. ns., and it is not to be separated from what should follow it, so that you may not say kal-amotuhu faAha [alone], for you tell of your nearness to the person, and that there is not any one between you and him: and if you will, you may use the nom. case, meaning wahecihi HaAluhu [this being his state], (Sb, TA,) i. e. fuwhu UilaI fiI-a [his mouth was near to my mouth], the clause [following kl-mth] occupying the place of a denotative of state. (TA.)

The saying faAhaA lifiyka, (Meyd, Ḳ, TA,) which is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) means May God make the mouth of misfortune to cleave to thy mouth; (Meyd, Ḳ,* TA;) [but lit. signifies, only, her, or its, mouth to thy mouth;] and is [likewise] an instance of one of the nouns that are used in the manner of inf. ns. expressive of imprecation, by reason of a verb not mentioned:
Sb says, fAhA is without tenween, meaning faA Ald-aAhiyapi, as is shown by the saying,
wadaAhiyapK mino dawaAhiI Almanuw
ni yarohabuhaA Aln-aAsu laA faA lahaA
[Many a misfortune is there, of the misfortunes of time, which men fear, that has no mouth, wherewith to bite]: (Sb, TA:) AʼObeyd says that its primary meaning is, may God make the ground to be in thy mouth; that it is like the sayings bifiyka AlHajaru and bifiyka AlOavolabu; (Ṣ, Meyd;) and [hence] it means disappointment [cleave] to thee: (Ṣ,* Meyd:) a man of Belhujeym, (Ṣ, Meyd,) cited by AʼObeyd, (Ṣ,) addressing a wolf that sought to get his she-camel, (Meyd,) says,
faqulotu lahu faAhaA lifiyka faUin-ahaA
qaluwSu QmoriYK qaAriyka maA Oanota HaAciruhu
[And I said to him, fAhA lfyk, for she is the youthful she-camel of a man who will give thee as a guest's entertainment that which thou fearest]; (Ṣ, Meyd; but in the Ṣ, as IB has observed, faUin-ahu is erroneously put for faUin-ahaA;) i. e. [who will entertain thee with] the shooting of arrows; (Meyd;) [by qaAriyka] he means yaqoriyka, from qiraI AlD-ayofi: (Ṣ:) it is also said that faAhaA is metonymically used as meaning the dust of the earth, which is termed the mouth of the earth because it drinks the water; and it is as though the saying meant the dust be in thy mouth: (Meyd:) Sh is related to have said, I heard IAạr say faAhFA↓ lifiyka, with tenween, meaning may God make thy mouth to cleave to the ground; [or rather, ground to thy mouth; lit., simply, a mouth to thy mouth;] and some say faAhaA lifiyka, without tenween, as an imprecation meaning † may God break thy fam [i. e. thy teeth, to which fam is often metonymically applied, as is also fuwh]. (TA.)

One says also, saqaI fulaAnN Uibilahu EalaI OafowaAhihaA, meaning ‡ Such a one drew for his camels the water when they came to it, while they were drinking; not having stored it for them in the drinking-trough: and jar-a fulaAnN Uibilahu EalaI OafowaAhihaA ‡ Such a one suffered his camels to pasture while going along [by his driving them gently: see art. jr]: so says Aṣ: and so accord. to the A and other lexicons; but the author of the Ḳ, by an omission, has assigned the latter explanation to the former phrase. (TA.)
lawo wajadotu Uilayohi faA kariXK, meaning OadonaI TariyqK, (Ḳ, TA,) has [with other, similar, phrases] been explained in art. krX [q. v.]. (TA.)

fuw farasK HamirK [Mouth of a horse that is suffering indigestion in consequence of his having eaten barley and so made it to stink] is an appellation applied to him who has stinking breath. (TA. [An ex. of it occurs in a verse of Imra-el-keys cited in the TA in art. Hmr as in Ahlwardt's “Divans of the Six Ancient Arabic Poets,” p. 125; and differently in De Slane's “Diwan d'Amro-'kaïs,” p. 36 of the Arabic text.])

And fuw juradK [Mouth of a large fieldrat] and fuw dabFA [Mouth of a sort of small wingless locust, or perhaps correctly fuw dabaApK mouth of a small wingless locust,] are nicknames applied to a little man. (TA.)
One says also, laA fuD-u fuwhu, meaning ‡ May his teeth, or front teeth, not be broken. (Ḳ,* TA.) And saqaTa fuwhu † His teeth fell out. (TA in art. fD [q. v.])

And maAta lifiyhi i. e. liwajohihi [meaning ‡ He died upon his face; prone: like saqaTa liwajohihi † He fell upon his face: the l in both being used in the sense of EalaI; as it is in the phrase xar-uwA liOacoqaAnihimo (expl. in art. xr), &c.]. (A, Ḳ, TA. [The explanation in the TḲ, being somewhat ambiguous (though correct), has misled Freytag in this case.]) And [in like manner, using li in the sense of ElI,] kb-ahu Qll-ehu lifiyhi, one of their forms of imprecation, meaning † May God cause him to die: or prostrate him [upon his face; as also kab-ahu liwajohihi]. (TA.)
[See also fuw-ahapN as syn. with fuwhN; like which it has OafowaAhN for a pl.]

fuwhN also, having for its pl. OafowaAhN, and pl. pl. OafaAwiyhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [which last is of very frequent occurrence,] signifies Perfume, or an odoriferous substance: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a thing, or substance, with which a perfume, or an odoriferous substance, is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju); like as tawaAbilu signifies things, or substances, with which sorts of food are compounded or prepared: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or the tawaAbil [or seeds used in cooking] with which food is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju) are also called OafowaAhu AlT-iybi: (Mṣb:) [the pl. and pl. pl. are now generally applied to spices, or aromatics:] or AlOafowaAhu, the pl. mentioned above, signifies [the seeds called] Alt-awaAbilu: and also what diffuse fragrance [I read nawaAfiHu, as in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, pl. of naAfiHN, q. v., instead of nawaAfiju (with jiym), the only reading that I find in other copies of the Ḳ, regarding the latter as indubitably a mistranscription,] of perfumes, or odoriferous substances: (Ḳ:) and the sorts, or species, of flowers; (Ḳ, TA;) thus says AḤn; and in one place he says that AlAfwAH signifies what are prepared for perfume, of sweetsmelling flowers; and sometimes they are of herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) and also sorts, or species, of a thing [app. of any kind]: (Ḳ:) and one says, huwa mino OafowaAhi AlTyb, and OafowaAhi Albuquwli, meaning It is of the sorts, or species, and of the mixtures, or compounds, of perfume, and of herbs, or leguminous plants: (Mgh:) but fuwhN is not applied to anything that is termed Eaq-aArN. (AHeyth, TA in art. Eqr.)

entry.sense: fawahN: see 1, last sentence.
Also The quality of a maHaAlap [or large sheave of a pulley] such as is termed fawohaMC, fem. of Oafowahu, q. v. (TA.)
fiyhi: see its syn. fuwhN.
fuwhapN: see fuw-ahapN, in five places.

hom.sense: fuw-ahN Certain slender, long, red roots, with which one dyes; beneficial for the liver and the spleen and the nasaA [app. as meaning sciatica or the sciatic nerve] and pain of the hip and of the flank, powerfully diuretic, and kneaded with vinegar and applied as a liniment it cures the [leprosy termed] baraS: (Ḳ, TA:) but the word was not known to Az in this sense, [which is the only meaning, except one which I think doubtful, that I find assigned to it;] and it is said to be the fuw-ap [which see in art. fw, i. e. madder]. (TA.)
See also fuw-ahapN.

entry.sense: fay-ihu, originally fayowihN: see mufaw-ahN.

hom.sense: fuw-ahapN: see its syn. fuwhN.

[Hence] it signifies also ‡ The fam [i. e. mouth] of a place; likened to the fam [properly so called] as being the first place of ingress, or entrance, to the interior: (TA:) [and so too as being the place of egress, or exit, from the interior:] it is of a river, or rivulet, (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and of a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, (Ḳ, TA,) and of a street, and of a road; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) signifying the fam [or mouth]; as also fuwhapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) without teshdeed; mentioned by IAạr: (TA:) or it signifies thus in relation to a river, or rivulet; (Lth, Mṣb, TA;) the foremost part thereof: or, as some say, the place of its pouring into the kiZaAmap [q. v.]: and accord. to Lth, in relation to a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, its raOos [or head, as though in this case having one, or each, of two contr. meanings, unless, as I believe it to be, the mouth, or outlet, of a valley or water-course or torrent-bed be sometimes called its rOs as being its foremost part]: (TA:) and of a street, it is the place of egress, or exit; (Mṣb;) the foremost part thereof: (TA:) and of a road, it is the fam [or mouth], which is the upper part thereof (AElAh): (Mṣb: [thus in my copy; but I think that AElAh is a mistranscription, in my copy, for Oaw-aluhu, and that the correct meaning is therefore the foremost part thereof, agreeably with what is said above in relation to a road and to a river or rivulet:]) but accord. to some, fuwhapN↓, without teshdeed, is not allowable; and one should say, AlT-ariyqi qaEada EalaI fuw-ahapK, and fuw-ahihi↓ [probably, I think, a mistranscription for fwhihi, with the w quiescent, both meaning He sat at the mouth of the road]; not fuwhatihi↓, without teshdeed: (TA:) and fuw-ahapN signifies also † the first, or foremost, part, of a thing; (Ḳ, TA;) like that of the street and that of the river or rivulet: [whence] one says, TalaEa EalayonaA fuw-ahapu Uibilika i. e. ‡ The first, or foremost, portion of thy camels [came to us, or came forth upon us]; like the phrase fuw-ahapu AlT-ariyqi: (TA:) the pl. of fuw-ahapN is OafowaAhN, (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) which is anomalous, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and (TA) fuw-ahaAtN [in the CK fuwohAtN] and fawaAYihu. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence] one says, daxaluwA fiI OafowaAhi Albaladi waxarajuwA mino Oarojulihi, (A, Ḳ,* TA,) in the copies of the Ḳ OarojulihaA, which is wrong, (TA,) i. e. ‡ They entered into the foremost parts of the country, or town, and went forth from the hindermost parts thereof: (A, Ḳ, TA:) the sing. of OafowaAh as here used is fuw-ahapN. (TA.)

It signifies also A say, or saying, or speech; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: hence one says, Uin-a rad-a Alfuw-ahapi laXadiydN (Ṣ, TA) Verily the retracting of that which has been said is difficult: (Ḥar p. 434:) and [hence] one says also, huwa yaxaAfu fuw-ahapa Aln-aAsi [He fears the say, or speech, of men]. (TA.)
And The Muslims' rending one another's reputation by evil speech, or by backbiting; (Ḳ, TA;) as also fuwhapF↓. (TA.)
Uin-ahu lacuw fuw-ahapK means Verily he is strong in speech, and free, or unconstrained, in tongue. (TA.)

And one says, maA OaXad-a fuw-ahapa baEiyrika fiI hecaA AlkalaOi, meaning [How vehement is] thy camel's eating [of this herbage]! and in like manner, fuw-ahapa farasika [the vehement eating of thy horse]: whence their saying OafowaAhuhaA majaAs-uhaA [which may be well rendered as it has been in art. js, q. v.], meaning Their good eating shows thee their fatness, causing thee to be in no need of feeling them to test their condition. (TA.)
And Milk, as long as there remains in it the taste of sweetness; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also fuwhapN↓; and sometimes correctly said with q, i. e. [quwhapN,] without teshdeed. (TA.)

entry.sense: faAwuwhapN A man who reveals, or discloses, everything that is in his mind; as also faAhK↓, (Fr, Ṣ, TA, [but omitted in one of my copies of the Ṣ,]) and faAhN↓: (Fr, TA:) and faAhK↓ bijuwEihi one who reveals his hunger; originally faAYihN, like as they said haArK and haAYirN. (TA.)

Oafowahu Having what is termed fawahN, meaning as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph [i. e. width of the mouth,, &c.]; fem. fawohaMCu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) the former applied to a man, and the latter to a woman; (Ṣ, TA;) and in like manner to horses. (TA.) fawohaMCu XawohaMCu, applied to a woman, means Wide-mouthed, ugly: and, applied to a mare, wide-mouthed, long-headed: or sharp in spirit. (TA.)
[Hence,] biYorN fawohaMCu A widemouthed well. (Ḳ.)
And TaEonapN fawohaMCu A wide wound made by piercing. (Ḳ.)

And maHaAlapN fawohaMCu [A large sheave of a pulley] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) that is wide (Ḳ, TA) and (TA) whereof the teeth between which runs the well-rope are long. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also maHaAlapN fawoqaMCu, in art. fwq.]

hom.sense: mufaw-ahN and fay-ihN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter originally fayowihN, (Ṣ,) Eloquent; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so fay-ihapN applied to a woman; (Ṣ, TA;) able in speech; an able speaker: or fay-ihN signifies good in speech; a good speaker: (TA:) or both signify good and eloquent in speech; as though taken from Alfawahu meaning “width of the mouth:” (IAạr, TA:) or having an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; a vehement eater; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man and to other than man: (TA:) and the latter (fay-ihN), having an inordinate and insatiable desire, or appetite, for food: (TA:) and this also signifies a man who eats much; syn. OakuwlN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so does musotafiyhN↓: (Ḳ [in some copies of which, kwfI is strangely put in the place of Akwl in the explanation here given]:) or musotafiyhN↓ signifies a man eating vehemently after scantiness, (Ṣ,) or after weakness: (thus in a copy of the Ṣ:) and mufaw-ahN is also expl. as meaning a man who eats vehemently. (TA.) And one says minoTiyqN mufaw-ahN (Ḳ, TA) meaning [Very] eloquent in speech: (TA:) and manoTiqN mufaw-ahN (Ḳ, TA) Good, or excel-lent, speech, or diction. (TA.)
XaraAbN mufaw-ahN means [Beverage, or wine,] perfumed (Ḳ, TA.) with [the odoriferous substances called] OafaAwiyhu [pl. pl. of fuwhu, q. v.]. (TA.)
And vawobN mufaw-ahN (Lth, Ḳ) and mufaw-FI (Ḳ) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with fuw-ah [or fuw-ap, i. e. madder]. (Lth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: musotafiyhN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: fiI is a particle governing the gen. case [and used in the manners and senses expl in what here follows]. (T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ.)

It relates to a receptacle; (Sb, Ṣ, M;) and, when used in a wider sense, to that which has some near resemblance thereto; (Sb, M;) [i. e.,] and also to what is considered as a receptacle: (Ṣ:) [in other words,] it denotes inclusion, or inbeing, (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ, TA,) either in relation to place or in relation to time: (Mughnee, Ḳ, TA;) properly and tropically. (Mṣb, Mughnee, TA.) gulibati Qlr-uwmu fiI OadonaI QloOaroDi wahumo mino baEodi galabihimo sayagolibuwna fiI biDoEi siniyna [The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land, and they, after the overcoming of them, shall overcome in some few years], in the Ḳur [xxx. 1 - 3], is an ex. of its relation to place and to time. (Mughnee.) And walakumo fiI QloqiSaASi HayewpN ‡ [And there is, to you, in retaliation, life, or an advantage, (respecting the meaning of which see art. HI,) in the Ḳur ii. 175,] is an ex. of its being used tropically, (Mughnee.) Oadoxalotu AlxaAtama fiI OuSobaEiI is an ex. of its relation to place, but the proposition is inverted [i. e. the meaning is I inserted my finger into the signet-ring]. (Mughnee.) [Using it properly,] you say, AlmaMCu fiI AlUinaMCi [The water is in the vessel]: (Ṣ:) and huwa fiI AljiraAbi [It is in the wallet,] and fiI Alkiysi [in the purse]: and huwa fiI baToni Oum-ihi [He is in the belly of his mother]: and huwa fiI Algul-i [He is in the shackle for the neck]: (M:) and zayodN fiI Ald-aAri [Zeyd is in the house], (Ṣ, M,* Mṣb,) or within the house, and in the midst of it, for fiI Ald-aAri, means daAxilihaA, and wasoTahaA: (T:) and [using it tropically, you say,] AlX-ak-u fiI Alxabari † [Doubt, or uncertainty, is in the information]. (Ṣ.) The saying fiyhi EayobN [In him is a fault, or blemish], if relating to a real Eayob, is proper; and if relating to an ideal Eayob, tropical: the former is such as the amputation of the hand of the thief, and the redundance of a hand; and the latter, such as the runningaway of a slave. (Mṣb.) [When relating to time, it may in some cases be rendered In, or during; as in the phrase fiI Oay-aAmK maEoduwdaAtK, in the Ḳur ii. 139, i. e. In, or during, certain numbered days. Uin-a OaSoHaAba Qlojan-api Qloyawoma fiI XugulK faAkihuwna, in the Ḳur xxxvi. 55, may be rendered † Verily the inmates of Paradise this day shall be in the midst of diverting occupation, cheerful, or happy.
