The phrase Oam-aA qawoluhu kacaA fiyhi maA fiyhi, lit. † As to his saying thus, in it is what is in it, is used as a polite expression of objection, or contradiction; like fiyhi taOam-ulN, q. v. In many instances, fiI may be rendered Of, or concerning, or in respect of; as in qaAla fiyhi kacaA † He said of, or concerning, him, or it, thus; for qaAla fiI cikorihi kacaA † He said in mentioning him, or it, thus, or fiI waSofihi in describing him, or it; or the like hence, for ex., one says kataba kitaAbFA fiI Eilomi All-ugapi † He wrote a book of, or concerning the science of lexicology: and hence, in the Ḳur ii. 133, Oat-uHaAj-uwnanaA fiI Qll-ehi † Do ye argue with us concerning, or in respect of, God?]

It also denotes concomitance, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and (Ḳ) in this ease (Mughnee) it is syn. with maEa. (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ.) Thus in the phrase, qaAla QdoxuluwA fiI OumamK [He shall say, Enter ye with peoples]. (Mṣb, Mughnee, TA,) in the Ḳur [vii. 36]: (Mṣb, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, fiI jamaAEapi OumamK [in the company of peoples]. (Mughnee.) Thus. too, in the phrase, in the Ḳur [xlvi. 15], fiI OaSoHaAbi Aljan-api [With the inmates of Paradise]. (Mṣb, TA.) [Or in these and similar instances, fiI may be rendered, more agreeably with the primary signification, as meaning Among.] In the Ḳ, the meaning as denoting concomitance and that which is identical with maEa are made distinct: and it has been said that bi denotes the continuance of concomitance and maEa denotes its commencement; though this is not invariably the case. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is used to denote a combination of two qualities: as in the phrase TuwlN fiI QsotiroxaMCK † Length together with laxness: (occurring in the Ḳ voce TanabN:) and sawaAdN fiI HumorapK † Blackness blending with redness: and the like. And in like manner it is used to denote the combination of the length and breadth of a thing: as in the phrase Tuwluhu EiXoruwna ciraAEFA fiI valaAvi OacoruEK EaroDFA Its length is twenty cubits with (or as we say by) three cubits in breadth: in which case the number of square cubits is expressed by the phrase EiXoruwna fiI valaAvK as though meaning Twenty as a multiplicand with three as its multiplier; i. e. twenty multiplied by three: see Daraba as signifying “he multiplied.”].

It also denotes the assigning of a cause. (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ.) Thus in the phrase fiI OarobaEiyna XaApN i. e. On account, or because, of completing [the possession of] forty sheep or goats, [the giving of] a sheep or goat [for the poor-rate] is incumbent [on the possessor: or this may be rendered, in the case of the possession of forty, a sheep or goat is to be given]. (Mṣb.)
And thus in the saying, [in the Ḳur xii. 32,] facelikun-a Ql-aciI lumotun-aniI fiyhi [And that is he because of whom ye blamed me]. (Mughnee.) Thus also in the saying, in a trad., Uin-a QmoraOapF daxalati Aln-aAra fiI hir-apK HabasatohaA [Verily a woman entered the fire of Hell because of a she-cat which she confined without food]. (Mughnee.) [And thus in the phrase Oasolafa fiI kacaA He paid in advance, or beforehand, for, or on account of, such a thing.]

It also denotes superiority; (Mughnee, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. (TA) it is used in the sense of EalaI. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA.) Thus in the saying, in the Ḳur [xx. 74], walaOuSal-iban-akumo fiI jucuwEi Qln-axoli [And I will assuredly crucify you upon the trunks of palm-trees]. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, TA.) And so in the verse of 'Antarah cited voce saroHN. (T, M, Mughnee, TA.) And Yoo asserts that the Arabs say, nazalotu fiI Oabiyka, meaning Ealayohi [i. e. I alighted, or descended and stopped,, &c., at the abode of thy father]. (Ṣ.)

It is also syn. with bi, (T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) sometimes. (Ṣ.) Thus in the saying of Zeyd-el-Kheyl,
watarokabu yawoma Alr-awoEi fiyhaA fawaArisu
baSiyruwna fiI TaEoni AlOabaAhiri wAlkulaI , (Ṣ, Mughnee, TA,) meaning, biTaEoni AlAbAhr wAlklI [i. e. And horsemen skilful in piercing the aortas and the kidneys ride in the day of fear therein]. (Ṣ, TA.) And thus in a verse cited by Fr, Oarogabu is made trans. by fiI and Eano instead of bi and Eano. (T, TA.) [Thus, also, layosa fiI XaIoCK is sometimes used for layosa biXaIoCK, meaning It is nought; or not of any account or weight;, &c.: see more in art. XyO.]
It is also syn. with UilaI. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) Thus in the Ḳur [xiv. 10], farad-uwA Oayodiyahumo fiI OafowaAhhm [And they put their hands to their mouths]. (Mughnee, TA.)

It is also syn. with mino. (M, Mughnee, Ḳ, TA.) Thus in the Ḳur [xxvii. 12], fiI tisoEi MyaAtK [Of, or among, nine signs]. (M, TA.) And in the saying, xuco liI EaXorFA mina AlUibili fiyhaA faHolaAni [Take thou for me ten of the camels; of, or among, them let there be two stallions.] (M, TA.) [Thus too in the saying huwa fiI OaSoli qawomihi He is of, or among, the purest in race,, &c., of his people: and the like thereof.]

It also denotes comparison; and this is when it occurs between a preceding [mention of a] thing excelled and a following [mention of a] thing excelling: as in the saying, [in the Ḳur ix. 38,] famaA mataAEu QloHayewpi Qld-unoyaA fiI QloMxirapi Uil-aA qaliylN [But the enjoyment of the present life, in comparison with that which is to come, is no other than little]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.)

It is also used for compensation; and this is when it is redundant as a compensation for another [fiI] which is suppressed: as in the saying, Darabotu fiymano ragibota for Darabotu mano ragibota fiyhi [I beat, or struck, him whom thou desiredst]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) but this is allowed by Ibn-Málik alone. (Mughnee.)

And it is used for corroboration: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) this is when it is redundant without its being for compensation: and this El-Fárisee allows in a case of necessity in verse; citing as an ex.,
OanaA OabuwA saEodK UicaA All-ayolu dajaA
taxaAlu fiI sawaAdihi yaranodajaA
[I am Aboo-Saạd; when the night becomes dark, thou imagining its blackness to be black leather]. (Mughnee.) And it is thus used in the saying, in the Ḳur [xi. 43], waqaAla QrokabuwA fiyhaA [for QrokabuwhaA, i. e. And he said, Embark ye therein, the like of which occurs also in xviii. 70 and xxix. 65], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to some. (Mughnee.)
fiI as a prefixed noun in the gen. case, syn. with fam, and fiI-a as syn. with famiI, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

entry.sense: faI-a is a word expressive of wonder: they say, yaA faI-a maA liI OafoEalu kacaA [O my wonder! What has happened to me that I do thus?]: or it is expressive of regret on account of a thing that is passing away [so that this exclamation may be rendered Oh! What has happened to me, &c.]: Ks says that it is not to be written withC [though it is so written in several of the lexicons in art. fyO, i. e. faIoCa]; and that it means yaA EajabiI [as first expl. above]: and in like manner one says, yaA faI-a maA OaSoHaAbuka [O my wonder! What are thy companions? i. e. what manner of men are thy companions? mA here denoting interrogation respecting qualities, or attributes; as in the Ḳur xxvi. 22]: and he says that mA in this case occupies the place of a noun in the nom. case. (M, TA.) Ks is also related to have said that some of the Arabs express wonder by faI-a and haI-a and XaIoCa; and some add maA, saying yaA fay-amaA and yaA hay-amaA and yaA XayoYamaA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! the Ḳ is faulty here; mentioning only yaA fay-amaA, and explaining it as denoting wonder. (TA.)
tafiy-apN: see tafiyoYapN, in art. fyO.

hom.sense: 1. faMCa, aor. yafiIoCu, inf. n. faIoCN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb) and fuyuwoCN, (O,) He (a man, Mṣb) returned; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and so AfMC↓, and AstfMC↓: (M, TA:) faIoCN, as also fayoYapN↓ and fiyYapN↓, [or the former of these, accord. to analogy, is an inf. n. of unity, and the latter an inf. n. of modality,] and UifaMCapN and AistifaMCapN al' signify rujuwEN: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, faMCa signifies particularly he returned to a good state or condition. (MF, TA.) One says, faMCa mino gaDabihi He returned [to a good state, or recovered, from his anger]: (M, TA:) and fulaAnN sariyEu AlfaIoCi mino gaDabihi [Such a one is quick in respect of the returning, &c. from his anger]: (Ṣ, M,* O:) and Uin-ahu lasariyEu AlfiyoYapi↓, (M,) or laHasanu AlfiyoYapi↓, (Ṣ, O,) i. e. [Verily he is quick, or good, in respect of] the returning [to a good state, or from his anger, or in respect of the manner of returning, &c.]: (Ṣ, M, O:) and huwa sariyEu AlgaDabi sariyEu AlfiyoYapi↓ [He is quick in respect of anger, quick in respect of returning, or recovering, therefrom]. (A, TA.) And faMCa UilaI AlOamori, and faMCahu [i. e. faMCa AlOamora], inf. n. faIoCN and fuyuwoCN, He returned [to the affair, or to the command, i. e. to that which was commanded]. (M, TA.) Hat-aI tafiIoCa UilaI Oamori Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur xlix. 9, means Until it [referring to a party (TaAYifap) before mentioned] return to the ordinance of God, or to that which God has commanded: (Bḍ:) or until it return (T, Mṣb) to obedience, (T,) or to that which is right. (Mṣb.) And faMCa UilaI AlOamori, inf. n. faIoCN, signifies also He reconsidered the affair, or case. (TA.)

faMCa AlmuWoliI (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) mini QmoraOatihi, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. faIoCN, (TA,) or fayoYapN↓, (Mṣb,) means The man who had sworn to abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife expiated his oath and returned to her. (M, Mṣb,* Ḳ. [See Ḳur ii. 226.]) But MF observes that this usage of faMCa to signify He expiated an oath belongs to the conventional language of the law. (TA.) In the case of a man who has sworn that he will abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife, a period of four months is appointed to him in the Ḳur-án; and if he have such intercourse with her in the four months, it is said of him, qado faMCa, meaning He has returned [or reverted] from his oath, to the doing that which he swore that he would not do, and is bound to expiate his oath: if he have not had such intercourse with her until the end of the four months from the day of his swearing, then, Ibn-ʼAbbás and a number of the Companions pass upon her a single sentence of divorce, making the [said sentence of] divorce to have effect at the end of the months; but many of the Companions and others say that in this case he must return, and expiate his oath, or he must divorce. (T, TA.) And [hence] one says lahu EalaI QmoraOatihi fayoYapN↓ He has the right of returning to his wife: (Mṣb, TA:) and huwa yamoliku fayoYatahaA↓ He possesses the right of returning to her; namely, a wife whom he has divorced. (A, TA.)
AlfaIoCu EalaI ciI Alr-aHimi occurs in a trad. as meaning The being favourably inclined, or affectionate, to the relation; and returning to kind treatment of him. (TA.)

faMCa said of the shade, (M, Mṣb,) aor. yafiIoCu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. faIoCN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) It shifted, or removed; (M, Ḳ;*) or [rather] it returned from the side of the west to the side of the east: (Mṣb:) and tafay-aOati↓ AlZ-ilaAlu The shades became changed in their manner of being; (Ṣ, O;) or [rather] they returned [towards the east] after midday. (T, TA. [See the Ḳur-án xvi. 50.])

And faMCati AlX-ajarapu; and tfy-Ot↓; (M;) and fy-Ot↓, inf. n. tafiyoYapN; (Ṣ, O, TA;) The tree had much shade. (M, TA.) faMCati AlHadiydapu The iron implement became blunt after its being sharp. (T, TA.)
fiYotu Alganiymapa, (mentioned, but not expl., in the Ḳ,) inf. n. faIoCN, (TA,) means I took the spoil. (TḲ.) [See also 10.]
2. fy-O AlZil-a, and AfMChu↓ He (God) made the shade to return [in the afternoon]. (El-Khafájee, MF, TA.)
qay-aOat said of a tree: see 1, near the end.
Said of the wind, It put in motion the seed-produce, or standing corn, and the trees. (M, TA.) And, said of a woman, She put in motion her hair, from self-conceit, or vanity. (M, TA.)
4. OafaOotuhu I made it to return. (O.) See also 2.

[Hence,] one says, OafaMCa Qll-ehu EalaI Almusolimiyna maAla Alkuf-aAri [God restored to the Muslims, as though it were theirs by right, or gave to them as spoil, the property, or wealth, of the unbelievers]; (Ṣ, O;) inf. n. UifaMCapN. (Ṣ.) And OafaMCa Qll-ehu Ealayohimu AlganaAYima [God restored, or gave, to them the spoils]. And OafaMCa EalaI qawomK fayoYFA He took for a party the spoil of another party and brought it to them: and he took for a party spoil that had been taken from them. (T, TA.)
And OafaOotu kacaA I made such a thing to be a faIoC [or spoil]. (TA.)
And OafaOotu fulaAnFA EalaI AlOamori I turned him to the thing, or affair, when he had desired another thing, or affair. (AZ, T.)
See also 1, first sentence.
5. tafay-aOati AlZ-ilaAlu: -b2- and tfy-Ot AlX-ajarapu: see 1, near the end.

tfy-O fiyhi means He shaded himself in it; i. e., in the shade termed faIoC. (M.) One says, tafay-aOotu fiI faIoCi AlX-ajarapi [I shaded myself in the afternoon-shade of the tree]. (Ṣ, O.) And tfy-O biAlX-ajarapi [He shaded himself by means of the tree; or] he entered into the OafoyaMC [or afternoon-shades] of the tree: (MA:) and [it is said that] tafay-aOotu AlX-ajarapa signifies I entered into the OafoyaMC of the tree, and shaded myself thereby: (Ḥar p. 500:) and Aboo-Temmám has made it trans. by itself [i. e. without a prep.] in his saying,
fatafay-aOotu Zil-ahu mamoduwdFA
[as though meaning And I protected myself from the sun by its shade, when it was extended]: but [perhaps he has thus used the verb in the last of the senses here following, for] it is said that this is irregular. (TA.)
[Hence] one says, tafay-aOotu bifayoYika meaning ‡ I have had recourse to thee for protection. (A, TA.)

tfy-O is said of a branch or twig [as meaning It bent, in a languid manner]. (T, M, L, Ḳ, voce taraO-ada;, &c.) And one says, tfy-Ot lizawojihaA, meaning She bent herself over her husband, and affected languor, or languidness, to him, feigning coyness, or opposition, and threw herself upon him: (T,* TA:) from AlfaIoCu signifying “the act of returning:” and some say tqy-Ot, with q; but Az says that this is a mistake, and that it is correctly with f (TA.)

tfy-O signifies also tatab-aEa [He sought a thing time after time, or repeatedly,, &c.]. (Ḥar p. 500.) And one says, fulaAnN yatafay-aOu AlOaxobaAra and yasotafiyWuhaA↓ [app. meaning Such a one seeks after news, or tidings, time after time, or repeatedly,, &c.]. (A, TA.)
10. AstfMC He took as spoil. (Ṣ, M,* O, Ḳ.) One says, AisotafaOotu hecaA AlmaAla I took this property as spoil. (Ṣ, O.)
See also 5.
As intrans., see 1, first sentence.

faIoCN Afternoon-shade; shade after the declining of the sun from the meridian; (T,* Ṣ, O;) [i. e.] the faIoC is what was sun, and has been annulled, or superseded, by shade; (M, Ḳ;) or that from which the sun has departed: so called because of its “returning” from side to side: (Ṣ, O: [see 1, first sentence:]) ISk says, (Ṣ, O,) the Zil- is what sun has annulled, or superseded; [correctly, what sun annuls, or supersedes; (see Zal-N;)] and the faIoC is what has annulled, or superseded, sun: (Ṣ, Mgh, O:) but AO says, on the authority of Ru-beh, that on which the sun has been and from which it has departed is faIoC and Zil-; and that on which the sun has not been is Zil-: (Ṣ, O:) [see more under this latter word:] pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaMCN and [of mult,] fuyuwoCN. (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And Spoil, booty, or plunder; syn. ganiymapN [q. v.]; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) thus called, by the inf. n., because it returns from one party to another; (Mṣb;) and fay-N in this sense is not allowable; (Mgh, Mṣb;) nor is it in the preceding sense: (Mgh:) or such as is obtained without difficulty: and therefore likened to shade. (MF.) And The [tax, or tribute, termed] xaraAj [q. v.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) frequently occurring in trads. as meaning such, of the possessions of the unbelievers, as accrues to the Muslims without war: (TA:) or such as is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods after the laying-down of arms: (AʼObeyd, Mgh and Mṣb voce ganiymapN:) or such as God has restored [as though it were theirs of right] to the people of his religion, of the possessions of those who have opposed them, without fighting, either by the latter's quitting their homes and leaving them vacant to the Muslims, or by their making peace on the condition of paying a poll-tax or other money or property to save themselves from slaughter: such is termed faIoC in the Ḳur-án. (T. [See more under ganiymapN.])
Also A flock of birds: (O, Ḳ:) [or a number of birds disposed in a row:] also termed EaraqapN and Saf-N. (O, TA.)

yaA faIoCa, (M, O, Ḳ, in the CK [erroneously] yA faIoCu,) or, accord. to Ks, correctly yA faI-a [q. v.]. (M,) [Oh! or O my wonder?] an expression of regret, (M, O, Ḳ,) accord. to most, (TA,) or of wonder, (Ks, M, Ḳ, TA,) meaning yaA EajabiI. (Ks, M.) [See XaIoCN, last three sentences.]

entry.sense: fiYapN A [party, portion, division, or distinct body, of men, such as is termed] TaAYifap: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or a company (Mṣb, TA) of soldiers who fight in the rear of an army, and to whom the latter has recourse in the case of fear or defeat: (TA:) or a company of men who [in war] have recourse, for aid, one to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a word having no proper sing.: (Mṣb, TA:) originally fiIoCN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) the p being substituted for the medial I, which is dropped: (Ṣ, O:) or its original form is fiYowN [or fiYoIN or fiYowapN or fiYoyipN (see art. fOw and fOI)]; the final [radical] letter being that which is elided; for it is from faOawotu [or faOayotu] “I divided;” and fiYapN is syn. with firoqapN: (IB, L, TA:) pl. fiYaAtN and fiYuwna, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in which latter the w and n are for the making good what is deficient [in the sing.]. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: fayoYapN: see 1, in four places.
[Hence] cuw fayoYapK a term applied to Date-stones (nawaI Alt-amori) when they are hard: [because,] being given as fodder to cattle, and eaten by them, they pass forth as they were at first. (T, TA.)
Also A time; syn. HiynN. (Ḳ.) One says, jaMCahu baEoda fayoYapK He came to him after a time. (TA.)
And The HidaOap [or kite], that seizes as its prey the chickens from the dwellings: (O:) or a certain bird resembling the eagle, (L, Ḳ,) which, when it fears the cold, migrates to El-Yemen. (L.)

entry.sense: fiyoYapN: see 1, first quarter, in four places.

tafiyoYapN, (M and Ḳ in art. tfO,) as also tafiy-apN, both mentioned by Lḥ, and the latter reckoned as a dial. var. of the former, (M in that art.,) [and taYif-apN and Uif-u and Uif-apN and Oaf-apN and Uif-aAnN and Oaf-aAnN, (see art. Af,)] The time of a thing: (M and Ḳ in art. tfO:) one says, Oatayotuhu EalaI tafiyYapi celika I came to him at the time of that: (M in that art.:) and [by extension of the signification] one says, daxala EalaI tafiYapi fulaAnK meaning Oavarihi [i. e. He entered near after such a one; as though treading in his footsteps]: (Ḳ in the present art.:) the t in tafiyoYapN is an augmentative letter; the word being [originally] of the measure tafoEilapN, but formed by transposition: Z says that the t would not be augmentative if the composition of the word were as it is here, without transposition: that it is not of the measure tafoEilapN from AlfaIoCu; for, if it were, it would be of the same measure as tahoyiYapN [i. e. it would be tafoyiYapN]; therefore, if not formed by transposition, it would be of the measure faEiylapN [i. e. it would be from tfO, as some hold it to be], because of the UiEolaAl [or alteration for the sake of alleviating the sound, such as takes place in yasiyru for yasoyiru, which cannot be in a noun of the measure tafoEilapN from a triliteral root like fyO, whose medial radical is infirm], the last radical being hemzeh: but its formation by transposition from taYif-apN [originally taOofifapN] to taf-iYapN, which is then changed to tafiyoYapN, as Z says in the “Fáïk,” is what determines the t to be augmentative, and the [original] measure to be tafoEilapN. (L and TA * in arts. tfO and fyO.)

mufaMCN A thing that has been made a faIoC [or spoil,, &c.]. (TA.) And A person whose country, or province, or town, has been conquered, and become a faIoC to the Muslims. (IḲt, O, TA.)
It is in a trad. of some of those who have gone before, laA yuWam-aru mufaMCN EalaI mufiIoCK↓, meaning An emancipated slave shall not be made governor over an Arabian; (Ḳ, TA;) or, as in the Nh [and O] and L, lA yaliyan-a [shall by no means rule]; (TA;) as though it were said, none of the people of the Sawád (which was conquered by force and became a faIoC to the Muslims) shall rule over the Companions (O, TA) and their next successors. (TA.)
mufiIoCN A person who makes a thing [or a country or the like] to be a faIoC. (TA.) See also mufaMCN.
mafiyoYapN: see the paragraph here following.
mafoyaOapN: see the paragraph here following.

mafoyuWapN A place of faIoC, i. e. of the shade thus termed; [a place of afternoon-shade;] (M, Ḳ;) as also mafoyaOapN↓; (Ḳ;) and, as AAF says, on the authority of Th, mafiyoYapN↓; (M, L, TA;) and so mafoyuwoCapN↓, like masomuwEapN [in measure]: (L, TA:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) mafoyuWapN is syn. with maqonuWapN, (Ṣ, TA,) which signifies a place on which the sun does not come: so says Az; and he adds that it is probably correct, but that he had not heard it on any other authority than of Lth. (TA.)
mafoyuwoCN i. q. maEotuwhN [Idiotic, or an idiot, i. e. deficient, or wanting, in intellect;, &c.]: so called from his keeping long [or much] in the shade. (M, TA.)
mafoyuwoCapN: see mafoyuWapN.
1. faAjato birijolihaA, aor. tafiyju, She (a camel) kicked with her hind legs, backwards. (TA.)
4. AfAj, mentioned in the O and L and Mṣb in this art.: see art. fwj.

hom.sense: fayojN A foot-messenger; a courier who journeys on foot: (Ṣ:) or a Sultán's foot-messenger: (L, Mṣb:) or one who journeys with letters: (L:) or a quick courier who carries tidings, or communications, from one town, or country, to another: (Nh, TA:) originally Pers., (Ṣ, O,) arabicized, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) from Payok: (O, Ḳ:) pl. fuyuwjN. (Ṣ, TA.) It is also expl. as meaning One going, or journeying, alone: thus in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, in which it is opposed to zaraAfapN meaning “a company [of men].” (TA.) And [the pl.] fuyuwjN, (O, Ḳ,) as used in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O,) means Men who enter the prison and go forth from it, keeping guard. (O, L, Ḳ: in some copies of the Ḳ, and keep guard.)
And A company [of men]; (Mṣb;) syn. with fawojN: (O and Ḳ in art. fwj:) and sometimes applied to a single person:pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaAjN and [of mult.] fuyuwjN. (Mṣb.)
Also A low, or depressed, place, such as is termed wahod, of the earth, or ground. (AA, O, Ḳ.)
And A state of dispersion; as also fiyjN↓. (TA. [See 4 in art. fwj.])

entry.sense: fiyjN: see what next precedes.
fay-aAjapN A she-camel that kicks with her hind legs [much or often], backwards. (TA. [See 1.])
faAYijN A wide [expanded and even tract such as is termed] basaAT, of land. (AA, O in art. fwj.)

faAYijapN A wide tract between two elevated portions, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, all in art. fwj,) of rugged ground, or of sand: (Ṣ, O:) or what has the form of a valley between two mountains, or between two rugged tracts containing stones and sand and earth, like a xaliyf [q. v.], but wider: thus expl. by ISh: pl. fawaAYiju. (TA in art. fwj.)
1. faAHa, aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN and fayaHaAnN: see art. fwH.

fAH Ald-amu, inf. n. fayoHN (L, Mṣb) and fayaHaAnN, (L,) It poured out, or forth: (L:) or it flowed; as also AfAH↓, inf. n. UifaAHapN: or, accord. to AZ, the latter is trans., and signifies as expl. below in relation to blood. (Mṣb.)
And faAHati AlX-aj-apu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. tafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN, (TA,) ‡ The wound upon the head spirted forth blood; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or poured forth much blood. (A.)

And fAH AlHur-u, aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN; and aor. yafwHu, inf. n. fawoHN; † The heat rose, or diffused itself, and raged vehemently. (L.) It is said in a trad., Xid-apu AlqayoZi mino fayoHi jahan-ama ‡ [The intenseness of the heat of summer is from the vehement raging of the heat of Hell]. (TA.) And one says, AlHum-aI mino fayoHi jahan-ama ‡ The fever is from the vehemence of the heat of Hell. (A.)
And faAHati Alqidoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. tafiyHu (Ṣ, TA) and tafuwHu, (TA,) † The cooking-pot boiled; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though it were the fire of Hell, in its heat. (TA.)

And faAHati Aln-aAru † The fire spread. (Mṣb.) And [hence, app.,] faAHati AlgaArapu, aor. tafiyHu, i. e. ‡ [The troop of horsemen making an attack, or incursion, upon a people] spread themselves. (Ṣ, TA.) See fayaAHi.

And fAH, (L, Mṣb, TA,) aor. yafaAHu, (L, TA,) [inf. n., app. fayaHN, which signifies “width” accord. to the Ṣ and Ḳ, and is agreeable with general analogy in this case, as the aor. of the verb is originally yafoyaHu, though it seems to be implied in the Mṣb that the aor. is not yafaAHu, but yafiyHu,] It (a sea, Ṣ,* L, Ḳ,* TA, and a place, L, or a valley, Mṣb) was, or became, wide. (Ṣ,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.)
2. lawo madakota Ald-unoyaA lafay-aHotahaA fiI yawomK waAHidK means ‡ [If thou possessedst all that the world contains,] thou wouldst dissipate it, or squander it away, in one day. (A, TA.*)
4. AfAH He poured forth, spilled, or shed, blood. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See also 1, first sentence.
AfAH Alqidora † He made the cooking-pot to boil. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OafiHo Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyrapi i. q. Oaborido, (Ḳ,) i. e. † Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (M, L, TA:) [as also Afixo:] the medial radical letter is both w and I. (M.)

fayoHN and fuyuwHN↓ Abundance of herbage of the [rain, or season, called] rabiyE, with ample extent of land: (Ḳ:) [accord. to the TḲ, both are inf. ns., of which the verb is faAHa, and the agent is Alr-abiyEu: but this, I think, is rendered doubtful by what here follows:] fywH occurs in a verse [as some relate it]; but accord. to the relation of IAạr, it is fatuwH, with t, [and with fet-ḥ to the f,] and this, which signifies “rain,” is said by Az to be the right reading: the pl. [of fayoHN] is fuyuwHN. (TA.)
fayaAHN: see OafoyaHu.

fayaAHi, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of the fem. gender, (L,) a name for The gaArap, (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) meaning troop of horsemen making a hostile attack, or incursion, upon a people. (T, L.) fiyHiI↓, fayaAHi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c., [in the CK, erroneously, fayoHiI,]) said by the people of the Time of Ignorance, (Ṣ,) when they impelled horses making a hostile attack, or incursion, and they spread out, (L,) means Spread out, O attacking troop of horsemen: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or spread out upon them, or against them, and disperse yourselves,, &c. (Sh, L.)
fuyuwHN: see fayoHN.
fay-aAHN: see OafoyaHu, in two places.
Also ‡ Profuse in bounty: (Ṣ, A:) so in the saying, Uin-ahu lajawaAdN fiy-aAHN ‡ [Verily he is liberal, munificent, or generous; profuse in bounty]. (Ṣ.)
And naAqapN fay-aAHapN ‡ A she-camel that yields much milk, (A, Ḳ,) and has a large udder. (Ḳ.)

OafoyaHu A sea, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and a valley, (Mṣb,) and any place, (L,) wide, or extensive; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also fay-aAHN↓: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) fay-aAHN↓ occurs in the story of Umm-Zarạ, accord. to AʼObeyd, applied to a bayot [i. e. house, or tent]; but accord. to others, it is fayaAHN↓, without teshdeed: (L:) [the fem. of OafoyaHu: and pl. fiyHN:] one says daArN fiyoHaMCu A wide, or an ample, house or abode: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner rawoDapN [a meadow,, &c.]. (L, Mṣb.)
And fayoHaMCu signifies also A sort of thin cooked food, such as is supped, or sipped, (HasaMCu,) seasoned with seeds such as are used in cookery. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. faAxati Alr-iyHu, aor. tafiyxu, inf. n. fayoxN and fayaxaAnN: see 1 in art. fwx.
Accord. to Kr and the Ḳ, fayoxN signifies A spreading, or becoming diffused; like fiyoHN: (TA:) but ISd expresses doubt of the correctness of this: (L, TA:) it is [said to be] an inf. n. in this sense. (TḲ.)
See also 4.
2. fy-x AlEajiyna He made the dough like the sukur-ujap [or fayoxap (q. v.) in form]. (TA.)

4. AfAx, (L,) inf. n. UifaAxapN, (L, Ḳ,) He (a man, L) emitted wind from the anus, with a sound; (L, Ḳ;) as also faAxa↓: (L:) or he voided excrement with an emission of wind. (L, Ḳ.) [See also art. fwx.]
AfAx, said of a man, signifies also suqiTa fiI yadihi [i. e. He repented of what he had done;, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
And AfAx mino fulaAnK He (a man, TA) turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, such a one; syn. Sad- Eanohu. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: fiyoxapN A state of dilatation of the place of exit of the urine. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And A tangled, luxuriant, or dense, and abundant, state of herbage. (Ḳ.)
And Vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A [kind of small saucer, or cup, such as is called] sukur-ujap [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) pl. fayoxaAtN. (O and Ḳ voce XufaArijN.)

1. faAdato lahu faAYidapN, (T, Ṣ, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. tafiydu, (Ṣ, A, O, &c.,) inf. n. fayodN, (Mṣb,) [Profit, or advantage, or the like, (see faAYidapN,)] accrued to him; (T,* Ṣ,* A, O,* L,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) or came to him. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

And fAd, aor. yafiydu, (T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. fayodN, (M, O, L,) said of property, It continued, or belonged or appertained, syn. vabata, (T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) lahu to him; (T, Ṣ, M, O, L;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (Ḳ in that art.:) or went away, passed away, or departed. (Ḳ. [But this last meaning, which I find only in the Ḳ, in relation to fAd, in this art. and in art. fwd, may be taken from what next follows, and relate to property as applied to cattle.])

And fAd, aor. as above, (T, M, L, Ḳ, and Ṣ, &c. in art. fwd,) and so the inf. n., (IAạr, T, L, and Ḳ in art. fwd,) He (a man, M, TA) died; (T, M, L, Ḳ, and Ṣ, &c. in art. fwd;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN; (Ḳ, &c. in that art.;) and so faAza and faAZa; (TA;) i. q. faAta. (A.) One says, maA faAda Hat-aI balaga rizoquhu Aln-afaAda, meaning maA faAta [i. e. He did not die until his means of subsistence became exhausted]. (A.)

And fAd, aor. as above, (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, O, L,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ;) as also tfy-d↓. (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.)
And, (M, L, Ḳ,) accord. to some, (M, L,) He was cautious of a thing, and turned aside from it. (M, L, Ḳ.) [See also 2.]
fAd said of saffron, and of the plant called warosa, It became pulverized, or reduced to powder by its being bruised or brayed. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. fayodN, (L,) He mixed it, (namely, saffron, Ḳ,) or moistened it with water, &c.; syn. daAfahu; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]; (TA;) as also fAdhu, aor. yafuwduhu, (T, M, L, &c., in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (Ḳ in that art.:) and he bruised, or brayed, it, (namely, saffron, and the plant called waros,) and then wetted it with water: (L in art. fwd:) and faAdatohu she (a woman) rubbed it (namely perfume) in water, in order that it might dissolve. (M, L.)

Eani fAd Almal-apa Alxubozapi, inf. n. fayodN; and AfAdhA↓; He removed the hot ashes from the cake of bread; syn. OazaAlahaA (TḲ. [In the O and Ḳ, this meaning of these two verbs is vaguely intimated, only by the words, Alfayodu Oano tufiydu biyadika Almal-apa Eani Alxubozapi.])
2. fy-d mino qironihi (Th, M, L) He turned away from, or avoided, his adversary: (Th, L:) or he fled from him. (M.) [See a similar meaning of fAd, above.]
And fy-d, (T, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoyiydN, (L, Ḳ,) He augured evil from the cry of the [bird called] fay-aAd. (T, O, L, Ḳ.)

4. AfAdhu He gave it, namely, property, (AZ, Ks, T, Ṣ, M, O, L, Ḳ,) to another: (AZ, Ks, T, Ṣ, M, L:) and AfAdhu maAlFA, inf. n. UifaAdapN, He gave him property. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fwd. (L in art. fwd.)

[And He, or it, profited, advantaged, or benefited, him; faAYidapF being understood. Hence,] one says, Uino OafadotaniI HarofFA faqado OaSofadotaniI OalofFA [If thou teach me a word, thou givest me what is worth a thousand dirhems]. (A in art. Sfd.)

[Hence, also, AfAd said of a word, and a phrase, It had, or performed, a useful office, as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed. And hence, It imported, or conveyed, a meaning; and particularly, when said of a phrase, a complete meaning, so that a pause might be well made after uttering it; faAYidapF being understood.]
See also 10.
And see 1, last signification.
Also, AfAdhu, inf. n. as above, He killed him; destroyed him; slaughtered him; namely, a man, and a beast. (T,* L, and Ḳ * in art. fwd.)
5. tfy-d, as intrans.: see 1, latter half.
tfy-dhu: see 10.

entry.sense: 6. humaA yatafaAyadaAni biAlmaAli bayonahumaA They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh, T, O, Ḳ:) you should not say yatafaAwadaAni: (Ḳ:) and hmA ytfAydAn AlEiloma They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (Ḳ in art. fwd [q. v.]:) or, in the opinion of MF, both of these verbs are allowable. (TA.)

10. AstfAdhu (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]; (T,* M,* Mgh, Mṣb, and L and Ḳ in art. fwd;) and AfAdhu↓ is syn. therewith, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as used by some, (Mṣb,) having two contr. significations, (Ḳ,) though disallowed by others, (Mṣb,) or it is more chaste than the former; (Mgh;) and tfy-dhu↓ signifies the same. (M, and Ḳ in art. fwd.)
[And He derived it, learned it, or inferred it.]
[And AstfAd mnohu He gained, or derived, profit, advantage, or benefit, from him, or it; faAYidapF being understood.]
fayodN Saffron: (IAạr, TA voce malaAbN:) or the leaves of saffron: (L:) or saffron mixed, or moistened with water, &c. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)
And The hair upon a horse's lip. (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
[fayiydN expl. by Golius as signifying (on the authority of Meyd) Vir pusillanimus pavidusque, is app. a mistake for faYiydN.]

fay-aAdN (T, Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Ḳ) and fay-aAdapN↓, (T, Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) in which latter the p is added to render the epithet intensive, (T, L,) A man who walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (T, Ṣ, M, A, O, L, Ḳ.) One says, fulaAnN yamoXiI EalaI AlOaroDi fay-aAdFA may-aAdFA [Such a one walks upon the ground] with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait,, &c. (A.)
Hence, Alfay-aAdu is said to signify The lion. (O.)
And The male of the buwm [or owl]: (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or i. q. AlS-adaI [which is also said to signify the male of the buwm: for other explanations see SadFI] (Ṣ, O.)
And fay-aAdapN↓, (M,) or this and fay-aAdN, (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) One who collects together what he can, and eats it. (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)
fay-aAdapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

faAYidapN a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, L, and Ḳ in art. fwd,) in the sense of vabata; (M, L;) or an act. part. n. from faAdato lahu faAYidapN; (Mṣb;) Profit, advantage, benefit, or good, which God bestows upon a man, and which he [the latter, consequently] gains, or acquires, and which he produces: (T, L:) an accession which accrues to a man: (Mṣb:) what one gains, or acquires, of knowledge, (Ṣ, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and polite accomplishments, (Mṣb,) and property: (Ṣ, A, O, L, Ḳ:) what one has recently acquired, of property, of gold or silver, or a slave, or the like: (AZ, Mṣb:) and [simply] profit, advantage, benefit, or utility: and good: and knowledge: and wealth, or property: (KL:) pl. fawaAYidu: (T, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it belongs to this art. and to art fwd: (TA:) some improperly derive it from AlfuWaAdu. (MF.)

[Hence, Utility as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed, or a word or phrase. And hence, A meaning, or an import, of a word or phrase; and particularly a complete meaning of a phrase, such that a pause may be well made after the uttering thereof.]
mafiydN [Perfume, &c.] mixed, or moistened with water, &c.; (Ṣ, O, L;) as also mafuwdN. (Aṣ, T in art. fwd.)
rajulN mitolaAfN mifoyaAdN A destructive man; as also mifowaAdN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád and O and Ḳ in art. fwd.)
fiyruwzajN [an arabicized word from the Pers. fiyruwzahu or Piyruwzahu The turquoise;] a well-known kind of stone. (TA.)
And A certain sort of dye [probably of the colour of the stone so called]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. faAXa, (O, Ḳ,) aor. yafiyXu, inf. n. fayoXN, (O, TA,) He gloried, or boasted, (O, Ḳ,) and magnified himself, imagining [in himself] what he did not possess; (Ḳ;) as also faX-a; like as you say caAma, aor. yaciymu; and cam-a, aor. yacum-u; (TA;) he was boastful, or proud, pretending to possess a thing and not being as he pretended; (TA;) and fAyX↓ [signifies the same; or] he gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him. (AHeyth, in L, art. Trmc.) [See also 5.]
fAX AlOataAna, aor. as above, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n. (IDrd, O,) He (the ass) mounted the she-ass: (IDrd:) said by Yoo to be from AlfayoXapu. (O, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 3. qAyXhu, (TA,) inf. n. fiyaAXN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and mufaAyaXapN, (O, Ḳ,) He vied, or contended, with him in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence. (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
Also, (TḲ,) inf. n. mufaAyaXapN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) He threatened him much in fight, and then was pronounced a liar. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TḲ.)
See also 1.
5. tfy-X AlX-aIoCa He arrogated the thing falsely; (Ibn-ʼAbbád,* O,* Ḳ,* TA;) without merit. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
tfy-X Eani AlX-aIoCi He turned back from the thing (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) through weakness and impotence; (TA;) like AnfX-. (TA.)

fayoXN and fayoXapN↓ The head [or glans] of the penis: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a swollen penis: (TA:) or ↓the latter word has the former meaning; and fayoXN is its pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN: (O:) and fayoXalapN↓ signifies the same as fayoXapN; and some say that its l is augmentative: (TA:) or fayoXN signifies a weak fayoXalap. (Lth, TA.)
fayoXapN: see fayoXN, in two places.
Also The uppermost part of the head. (TA.)

hom.sense: fiyaAXN: see fayoXuwXapN.
[See also 3.]

entry.sense: fayuwXN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

fay-aAXN A man who glories, or boasts, and magnifies himself, imagining [in himself] what he does not possess; (Ḳ;) vainly boastful, without merit; (TA;) who contends for superiority in that which he does not possess; (Ḳ;) and [in like manner] fayuwXN↓ one who pretends to possess a thing, not being as he pretends; (TA;) both signify one who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him: (AHeyth, in L, art. Trmc:) and ↓the latter is said to signify a cowardly and weak man. (TA.)
Also, A chief, or lord, abounding in excellence, or generosity, or bounty, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) who vies with others in glory. (TA.)
faAXuwXN A weak and lax man. (TA.)
fayoXuwXapN Weakness and laxness; (O, Ḳ;) and so fiyaAXN↓. (TA.)
fayoXalapN: see fayoXN.

1. faASa fiI AlOaroDi, aor. yafiySu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) He went away into the country, or in the land. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) In the following verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
manaAbituhu mivolu Als-uduwsi walawonuhu
kaXawoki Als-ayaAli fahowa EacobN yafiySu
respecting which Aṣ said, I know not what is [the meaning of] yafiyDu, this word is said to be from fAS signifying as expl. above: (Ṣ, O:) [but I do not see what meaning that would be apposite in this case could be thence derived without straining:] but fAS signifies also it shone, or glistened; syn. baraqa; (TA;) and some say that yfyS in this verse means yaboruqu; (O, TA;) and the pronoun in manaAbituhu relates to the front teeth; (O,* TA;) by EacobN yafiyDu being meant the lustre (maMC) thereof: (O:) [accordingly, the verse may be rendered, The places of growth thereof, i. e. their gums, were like the (garment called) suduws, and their colour was like the thorns of the sayaAl (q. v.), so that they were sweet and glistening:] (see the context in “the Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets,” edited by Prof. Ahlwardt:) or, as some relate the verse, the last word is yufiySu↓, (IB, O, TA,) from maA OafaASa bikalimapK [q. v.], (O,) so that it is a denotative of state, the meaning being EacobN fiI HaAli kalaAmihi [i. e. sweet when (displayed in) speaking; or rather, clearly uttering; but it will be seen below that yafiySu, as well as yufiySu, may, accord. to the M and Ḳ, be used in this sense:] (IB, TA:) see 4.
maA QsotaTaEotu Oano OafiySa minohu, meaning I was not able to turn aside, or away, from, or to avoid, him, or it. (Ṣ, O.) [See also mafiySN: and see 4.]

And waQll-eh maA fiSotu, like as one says wQll-eh mA bariHotu [perhaps meaning By God I did not quit my place; as well as I did not cease:] (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) mentioned on the authority of AHeyth: (TA:) [that it has the latter meaning is clear; for] one says, maA fiSotu OafoEalu I did not cease (maA bariHotu) doing [such a thing]: (M:) and AstfAS↓, likewise, signifies bariHa. (IB, TA.)
3: see 3 in art. fwS.

4. AfAS AlD-ab-u Eano yadihi [The lizard called Db- escaped, or slipped, from his hand, is expl. as meaning] his fingers became unclosed (Ainofarajat) from [the grasp of] the Db-, so that it escaped from him. (M, TA.) And one says, qabaDotu Ealayohi falamo yufiSo I grasped him and he did not escape, or get loose. (AHeyth, TA.) And qabaDotu EalaI canabi AlD-ab-i faOafaASa mino yadiI Hat-aI xal-aSa canabahu [I grasped the tail of the Db- and it slipped from my hand so that it freed its tail]: (Lth, Ṣ, O, TA: [but in the O, mino is omitted before yadiI; not intentionally, for the verb before mn is there masc., as above:]) this is when thy fingers become unclosed (tatafar-aju) from the grasp of its tail: (Lth, O:) and this [state of the fingers] is termed Alt-afaAwuSu↓. (TA.) [It is also said that] OafaASati Alyadu signifies The fingers of the hand became unclosed (tafar-ajato) from the grasp of the thing. (Ḳ, TA. [But I doubt the correctness of this.])

And AlUifaASapu signifies The being clear, or perspicuous; syn. AlbayaAnu; (O, Ḳ;) like AlmufaAwaSapu, [expl. in art. fwS;] and the being fluent. (O.) [And also The making speech clear, or perspicuous.] One says, fulaAnN cuw UifaASapK UicaA takal-ama Such a one is a person endowed with clearness, or perspicuity, and fluency, when he speaks. (O.) And AfAS lisaAnuhu biAlkalaAmi His tongue made speech, or the speech, clear, or perspicuous; and so faASa↓, aor. yafiySu; (M;) and maA yafiySu bihi lisaAnuhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) his tongue does not make it clear, or perspicuous (Ḳ, TA.) And maA OafaASa bikalimapK He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or a sentence. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, O, TA.) See also 4 in art. fwS: and see 1 in the present art. [And it is said that maA OafaADa bikalimapK signifies the same. Or, accord. to Mṭr, if he be correctly cited in Ḥar p. 447, the verb in this sense, and app. as thus used in all the phrases mentioned above, is correctly with D, and not so with S: but this I greatly doubt.]
One says also, AfAS bibawolihi He ejected his urine: (O, Ḳ:) or AfAD bh. (El-Ghooree, in Ḥar ubi suprà.)

6. Alt-afaAyuSu is said to be the original and regular form of Alt-afaAwuSu, which signifies The speaking, talking, or discoursing, each to another, or each with another: the I being changed into w because of the ḍammeh. (M in this art. and in art. fwS, and TA.)
See also another explanation in art. fwS: and see 4 in the present art.
10: see 1, last sentence.

maA Eanohu mafiySN There is not any place to which to turn aside, or away, from it: or there is not any turning aside, or away, from it: syn. maHiydN [which may be meant either as a n. of place or as an inf. n.]: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or maEodilN. (IAạr, M.)

1. faADa, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yafiyDu, inf. n. fayoDN (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fayoDuwDapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) andfuyuwDN (M, O, Ḳ) and fiyuwDN and fuyuwDapN (M, Ḳ) and fayaDaAnN, (M, O, Ḳ,) It (water) overflowed: poured out, or forth, from fulness: (Mgh:)
it (water, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, or a torrent, Mṣb) became abundant, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and flowed from [over] the brink of the valley, (Mṣb,) or so as to flow over the side of the valley, (Ṣ, O,) or so as to flow like a valley; (Ḳ;) and AfAD↓ signifies the same: (Mṣb, TA:) it (water) became abundant: (TA:) [contr. of gaADa, aor. yagiyDu:] it (water, and that of the eyes, and the like, M, or anything fluid, Mṣb) ran, or flowed: (M, Mṣb:) or it poured out, or forth; or poured out, or forth, vehemently; gushed out, or forth: (M:) and it (water, and blood,) fell in drops. (Mṣb.)

It (a vessel) became full: (Mṣb:) [or it overflowed: for you say,] faADa Aln-ahoru bimaAYihi The river overflowed with its water: and faADa AlUinaMCu bimaA fiyhi The vessel overflowed with what was in it: (Mṣb:) and a poet says,
Xakawotu wamaA AlX-akowaI limivoliIa EaAdapF
walekino tafiyDu AlkaOosu Einoda QmotilaAYihaA
[I complained; and complaint is not a custom of the like of me; but the cup overflows on the occasion of its being full]. (A) You say also faADato Eayonuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN, The eye flowed [with tears]. (TA.) And faASa EaraqFA, said of a man, [He sweated;] sweat appeared upon his body, on an occasion of grief. (IḲṭṭ)

† It (a thing) was, or became, much, abundant, many, or unmerous. (O, Ḳ.) You say, faADa All-iYaAmu † The mean became many: (Ṣ, O:) opposed to gaADa, q. v. (Ṣ and A in art. gyD.) And faADa Alxayoru ‡ Good, or wealth,, &c., became abundant, (A, Mṣb,) fiyhimo among them. (A.)

Aor. as above, (Ṣ,) inf. n. fayoDN, (TA,) ‡ It (a piece of news, or a story,) spread abroad; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also AstfAD↓; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) it spread abroad among the people. (Mṣb and TA in explanation of the latter verb,) like water. (TA.) ↓The latter is also said of a place, meaning ‡ It became wide, or ample. (A.) And you say, faADa Ealayohi Ald-iroEu ‡ [The coat of mail spread over him; or covered him]. (A.)

Aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN and fuyuwDN, ‡ He (a man, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) died: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) and, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) in like manner, (Ṣ, O,) faADatN nafosuhu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. fayoDN, (M, Mṣb,) ‡ his soul departed, or went forth; (Ṣ, M, A,* Mgh,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) of the dial. of Temeem; (Ṣ, M, O;) on the authority of AO and Fr; and AZ says the like; but Aṣ says that one should not say, fAD Alr-ajulu, nor fADt nfsh, for fAD is only said of tears and of water: (Ṣ, O:) to which is added in the O, but one says, faAZa, with Z, [as is also said in the Mgh,] as meaning “he died,” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: (TA:) [see, however, the remarks of IB below:] or the more chaste expression is fAZ, with Z, without the mention of the nfs; and some do not allow any other: (Mṣb:) but in the L we find as follows: IAạr says. fAD Alrjl and fAZ, meaning “the man died:” and Abu-l-Ḥasan says, fAZt nfsh, the verb relating to the nfs; and fAD Alrjl and fAZ: but Aṣ says, I heard AA say that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “he died;” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: IB, however, says that what IDrd has cited from Aṣ is different from that which J has ascribed to him; for IDrd cites the words of Aṣ thus: the Arabs says, fAZ Alrjl, meaning “the man died;” but when they speak of the nfs, they say fADt nfsh, with D; and he quotes the ex.
fafuqiYato EayonN wafaADato nafosu
[And an eye was put out, and a soul departed]: and he [IB] adds that this is what is commonly known to be the opinion of Aṣ: but J has committed and error; for Aṣ quotes from AA that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “he died;” not fAD, decidedly and he also says, nor does it necessarily follow from what he relates that he firmly believed it: AO says that fAZt nfsh is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial of Temeem and AḤát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say, fADt nfsh: in like manner also El-Mázinee says. on the authority of AZ. that all the Arabs say, fAZt nfsh. except Benoo-Dabbeh, who say, fADt nfsh with D. (TA.) [See also art. fyZ. It is further said, that] AlfayoDu signifies Death: (A, Ḳ;) as occurring in a trad respecting Ed-Dejjál, where it is said, vum-a yakuwnu EalaI Oavari celika AlfayoDu [Then shall be, after that, death] (A, TA:) Sh says, I asked El-Bekráwee respecting this, and he asserted AlfyD, in this case, to signify “death;” but I have not heard it from any other; unless it be from faADato nafosahu signifying His slaver collecting upon his lips at the departure of his soul [flowed]. (TA.)

You say also faADa Sdoruhu mina AlgayoZi ‡ [His bosom overflowed with wrath, or rage], (A, TA.) And faADa Sadoruhu biAls-ir-i His bosom disclosed, or concealed, the secret; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) his bosom could not conceal the secret; (M;) his bosom was full with the secret, and disclosed it, not being able to conceal it. (TA.)
And fayoDN is used as meaning † God's suggesting (UiloqaMC) [of a thing]: what the Devil suggests (yuloqiyhi) is termed Alwasowasapu. (Kull p. 277.)
faADa AlbaEiyru bijir-atihi: see 4, latter half.

hom.sense: 4. AfAD: see 1, first sentence.
He filled a vessel so that it overflowed: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or [simply] he filled a vessel, (M, Mṣb,) accord. to Lḥ; but the former. [says ISd,] in my opinion, is the correct signification. (M.)

He made water, and tears, and the like, to run, or flow; or to pour out, or forth; or to pour out, or forth, vehemently; to gush out, or forth: (M:) he poured [water, &c.] out, or forth: (A, TA:) or he poured water out, or forth, copiously. (Mgh.) You say, AfAD AlmaMCa EalaI nafosihi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or ElI jasadihi, (Mṣb,) He poured the water (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) upon himself, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or upon his body. (Mṣb.) And AfAD dumuwEahu, (Ṣ,) or damoEahu, (Mṣb,) He poured forth his tears. (Mṣb.) And AfADt AlEayonu Ald-amoEa [The eye poured forth tears]. (TA.)
AfAD Qll-ehu Alxayora ‡ God made good, or wealth,, &c., to abound. (Mṣb.)
AfAD Ealayohi Ald-iroEa ‡ He put on him the coat of mail: like as you say Sab-ahaA [lit he poured it]. (A, TA.)

OafaADuwA mino EarafaAtK ‡ They pushed on, pressed on, or went quickly, syn. dafaEuwA, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or AinodafaEuwA, (M, A,) with multitude, (M, Mgh, O,) from 'Arafát, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to Minè, (Ṣ, M, O,) exclaiming lab-ayoka: (M:) or they returned, and dispersed themselves from 'Arafát: (O, Ḳ:) or they hastened from 'Arafát to another place: (Ḳ:) the last rendering is taken from Ibn-ʼArafeh; and agreeably with all of these renderings, the phrase in the Ḳur [ii. 194], faUicaA OafaDotumo mino EarafaAtK, has been explained: (TA:) and [in like manner,] you say AfADwA mina minaI UilaI mak-ipa ‡ They returned from Mine to Mekkeh; on the day of the sacrifice: (Mṣb:) UifaADapN signifies ‡ the advancing, and pushing on, or pressing on, in journeying, or pace, (A,* TA,) and the like, (A,) with multitude, and is only after a state of separation and congregation: (TA:) it is from the same word as signifying the “pouring out, or forth;” (A, O, TA,) or from AfAD AlmaMCa signifying “he poured the water out, or forth, copiously” (Mgh:) and the original expression is AfAD nafosahu. or raAHilatahu; but they omit the objective complement, and hence the verb resembles one that is intrans.: (O, TA:) or AfADp signifies the quickly impelling or urging [a beast] to run, with one's foot or leg, or feet or legs: and AfAD, he (a rider) made his camel to exert himself beyond measure, to go a quick run, between the utmost rate and what is less than that; AfADp denoting the half [of the full rate] of the run of camels having riders upon them; and being only applied when they have riders upon them: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh:) and every dafoEap [or act of pushing on, or pressing on,] is termed UifaADapN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, TawaAfu AlUifaADapi, signifying The circuiting [around the Kaạbeh] on the return from Mine to Mekkeh; (Mṣb, TA) on the day of the sacrifice: (TA:) or the circuiting of visitation. (Mgh.)

AfADwA fiI AlHadiyvi ‡ They pushed on, or pressed on, in discourse; syn. AinodafaEuwA: (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, A, O,) they entered thereinto; launched forth, or cut, thereinto: (Lḥ, M, O;) they were large, or copious, or profuse, therein; (O, TA:) or they dilated therein (M:) or they began, commenced, or entered upon, discourse: (Mṣb;) as also AstfADwhu↓, (M, Mṣb,) accord. to some; (Mṣb;) but this latter is disallowed by most; (M;) or by the skilful, (Mṣb.) You say also, AfAD fiI EamalK † He entered into an action, or employment; and pushed on, or pressed on, therein: (Bḍ in x. 62:) or he began it, commenced it, or entered upon it. (Jel, ibid.)
AfAD baAlX-ayoCi He impelled, or thrust, with the thing: (M:) he cast, or threw, the thing. (M, TA.)

AfAD AlbaEiyru bijir-atihi, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, A, O,) and (Ṣ, O) AfAD alone, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and faADa↓ bijir-atihi, (TA,) ‡ The camel propelled his cud (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) from his inside, (Lḥ, M, A,) or from his stomach, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and expelled it, or ejected it: (Ṣ:) or cast it forth in a scattered and copious state: or it means [he made to be heard] the sound of his cud, and of his chewing. (M.)
maA AfAD bikalimapK † He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or sentence. (Mṣb, TA.) [And mA AfAD bklmp signifies the same.]

AfAD biAlqidaAHi, (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ,) and EalaI AlqidaAHi, meaning biAlqidaAHi, for prepositions stand in the places of other prepositions, (Ṣ, O,) and AfAD AlqidaAHa, (O, Ḳ,) ‡ i. q. Daraba biAlqidaAHi [which has two significations: He turned about, or shuffled, the gaming-arrows: and he played with the gaming-arrows]: (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ:) and OajaAlahaA [which has the former of the above significations]: or he dealt them forth. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing a [wild] he-ass and his she-asses,
fakaOan-ahun-a ribaAbapN wakaOan-ahu
yasarN yufiyDu EalaI AlqidaAHi wayaSodaEu : (Ṣ, TA) ‡ [And it was as though they were a bundle of gaming-arrows, and as though he were a shuffler thereof, shuffling or] dealing out the arrows, and deciding, and making known what he produced: (TA:) or, accord. to Kh, and speaking with his loudest voice, saying “The arrow of such a one has won,” or “This is the arrow of such a one:” or, accord. to some, distributing, or dispensing, by means of the arrows: (TA in art. SdE:) by EalaI AlqidaAHi is meant biAlqidaAHi. (Ṣ voce EalaI.) One relation of this verse substitutes yaxuwDu for yufiyDu. (TA.) Az says that UifaAD [a mistranscription for UifaADapN] is always a consequence of a state of separation, or dispersion, and abundance, or copiousness. (TA.)

Hence the saying in a trad. respecting a thing picked up from the ground, vum-a OafiDohaA mino maAlika, [app. a mistake for fiI maAlika,] i. e. † Then put thou, or throw thou, it, and mix it, among thy property. (TA.)
OufiyDato She (a woman) became wide in the belly: [as though spread out:] or she became large in the belly, and flabby in flesh. (M.)

AfAD AlmaroOapa He made the masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] of the woman to become one, on the occasion of devirgination; (M;) i. q. OafoDaAhaA [from which it is app. formed by transposition, as is indicated in the M.]. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tfy-D It flowed. (Ḥar p. 610. [But this I do not find elsewhere.])

hom.sense: 10. AstfAD He asked for the pouring out (UifaADap) of water, (Ḳ, TA,) &c. (TA.)
Said of a piece of news: and of a place: see 1, in the first half of the paragraph. You say also, AstfAD AlwaAdiI XajarFA ‡ The valley became wide, and abundant in trees. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
AstfADwA AlHadiyva: see AfADwA fiI AlHadiyvi. [It seems to be indicated in the Ṣ and O that it signifies They spread abroad the story among the people; as used by some: see musotafiyDN.]

entry.sense: fayoDN A river, (M, TA,) in general: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaADN and [of mult.] fuyuwDN: the pluralization thereof shows that it is not an inf. n. used as a subst.: (M, TA:) [and a river, or water, that overflows.] AlfayoDu is [hence] applied to The Nile of Egypt: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the Tekmileh, to a place in the Nile of Egypt: (TA:) and to the river of El-Basrah: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or this last is called fayoDu AlbaSorapi, because of its greatness. (M.) You say also OaroDN caAtu fuyuwDK Land in which is water: (Lḥ, M:) or in which are waters that overflow. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
A horse ‡ that runs much; (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) that is fleet, or swift; (M;) that runs vehemently; likened to water pouring forth; as also sakobN. (Eth-Thaalebee, in TA, art. skb.)
A man ‡ bountiful, or munificent; as also faAYiDN↓, (A,) and fay-aADN↓: (Ṣ, O:) or, as also ↓the last, a man abounding [or profuse] in beneficence or bounty. (M.)
Much, or abundant, water. (M.)
‡ Much, or abundance: as in the saying, OaEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK ‡ He gave him little from much. (Ṣ, M, O.) Anything much in quantity. (KL.)
† A large gift: [and simply a gift, favour, or grace:] pl. fuyuwDN. (KL.)
[See also 1, last sentence but one. Hence biTariyqi AlfayoDi meaning † By way, or means, of instinct; instinctively.]
‡ Death: [as being the outpouring of the soul:] see 1. (Sh, on the authority of El-Bekráwee; and Ḳ.)
cahabonaA fiI fayoDi fulaAnK † We went with the corpse and bier of such a one. (M.)
faADapN: see mufaADN.
Oamoruhumo fayoDaI bayonahumo: i. q. fawDaI, q. v. (TA in art. fwD.)
Oamoruhumo fayoDuwDaI bayonahumo, and fayoDiyDaI, and fayoDuwDaMCu, and fayoDiDaMCu, and fayuwDaI↓, i. q. fawoDaI, q. v. in art. fwD. (AZ, Ḳ.)
fayuwDN: see mufaADN.
Oamoruhumo fayuwDaI bayonahumo: see fayDuwDaI.
fay-aADN A river containing much water: (Ṣ:) or that flows much. (Ḥam p. 375.)
Applied to a man: see fayoDN, in two places.
faAYiDN A watering-trough full: a sea, or great river, [overflowing: see 1: or] pouring, or pouring vehemently. (TA.)
Applied to a man: see fayoDN.
mufaADN pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.].

HadiyvN mufaADN fiyhi ‡ Discourse in which people have pushed on, or pressed on: (Ḳ:) [or into which they have entered: or in which they have been large, or copious: or in which they have dilated: or begun: see 4; and see also musotafiyDN.]

diroEN mufaADapN ‡ A wide, or an ample, coat of mail; (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ;) as also faADapN↓ (IJ, M) and fayuwDN. (M.) [In the CK, this word is erroneously written mufAwaDap, as applied to a coat of mail and to a woman.] mufaADN applied to a man, ‡ Wide in the belly: fem. with p {mufaADapN}: (M:) or the latter, a woman large in the belly, (Ṣ, M, A, O, Ḳ,) and flabby in flesh, (M, A,) and, as some add, inordinately tall: (TA:): or, as some say, the latter signifies a woman having her masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] united; as though formed by transposition from mufoDaApN: (M:) and, accord. to some, mufaADN signifies having a fulness. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, kaAna mufaADa AlbaToni, meaning ‡ He had the belly even with the breast: (O, Ḳ:) or he had a fulness in the lower part of the belly. (TA.)
musotafaADN: see the next paragraph

hom.sense: musotafiyDN One who asks for the pouring out (UifaADap) of water, &c. (Ṣ, O.)

A story, or a piece of news, ‡ spread abroad (Ṣ, M, A,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ) among the people, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) like water; (TA;) as also musotafaADN fiyhi; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) but you should not say musotafaADN [alone], (Aṣ, Fr, ISk, and the lexicologists in general, and Az, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, and Ḳ,) for this is a mistake of the inhabitants of the towns and villages: (Aṣ, Fr, ISk, &c., and Mṣb:) or this last is a word of weak authority: (Ḳ:) it is, however, used by some; (Ṣ, O;) for instance, by Aboo-Temmám; (TA;) as meaning begun, commenced, or entered upon; but most disallow it unless followed by fiyhi. (M.)

entry.sense: 1. faAZa, aor. yafiyZu, inf. n. fayoZN (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and fuyuwZN and fayaZaAnN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and fayoZaAnN (Lḥ, TA) and fayoZuwZapN, (Lth, M, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ) died; (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also, (sometimes, Ṣ) faAZa↓, aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and fawaAZN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA; but in the CK, fuwaAZN, and there said to be with damm;) or, accord. to IJ, only the inf. n., fawoZN, of the latter verb is used, though the verb itself is allowable on the ground of analogy. (M.) You say also, HaAna fayoZuhu and fawoZuhu↓, [in the CK fuwoZuhu,] The time came for his dying. (M, Ḳ.) In like manner, (Ṣ,) you say also, faAZato nafosuhu His soul departed, or went forth; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M;) on the authority of AO and Ks; and the like is related on the authority of AZ; (Ṣ;) aor. tafiyZu, (M,) inf. n. fayoZN (Lth, T, M) and fayoZuwZapN; (Lth, T;) and [accord. to some,] faAZato nafosuhu, inf. n. fawoZN: (M:) or, when the nfs is mentioned, you say, faADato, with D: (Ḳ:) Aṣ says, I heard Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà say that one should not say faAZato nafosuhu, (T,* Ṣ, M,*) but fAZ, (Ṣ, M,) meaning “he died;” and not faADa, with D, decidedly; (Ṣ;) or not faADato: (T:) [but what was said by Aṣ respecting these two verbs has been stated more fully, and variously, in art. fyD, q. v.:] AO says that fAZt nafosuhu is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial. of Temeem: Fr says that the people of El-Ḥijáz and Teiyi say the former; and Ḳuḍáʼah and Temeem and Keys say the latter: AḤát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say the latter; and El-Mázinee relates the like on the authority of AZ. (TA.)
You say also, faAZa nafosahu, (Ks, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yafiyZu, (Ks, T,) He vomited forth his soul: (Ks, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Ks, Ṣ.)

4. AfAZhu He (God) caused him to die. (Ḳ, TA.) And you say also, Darabotuhu Hat-aI OafaZotu nafosahu [I beat him, or smote him, until I made his soul to depart, or go forth]. (Ṣ.) And laOufiyZan-a nafosaka [I will assuredly cause thy soul to depart, or go forth] (M.) And AfAZhu Qll-ehu nafosahu [God caused him to vomit forth his soul]. (Ks, T, Ṣ, M.)

tfy-ZwA Oanofusahumo They constrained themselves to vomit forth their souls. (Ṣ, TA.) [But in one copy of the Ṣ, I find yufiyZuwA Oanofusahumo, expl. as meaning They cause to vomit forth their souls; which suggests that the right reading may perhaps be yufiyZuwA: or it may be yafiyZuwA, from faAZa nafosahu.]

fayofN A place that is even, level, or flat: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (T, O,) a waterless desert, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) such as is even, level, or flat, and wide, or spacious; (T, O;) and fayofaApN↓ and fayfaMCu↓ (M, Ḳ) and fayofaI↓ (Ḳ) also signify [thus, or] a waterless desert: (M. Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to El-Mu-arrij, (T, O,) fayofN signifies a portion of the earth that is a place whereof the winds are variable; (T, O, Ḳ;) and this is the explanation that is preferred by Sh: (T:) and accord. to AA, it signifies [also] any road between two mountains: (T, TA:) its pl. is OafoyaAfN [a pl. of pauc.] and fuyuwfN [a pl. of mult.]. (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)
fayofaI: see the preceding paragraph.
fayofaApN: see fayofN: and see also mufaAzapN, in art. fwz.

fayofaMCu is syn. with fayofN, q. v.: therefore its A is augmentative, (Ṣ, M,) accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr: (Ṣ:) and it signifies (Ṣ, M, O,) also (M) a smooth [desert such as is termed] SaHoraMC: (Ṣ, M, O:) its pl. is fayaAfK. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ. [In the CK, this pl. is written fiyAfN, as though it were a pl. of fayofN.])
1. faAqa, aor. yafiyqu: see fAq binafosihi, in art. fwq.
4. Oafiyqa, said of a poet, i. q. Oafolaqa: (Ḳ:) or an imitative sequent thereto. (Aboo-Turáb, O.)
fiyqN: see art. fwq.
fuyuqN and fiyaqN: see art. fwq.
fayoqapN and fiyqapN: see art. fwq.
fuyaAqN: see art. fwq.
mufiyqN: see art. fwq.

hom.sense: 1. faAla raOoyuhu, aor. yafiylu, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. fuyuwlapN, (Ṣ,) thus in some copies of the Ḳ and in the A, (TA,) or fayoluwlapN, (M, O,) thus in other copies of the Ḳ, (TA,) and fayaAlapN, thus in the O, but in the copies of the Ḳ fayolap, (TA,) His judgment, or opinion, was weak, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and erroneous; (M, Ḳ;) as also tfy-l↓; (M, Z, Ḳ, TA;) and [in like manner] fay-ala↓ fiI raOoyihi [not fuy-ila] he was incorrect in his judgment, or opinion; and fay-aluwA↓ occurs in a trad. as meaning fAl raOoyuhumo: (TA:) [and faAla alone, said of a man, signifies the same as fAl raOoyuhu, as is shown by a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the T and M and O and TA: but it seems from what here follows (taken from a passage unconnected with the foregoing) that the first and third of what are mentioned above as inf. ns. are regarded by some as simple substs.:] and one says, fiI raOoyihi fayaAlapN↓, (T, M, Ḳ, TA,) the last word like saHaAbapN, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, fI riwaAyapK fiyaAlapN,]) and fuyuwlapN↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) meaning [In his judgment, or opinion, is] a weakness. (TA.)

And fAl signifies also He (a man) magnified himself, and became like the elephant (Alfiyl); or he showed a morose aspect: (TA:) [or it may so signify:] IAạr cites the following verse:
mina Aln-aAsi OaqowaAmN UicaA SaAdafuwA AlginaI
tawal-awoA wafaAluwA lilS-adiyqi wafax-amuwA
which may mean [Of mankind are folks who, when they find riches, turn the back, and] magnify themselves and become like the elephant [to the friend, and aggrandize themselves] or show a morose aspect to the friend [&c.]; for the elephant is morose in aspect. (M.)

entry.sense:
2. fy-l raOoyahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tafoyiylN, He declared [or esteemed] his judgment, or opinion, to be weak, (Ṣ.) or bad, and erroneous. (M, Ḳ.) Umeiyeh Ibn Abee-'Áïdh says,
falawo gayorahaA mino wulodi kaEobi boni kaAhilK
madaHota biqawolK SaAdiqK lamo tufay-ali
meaning lamo yufay-alo raOoyuka (SKr, M) i. e. [But hadst thou praised other than her, of the children of Kaab Ibn-Káhil, with a true saying,] thy judgment, or opinion, would not have been declared weak. (SKr.)
See also 1, in two places.
3. faAyala, [inf. n. mufaAyalapN and fiyaAlN, (see AlfayaAlu below,)] He played [at the game called AlfayaAl: see its part. n. below]. (O.)

hom.sense: 5. tfy-l: see 1.
Also He (a man, Ḳ, [or a camel, as is indicated in the O,]) became fat, (O, Ḳ,) as though he were a fiyl [or an elephant]. (O.) [See also 10.]
And, said of youth, or young manhood, (AlX-abaAb,) It increased, (Lth, T, M, O, Ḳ,) and became in its prime and fulness. (Lth, T, O.)
And, said of herbage, It became tall, and full-grown; or became of its full height, and blossomed. (Th, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. Aisotafoyala He (a camel) became like the fiyl [or elephant] (M, Ḳ, TA) in bigness: (TA:) mentioned by IJ among the class of AsotaHowaca and the like: part. n. musotafoyilN. (M.) [See also 5.]

hom.sense: faAlN: see fiylN, latter half:
and the paragraph commencing with faAYilu Alr-aOoIi, near its end:
and see also faOolN, in art. fOl.

entry.sense: fayolN: see the paragraph here following.

fiylu [The elephant; Pers. Pyl;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known:pl. [of pauc.] OafoyaAlN and [of mult.] fuyuwlN and fiyalapN; (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) not OafoyilapN: (ISk, Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) accord. to Sb. fiylN may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (Ṣ, M, O,) pronounced with kesr because of the I, like as they said OaboyaDu and byDN; but Akh says, this is not the case in the sing, but only in the pl.: (Ṣ, O:) fem. with p. (M, Ḳ)

Hence, layolapN mivolu lawoni Alfiyli [lit. A night like the colour of the elephant;] meaning a night that is black. (M, TA,) and dust-coloured; (M;) in which one knows not the right course to pursue: the colours of the fyl being of this kind. (M, TA.)

[Hence, also, daMCu Alfiyli The disease called by us the tumid Barbadoes leg; because the leg of the patient resembles that of the elephant by reason of its enormously-swollen state: not (as some have supposed it to be) elephantiasis; this latter being termed jucaAm (q. v.)].
[And hence, likewise, used as an epithet,] fiylN signifies also ‡ Heavy [or dull]; and low, ignoble, or mean. (Ḳ, TA.)

And one says rajulN fiylu Alr-aOoIi, meaning A man weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) and so fiyoluhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) and faAYiluhu↓: (T, M, O, Ḳ;) and fay-iluhu↓, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) of the measure fayoEil; (O:) and faAluhu↓, (T, M, O, Ḳ,) and faAlN alone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) meaning weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) erring in insight: (Ṣ:) pl. [of the first] OafoyaAlN: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) but AO says, the faAYil↓ is one who, inspecting, forms an opinion and errs; if he err after examining a horse in all its states or conditions and forming an opinion respecting it from his inspection, [not while doing so,] he is not reckoned to be fAYl. (TA.)

AlfayaAlu and AlfiyaAlu, (Lth, T, M, O, Ḳ) the former a subst, and the latter an inf. n. [of 3], (Lth, T, O,) and AlmufaAyalapu↓ [which is likewise an inf. n. of 3], (M, Ḳ,) A certain game, (Lth, T, M, O, Ḳ,) well known, (O,) of the children, (T,) or of the youths, or young men, of the Arabs (M, Ḳ) of the desert, (M,) with earth, or dust: (Lth, T, M, O:) a thing is hidden in earth, or dust, which is then divided (T, M) into two portions; then the hider says to his companion, In which of them twain is it? (T;) and if he [who is thus questioned] mistake, the hider says to him faAla raOoyuka: (T, M,* Ḳ;*) ISk termed it AlfiYaAlu, with C; (O;) and it has been mentioned before in art. fOl: (T, O, Ḳ:) accord. to some, (TA,) this game is called AlT-abanu and Alsud-aru. (T, TA. [But see the former of these two words.])
fayaAlapN: see the first paragraph {1}.
fuyuwlapN: see the first paragraph {1}.
fay-ilu All-aHomi A man having much flesh: (T, O,* Ḳ:) some pronounce it with C, (T, O,) saying fayOal, (T,) or faYil; (O;) both mentioned before [in art. fOl]. (TA.)
fay-ilu Alr-aOoIi: see fiylN, latter half.
fay-iAlN The attendant, or master, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the keeper, or driver, (MA, KL,) of the fiyl [or elephant], (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb, KL,) or of the fiylap. (So in the M and Ḳ.)

hom.sense: faAYilu Alr-aOoIi: see fiylN, latter half, in two places.

AlfaAYilu [as a subst.] signifies The flesh that is upon the xurobap, (Ṣ, O,) or xurob, (Ḳ, [in the M, accord. to the TT, Hrf, app. a mistranscription,]) of the warik; (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) [which, I think, will be plainly seen from what follows to mean the flesh that is upon the sacro-ischiatic foramen; though xurobapu Alwariki and xurobu Alwariki are said in the TA, in art. xrb, to mean “the hole where the head of the thigh-bone is inserted;”] so says AʼObeyd: (Ṣ, O:) or, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) as some say, so adds AʼObeyd, (Ṣ, O,) a certain vein (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) in the xurobap of the warik, descending into the leg, (T,) or in the thigh: (Ṣ, O:) Aṣ says, in “the Book of the Horse,” in the warik is the xurobap, which is a nuqorap wherein is flesh, no bone being in it; and in that nuqorap is the faAYil, and there is no bone between the said nqrp and the belly, but only skin and flesh; (T,* Ṣ, O;) and he cites the saying of El-Aạshà,
qado naxoDibu AlEayora fiI makonuwni faAYilihi
waqado yaXiyTu EalaI OaromaAHinaA AlbaTalu
[Oft we stain the ridge of the spear-head in what is concealed in the interior of his fAYl, and oft the man of valour dies by means of our spears]; makonuwnu AlfaAYili means his blood: he says [by implication], we are skilful in respect of the place of piercing: (Ṣ, O:) but Aṣ said mino in the place of fiI; and AA, qado naToEunu; which has been pronounced to be wrong: (O:) or the faAYilaAni, (T, M,) or the faAYilataAni↓, (so in the Ḳ, [app. a mistranscription,]) are two veins entering into the interior parts of the thighs (T, M, Ḳ,) in the hinder parts thereof; (M, Ḳ;) and they adduce as an evidence thereof the verse of El-Aạshà cited above, saying that the epithet mknwn would not have been used if the fAYl were not a vein; but others say that [the poet meant that] he made the spear-head to become concealed in the furthest part of the flesh; and if the fAYl were a vein, it would not have been mentioned as it has been in a phrase of Imra-el-Ḳeys which will be cited in what follows: (M:) [hence it is said,] or they are two portions of flesh [between which is the lower part of the os sacrum, i. e.] the lower parts of which are upon the SalawaAn [dual of SalFA], from the region of the lower portions of the HajabataAni to the Eajob, bordering upon the EuSoEuS on either side, descending in the two sides of the two thighs; [so in a human being,] and thus in the horse: (M, Ḳ: [for the meanings of the words that I have here left untranslated, I must refer to their several proper arts.; as they are variously explained:]) AlfaAlu↓ is a dial. var. of AlfaAYilu; (M, Ḳ, TA;) which is expl. by Ṣgh [in the O] as meaning a certain vein issuing from the faw-aArap of the warik [i. e. from the sacro-ischiatic foramen]: (TA:) [but the assertion that AlfAl is a dial. var. of AlfAYl seems to be founded only upon what here follows:] Imra-el-Keys says, [describing a horse,]
lahu HajabaAtN muXorifaAtN EalaI AlfaAli ; (Ṣ, M; or ElI AlfaAliI, as in the O and TA;) [i. e. He has edges of the haunch-bones projecting above, or beyond, the fAYl; for] he means ElI faAYili, having altered the latter word by transposition. (T, Ṣ, O, TA.)

entry.sense: faAYilapN: see its dual in the next preceding paragraph, near the middle.

Oafoyalu [More, and most, weak, or erroneous; relating to a judgment, or an opinion]. Oafoyalu mina Alr-aOoIi Ald-abariI-i is a prov., meaning [More weak] than an opinion that is given after the affair [to which it relates] has passed. (Meyd.)
mufaAyilN [in the Ṣ and O in art. fOl, with C, i. e. mufaAYilN,] Playing at the game called AlfayaAlu. (M, O.)
AlmufaAyalapu expl. as a subst.: see AlfayaAlu.
mafoyuwlaMC [a quasi-pl. n. (like maXoyuwxaMCu, &c.), but one of which the sing. (if it have one) is not mentioned,] The young ones of the fiyl [or elephant]. (O, Ḳ.)
musotafoyilN part. n. of 10, q. v. (M.)
1. faAna, aor. yafiynu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. fayonN, (TA,) He, or it, came. (Ḳ.)

fayonapN A time; syn. waqotN, or waqotN mina Alz-amaAni; (T;) or HiynN; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and saAEapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, laqiytuhu Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi [I met him time after time]: (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ; but some copies of the Ḳ omit the words bEd Alfynp:) and laqiytuhu fayonapa [I met him at a certain time]: (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ; but in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, fayonapF:) thus fynp is made determinate in two different ways; by its having the article Al prefixed to it [in the former case], and as a proper name [in the latter case; with which compare what is said of bukorapa, &c.]: (AZ, M:) and you say, Uin-iI laMtiI fulaAnFA Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi i. e. [Verily I come to such a one] time after time; not continually repairing to him: (AZ, T:) and, accord. to ISk, maA OaloqaAhu Uil-aA Alfayonapa i. e. [I do not meet him save occasionally, or] time after time. (TA.) [See also fan-apN.]

fayonaAn Having beautiful and long hair: (Ḳ:) or so fayonaAnu AlX-aEari; applied to a man: (Ṣ:) fayonaAn [is also applied as an epithet to hair; and] has been mentioned in art. fn q. v.: (Ḳ:) if it be from fananN, meaning “a branch,” it is [of the measure fayoEaAlN, and therefore] perfectly decl. when indeterminate, and likewise when determinate [as a proper name]; but if from fayonapN, meaning “a time,” [which seems to be hardly reasonable,] it is [of the measure faEolaAn, and therefore] perfectly decl. in the former case and imperfectly decl. in the latter case. (Lḥ, T.)
One says also Zil-N fayonaAnN, meaning Wide, extensive, shade. (TA.)
OafoyuwnN, also written OufoyuwnN and UifoyawonN, held by some to belong to this art. and by others to belong to art. Afn, has been mentioned in page 70.
1. faAha, aor. yafiyhu: see faAha, aor. yafuwhu, in art. fwh.
fayohajN A wine-measure: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) a Pers. word arabicized [and therefore all its letters are regarded as radical]. (Ṣ.)
And A strainer (O, Ḳ, TA) for wine. (TA.)

And (sometimes, Ṣ, O) a name for Wine: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or clear wine: (O, TA:) or an epithet applied to wine [app. signifying clear]: (TA:) or wine such as is mxtlq [app. a mistranscription for muxal-aq, a word now used as signifying aromatized]; like qinodiydN [q. v.] and Oum-N zanobaqK. (IAmb, TA.)
